headline: Blast Kills Filipino Student
abstract: A student passer- by was killed and 11 other people were injured in an explosion at a militia outpost in the heart of this southern Philippines city tonight, the police said.

headline: OF BIRDS AND BERRIES: MOSCOW'S WINTER FORECAST
abstract: The first snow of the winter has fallen in Moscow, a month earlier than last year, but the old women on the city's park benches were not surprised.    As the small, dry flakes sifted down through yellow autumn leaves and children made the season's first snowballs, the old women talked of berries, mushrooms, nuts and the flight of birds and predicted that this winter would be worthy of Russia's legends.   But the sudden flurries seemed to have caught the rest of Moscow off guard, and few men in the streets had yet put on the fur hats that are the surest sign that winter has come. They seemed still to be waiting for that mysterious day when all Muscovites, like migrating birds responding to an unseen signal, dress for winter.

headline: TYPEWRITERS OF ELECTRONIC ERA
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation, which used to dominate the market for office typewriters with its ubiquitous Selectric line, has found itself losing ground since the arrival of electronic models.    Electronic typewriters come equipped with circuit boards, which contain a host of semiconductor chips, eliminating much of the machinery that drives manual and electric typewriters and providing advanced features such as memory capacity. Because electronic devices have fewer moving parts, they are generally considered more reliable than their electric counterparts.    After electronic typewriters were introduced in 1978, sales of electric models began to decline rapidly. At the peak of their popularity six years ago, 10 million electric machines were chattering away in American offices, according to Dataquest Inc., a San Jose, Calif., research concern. By the end of this year, the number of electric typewriters is expected to be down to seven million, with I.B.M. accounting for 70 percent of that.

headline: EQUITABLE LIFE WILL PURCHASE SECURITIES FIRM
abstract: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States announced yesterday that it would purchase Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., a leading Wall Street securities firm. The acquisition continues the blending of the stock brokerage, banking and insurance industries as these businesses seek their niches in a deregulated marketplace.   In recent years, the Prudential Life Insurance Company of America has bought the Bache Group Inc., a major stock brokerage firm; the American Express Company has diversified into securities, and many banks have begun      Gulf and Western said it would make a tender offer of $70 a share for Prentice-Hall stock. Page D1.

headline: More Eurobonds Carry Warrants
abstract: New offerings of corporate securities in the Eurobond market continue to be accompanied by warrants giving investors the option of buying additional bonds.    Investor demand for the bonds and warrants is brisk because of expecations that American interest rates will decline.

headline: An Indian Is Named Cape Town's Archbishop
abstract: Bishop Stephen Naidoo became the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Cape Town today.

headline: Unleaded Gas Trading Set
abstract: The New York Mercantile Exchange has scheduled trading in unleaded gasoline futures to begin today, joining contracts in heating oil, crude oil and leaded gasoline.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
abstract: Amerada Hess   $40,600,000   - 45.9

headline: TIRELESS FRIEND OF THE POOR
abstract: For Unicef's executive director, James P. Grant, the dramatic success of the organization's child survival program comes as the culmination of a lifetime spent in the service of the third world's poor.  But it also represents the continuation of a family tradition.  Since becoming Unicef director in 1980, Mr.  Grant has labored tirelessly on behalf of the simple but effective health care program that has saved the lives of so many children.  He has traveled around the globe, lobbying governments and drumming up private support for the program.

headline: Family's Move to Sell CFS Continental Stake
abstract: ''Since we went public in 1970, we haven't really considered this as a family company,'' said Philip Cohn, chairman and chief executive officer of CFS Continental Inc. ''But agreeing to sell our interests was nevertheless a tremendously emotional decision.''    On Monday, Mr. Cohn, his brother Alvin and other members of the family said they had agreed to sell the 1.5 million shares they hold in CFS - a diversified food service company their father, Jacob Cohn, founded in 1915 - to Dart & Kraft Inc. for $33 a share, or about $49.5 million.    Under the terms of the agreement, Dart & Kraft was given an option to buy an additional 1.6 million shares at the same price, which combined with the Cohn family shares would give Dart & Kraft a 36 percent stake in CFS. Dart & Kraft then intends to make a tender offer for the remaining shares. Acquiring the entire company at $33 a share would cost about $290 million.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: American Magnetics Corp., Sherman Oaks, Calif., a manufacturer of magnetic heads, said its board had authorized the purchase of up to 100,000 common shares.     *   American Sterilizer Co. , Erie, Pa., said it had been notified that Bristol- Myers Co. plans to exercise an option to purchase American Sterilizer's Amsco-Hall Surgical division.

headline: LTV Asset Shift
abstract: The LTV Corporation said that all of the assets of the company's Gadsden, Ala., steel plant had been transferred to a new company, the Gulf States Steel Corporation.

headline: U.S. GTS TOUGH WITH 2 BIG BANKS
abstract: The Government's unprecedented move to force the First National Bank of Chicago and Bank of America, parents of two of the nation's biggest banks, to shore up their foundations, reflects increasing worries that fiercer competition will lead to more failed banks. The move requires the banks to improve liquidity by increasing their capital base, and to toughen their credit policies. The Comptroller of the Currency was particularly hard on First Chicago, which reported a $71.8 million loss for the quarter after charging off $278 million in bad loans. First Chicago's main competitor, Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust, collapsed earlier this year, mainly because of bad loans and an eroded capital base.    Beyond the threat that the Comptroller can remove the banks' senior officers was the signal that Federal regulators would keep a closer watch on the big banks and would try to step in earlier to prevent trouble.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD;
abstract: Six masked gunmen stole 220 pounds of gold, worth more than $1 million, from a metal refinery today after holding the refinery director, his family and two other people hostage for five hours, the police said.   The police said they believed the robbers were professionals who may have had informers inside the refinery.

headline: U.S. APPEARS IRKED BY ISRAELIS' MOVE
abstract: A State Department official said today that the United States and Israel were on ''different wavelengths'' over whether the Reagan Administration had offered a 90-day moratorium on debt repayments to Prime Minister Shimon Peres when Mr. Peres was in Washington last week.   The official made the comment aboard Secretary of State George P. Shultz's aircraft as Mr. Shultz returned here from a 24-hour trip to Toronto. Mr. Shultz, in a news conference in Toronto, said the way the Israelis had explained the situation was ''strange.''    American officials did not seem angered so much as irritated at the announcement in Israel on Monday that the United States had proposed a 90- day delay in Israel's payments from January to March 1985, and that Israel had accepted.   (In Jerusalem, the Cabinet Secretray, Yossi Beilin, said that ''technically'' United States officials were correct that nothing had been finalized, but he reiterated that the Americans had made an offer to postpone until March the $500 million in debt repayments during the talks Mr.  Peres held with President Reagan.)

headline: CONVERSION OF CHEMICAL IS BEGUN AT PLANT IN INDIA
abstract: Scientists and engineers began converting methyl isocyanate into pesticide here today in an effort to prevent another deadly leak of the substance.    Three metric tons of the lethal chemical were safely converted today at the Union Carbide plant, scientists and company officials said, and 12 metric tons remaining in a storage tank are to be converted in the next several days.    They said they were optimistic that any remaining danger to the city could be eliminated.   More than 2,000 people were killed and thousands of others were injured when methyl isocyanate gas escaped from the plant here Dec. 3.

headline: IRAQIS SAY THEY DESTROYED 4 SHIPS IN IRAN CONVOY
abstract: Iraq said that its navy attacked an Iranian naval convoy in the Persian Gulf today, destroying four vessels.    ''The Iraqi naval forces this morning destroyed four big, hostile naval targets that were part of a convoy trying to get into the Bandar Khomeini Canal,'' the state-run Iraqi News Agency said. ''Three of the targets sank and the fourth was set ablaze.''

headline: American Youth in Costume Is Wounded in San Salvador
abstract: A United States Embassy official's son, dressed in camouflage fatigues and carrying a toy pistol for a Halloween party, was wounded in the thigh by a security guard, an embassy spokesman said today.

headline: Treasury Plan Is a Best Seller
abstract: Publication of the Treasury Department's plan for revising the income tax system set off a lively scramble by lawyers, lobbyists, accountants and other Washington operatives.

headline: Japan Scrambles 32 Jets To Meet Soviet Bombers
abstract: The Japan Defense Agency said today that it scrambled 32 jet fighters when 7 Soviet bombers flew south in international airspace between South Korea and Japan.    Forty Japanese fighters were scrambled on Monday when a TU-16, one of nine Soviet bombers flying south past the strait, violated Japanese airspace above the island of Okinoshima for two minutes despite repeated warnings.

headline: Ex-Solidarity Member Voted University Rector
abstract: Faculty and student representatives, whose rights of self-government are being threatened by proposed legislation, elected a former Solidarity member Monday to serve as rector of Warsaw University.   When the university electors reached a similar decision last spring, their choice, another Solidarity sympathizer, Prof. Klemens Szaniawski, a philosopher, was kept from assuming the post through the exercise of emergency powers retained by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader.   On Monday, by voting in Prof. Grzegorz Sienawski, a physicist, the electors may have set the stage for a repetition of what happened in the spring, when an acting, temporary rector had to take over.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS ; Bond Prices Change Slightly
abstract: Bond prices were little changed in sluggish trading yesterday.     ''The markets were pretty stable,'' said Richard Green, president of Money Market Services Inc., an economic information firm in Belmont, Calif. ''The reduction in the prime rate was not at all surprising, and not large enough.'' Also he said, the Treasury Department's tax proposals and the Government's one- year bill auction did not have much of an impact.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: BAII Banking Corp.  has elected to its board Charles William Carson Jr., managing director and a senior partner at William Sword & Co. in Princeton, N.J.     *  Calfed Inc., Los Angeles, has named George P. Rutland, president, to the additional post of chief executive of the holding company, succeeding Robert R. Dockson, who continues as chairman of both Calfed and California Federal Savings and Loan Association. Also, David J. Reed Jr. was named president and chief operating officer of California Federal Savings and Loan.     *  Chase Manhattan Bank has appointed Donald L. Boudreau, Robert M. Lichten and Michael Urkowitz executive vice presidents.

headline: Michigan Hospital Bond Issue Set
abstract: The Michigan State Hospital Finance Authority is offering $48 million of bonds on behalf of the Henry Ford Hospital with a maximum yield of about 10.56 percent for bonds due in 2008. For shorter maturities, bonds were offered with yields ranging from 6.25 percent in 1985 to 10 percent in 1997.

headline: GANDHI CALLS VOTE FOR NEXT MONTH, 2 STATES EXCEPTED
abstract: The new Government of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi today called a general election for Dec. 24 and 27.   By constitutional requirement, the election was due to be held at the latest by next Jan. 20, when the five-year term of the present lower house of Parliament expires.   In calling for the vote on schedule, Mr. Gandhi was regarded as having made a further effort to insure stability and continuity after the assassination of his mother, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, on Oct. 31. Mrs. Gandhi was killed by two gunmen identified by the police as Sikh members of her bodyguard. The assassination touched off a major political crisis, and questions were immediately raised about whether and when the election would be held.

headline: Rockwell Receives Military Contract
abstract: The Rockwell International Corporation received a $1.9 billion Air Force contract for continued advanced buying of parts for B-1B bomber air frames, the Defense Department said.

headline: Peruvian Insurgents Raid a Mining Center
abstract: In an attack Sunday night, Maoist guerrillas took over an Andean mining center for more than an hour and blew up the police station, wounding at least five officers, the authorities said today.   Unconfirmed reports said 10 villagers, including children, might have been killed in the attack at Minas Canarias, 300 miles southeast of Lima.

headline: U.S. ENVOY ACCUSED OF INSENSITIVITY BY MEXICANS
abstract: After more than three years of keeping a relatively low profile, the United States Ambassador to Mexico, John Gavin, has recently become front-page news here. The news has not been good.   The leader of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, Adolfo Lugo Verduzco, accused Mr. Gavin recently of making ''imprudent'' statements and asserted that the Ambassador ''still doesn't understand the idiosyncrasies of the Mexican people and our profound nationalistic feelings.'' Congressmen in the leftist opposition have called for Mr. Gavin to be declared persona non grata and expelled from the country for meddling in Mexico's internal affairs.

headline: Vietnamese Attack Cambodian Rebel Camp
abstract: Vietnamese tanks and artillery attacked a Cambodian rebel camp today in what Thai military officials said could signal the start of an early dry- season offensive.

headline: PRESSURE FOR DEATH PENALTY GROWS IN CANADA
abstract: Public sentiment in Canada for reinstating capital punishment for at least some crimes appears to be rapidly mounting after the killings of six policemen this year.    Last week, more than 1,000 police officers, prison guards and supporters marched on Parliament Hill to demand the return of the death penalty, which was abolished by the House of Commons in 1976. No Canadian has been executed since 1962.   Prime Minister Brian Mulroney has indicated that he would allow a vote on the issue, in which members of his Progressive Conservative Party would be free to vote according to their consciences rather than follow party lines. Polls indicate that about 70 percent of Canadians support a return to the gallows, Canada's past method of execution.

headline: United Jersey In Heritage Bid
abstract: The Heritage Bancorporation of Jamesburg, N.J., said it had received an unsolicited merger proposal from United Jersey Banks yesterday, a day after an appeals court blocked a bid by the giant Mellon Bank Corporation to acquire Heritage for $175 million.   Sandra Sosinski, a spokesman for United Jersey, of Princeton, N.J., said she could neither confirm nor deny the bank had made an offer.

headline: GORBACHEV, A SOVIET LEADER, TO VISIT BRITAIN IN DECEMBER
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher announced today that a key member of the Soviet Union's ruling Politburo will visit Britain next month to discuss nuclear arms control.   She told Parliament that Mikhail S. Gorbachev, 53 years old, who is in line to succeed Konstantin U. Chernenko, will lead a delegation of the Supreme Soviet, the nominal Parliament. Mr. Gorbachev is to be followed next year by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, another member of the Soviet leadership group.   ''We shall hope during these visits to take forward the search for ways to reduce the burden of armaments,'' Mrs. Thatcher said. ''With our Western partners, we have made far-reaching but practical proposals in every arms control negotiation. So far, the response from the Soviet Union has not been forthcoming.''

headline: Poisoning of Candy In Japan Forces Layoffs
abstract: The Morinaga candy company, hit by sales losses after extortionists poisoned its products with cyanide, laid off 450 workers today and cut production in half.

headline: O.A.S. HOPES FOR 'REVITALIZED' ROLE IN REGION
abstract: After a week of discussions, the 31 members of the Organization of American States have agreed to make a new attempt at strengthening the regional body.    At its annual general assembly here last week, a succession of speakers lamented the credibility crisis affecting the O.A.S. and called for its ''revitalization.'' A special assembly was fixed for next year to discuss how this can be done.

headline: Reckitt Purchase Of Airwick Set
abstract: The London-based Reckitt & Coleman Group has agreed to buy the Airwick Group from Ciba-Geigy Ltd. of Basel, Switzerland's largest chemical company, for about $200 million, the two companies said. The agreement is conditional on approval by the Reckitt & Coleman shareholders.

headline: The Patou Revival
abstract: Although many top perfume lines such as Chanel No. 5 and Joy have been around for generations, special fragrances to commemorate particular events have long played important - albeit brief - roles in the French perfume industry. Usually the lines are dropped shortly after the event.

headline: Marcos Authorizes Anti-Government Rally
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos today authorized an anti-Government rally scheduled for Sunday after a group of businessmen appealed to him and assured him the gathering would be peaceful, Maj. Gen. Prospero Olivas, the chief of police, said.

headline: U.S. EXPERTS CITE UNESCO BENEFITS
abstract: American scientists, scholars and cultural organizations stand to lose significant benefits through the abandonment of Unesco membership, according to many experts in cultural and scientific fields and others who have worked through the organization's agencies and related programs.     Moreover, they generally contend that the adverse effects of withdrawal in this country have not been taken sufficiently into account by the Reagan Administration, which announced yesterday that it was leaving the organization at the end of the year.    Representative Jim Leach, the Iowa Republican who is a leading opponent of withdrawal in Congress, said before the decision was announced, ''The Administration has never calculated the different alternatives and their cost.''    Several recent studies - including reports by the National Research Council, the National Science Foundation, the United States National Commission for Unesco and the Committee on Foreign Affairs - have argued the advantages of staying within Unesco even while agreeing with some of the Administration's criticisms of the organization's policies.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *  Diversified Industries, Richmond Heights, Mo., said it had acquired all production assets of Midwest Steel Processing Inc. of Center Line, Mich., which processes steel wire. Midwest is a wholly owned unit of Allied Products Corp.; terms were not disclosed.

headline: Market Place; The Outlook For Cosmetics
abstract: THE cosmetics industry, after several lackluster years, appears to be on the rebound. But  analysts are debating when - or if - this once-spotlighted group will again become truly attractive to investors.   While acknowledging the growing consumer demand for toiletries and cosmetics, and praising the prospects of individual issues, many analysts continue to cite the serious problems that have plagued the industry as a whole over the last half decade. These problems include excessive advertising and other product start-up outlays, along with some overdiversification.

headline: Canada's 1985 Outlook
abstract: Canada's top forecasters agree with Finance Minister Michael Wilson that its economy will grow 4.2 percent this year and 2.4 percent in 1985, the Conference Board of Canada said today after a survey of 17 economists.

headline: Dow's Rally Sparked by the Drop in a Key Rate
abstract: Daily close of the Dow Jones industrial average vs. the effective daily average Federal funds rate (in percent)    Dow Jones Industrials Left scale 1,150 1,175 1,200 1,225 1,250  Dec. 18 1,211.57 x34.78      Federal Funds Rate Right scale 6.5 7.0 7.5 8.0 8.5 9.0 9.5 10.0 10.5%  Dec. 18 6.65% Est.  cf39,8 Nov.Dec.

headline: OIL PARLEY FACES BIG OBSTACLES
abstract: As the OPEC oil ministers gather this week in Geneva, they face three formidable challenges to their increasingly battered pricing system.   Those challenges are the warm winter enjoyed by most consuming countries, the discounts offered by Norway and Britain and the task of reducing the price differentials between light and heavy crude oil.   Many other problems await Wednesday's conference of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries: cheating by about 10 of the 13 OPEC members in official prices or production levels; Nigeria's abandonment of OPEC prices and quotas; conflicts of interest within the organization; its diminishing credibility, and a market psychology that, though fickle, now runs against it.   ''At no point in the last decade has the cartel been faced with so many real and diverse challenges to their ability to control the price of oil,'' said Peter C. Beutel, an analyst with the Rudolf Wolff Energy Group in New York. ''This meeting must address certain fundamental issues if OPEC is to regain the full measure of pricing clout it until recently enjoyed.''

headline: COCA-COLA UP 15.6% IN QUARTER
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company reported yesterday that its third-quarter net income rose 15.6 percent, to $175.3 million, or $1.34 a share, from $151.6 million, or $1.11 a share, a year earlier.    Revenues for the soft-drink giant advanced 14.8 percent to $2.1 billion, from $1.83 billion.   Roberto C. Goizueta, chairman and chief executive, said soft-drink growth in the Pacific area, particularly Japan, where Diet Coke was recently introduced, was strong. He also said there were gains in another important market, Latin America, mainly as a result of an improved political climate.

headline: Japan Develops 1-Megabit Chip
abstract: The Toshiba Corporation today joined several other semiconductor makers by announcing its development of a chip that can store 1 million bits of data.   Development of the 1-megabit chip - whose storage capacity is about four times that of the current generation of chips in production - also has been pursued by several of Toshiba's Japanese counterparts, including Hitachi Ltd., the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation and the NEC Corporation.   In the United States the International Business Machines Corporation, the National Semiconductor Corporation and Texas Instruments Inc. are developing the chip, and Siemens A.G., West Germany's largest electronics concern, has similar plans.

headline: I.M.F. Plan Denounced
abstract: Foreign Minister Arturo Tolentino said today that the conditions placed on a loan package by the International Monetary Fund would drive the Philippines deeper into debt.   Mr. Tolentino called the conditions a new kind of ''colonialism'' that makes it almost impossible for nations to pay their debts.   His attack came as President Ferdinand E. Marcos's Government was conducting negotiations with the I.M.F. and foreign banks on a $4 billion rescue package.

headline: NEW ETHIOPIA: FEUDAL WAYS YIELD TO MARX
abstract: A decade is but a moment in the life of an empire that traces its origins to Solomon and Sheba. But in only 10 years since the overthrow of Emperor Haile Selassie, a new Ethiopia has been born.    Guided by ''scientific socialism,'' Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam and the small circle of military men who rule have completed the structures that are transforming Ethiopia from a feudal monarchy into a Communist dictatorship.   Western diplomats and Ethiopians interviewed in September said Colonel Mengistu, or Comrade Chairman Mengistu, as he is now called, was more firmly in control and stronger politically than ever before.    The experts also agreed that for the foreseeable future, Ethiopia was likely to remain hostile to the United States and firmly allied to the Soviet Union, despite the country's dependence on huge donations of grain each year from the West.

headline: Nicor Write-Down
abstract: Nicor Inc. said that because of the depressed energy markets it serves, the company expected ''significant asset write-downs'' to be included in its full-year 1984 results.

headline: Futures/Options; How to Help Industry Image
abstract: BEFORE the commodity industry introduced financial and stock index futures and options a few years ago, its members seemed inured to their public image as devil-may-care gamblers. While most were vexed by that image, it was generally attributed to the then esoteric nature of their trade. Not any more.   For one thing, the financial and index markets have attracted a new breed of futures trader who, like as not, comes from the securities business and finds the gambler image harmful in building potentially lucrative institutional hedging activity.

headline: JUDGE AIDS CLAIMS ON ASBESTOS
abstract: In a major victory for those with asbestos-related diseases, a Federal judge in Chicago ruled yesterday that 17,000 asbestos-related claims against UNR Industries - an asbestos maker that filed for reorganization under the Federal bankruptcy laws - could not be heard in bankruptcy court, but would have to be tried by district courts.    District Judge William T. Hart did not order the trials, which were frozen by the company's 1982 bankruptcy filing, to go ahead immediately, nor did he say which district courts should hear them.

headline: HONDURAN, AT THE U.N., SUGGESTS LATIN NATIONS MEET
abstract: The Foreign Minister of Honduras today invited four other Central American nations involved in the Contadora peace process to meet on Oct. 19 to try to insure the effectiveness of the plan.    Speaking at the 39th session of the United Nations General Assembly, the Foreign Minister, Edgardo Paz Barnica, invited his counterparts from Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Guatemala and El Salvador to gather in Tegucigalpa, the Honduran capital, to ''study'' a draft treaty proposed by the Contadora group.    The draft by the Contadora group, which comprises Colombia, Venezuela, Panama and Mexico, calls for political amnesty for dissidents and negotiations to end conflicts.   In his speech, Mr. Paz also repeated his Government's approval of the draft treaty, but said it needed tightening to insure that proposed reductions in arms, troops and advisers take place.

headline: Major Moves by I.B.M. In Opel's Final Year
abstract: John R. Opel's final year as chief executive at the International Business Machines Corporation was a memorable one.    Mr. Opel will remain as chairman of the company, which in the last year strengthened its grip on the personal computer market, made its first major acquisition in 22 years and settled a bitterly fought European antitrust case.

headline: Merger Talks By Fieldcrest BOSTON, Oct. 30 (Reuters)
abstract: The Amoskeag Company   and Fieldcrest Mills Inc. said   they are holding talks on a possible merger. Amoskeag currently owns 38.5 percent of   Fieldcrest's shares outstanding.

headline: LETTERS
abstract: SPENDING POLICY     To the Editor   In ''Dangers of Off-Budget Antics'' (Sept. 2), Stephen Berger states that ''In addition to farming, major off- budget programs include housing (the biggest program), rural electric loans, guaranteed student loans, the Tennessee Valley Authority and the Export-Import Bank.''    The Export-Import Bank of the United States is    not  an off-budget program.

headline: AGENTINA AND CHILE IN ACCORD ON BEAGLE CHANNEL
abstract: Argentina and Chile announced tonight that they had reached ''full understanding'' in their century-old territorial dispute over the Beagle Channel.    President Raul Alfonsin of Argentina, speaking at a ceremony in which he received an award for his work on human rights, did not give any details of the agreement but read the text of a communique also made public in Rome and in Santiago, Chile.   The communique said that delegations from the two countries would remain in Rome to draft a final treaty. A Vatican mediation committee set up by Pope John Paul II is assisting in the negotiations.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM AN ADDRESS BY RAJIV GANDHI
abstract: Following are excerpts from the English portion of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's address to the nation today:      Yesterday, the mortal remains of Indira Gandhi were consigned, as she had wished, to the mighty Himalayas. Her immortal spirit beckons to us to build the India of her dreams.   She fought against fanaticism and narrowness in all their forms. She made the nation self-reliant in agriculture, industry and several branches of technology. She battled relentlessly against poverty. Hers was the foremost voice for international peace in our tense and troubled world.

headline: 2 MANILA POLICEMEN ARRESTED FOR FIRING GUNS DURING RALLY
abstract: An army general told the National Assembly today that two policemen had been arrested for firing their guns during a clash with anti-Government demonstrators that left scores of people wounded.   One of 12 people hospitalized with gunshot wounds died two days after the street battle near the presidential palace last Thursday.   The National Assembly is conducting its first investigation of the police and military actions against opposition groups since President Ferdinand E. Marcos imposed martial law in 1972. He lifted military rule in January 1981, but retained many authoritarian powers.

headline: Hutcheson & Shutze?
abstract: Virgil Shutze, 40, executive vice president and director of creative services at McDonald & Little, the Ted Bates Worldwide subsidiary in Atlanta, is leaving the agency to join Hutcheson & Anderson, also in Atlanta. The agency has promised to change its name to Hutcheson & Shutze and give Mr. Shutze the titles of vice chairman and director of creative services. Don Hutcheson last month bought out his partner, William Anderson.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM; WHY DO WE IGNORE THE EVIDENCE?
abstract: Few environmental problems   have been studied as much as  acid rain. Fewer still have acid rain's ability to wreak widespread economic and environmental damage. And no problem is as much in need of immediate action.   More than 10 years ago researchers began to document acid rain's effects in the lakes in the Adirondack Mountains and warned of potential adverse impacts. Today, hundreds of lakes in New England, the Upper Middle West, the Mountain states and the Southeast that once teemed with fish have been stilled by acidification.

headline: Gun and Machete Fight Takes 15 Lives in Bolivia
abstract: At least 15 people were killed and 45 were wounded Friday in a gun and machete fight between truck drivers and peasants who blocked a highway in eastern Bolivia, Interior Minister Federico Alvarez Plata said today.   Army troops and policemen were dispatched early today to the road linking the cities of Santa Cruz and Trinidad, about 240 miles east of here, to restore order after the clash, Mr. Alvarez Plata said.    He said the battle started when truck drivers tried to break through a roadblock set up by peasants demanding Government action to improve local conditions.

headline: U.S. COMPANIES BOLSTER ANTI-APARTHEID CODE
abstract: About 120 American companies that operate in South Africa agreed yesterday to press for broad changes in South African society, including the repeal of all apartheid laws.   The agreement came in the form of an addition to the Sullivan Principles, a code of conduct designed by the Rev. Leon H. Sullivan of Philadelphia and subscribed to by many American corporations doing business in South Africa. Previously the Sullivan Principles focused on company matters - such as paying white workers and black workers the same wages - but the new provisions commit the companies to lobby for sweeping social change.   ''This is the first time American companies have entered the political arena in South Africa and pushed for an end to apartheid,'' said Mr. Sullivan after yesterday's meeting in New York. Others said some American companies already have taken similar political positions, but organizations favoring divestiture criticized the additions as cosmetic and ineffective.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM; THE LOOPHOLES DISTORT INCENTIVES
abstract: Why is the Federal Government racking up record budget deficits while most Americans believe - and rightly so - that they are paying more in taxes than ever before?   One answer can be found in the demise of the corporate income tax. Once, back in the 1950's and 1960's, businesses supplied one-quarter of all Federal Government revenues. By 1983, that share fell to 6.2 percent.

headline: PAKISTANI CHIEF STARTS CAMPAIGN TOUR FOR REFERENDUM
abstract: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, seeking the widest possible endorsement in a referendum later this month, set out today on a 10-day campaign tour that will take him all over the country.     The military Government has been apprehensive that there might be widespread boycotting of the Dec. 19 referendum, which is designed to give President Zia five more years in office. After opposition leaders began urging voters early this week not to vote, the Government decreed that advocating a boycott would be a crime punishable by three years in prison.   ''Now I'm not quite sure what we will do,'' said an opponent of General Zia in Karachi. ''But either way it will be a fraud and either way Zia will, of course, win.''

headline: Israelis Want a Local Force To Patrol Southern Lebanon
abstract: An Israeli general who is negotiating conditions for a withdrawal from Lebanon said today that Israel wanted a territorial force of 3,000 or 4,000 south Lebanese, and not the Lebanese Army, to look after security in the border area.   Brig. Gen. Amos Gilboa, head of the Israeli delegation to the talks, said at a briefing here that Israel had strong doubts about the ability of Lebanese Government forces to keep the peace.    Unless there are acceptable security arrangements, he said, Israeli forces will remain in Lebanon.

headline: People
abstract: *  Glen A. Dell is joining the JWT Group as executive vice president-finance and administration.

headline: FED EASED POLICY IN SEPTEMBER
abstract: The Federal Reserve reported today that it ''eased appreciably'' its grip on the nation's money supply in September but that a majority of its policy makers declined to ease even further in October.    The September relaxation and its ratification at the policy makers' Oct. 2 meeting by a vote of 9 to 3 appeared to have contributed to the decline in short-term interest rates before this week's election.   In a reflection of the easing, the 12- member Federal Open Market Committee set an annual growth rate of 6 percent from October through December for the basic money supply, or M-1, which includes currency in circulation and checking accounts. This was a full percentage point above the ''5 percent or slightly less'' set in the Aug. 21 meeting. The committee also decided that the Fed ''should be prepared to respond a little more promptly in an easing than in a tightening direction.''

headline: Czechs Foil Bus Hijacking
abstract: Czechoslovak border guards and policemen disarmed and arrested a man who had hijacked a bus with 48 passengers aboard and tried to force the driver at gunpoint to cross into West Germany at a border checkpoint on Friday night, the official Czechoslovak press agency reported today.

headline: United Ties Planes To Labor Pact
abstract: Richard J. Ferris, the chairman and chief executive of United Airlines, said the airline would buy more planes if a proposal it has sent its pilot union leads to a labor agreement. United, a unit of UAL Inc., has been in negotiations with the union for 10 months.

headline: Group Buys 7.4% Of Pioneer Corp.
abstract: An investment group led by Irwin L. Jacobs of Minneapolis told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had acquired 7.4 percent of the common shares of the Pioneer Corporation. The group said it had bought the stock to ''obtain an equity position'' in Pioneer, but ''might under certain circumstances consider seeking control.''

headline: Market Place ; The Rumors About Tenneco
abstract: This week's frantic activity in the stock of   Tenneco Inc. raises the question of whether   the Houston-based oil and gas producer is being considered as a takeover candidate.   But who would pay the $7 billion necessary to buy a company with a key subsidiary that is losing millions of dollars?   Although Tenneco joins an illustrious list of oil companies rumored as ripe for takeover - Unocal, Amerada Hess, Sun and Mobil, for example, - it is that question that makes most analysts doubt a Tenneco takeover is in the offing.        ''It's not one of the more likely takeover candidates,'' said Raymond J. Urban, vice president and oil analyst at Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago. ''The stock is selling at about 75 percent of its breakup value, and that would not be an attractive discount to get someone interested in buying the company. There are other oil producers who are selling at a greater discount, such as Mobil, which is selling at 40 percent of its breakup value.''

headline: Addenda
abstract: * Life magazine increasing its circulation rate base 7 percent, to 1.5 million, from 1.4 million, and its advertising rates 13.6 percent with the April issue.     * Forbes magazine increasing its circulation rate base six-tenths of 1 percent to 720,000, from 715,000, and its advertising rates about 9.5 percent starting with the Jan. 14 issue.

headline: REBEL REPORTS NO SANDINISTA BUILDUP
abstract: The chairman of the largest anti-Sandinista rebel force says his troops have seen little evidence of the major buildup of Soviet arms in Nicaragua that Reagan Administration officials have described.    In an interview, Adolfo Calero, head of the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, said that ''the only things we have seen in the field so far are the same weapons they have used for many months.''   In recent weeks, Reagan Administration officials have talked of unprecedented shipments of arms to Nicaragua from the Soviet Union and other Eastern bloc countries.    Earlier this month, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said the Russians had been supplying ''a great deal of heavy offensive arms to Nicaragua.''

headline: Lyon Metal-KS
abstract: Lyon Metal Products Inc. said the tender offer of $15 a share being made by KS Holdings Inc., a company owned by Irwin L. Jacobs and three associates, was inadequate and not in the best interests of shareholders. The board said book value of the stock is currently about $19 and a substantial increase is expected upon receipt of funds resulting from the recent termination of Lyon's shares. Lyon shares, trading over-the-counter, were bid yesterday at 15, up 37.5 cents from the previous day's bid.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Business Products Inc.  of Atlanta, a supplier of specialty paper products, elected Jeff Davidson, president and chief executive officer of the Gannett Broadcasting Group, to its board of directors.     * Carson Pirie Scott & Co.  of Chicago announced the resignation of William S. Bailey, president and chief executive of its subsidiary, County Seat Stores Inc. of Dallas.

headline: First Interstate's $150 Million Issue
abstract: First Interstate Bancorp offered $150 million of seven-year senior notes at competitive bidding.

headline: BRITONS GLOOMY OVER COAL STRIKE
abstract: Senior coal industry officials said today that they had given up hope of negotiating a settlement of the eight-month-old strike by most of Britain's deep-pit miners, already the longest major industrial stoppage in this country's history.   After the breakdown late Wednesday night of what had been described as ''last chance'' talks between the National Coal Board and the National Union of Mineworkers, headed by Arthur Scargill, it appeared highly likely that the strike would drag on into next year. Nigel Lawson, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, says it will have cost the country almost $2 billion by late December.

headline: POLE WITHOUT HONOR IN OWN COUNTRY IS HONORED
abstract: In an apartment across the street from Mokotow Prison where he spent two and a half years, Adam Michnik, the Solidarity adviser and activist, received an honorary doctorate Monday from the New School for Social Reseach.   Mr. Michnik accepted the green and white academic hood presented to him by Jonathan F. Fanton, president of the New School, in the living room of Edward Lipinski, the 98- year-old Polish social activist.    It was in this same apartment that Mr. Michnik and his colleagues formed the now banned Commmittee to Defend Workers, which was known by its Polish initials KOR and which acted as an intellectual support group for the Solidarity movement.   Mr. Michnik, 37 years old, who has spent an aggregate of some six years in prison, as well as having been banished from a Polish university and ordered to work in a lamp factory for his political activism, attained wide international attention through his long analytical and often quite humorous letters smuggled out of prison and published in many languages.

headline: SPANIARDS SIGN ACCORD ON LABOR AND SALARIES
abstract: An agreement governing labor relations and salaries over the next two years was signed today by Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez and representatives of employers and Socialist unions.   Thus, Mr. Gonzalez, a Socialist, won some breathing space for the Government's attempt to overhaul Spanish industry in preparation for the expected Spanish entry into the European Economic Community within 15 months.   Barring any breakdowns, the pact will also cover Mr. Gonzalez through scheduled general elections in 1986, further assuring what analysts here are already saying is his almost certain re-election.   Pragmatism Reflected    By holding wage rises below the inflation rate and by moving toward making it easier for employers to dismiss workers, the pact tends to favor business interests. It reflects the pragmatism of Spain's Socialist Government and falls in step with the recent willingness elsewhere in Europe, especially in France and West Germany, to take on entrenched unions.

headline: Walesa Offers Condolences
abstract: Lech Walesa visited the Indian Embassy today to offer condolences over the assassination of Indira Gandhi. The Nobel Peace Prize winner wrote in the embassy's condolence book, ''Deeply startled by the barbaric act of terror, in feeling of real brotherhood and solidarity, I join with the nation of Mahatma Gandhi and pray for peace and unity in your country.''

headline: Northeastern Air Shuffling Fleet
abstract: Northeastern International Airways is shuffling its fleet of Boeing 727 jetliners in an effort to overcome cash problems, the carrier's chairman said. The airline earlier announced the layoffs of 100 employees and suspension of service to Oklahoma as part of a temporary cutback.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: *  Beneficial Corp., Wilmington, Del., has named Frederick M. Dawson to the post of chairman and chief executive officer of the Beneficial Insurance Group.     *  Designhouse International Inc., Atlanta, has named Salvatore F. Battinelli president and chief operating officer, succeeding David Kameron, who remains chairman and chief executive officer.     *  Revlon Inc.  announced that George Fellows had joined it in the newly created position of senior vice president and assistant to the president, Revlon Beauty Group.

headline: OTTAWA, PARIS IN TALKS
abstract: Canadian and French officials met this week to discuss increasing trade between the two countries, the president of Canada's Treasury Council said Thursday.

headline: MISSING THE HAND TOOL BOOM
abstract: By all rights, with the baby boom generation buying and fixing up houses, sales of tools for the do-it-yourself market should be humming. And, indeed, the industry-leading Stanley Works of New Britain, Conn., with a vigorous marketing and advertising campaign to make its name synonymous with quality, is forging record sales and profits.    But such winning results do not await every player in the game. At the century-old brick plant of Easco Hand Tools Inc. here, where 65 percent of the output goes to Sears, Roebuck & Company for sale under its Craftsman label, the outlook is grim.    A third of the plant's 1,000 blue-collar workers have been laid off, and managers are packing up their filing cabinets. While a scaled-down production line remains open, the division - the parent Easco Corporation's largest hand tool facility - will be closed by spring, and the staff will be transferred elsewhere. Its warehouses are crammed with millions of dollars worth of excess Craftsman- label products.

headline: JUDGE SUGGESTS A BYSTANDER SAVED POPE
abstract: The judge who investigated the purported plot to assassinate Pope John Paul II was quoted today as having said that an unidentified spectator may have saved the Pope's life by shoving the arm of the Turkish gunman convicted of shooting him.    In an interview published in the Turin daily La Stampa today, Judge Ilario Martella was quoted as having said that Mehmet Ali Agca, the man convicted of attempting to assassinate the Pope, ''was very clear'' in declaring that he would have continued shooting at the Pope had he not been pushed.   The Pope was badly wounded in the attack on May 13, 1981.   According to the report in La Stampa, the judge quoted Mr. Agca as having said, ''I would have continued to fire if someone near me had not shoved me with force.''

headline: Pay Is Better At Clients
abstract: getting out of graduate business schools can get almost  $35,000 a year to start, according to Judd-Falk, the headhunters. But they note, despite the   glow of great wealth that radiates from ad agency people,   people on the payrolls of the advertisers are doing far, far better - as much as 30 percent   better on senior levels, and 60   percent better on junior levels.

headline: EUROPEANS SEEK A MILITARY IDENTITY
abstract: Foreign and Defense Ministers from seven NATO countries met here today without the United States in an attempt to bring a more clearly defined European character to their military cooperation.     But a year after a wave of interest developed in Europe about broadening the European role in the decision-making and procurement processes of the Atlantic alliance, speeches at the session today emphasized that there was no desire to supplant NATO or bypass the role of the United States.    The meeting brought together the member nations of the Western European Union, a 30-year-old organization that had been largely dormant. It was the first conference since the 1950's, officials said, involving Western European ministers on security issues outside the auspices of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

headline: 3 Diverse Selections For Ad Hall of Fame
abstract: A former agency head, the ad director of a major package goods company and a marketing educator have all been elected to the Advertising Hall of Fame of the American Advertising Federation.    They are Thomas B. Adams, longtime leader of Campbell-Ewald in Detroit where he ran the Chevrolet account; James S. Fish, a graduate school teacher since retiring as vice president and head of advertising worldwide for General Mills, and Charles H. Sandage, professor emeritus of the University of Illinois.    The induction will be March 26 at a luncheon in the Waldorf Astoia.

headline: TISSUE MARKERS' NEW TACTICS
abstract: In a push for market share, some makers of facial and bathroom tissue are going beyond the usual promises of ''softer'' and ''more absorbent.''    The Procter & Gamble Company recently introduced Special Touch by Puffs, a facial tissue treated with lotion, which will share the name of their premium-priced Puffs. The huge consumer products company has also been testing a lotion-treated toilet paper called Certain, although with no great success thus far.    The Scott Paper Company recently began test-marketing Sofkins, a cleansing wipe akin to their Baby Fresh product, for use along with bathroom tissue. And earlier this month, the Kimberly-Clark Corporation, the maker of Kleenex, began a limited introduction of Avert Viralcidal Tissues, a facial tissue treated with antiviral agents.

headline: States Repeal Unitary Tax Some four decades ago, California legislators, looking for a
abstract: way to raise revenues, put in   place a global unitary tax. The   new tax used an accounting   method to assess companies on   a fraction of their international   operations - not just those located in the state or country.

headline: Morocco and Guerrillas Report Fierce Fighting
abstract: Morocco and its Polisario guerrilla foes reported fierce fighting in the Western Sahara today that left scores of dead and wounded.   An official communique issued by the Moroccan press agency said 114 guerrillas were slain and eight of their Soviet-made T-55 tanks destroyed in the clash Sunday.

headline: Beecham to Buy Cosmetic Units
abstract: Beecham Group P.L.C., a holding company with pharmaceutical, food and cosmetics interests, said it would acquire the cosmetics units of B.A.T Industries P.L.C. for about $:125 million, or about $105 million.   Beecham said it would pay $:21 million to B.A.T for the assets of Germaine Monteil U.S.A., a United States subsidiary. Beecham said it would sell $:104 million worth of Beecham common stock, or about 4 percent of its issued capital, to pay for acquiring the remaining units.

headline: Nationwide Adds Radio Stations
abstract: The Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company said its Nationwide Communications Inc. subsidiary had agreed in principle to acquire eight radio stations from Western Cities Broadcasting for more than $40 million.   The company said the transaction would give it 15 stations. It said the stations being acquired are in Sacramento and San Jose, Calif.; Las Vegas, Nev., and Phoenix and Tucson, Ariz.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Another Officer Resigns at Warner
abstract: Warner Communications Inc. said this weekend that Caesar P. Kimmel, executive vice president and one of the company's founders, had resigned to pursue personal interests.   A company spokesman, Geoffrey W. Holmes, said Mr. Kimmel had not been pushed out by Warner, which in the last three months has lost two other high-level executives.

headline: CANADA SENDS U.S. MORE GAS
abstract: Because of Canada's recent formal deregulation of export prices, its natural gas is beginning to pour across the border in large quantities at increasingly low prices after years of being overpriced compared with American gas.    ''We've seen an immediate volume increase, and see the prospect of an even greater one,'' a Canadian Government official said.    The Nov. 1 Canadian deregulation came two months before the United States Government is scheduled to increase the proportion of gas output removed from price controls to half, from less than 10 percent, under its six-year-old deregulation schedule.   Downward Push Expected    In today's soft market, that can only push American gas prices, already weak, downward. Experts say Canada might raise its share of the American gas market to 8 percent, from 4 percent.

headline: CURRENT RULES FOR THE DOLLAR
abstract: THE United States trade deficit is running at a   record annual rate, big money-center banks   have just cut their prime rate of interest by a quarter to a half percentage point and industrial production is slipping, but the dollar continues to hit record-breaking highs against other major currencies. Have the old rules of what causes a nation's currency to strengthen or weaken been repealed?    R. T. Mcnamar, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, contends that the rules of the game have indeed changed since the 1970's because of the enormous increase in international capital flows. Trade in goods and services total about $2 trillion a year, while capital flows are in the $20-to-$30-trillion range, or about 15 times goods and services.

headline: FRANCE REPLACES FOREIGN MINISTER
abstract: Roland Dumas, a close friend of President Francois Mitterrand, was named Foreign Minister today, replacing Claude Cheysson.    Mr. Dumas, a 62-year-old lawyer, was Minister of European Affairs and Government spokesman. The President announced on Tuesday that Mr. Cheysson would become a member of the European Commission, the European Economic Community's executive body. It is a job he held before his appointment as Foreign Minister after the Socialist election victory in 1981.

headline: Deficit Expected By Castle & Cooke
abstract: Castle & Cooke Inc., a producer and distributor of fresh products and packaged goods, said yesterday that it expected to report a net operating loss of about $35 million for its quarter ending Dec. 29.   The deficit was ''several times greater'' than the company had anticipated, a spokesman said, primarily because of greatly reduced selling prices for bananas and lettuce.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Nov. 12 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 3 P.M.

headline: BRIEFS ;  Debt Issues
abstract: Coca-Cola Co.  is issuing $100 million of 11 3/8 percent four-year Eurobonds priced at 103.60 with the price including four-year warrants to buy a similar amount of seven-year bonds with the same coupon through Morgan Guaranty Ltd.     *  Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, in conjunction with its $125 million of two- year notes in the U.S. market, is issuing 125,000 debt warrants in Europe through Goldman Sachs International Corp.     *  Ralston Purina Co.  is offering $100 million of 10-year callable bonds with warrants to buy 12-year callable bonds through Morgan Guaranty Ltd.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD ; Zimbabwe Leader Vows To Have Free Election
abstract: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe said today that the Government would do all it could to insure that a general election due by next March was free and fair.   He said at a news conference that he did not believe there was tension in the country, even in Matabeleland and Midlands Provinces, where rebels have been fighting the Government for two years.   He called on the opposition party of Joshua Nkomo, his ally in the guerrilla war for independence, to end its backing of the rebels, but the party denies it is backing them.

headline: Auto Strikes In Britain
abstract: Thousands of automobile workers went on strike today, halting production of luxury Jaguar cars and Austin Rover models.   Workers at Austin Rover walked out ahead of schedule at two plants.

headline: Polysilicon Plant
abstract: The Wacker Siltronic Corporation said it would build a polysilicon production plant in Portland, which would be the world's largest. Polysilicon is a major component in the wafer chips used in transistorized electronic equipment. An official said shipments should begin by 1987.

headline: People
abstract: *  Michael D. Drazen is joining Havas Conseil Marsteller as executive vice president-creative director.

headline: Two Are Killed in India In Moslem-Hindu Clash
abstract: Moslems and Hindus clashed in the northeastern state of Assam today and two people were killed, state officials reported.   They said that Moslems attacked a Hindu religious procession in Mankachar, 370 miles northeast of Calcutta, and that at least one person was killed and more than 100 were injured.

headline: A UNION COPES WITH DEREGULATION
abstract: WASHINGTON     THE gathering at the Philadelphia Convention Center on   March 28, 1983, could have been mistaken for a conclave of futurists. Alvin (''Future Shock'') Toffler gave the keynote speech. A Committee on the Future unveiled a blueprint for ''shaping our destiny.'' The 1,700 delegates furrowed their brows over discussions of new technology and ''survival skills.''    In fact, it was a union meeting. The Communications Workers of America, faced with the court-ordered breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, their biggest employer, had called the special convention to discuss strategies for coping with the transformation. By then, the Committee on the Future had already spent 18 months looking for ways to avoid the battering suffered by unions in airline, trucking, and other deregulated industries. ''No other union was doing this kind of thing'' when C.W.A. started its future-gazing, said Glenn E. Watts, the union's president.

headline: IRAQ REPORTS DOWNING 2 JETS
abstract: Iraq said its jet fighters downed two Iranian F-4 Phantom warplanes today when the Iranians tried to break up an air strike against their positions.

headline: 2 Killed in Philippines
abstract: Two people were killed in the latest outbreak of guerrilla fighting in this southern Philippine city. Military sources said today that on Saturday night gunmen shot dead a banana plantation security guard and a woman suspected of being an informer for the Communist New People's Army.

headline: WARSAW TO FREE TWO SOLIDARITY ACTIVISTS
abstract: The former second-ranking member of the Solidarity underground and another Solidarity member will be freed under the terms of this summer's amnesty, the Polish television announced tonight.   Bogdan Lis, a 31-year-old former shipyard mechanic and former Communist Party member, has been held since his arrest in June, along with Piotr Mierzejewski, a former Solidarity member, while the authorities weighed a case of high treason against them. Such a charge, which carries a death penalty, was specifically exempted from the amnesty proclaimed on June 22 when 652 political prisoners were released.    Their release was seen, in part, as a conciliatory gesture toward the West.

headline: NITZE URGES OPTIMISM IN JANUARY ARMS TALKS WITH RUSSIANS
abstract: Ambassador Paul H. Nitze said today that Secretary of State George P. Shultz should approach next month's arms-control talks with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union hopeful of progress ''until that's demonstrated to be wrong.''   In his first interview since being named by President Reagan on Wednesday as Mr. Shultz's ''special adviser'' for the Gromyko talks, Mr. Nitze looked philosophically at the sharp splits within the Administration over how to deal with the Russians.    The 77-year-old veteran negotiator said the clashes between the State Department and the Defense Department were ''natural differences of point of view'' that have persisted within the Washington bureaucracy since the immediate postwar years.   Reluctant to Discuss New Role      Mr. Nitze was reluctant to describe his new role as Mr. Shultz's special adviser. In recent days he has moved into an office near Mr. Shultz's seventh-floor suite. But the interview today was given in Mr. Nitze's old office on the fifth floor of the department, where he had operated as head of the American delegation to the negotiations on medium-range missiles.

headline: Butcher Pleads Not Guilty
abstract: Jacob F. Butcher pleaded not guilty today to diverting $14.9 million from two banks. A judge who received $900,000 in loans from a Butcher bank disqualified himself from the case.

headline: INDIAN POLICE ARREST 3d SIKH IN GANDHI SLAYING
abstract: A Sikh identified by the authorities as one of two men who killed Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has reportedly confessed and provided details of the plot. His statements were said to have led to the arrest of a third Sikh and a police search for two more people believed to be linked to the case.    In a statement dictated Saturday Satwant Singh reportedly confessed that he killed Mrs. Gandhi on Oct. 31, apparently giving the investigating team a breakthrough. The other Sikh bodyguard that the Indian police said was involved in the killing, Beant Singh, was shot dead by Mrs. Gandhi's security men just after she was killed; Satwant Singh was seriously wounded by the same guards.

headline: VOTE COMES TO A 'HOMELAND,' BUT AFRICAN PROBLEMS LINGER
abstract: Under capricious skies that brought rain and light by turn to places of little hope, the officials and the policeman stood before the galvanized iron hut that represented a polling booth and said, well, yes, the turnout had been sluggish.    The officials numbered 7 or 8; the voters this day numbered 26, they said, from an area of shacks and barren land that is home to 5,000 people.     ''Maybe it will pick up,'' one of them ventured. The others mused on this frail oracle with expressions that seemed to say: ''And maybe not.''    First Vote In Area    And thus did democracy stir, for the first time, this week in KwaNdebele, South Africa's second smallest, and most improbable tribal ''homeland,'' a repository for black people wanted in white South Africa only for their labor.

headline: GANDHI MAKES FEW CHANGES IN PARTY TICKETS
abstract: As the first phase of India's national election draws to a close and the campaign is about to begin in earnest, it has become apparent that Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi has made no sweeping changes in the character of his Congress-I Party ticket.   Many politicians, political scientists and political commentators had believed - or at least hoped - that Mr. Gandhi would make wholesale alterations in the list of Congress-I candidates in order to purge the party of some unsavory elements and bring in new blood.   Indian politics generally has in recent years attracted a number of what are widely seen as corrupt, unscrupulous and even criminal practitioners.   But as the deadline for candidates to file their nomination papers for the Dec. 24-28 election passed on Tuesday, it appeared that no large- scale change had taken place, though a number of the most notorious figures were denied spots on the ticket.

headline: An Early Retirement At European American
abstract: As part of an early retirement program intended to streamline operations at the European American Bank, Nicholas A. Sica, the bank's 63- year-old president, announced that he would leave at the end of the year.   Susan W. Cole, a spokesman for the bank, said the position would not be filled and that Raymond J. Dempsey, the bank's 49-year-old chairman and chief executive officer, had not made a decision about assuming the additional title.    Mr. Dempsey, former chairman and chief executive at Fidelcor of Philadelphia, replaced Hary E. Ekblom at European American last March.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Oct. 11, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Syrian Vice President Meets With U.S. Aide
abstract: Vice President Abdel Halim Khaddam conferred here today with the American Assistant Secretary of State, Richard W. Murphy, the Syrian press agency reported.

headline: HONG KONG ACCORD IS SIGNED IN PEKING
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today signed the agreement formally committing Britain to surrender Hong Kong to China in 1997 in return for terms guaranteeing a 50-year extension of its capitalist economic system.    ''We have accomplished a task of historical significance,'' Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang said after he and Mrs. Thatcher exchanged red velvet binders containing Chinese and English copies of the accord. Mrs. Thatcher responded by calling the pact ''a landmark in the life of the territory, in the course of Anglo-Chinese relations and in the history of international diplomacy.''    Moments earlier, before onlookers who included China's pre-eminent leader, Deng Xiaoping, and a live-television audience in Hong Kong, the two Government leaders signed the document that will put an end to a century and a half of British rule in the enclave that began as a replenishment station for the British Navy and grew to become one of the most thriving outposts of free enterprise in Asia.    The agreement will assume binding effect only after it is ratified. Britain's Parliament approved the accord last week, and China's nominal legislature, the National People's Congress, is to take similar action before July 1. A joint consultative body will monitor progress toward the transfer.

headline: Treasury Plans a Heavy Schedule
abstract: Treasury financings will dominate the credit markets this week, assuming the Federal debt ceiling is increased. Last week, Treasury officials announced plans to hold the regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, as well as sales of 7- and 20-year issues that were delayed from late September because of the debt ceiling.    The regular auction of Treasury bills will be held Tuesday, because the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and the Government securities markets will be closed for the Columbus Day holiday today. Late Friday, outstanding three-month bills were trading around 10.12 percent with the six-month issue at 10.26 percent.

headline: THE WORLD OF THE LONE-WOLF ENTREPRENEUR; A FULL-SERVICE AGENCY ROLLED INTO ONE
abstract: JOSEPH SONNENREICH is no rookie at working alone. Since 1950, he has done advertising work that most agencies parcel out to at least three or more different departments. He single-handedly takes his ads from concept through story board through publication.

headline: MGM Hotel Stake
abstract: Kirk Kerkorian said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had raised his stake in MGM Grand Hotels Inc. to 69.4 percent of the common shares outstanding, or 15,739,173 common shares. He had owned 50.5 percent. According to the filing, the Tracinda Corporation, of which Mr. Kerkorian is the principal executive officer, acquired 4,287,734 MGM shares in a $12-a-share tender offer completed on Oct. 31. On the New York Stock Exchange today, MGM closed at $11.75, up 12.5 cent s.

headline: OIL PRICES CONTINUE DROPPING
abstract: Oil prices dropped again yesterday, some to their lowest level of the year, as speculation mounted that oil- producing nations would be forced to lower their prices again.   The declines occurred despite a report Tuesday night from the American Petroleum Institute that inventories of crude oil and distillates declined last week. A decline in inventories can indicate a need to restock, which would drive up prices.

headline: CHARGES AGAINST A REPORTER IN PUNJAB STIR PROTEST
abstract: An effort to prosecute an Associated Press reporter here has set off protests by representatives of Western news organizations, some of whom see the case as a gross violation of the principle of freedom of the press, a principle officially subscribed to by the Indian Government.    The reporter, a 27-year-old Indian national named Brahma Chellaney, surrendered voluntarily to a magistrate 10 days ago on charges that he falsely reported certain facts about the Indian Army raid on the Golden Temple in the northern state of Punjab last June, and that his reports inflamed sectarian passions.    Mr. Chellaney, who upon surrendering was temporarily relieved of the obligation to turn himself over to the police and released on bail, could be jailed for up to six years if convicted.

headline: REPORTS OF INSIDER TRADING
abstract: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.   The reports of changes follow:  NEW YORK EXCHANGE      AMERICAN EXPRESS COMPANY- Sanford I. Weill, director, sold 50,000 shares leaving him directly with a balance of 454,999 shares.

headline: Shell, Arco Cuts
abstract: The Shell Oil Company, based in Houston, and the Atlantic Richfield Company of Los Angeles cut their posted price for West Texas Intermediate, a light crude, by $1 a barrel, to $29. That virtually completes the round of price cuts that has been sweeping the nation's oil industry. After the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to curb production by 1.5 million barrels a day Nov. 1 to bolster sagging world oil prices, major American oil companies began reducing the price they are willing to pay for high-quality, light domestic crude oil.

headline: Flooding in British Columbia
abstract: More than 100 people were evacuated from their homes and some were stranded on the upper floors of buildings by high water today in a flood-ravaged area around Pemberton, about 80 miles north of Vancouver. The Lillooet River and Ryan Creek have risen nearly 15 feet and inundated low- lying farmland and houses.

headline: Jacobs Has Stake In G. C. Murphy
abstract: Irwin L. Jacobs, who recently sold for a profit a major position in Walt Disney Productions, disclosed yesterday that he had acquired 376,900 shares of the G. C. Murphy Company, a McKeesport, Pa., retail concern, for about $12.4 million. The Jacobs stake represents about 8 percent of Murphy's common shares outstanding.

headline: New President Named By Collins & Aikman
abstract: The Collins & Aikman Corporation said yesterday that Alfred S. Crimmins had been promoted to president.   Mr. Crimmins, who is 49, succeeds Donald F. McCullough, 59, who has held the post for the last five years and who will remain chairman and chief executive officer.

headline: Land Fraud Of $2 Billion
abstract: Two men have pleaded guilty to bilking thousands of investors in the Netherlands out of as much as $2 billion in what the prosecutor called the largest land fraud in United States history.   Bernard Whitney, a 66-year-old California lawyer, and Rienk Hendricus Kamer, 41, a Dutch real estate promoter, pleaded guilty Tuesday to one count each of mail fraud, wire fraud and conspiracy.

headline: Cuisine Magazine Ceasing Publication
abstract: CBS Inc. announced yesterday that it was closing down Cuisine magazine, which was operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws when it was acquired for $2.7 million in April 1982. CBS sold the Cuisine subscription list to Conde Nast, publisher of Gourmet.    Peter G. Diamandis, president of CBS Magazines, said that even though the monthly magazine was up 31 percent in ad pages for the first 10 months of the year and up 45 percent in ad revenues for the first six months, it was not profitable. And although neither publishing company would disclose price, CBS did say it was making a profit on the list sale.

headline: Military Contracts
abstract: -The Mobil Oil Corporation, a unit of the Mobil Corporation, received a $221.3 million contract for jet fuel from the Defense Logistics Agency, the Defense Department said.  Other contracts for jet fuel included $93.6 million to the Hess Oil Virgin Islands Corporation, $45.9 million to Papago Chemicals Inc. and $32.9 million to texaco Inc., the department said.  In addition, it said the Navy had given the McDonnell Douglas Aircraft Company a $105.1 million contract for aircraft support equipment.

headline: Cattle Supply Grows
abstract: Cattle being fed for the consumer market as of Nov. 1 in the seven major beef-producing states totaled 8.22 million head, up 7 percent from one year ago and 1 percent from two years ago, the Agriculture Department reported today.

headline: Kaneb Writedown
abstract: Kaneb Services Inc. said it had taken a $55 million writedown of the carrying value of some assets and had cut its quarterly dividend to 10 cents a share, from 26 cents.

headline: HOLIDAY SALES OFF AT STORES
abstract: With one shopping day left, the year's Christmas season is concluding a generally disappointing run, according to retailers in various cities.    While seasonal sales picked up in the last few days and were stimulated by price-slashing in almost every city, sales were not robust enough to match the 11 percent gain posted for the Christmas period last year, the merchants said.   By the weekend, sales for the 31- day holiday shopping period were running from slightly behind to about 8 percent ahead of last year, the merchants said. And sales today, when most stores will close early, are not expected to make a marked difference.

headline: Times Co. Net Up 39% In Quarter
abstract: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its third-quarter net income rose 39 percent, to $20.4 million, or 51 cents a share, from $14.6 million, or 37 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.   Revenues climbed 15 percent, to $289.1 million, from $250.7 million.   ''The strongest elements of our earnings in the third quarter were in the newspaper group and in our forest products equity interests,'' Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman and chief executive officer, said.

headline: A 'Positive Shift' From Coffee Campaign
abstract: The pro-coffee effort created by Advertising to Women caused a ''positive shift among the target group,'' according to the National Coffee Association of the U.S.A., its sponsor.

headline: Swaziland Rounding Up South African Guerrillas
abstract: The police have begun rounding up the last 23 African National Congress guerrillas still in Swaziland, a police spokesman said today.   The crackdown follows a warning by the Swazi police a week ago that the men, who fled to Swaziland from neighboring Mozambique this year, had to surrender or be deported to South Africa, where the African National Congress is fighting white minority rule.   The announcement came a day after South Africa and Swaziland announced an agreement to exchange trade representatives, the first such exchange of permanent envoys by the two nations.

headline: Article 083658 -- No Title
abstract: A group that has financial backing from the Chemical Bank filed suit today asserting that Washington State has a moral obligation to pay $7.25 billion in principal and interest to the bondholders of two terminated nuclear power units. The suit, brought by a bondholder committee, charges fraud, negligence, misfeasance and that the State Auditor failed to warn bondholders of the Washington Public Power Supply System's ''serious financial difficulties.''

headline: New Violence and Arson Erupt in South Africa
abstract: One day after troops and policemen raided three black townships, renewed stone-throwing and arson broke out in other black communities, a police spokesman said today.    New violence broke out in townships near Johannesburg and Port Elizabeth, while black areas subjected to a large- scale crackdown Tuesday remained quiet, the spokesman said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Avalon Energy Corp.  of Atlanta said it had an agreement in principle to acquire Tri-South Investments Inc., also of Atlanta, by swapping 1.18 common shares of Avalon for each common share of Tri-South.     *   Boise Cascade Corp., a forest products company, said it had purchased the assets of Business Essentials Inc. of Kansas City, Mo.

headline: LAKER CIVIL ANTITRUST SUIT TO GO ON
abstract: The liquidator for Laker Airways said today that his civil antitrust suit against British and American airlines accused of a price- fixing conspiracy to drive Laker out of business would continue, despite President Reagan's decision on Monday to halt a criminal antitrust investigation.    However, sources here said they were hopeful that the President's move might clear the way for a quick settlement of disagreements between Washington and the British Government. These have blocked attempts by airlines to cut prices over the North Atlantic this winter.

headline: MERRILL OPERATING EARNINGS OFF 24.5%
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company, suffering from a lack of trading by individual investors, reported yesterday that its operating earnings in the third quarter dropped 24.5 percent, to $25 million, or 27 cents a share, from $33.1 million, or 38 cents a share, in the period last year.   Nevertheless, analysts noted that the operating profit at the parent of the nation's largest brokerage firm contrasted sharply to a $32.8 million operating loss in this year's second quarter. They said the improvement resulted from somewhat more favorable markets, which sparked institutional business and were likely to be reflected in earnings of the brokerage industry.   Including special items, Merrill reported a third-quarter net income of $80 million, or 87 cents a share, compared with $33 million, or 38 cents a share a year ago. Revenues increased to $1.66 billion, from $1.31 billion last year. The one-time items included a $127 million gain - $46 million after taxes, or 50 cents a share - from the sale of its headquarters building at One Liberty Plaza. Merrill is planning to move to the new World Financial Center in lower Manhattan. Because of a change in the tax laws, the company also had a special tax credit of $9 million, or 10 cents a share, from its Family Life Insurance Company.

headline: U.S. DROPS ONE IDEA FOR CHANGE IN UNESCO
abstract: The United States today withdrew one of its key proposals for changing the adminimstration of Unesco.   The proposal was to require a vote of 85 percent of the membership to pass the organization's budget.

headline: Burroughs Plans 3 New Products
abstract: The Burroughs Corporation said it would introduce a new mainframe, a minicomputer and systems software at a news conference Tuesday.   Burroughs declined to provide details. However, industry analysts said the presentation is expected to include the latest addition to the company's ''A-Series'' mainframe line and a minicomputer cabable of running on the Burroughs proprietary system, as well as at least one additional network.

headline: MANAGUAN HELD UNLIKELY TO GET ADVANCED JETS
abstract: There is little prospect that Nicaragua will receive advanced jet aircraft anytime soon, in the view of most foreign diplomats and independent military analysts here.     ''The Russians have made it fairly clear that they aren't going to donate the planes,'' a senior Western diplomat said here a few days ago, ''and the Sandinistas have no money to pay for them anywhere else. For strategic and financial reasons, these guys are going to have to live with pretty much what they have now.''    But the diplomats said they believed that the Government might well manage to obtain some less powerful aircraft to bolster its small air force.

headline: Market Place; Chesebrough's Slowing Pace
