abstract: -POND'S Inc., with products including such household names as Vaseline petroleum jelly, Ragu spaghetti sauce and Health-tex children's apparel, has forged an enviable record of 28 straight years of earnings growth.   The pace of profit increases has slowed markedly in the last several years, but in 1983 the giant company, based in Greenwich, Conn., managed to keep its record intact with earnings of $3.58 a share. Moreover, as recently as mid-October, Chesebrough indicated that it expected earnings for the current year to be flat to slightly higher.   But yesterday a company spokesman confirmed that Chesebrough has been telling Wall Street analysts that it now looks for the 1984 profit to run slightly below last year's level.

headline: THE HUMBLING OF CONTINENTAL'S BOARD
abstract: Last spring this city's proud, vibrant business community was taken down a notch when the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, the pride of Chicago banking, nearly collapsed.    And this week the business establishment was humbled again when the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation ousted 10 of Chicago's leading business figures from Continental's board.   ''Those people were upset that they were summarily dismissed like that,'' said Walter D. Fackler, a professor at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business. ''A lot of them are first-rate people.''

headline: Insider Reports
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.   The report of changes follows:  NEW YORK EXCHANGE      AVNET INC.

headline: TAX SHELTER CRACKDOWN BEGINS TO HAVE AN EFFECT
abstract: New tax law provisions intended to identify abusive tax shelters and punish violators more severely are bolstering efforts by the Internal Revenue Service and the Justice Department to curb unwarranted deductions.     The I.R.S. says the 1984 tax act, approved by Congress two months ago, is helping it to block shelters that are essentially tax dodges, lacking economic merit. It also reports that the courts are getting tougher and that the service's success rate in audits has improved markedly.    The Justice Department's tax division, meanwhile, says it will have two dozen lawyers working exclusively on fraudulent shelters.    A tax shelter, basically, is an investment that provides substantial deductions from income otherwise taxable to the investor. Real estate and oil exploration are two of the most popular. The Government regards as abusive the shelters that promise immediate deductions of several times the taxpayer's cash investment, especially if the venture seems to have little prospect of earning profits.

headline: COMPUTER WORK BENDS COLLEGE SECRECY RULES
abstract: Some of the nation's leading universities have quietly carved exceptions to their traditional prohibitions against secret research on campus to help develop a host of products for the computer industry.     The universities concede they have bent or broken their normal rules promoting wide exchange of new knowledge. But they say that to work on the most state-of-the-art technology, they must be willing to accept, and help protect, trade secrets and product plans of corporations. The companies are spending tens of millions of dollars on the campus research, most of which centers on a new generation of computer software and complex data communication networks.    Critics contend that the spread of secret campus research is just what they warned against when advances in biotechnology thrust universities directly into commercial ventures four years ago. The universities, they argue, have begun to restrict the free exchange of information - considered the cornerstone of academic freedom - to attract big research contracts.

headline: Morris Talks End
abstract: The Ex-Cell-O Corporation said it had ended negotiations to acquire the Smith Morris Corporation, a privately held maker of parts for aircraft engines. The reasons for the action were not disclosed.

headline: 40 Laid Off by Asarco
abstract: Asarco Inc., a copper producer with headquarters in New York, laid off 40 more workers at its Mission Mine at Sahuaritia, bringing the number of copper workers let go this month to 120.

headline: BRANDT VISITS MANAGUA BUT FAILS TO SETTLE NICARAGUA VOTE DISPUTE
abstract: Former Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany, who arrived here less than 48 hours ago to mediate disputes over Nicaragua's planned presidential election, left today, his mission apparently a failure.     During his visit, Mr. Brandt, the president of the Socialist International, met with the president of the Roman Catholic Episcopal Conference, Bishop Pablo Antonio Vega, and with leaders of the Government and the opposition. Among them was Arturo Jose Cruz, an opposition presidential candidate who has refused to register his candidacy on the ground that election laws unfairly favor the ruling Sandinista Front.

headline: WEST BANK ARABS GIVE MIXED REVIEWS TO PALESTINIAN PARLEY
abstract: -Occupied West Bank, Nov. 30 - The meeting of the Palestine National Council in Amman earned mixed reviews today from the Arabs of Israel and the occupied territories, who were able to watch most of the proceedings live on television from the Jordanian capital.   The meeting of the council, which the Palestinians call their parliament in exile, ended late Thursday night with the reaffirmation of the leadership of Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.   The council gave Mr. Arafat the power to develop a joint strategy with Jordan for a negotiated Middle East settlement and to continue his exchanges with Egypt, but did not produce any new peace initiatives because of the fear that this might irrevocably split the organization.   The fact that most of the proceedings of the P.L.O.'s legislative council were carried live and in color by Jordanian television - which can be seen all over Israel - seemed to instill a palpable sense of pride among the local Arabs and gave them a view of the P.L.O. leadership that many of them had never had.

headline: Consumer Prices
abstract: To the Editor:     The references to a Consumer Price Index increase rate of 4 to 5 percent for 1984 (''Week in Business,'' Oct. 28) reflect the universal acceptance, against all evidence to the contrary, of the sanctified reliance on such official figures.    In fact, any heavy shopper has become aware that something has gone haywire in the computations that produced such a monstrous C.P.I. Hoax in 1984.

headline: Kohl Ends Visit to China
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany left Shanghai for Islamabad, Pakistan, today after a six-day visit to China.

headline: VIDEO SCREEN FOR DASHBOARD
abstract: COMPUTER technology in automobiles has come a long way, sparked by the need for fuel efficiency through precise engine controls. Those under-the-hood electronics are of interest primarily to engineers, but now the microchip is being pressed into service in new ways that are liable to excite even the sometime driver.   Specifically, the new technology involves video screens implanted in dashboards and hooked to the computers that control the car's audio, temperature and trip-monitoring systems. And Cary Wilson, a General Motors Corporation engineer, has 100 rolling examples of the car of the future.

headline: DENG WARNS OF 'ERUPTION' IN U.S.-CHINA TIES OVER TAIWAN
abstract: United States policy toward Taiwan could lead to an ''eruption'' in American-Chinese relations, China's leader, Deng Xiaoping, was quoted today as saying.    Japanese visitors said Mr. Deng added that he told Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger in Peking last year, ''Now China does not have the military force to invade and occupy Taiwan, but we have the military power to blockade'' the Strait of Formosa.   Mr. Deng also said for the first time that China had differences with its closest ally, North Korea.    Mr. Deng's reported statement on Taiwan broke a lull in anti-United States polemics on the issue and appeared to reflect Peking's impatience for movement toward reunification with the island. There was no suggestion in Mr. Deng's reported remarks that he was signaling a change in policy toward either Taiwan or North Korea.

headline: LENS HOLDS COMPANY'S FATE
abstract: The Staar Surgical Company, a two-year-old concern based in Monrovia, Calif., has a limited history, distinguished by modest sales and awesome losses. It faces heavy research expenses, and it is banking on a first- of-its-kind product that will not reach the market for another three years, if ever. The first six months this year, Staar lost $890,000 and had revenues of only $329,000.    ''At that rate of loss,'' said Ruth Alon, an analyst with Montgomery Securities in San Francisco, ''capital will be eliminated in two to three quarters, unless supplemented by some type of financing. The company is in a desperate cash situation.''

headline: SOME PRIESTS IN MOZAMBIQUE PUT MATERIAL MATTERS FIRST
abstract: ''I'm a materialist,'' said the Rev. Giuseppe Brunelli, walking his motorcycle along a bone-dry dirt path in the northern village of Boroma, where 50 people died of starvation earlier this year and food is again running out.    ''The Pope would excommunicate me as a liberation priest,'' he said, ''but I think the soul is very much attached to the body. Matter is sacred.''   Now that the Marxist-Leninist Government of President Samora M. Machel has considerably relaxed its pressure on the Roman Catholic Church, which was severe in the earlier years of independence, Father Brunelli is building a chapel, in addition to his main work of helping improve agricultural productivity.

headline: 5 Thrift Units Ordered Shut
abstract: Five Tennessee savings and loan associations were closed and their insured deposits transferred to a newly created institution, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced Friday.   All of the institutions were insolvent and had ''dissipated assets through violations of the law,'' the board said.

headline: Executives Join In Caressa Bid MIAMI, Oct. 15 (Reuters) -
abstract: Caressa Group Inc., which designs and makes women's footwear, said it had reached a   definitive agreement to be acquired by Footwear Holdings   Inc. for $15.75 a share, or a total   of about $72 million. Footwear will be owned by a   group of investors formed by   AEA Investors Inc. and by Caressa's co-chairmen, L. Donald   Taicher and Robert Taicher, as   well as other Caressa executives.

headline: A CHANGE IN SELLING ABROAD
abstract: After suffering all year from the strong dollar, which made their products more expensive abroad, exporters on Jan. 1 will lose one incentive program and gain another, less favorable one.    Responding to this change, thousands of exporters are racing abroad to establish Foreign Sales Corporations, or F.S.C.'s, which are the centerpiece of the new program. With such a corporation, the parent company pays up to 15 percent less tax on its exports.   Competition Abroad    The General Electric Company has already set up a Foreign Sales Corporation in the Virgin Islands, while the Boeing Company is setting one up in Guam. Other companies are still weighing the relative advantages of the dozen or so likely prospects for new export outposts.

headline: 2 RELIGIOUS PARTIES IN ISRAEL'S COALITION RESOLVE THEIR FIGHT
abstract: A dispute that threatened to break up Israel's three- month-old national unity Government was resolved early today.    The Cabinet crisis ended when two religious parties belonging to the governing coalition agreed on how state funds should be channeled to local authorities for religious functions.

headline: LOSSES AT ASARCO AND PHELPS DODGE
abstract: Asarco Inc., hurt by substantially lower prices for silver and copper, yesterday reported a loss of $10.1 million for the third quarter, reversing a profit of $2.9 million in the 1983 period.    The leading producer of silver, copper, lead, zinc and other nonferrous metals said sales dropped 25.7 percent, to $287.2 million, from $386.8 million.   Producer prices for silver averaged $7.43 an ounce in the third quarter, down sharply from $12.03 in the period a year earlier and $8.98 in the second quarter of 1984.

headline: Editors Group Bids India Drop Reporter Case
abstract: The Associated Press Managing Editors Association adopted a resolution today calling on the Government of India to ''cease all proceedings, under way and contemplated'' against an Associated Press correspondent.

headline: CHILE TOLERATES FEW VISITORS AT REMOTE CAMP FOR EXILES
abstract: The town of Pisagua 100 miles north of here is closed to most outsiders. The closest anyone can come to it without a pass permitting safe conduct is the aluminum ''control'' station perched on the sandy bluff above the remote fishing town in northern Chile.   Below the guard post, which sits in the middle of bald, softly sloping mountains, is the town where Chilean mothers threaten to send badly behaved children. The cove, surrounded on three sides by steep hills, and on the other by the Pacific Ocean, makes a perfect fortress or jail.

headline: AFRICAN, IN U.N., DEMANDS RIGHTS FOR THIRD WORLD
abstract: The leader of Bourkina Fasso, formerly Upper Volta, said in the General Assembly today that, while his country was part of what has been ''maliciously baptized'' as the third world, ''we won't be the world left behind by the West.''     In a fiery speech, the leader of the West African nation, Capt. Thomas Sankara, called on developing countries to maintain the struggle against foreign domination.    At the same time, he denounced ''development specialists in the third world who are sending us back to the world of slavery.''

headline: Advertising; Creative Troika At W.R.G.
abstract: speaking world, Wells, Rich, Greene has selected a Briton as its third creative director.    He is Dennis Barham, 46-year-old European creative director of the Leo Burnett Company and chairman of its London office.   Kenneth S. Olshan, chairman of W.R.G. Worldwide, and Charles Moss, vice chairman and corporate creative director of W.R.G., the parent company, characterized Mr. Barham as a man with a burning desire to become a part of the New York agency scene and to revel in the opportunities presented by the overabundance of our media.    Mr. Barham joins William M. Mullen and Nancy Vaughan, whose appointments were announced Nov. 12, to form the creative troika taking over the job from Mr. Moss, who has been creative czar for 16 years. Mr. Moss has not only presided over all of the advertising of what has become one of the best known creative agencies, but he has also been in charge of the hiring and training of all of the copywriters, art directors and commercial producers, whose output is the heart of the company.

headline: EX-NAZI, IN U.S. SINCE 1949, IS DEPORTED TO SOVIET UNION
abstract: Fyodor Fedorenko, a former Nazi death camp guard who had been living in the United States since 1949, was deported Friday night to the Soviet Union, ending seven years of litigation, the Justice Department announced yesterday.   The agency said he landed in Moscow yesterday morning New York time. He was the sixth person to leave the country in war crimes cases in recent months. The departure was by commercial flight through Europe, but no other details were made public.

headline: DUARTE IS FAULTED ON PLAN FOR TALKS
abstract: A leading Salvadoran rebel accused the Government today of violating ''the spirit of dialogue'' by failing to discuss proposals for a second round of peace talks with the rebels.    The rebel criticism came at a time when some rightist political leaders here have expressed increasing wariness of President Jose Napoleon Duarte's aims in meeting with leftist guerrillas.   The rebel leader, Hector Oqueli, said in a telephone interview that the rebels feared that Mr. Duarte intended to decide where and when the next round of talks would be held without consulting the guerrillas through intermediaries in the Roman Catholic Church.   Mr. Duarte said Wednesday that the talks would be held as planned in El Salvador before the end of the month. He added that details would be announced Sunday.

headline: Blast Kills Filipino Student
abstract: A student passer- by was killed and 11 other people were injured in an explosion at a militia outpost in the heart of this southern Philippines city tonight, the police said.

headline: OF BIRDS AND BERRIES: MOSCOW'S WINTER FORECAST
abstract: The first snow of the winter has fallen in Moscow, a month earlier than last year, but the old women on the city's park benches were not surprised.    As the small, dry flakes sifted down through yellow autumn leaves and children made the season's first snowballs, the old women talked of berries, mushrooms, nuts and the flight of birds and predicted that this winter would be worthy of Russia's legends.   But the sudden flurries seemed to have caught the rest of Moscow off guard, and few men in the streets had yet put on the fur hats that are the surest sign that winter has come. They seemed still to be waiting for that mysterious day when all Muscovites, like migrating birds responding to an unseen signal, dress for winter.

headline: TYPEWRITERS OF ELECTRONIC ERA
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation, which used to dominate the market for office typewriters with its ubiquitous Selectric line, has found itself losing ground since the arrival of electronic models.    Electronic typewriters come equipped with circuit boards, which contain a host of semiconductor chips, eliminating much of the machinery that drives manual and electric typewriters and providing advanced features such as memory capacity. Because electronic devices have fewer moving parts, they are generally considered more reliable than their electric counterparts.    After electronic typewriters were introduced in 1978, sales of electric models began to decline rapidly. At the peak of their popularity six years ago, 10 million electric machines were chattering away in American offices, according to Dataquest Inc., a San Jose, Calif., research concern. By the end of this year, the number of electric typewriters is expected to be down to seven million, with I.B.M. accounting for 70 percent of that.

headline: EQUITABLE LIFE WILL PURCHASE SECURITIES FIRM
abstract: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States announced yesterday that it would purchase Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., a leading Wall Street securities firm. The acquisition continues the blending of the stock brokerage, banking and insurance industries as these businesses seek their niches in a deregulated marketplace.   In recent years, the Prudential Life Insurance Company of America has bought the Bache Group Inc., a major stock brokerage firm; the American Express Company has diversified into securities, and many banks have begun      Gulf and Western said it would make a tender offer of $70 a share for Prentice-Hall stock. Page D1.

headline: More Eurobonds Carry Warrants
abstract: New offerings of corporate securities in the Eurobond market continue to be accompanied by warrants giving investors the option of buying additional bonds.    Investor demand for the bonds and warrants is brisk because of expecations that American interest rates will decline.

headline: An Indian Is Named Cape Town's Archbishop
abstract: Bishop Stephen Naidoo became the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Cape Town today.

headline: Unleaded Gas Trading Set
abstract: The New York Mercantile Exchange has scheduled trading in unleaded gasoline futures to begin today, joining contracts in heating oil, crude oil and leaded gasoline.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
abstract: Amerada Hess   $40,600,000   - 45.9

headline: TIRELESS FRIEND OF THE POOR
abstract: For Unicef's executive director, James P. Grant, the dramatic success of the organization's child survival program comes as the culmination of a lifetime spent in the service of the third world's poor.  But it also represents the continuation of a family tradition.  Since becoming Unicef director in 1980, Mr.  Grant has labored tirelessly on behalf of the simple but effective health care program that has saved the lives of so many children.  He has traveled around the globe, lobbying governments and drumming up private support for the program.

headline: Family's Move to Sell CFS Continental Stake
abstract: ''Since we went public in 1970, we haven't really considered this as a family company,'' said Philip Cohn, chairman and chief executive officer of CFS Continental Inc. ''But agreeing to sell our interests was nevertheless a tremendously emotional decision.''    On Monday, Mr. Cohn, his brother Alvin and other members of the family said they had agreed to sell the 1.5 million shares they hold in CFS - a diversified food service company their father, Jacob Cohn, founded in 1915 - to Dart & Kraft Inc. for $33 a share, or about $49.5 million.    Under the terms of the agreement, Dart & Kraft was given an option to buy an additional 1.6 million shares at the same price, which combined with the Cohn family shares would give Dart & Kraft a 36 percent stake in CFS. Dart & Kraft then intends to make a tender offer for the remaining shares. Acquiring the entire company at $33 a share would cost about $290 million.

headline: GRENADA INVASION:ROOTS OF PURPORTED AMERICAN SHORTCOMINGS ARE TRACED
abstract: A strong desire to avoid a hostage crisis like the one in Teheran affected planning and operations in the invasion of Grenada last year, according to an Army military analyst. It also contributed to what some critics believe were military shortcomings.  Some military analysts said a somewhat related desire to permit elements of a highly secret special operations group to show what it could do also left several major objectives of the Grenada operation unsecured for many hours.     On the other hand, even the harshest critics acknowledge that 595 American medical students were successfully evacuated from the Caribbean island without loss of life or serious injury, and that United States military casualties were light, even though some were caused by accidents and friendly fire.

headline: Reform Talk Worries Bond Dealers
abstract: While executives from securities firms were basking here in the warmth of prosperity brought by strong public demand for state and local government bonds, they were also looking nervously over their shoulders at a vast cloud of uncertainty called tax reform.     At the annual meeting here of the Public Securities Association, a trade group for nearly 300 securities concerns and banks that trade and sell bonds issued by the Federal and local governments, executives spoke often about the need to reduce Federal budget deficits. But they spoke just as often about the risks of attacking the deficit through tax reform.   Some tax reform proposals, they said, could disrupt the existing system in which local governments finance housing, roads, electric plants, schools and other projects through sales of bonds that pay interest that is exempt from the Federal income tax.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: AS EGYPT RE-EMERGES, SYRIA IS ISOLATED
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak's state visit to Jordan, which ended here today, was in effect an invitation to other Arab leaders to join Jordan in extending recognition to Egypt and, in the process, to form a new regional alliance.  Such an alliance would end a kind of vacuum in the Arab world caused by the isolation of Egypt - the most populous Arab nation and once the most influential - for the last five years because of President Anwar el-Sadat's signing of the Camp David accords with Israel.     Such an alliance would also put a new face on the divisions within the region by deepening the isolation of Syria, particularly in its support of Iran against Iraq in the Gulf war, which has entered its fifth year.    Jordan's leader, King Hussein, has made it clear recently that this is one of his key goals. The King is known to view Islamic fundamentalism as extremely dangerous and to fear that a victory by the Iranian forces of Ayotollah Ruhollah Khomeini would bring a cataclysm that could sweep current rulers from power.

headline: Killing Called Spontaneous
abstract: Ujagar Singh Bawa, general secretary of the Sikh Association of America, who teaches economics at Bloomsburg State College in Pennsylvania, said here today that the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India by two of her guards could have been a spontaneous ''act of personal revenge.'' He said that ''Sikhs have never perpetrated or condoned acts of terrorism or assassinations and this act of two individuals was completely unorchestrated and unrehearsed.''

headline: Turner Offer Grows in Size
abstract: The Turner Broadcasting System is offering 200,000 units of debentures, common stock and stock warrants at a price of 99 3/8 through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities. The offering was increased from 125,000 units.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Abbott Laboratories , North Chicago, said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 1 million shares of its common stock on the open market or in private transactions during the next 19 months. The company has about 120 million shares oustanding.

headline: Investor Group Ends Dorsey Bid
abstract: The Dorsey Corporation said it had bought 1,064,600 shares, or about 28.5 percent of its common shares outstanding, from an investor group for $33 a share plus $1 a share in related costs and expenses.    The company also said the group, consisting of Shamrock Associates, Hecco Ventures and Coniston Partners, had terminated its $35-a-share tender offer for 1,235,400 Dorsey shares.

headline: People
abstract: *  Joseph Dell Aquila elected a senior vice president of Doyle Dane Bernbach.

headline: Shultz to Visit Europe
abstract: Secretary of State Geroge P. Shultz will attend the autumn meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization Foreign Ministers in Brussels on Dec. 13 and 14, the State Department announced today.

headline: TRYING TO RECONCILE SECRECY AND COMPUTER USE IN RUSSIA
abstract: For anyone feeling threatened by the spread of little computers into businesses, schools and homes, there is still a sanctuary in the developed world where the abacus is king and floppy disks are badly manufactured phonograph records.    No young Russians sit glued to video screens chasing invaders from outer space, and none of their older brothers are busy at their personal computers finding ways to break into private mainframes.    The situation is one that may give comfort to the guardians of secrecy in the Kremlin. But it is one that is alarming members of the scientific and academic elite, who are saying that unless something is done to raise computer consciousness in the Soviet Union, the East-West gap in electronic technology will become unbridgeable.

headline: GUIDELINES THE GRADUATE COURSE
abstract: CERTAIN routes to easy money should make an investor wary. Take the case of Thomas C. Reed, a former national security adviser in the Reagan Administration. He turned a quick $431,000 profit on the $3,400 he invested in Amax Inc. after his father, a director of the mining company, told him the company was the object of a takeover . But Mr. Reed did not get to keep his profits for long. When the Securities and Exchange Commission complained that Mr. Reed had engaged in illegal inside trading, he relinquished the profits - and now faces Federal criminal charges of securities fraud, wire fraud, perjury and obstruction of justice.    Mr. Reed is not alone. A growing number of investors are being charged with illegal insider trading. They include not only such obvious targets as clerical employees of brokerage and investment houses or attorneys at the major law firms that handle takeovers, but also members of the Reagan Administration, such as Mr. Reed, and Paul Thayer, the former Deputy Secretary of Defense, who is facing charges of helping eight people make $1.9 million in stock-trading profits by illegally passing along inside information. And R. Foster Winans, a former Wall Street Journal reporter, is under indictment, accused of having leaked advanced information about coming stories.

headline: Sharp Criticism From Cuomo
abstract: Governor Cuomo yesterday sharply criticized the Treasury Department's proposal to disallow Federal deductions for the payment of state and local taxes.    The Governor sent a letter to President Reagan urging him to reject the proposals, part of the Treasury Departmant's tax plan.

headline: Norstar Acquisitions
abstract: Norstar Bancorp Inc., a $7.2 billion bank holding company, said today that it had bought Chapdelaine & Company, a government securities brokerage, and had completed the previously announced $9.2 million acquisition of the Bank of Long Island.

headline: KOHL DENIES BONN CLAIMS LOST EASTERN TERRITORIES
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl today used the visit by Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania to rebut Soviet accusations that West Germany claimed former German territories in Easern Europe.   At a lunch in honor of Mr. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, who is a First Deputy Prime Minister, Mr. Kohl called the Soviet contention ''nonsensical, unjustified and unfounded.''

headline: 4TH-QUARTER G.N.P. RISE PUT AT 2.8%
abstract: The economy is expanding at a 2.8 percent annual rate in the current quarter, somewhat faster than most analysts have been expecting, the Commerce Department's ''flash'' estimate of gross national product showed today.    The rise is less than robust and far below the booming gains of the first half of the year. Nonetheless, it and the reported 2.9 percent inflation rate were the latest of several mostly favorable economic reports in recent days and represented what now seems fairly conclusive evidence that the earlier abrupt slowdown is not developing into a recession.    ''This is basically a good package of numbers,'' said Robert Ortner, the department's chief economist. ''The worst of the slowdown may very well be behind us.''

headline: Scott & Fetzer Backs Kelso Bid
abstract: The Scott & Fetzer Company said it had approved Kelso & Company's offer to acquire the company for $62 a share, or about $411 million.

headline: BRITISH TELECOM SHARES SOAR
abstract: Records were smashed in hectic dealing and recriminations sounded in the House of Commons as British Telecom shares began trading here today at a 90 percent markup on their sale price.   ''It was pandemonium, both on the Stock Exchange floor and in the dealing rooms around the City,'' said Jack Summerscale, a partner at de Zoete & Bevan, one of the four large stock brokerage firms that have been sponsors of the $4.7 billion share sale. ''The price is higher than what even the super-bulls were expecting.''

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Cipher Data Products Inc., a San Diego-based designer and maker of magnetic tape peripherals, said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire closely held Spectra Logic Corp. of Mountainview, Calif., for an undisclosed number of shares of Cipher's common stock.     *  CGA Computer Inc., Holmdel, N.J., said shareholders had approved a $43.5 million leveraged buyout by members of CGA's senior management and General Atlantic Corp., a private investment company.

headline: Burlington Signs Pacts to Haul Coal
abstract: The Burlington Northern and Western Fuels Association, a supplier of coal to rural cooperatives and municipal utilities, have signed four coal transportation contracts, each for 20 years.

headline: U.S. ECONOMY GREW AT LOW 2.7% RATE IN THIRD QUARTER
abstract: The nation's economy grew at a surprisingly slow annual rate of 2.7 percent from July through September, the Commerce Department reported today.   Growth of the gross national product, the most comprehensive gauge of the economy's performance, was substantially weaker int he third quarter than the 3.6 percent annual rate that the Government first estimated last month. The pace was also sharply below the 10.1 percent rate of growth inthe first quarter and the 7.1 percent in the second.  Moreover, it was the slowest rate since the first months of 1983, when the recovery started accelerating.

headline: EUROPE'S PLACE IN NATO
abstract: A year ago some of the West European members of NATO, rattled by the problem of winning public opinion to the deployment in Europe of new American nuclear missiles, began talking about a way to put a more visible European stamp on Western security policy.  The discussion fell under the catchword ''Europeanization,'' and it largely involved a plan to revivify the Western Europe Union, a little-used intergovernmental defense policy agency.     The goal, beyond the officially stated desire to strengthen the European pillar of the Atlantic alliance, was to take a little distance from the Reagan Administration and from what was widely regarded as its overly confrontational style of dealing with the Soviet Union.   Last weekend, plans for reorganizing the W.E.U. were announced by the foreign and defense ministers of the seven participating countries, who met here without the United States. But the program was discreet, and the put-the- Americans-at-arms-length undertone virtually gone. In the space of a year, it appeared, a central concern of the Europeans had become keeping the United States close at hand.

headline: Lybrand, S.E.C. Settle
abstract: Coopers & Lybrand and M. Bruce Cohen, a partner in the accounting firm's Philadelphia office, have settled a disciplinary proceeding brought against them by the Securities and Exchange Commission in July, the commission announced today. The firm had been accused of ''unethical or improper professional conduct'' in audits of Digilog Inc., a computer company based in Montgomeryville, Pa.

headline: TEHERAN REPORTS ITS MEN TAKE JET AND FREE CAPTIVES
abstract: Iranian security men stormed the hijacked Kuwaiti airliner at the Teheran airport shortly before midnight Sunday and freed the last nine hostages, the Iranian press agency reported. The four Arabic-speaking hijackers surrendered, the agency said.     The hijackers had planted explosives near the fuel tanks and appeared ready to blow up the plane, destroying themselves and their hostages, according to a group of seven passengers freed about three hours earlier.    (In Washington, State Department officials said they were receiving some diplomatic reports that tended to confirm the account made public by the Iranian press agency.)

headline: SYRIANS REPORTED TO ASK IRANIANS TO SOFTEN POLICIES AND END WAR
abstract: Syria is seeking to persuade Iran to moderate its policies on a number of Middle East issues and to prevail upon its followers in the region to do the same, according to Arab diplomats and some press reports here.     The Arab diplomats said President Hafez al-Assad is seeking Iranian cooperation to end the four-year war with Iraq and improve relations between Iran and France. He is also believed to be seeking Iran's support for the troop withdrawal negotiations between Lebanon and Israel that resumed last week.

headline: No Headline
abstract: A Founder Returns As Chief of Eagle      The financially troubled Eagle Computer Company said yesterday that Gary L. Kappenman, who last June left the company he helped found and served as vice president, was returning as president and chief executive. The appointment is effective Nov. 5, Eagle said.    Mr. Kappenman, who is 39 years old, succeeds Ronald N. Mickwee, also 39. Mr. Mickwee will remain as chairman, however, a post he assumed last July, replacing Mr. Kappenman's brother, Charles.

headline: Addendum
abstract: * Friedberg-Feder, a new health- care ad agency at 10 East 39th Street.

headline: DRAWING UP A FINANCIAL BLUEPRINT
abstract: THOSE who can send their children to the best colleges or retire in luxury are not necessarily corporate chieftains or lottery winners. Many have simply invested wisely and consistently. ''People who just save whatever is left over,'' David Bugen, a financial planner in Morristown, N.J., said. ''usually have too much month at the end of their money.''   The problem, of course, is determining how much money to save each month and then how to put it to work. In deciding how much to save, many people rely on the rule of thumb that they should set aside 10 percent - if not more - of their pay before taxes. ''If people could diligently set aside 20 percent, they'd be making some headway,'' Mark Bass, a financial planner in Lubbock, Tex., said. ''But in real life, there are very few people that can meet that, unless they're extremely disciplined.''    But rules of thumb are not always ideal, because they do not account for differing needs and desires. Planners, therefore, strongly recommend that people sit down and calculate exactly when their children will be in college and what their education is likely to cost, as well as when they plan to retire and how high they expect their monthly expenses to run. On the incoming side of the ledger, pension plan payouts and inheritances can also be estimated.

headline: U.S. AND RUSSIANS AGREE TO RESUME ARMAMENTS TALKS
abstract: The United States and the Soviet Union announced today that Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko would meet in Geneva Jan. 7 and 8 to negotiate an agenda for talks on limiting nuclear arms.    The White House said the agenda would be for future talks on ''the whole range of questions concerning nuclear and outer space arms.''    Robert C. McFarlane, President Reagan's national security adviser, said at a news conference that the preliminary talks between Mr. Gromyko and Mr. Shultz had been agreed to without conditions.    'Ready to Discuss All Issues'      ''We are open and ready to discuss all issues,'' Mr. McFarlane said. ''We're at a moment where each side has decided to make a determined effort to reduce tensions.''

headline: GM 'FACTORY OF FUTURE' WILL RUN WITH ROBOTS
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said today that it planned to invest $52 million in what it calls a ''factory of the future'' - an automated, highly flexible manufacturing complex that can operate for an eight-hour shift without any human production workers.    The new operation, to be housed in an existing building at the Saginaw Steering Gear division, will be in partial operation by next fall, officials said. Because the technology is so new, G.M. said, the plant will not be in full production until late 1987.

headline: Jakarta's Trade Surplus
abstract: Indonesia had a trade surplus of $720 million in August with exports of $1.82 billion and imports of $1.1 billion, the Government said today. The August 1983 surplus was $950 million.

headline: SHAD ASKS TIGHTENING BY NASDAQ AND AMEX
abstract: The National Association of Securities Dealers and the American Stock Exchange have been asked by the head of the Securities and Exchange Commission to consider raising the standards for companies whose stock trading they supervise, Gordon S. Macklin, the association's president, and Arthur Levitt Jr., the exchange's chairman, said yesterday.   The idea - suggested by John S. R. Shad, the commission's chairman - is meant to ease pressure on the New York Stock Exchange. The Big Board has been considering a lowering of its standards to meet increased competition for company listings, in particular from the Nasdaq over-the-counter market run by the securities dealers' association.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Nov. 27, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: HONDA DEALERS SIGN WITH NEEDHAM HARPER
abstract: Needham Harper Worldwide's New York office has been tapped to do advertising for the Tri-State Honda Dealers of Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware and also for the Greater Pittsburgh Honda Dealers.    Only the Pittsburgh gang had a previous agency, the Robert L. Stevenson agency.    Needham estimates that total billings should be between $2.5 million and $3 million.

headline: A BIG TEXTRON BID BY CHICAGO PACIFIC
abstract: Flush with cash only four months after emerging from the reorganization of the bankrupt Rock Island Railroad, the little- known Chicago Pacific Corporation offered yesterday to pay $43 a share in cash, or about $1.6 billion, for Textron Inc., the Rhode Island-based industrial giant known for such products as Bell helicopters, Homelite chain saws, Bostitch staplers and Jacobsen lawn mowers.     The new Chicago company said that it had some $200 million after paying off creditors and had received ''reasonable assurance'' from Citibank that it could obtain commitments to finance the deal.    Robert P. Straetz, chairman and chief executive of Textron, said the offer was ''unsolicited,'' had been made without consultation and was ''completely unacceptable.'' Mr. Straetz said shareholders, employees and customers would be ''better served'' if Textron remained independent.    Asked what the company would do in view of Textron's apparent rejection, a spokesman for Chicago Pacific said he could not comment.

headline: INDIA HOLDS SECURITY AIDE TO INDIRA GANDHI IN CONSPIRACY INQUIRY
abstract: Officials investigating the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi have arrested a member of her security team and interrogated several of her bodyguards in what the prosecutor today called ''a criminal conspiracy.''   Magistrate O. P. Gogne rejected an application for bail today from the arrested man, Jagtar Singh, a Sikh who was a member of the Prime Minister's inner security ring. His arrest on Oct. 31, the day Mrs. Gandhi was assassinated, had not been disclosed previously.

headline: U.N. CHIEF TO HEAR WOMEN'S JOB COMPLAINTS
abstract: The Secretary General of the United Nations is scheduled to meet again Monday with representatives of a women's rights group in an attempt to end practices that many women employed here say are discriminatory and undermine the organization's commitment to job equality.   Last Tuesday, according to a spokesman for the Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, the women presented a list of grievances including what they described as pay inequities and the un derrepresentation of women in professional positions. The members of the Ad Hoc Group on Equal Rights for Women also reminded Mr. Perez de Cuellar of his promise to appoint a high-level coordinator for women's affairs.    Six years after the passage of a General Assembly resolution mandating that 25 percent of professional posts in the United Nations be filled by women, the target has not been reached. Women now hold 22.6 percent of the professional posts, up four-tenths of 1 percent in the last two years. They comprise over 50 percent of the entire staff.

headline: Reagan and Thatcher To Meet in December
abstract: President Reagan will confer with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher at the Camp David retreat in Maryland on Dec. 22.   Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said Mrs. Thatcher would pass through the United States after visits to Peking and Hong Kong.   He said the agenda would include East-West relations, Mr. Reagan's hopes for talks with the Soviet Union, prospects for renewed arms control talks and the economic summit meeting to be held in Bonn in May.

headline: VOTERS IN SINGAPORE GIVE PARTY IN POWER A SWEEPING VICTORY
abstract: The People's Action Party of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew won a sweeping victory in parliamentary elections today.    Mr. Lee's party emerged with all but 2 of the 79 seats in Parliament.   That was an improvement for opposition candidates. In the last four general elections, in 1980, 1976, 1972 and 1968, the People's Action Party won all the seats at stake.

headline: Knight-Ridder
abstract: -Ridder Newspapers Inc. has sold its interest in cellular telephone license applications pending before the Federal Communications Commission after the Government decided to award them through a lottery.

headline: PHONE LINE RATE BID REJECTED
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission today ordered local telephone companies to scale back their proposed increases in access charges that long- distance companies pay for private lines used by businesses and government agencies.   The additional charges presumably would be passed on to the users. Private lines, which are used for data processing as well as for ordinary voice telephone service, typically link distant offices of a single customer.

headline: Afghan Diplomat Says French Reporter Is Free
abstract: The Afghan charge d'affaires, Abdullah Keshmand, said here today that Jacques Abouchar, a French television reporter, was released from prison today and was free to return home.

headline: BHOPAL'S DOCTORS GIVEN HIGH PRAISE
abstract: In the fateful early morning hours of Dec. 3, as clouds of toxic gas began to escape from the Union Carbide pesticide plant here, the medical community of Bho pal faced an emergency of staggering proportions.    Tens of thousands of patients began streaming into hospitals of the area, hysterical, rubbing their eyes in pain and gasping for breath. Many doctors themselves were choking and shedding profuse tears because of the fumes.   The superintendent of Hamidia Hospital, the largest and closest to the scene of the leak, was coughing so badly he could not take telephone calls for a critical half hour at the start of the crisis.    Yet somehow, starting from chaos in the dark of night, the medical system here managed to cope, and cope very well.

headline: Acid Rain
abstract: To the Editor:   I was glad to see the exchange of views on acid rain (''The Battle Over Acid Rain Legislation,'' Oct. 28). On the one hand, Carl E. Bagge, president of the National Coal Association, says we shouldn't pass a law until we've satisfied all doubts about several lingering uncertainties. Congressman Henry A. Waxman says we know enough about the problem to do something about it now. On this question, I side with Mr. Waxman.

headline: Jordan, Case Acquires Bloom & Gelb Agency
abstract: Jordan, Case & McGrath has acquired the Bloom & Gelb direct-response ad agency and is so excited about it that it will announce the fact in an ad in The New York Times and segments of the advertising trade press.    Since the agency's managers are far from profligate spenders they will also use the ad to promote a little business by including a coupon that might collar prospects.

headline: Czech Fire Kills 26, Hurts 2
abstract: A fire killed 26 residents of a home for the disabled in the town of Medenec in northwestern Czechoslovakia, the Communist Party newspaper Rude Pravo reported today. Two people were injured in the blaze, which struck ''at the end of last week during the night,'' Rude Pravo said.

headline: Insider Reports
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.   The report of changes follows:  NEW YORK EXCHANGE      AMERICAN STANDARD INC.

headline: American Express Credit's Notes
abstract: The American Express Credit Corporation offered $100 million worth of five-year notes.    The notes, which mature on Jan. 15, 1990, were offered with a coupon of 11 1/8 percent at 99.80 to yield 11.17 percent.   Investment bankers from Lehman Brothers led the underwriting, which carries a rating of A-plus from McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei; AA-2 from Moody's, and AA from Standard & Poor's.

headline: INNUENDO GOES ON DISPITE SOVIET PREMIER'S DENIAL
abstract: The Communist Party daily Pravda repeated assertions today that ''external forces'' - by implication the United States - were involved in the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.   The article by a Pravda commentator, Vsevolod Ovchinnikov, followed by one day a meeting between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the Soviet Prime Minister, Nikolai A. Tikhonov, in which Mr. Shultz complained about suggestions in the Soviet press of American involvement in the slaying.   ''When a political assassination is committed, the question of who benefits from it naturally emerges,'' the commentary said. ''Prominent Indian political and public figures are unanimous that external forces hostile to India are, if not directly, then indirectly, involved in the crime.''

headline: Marines Switch Recruiting Theme Line
abstract: The other news from J. Walter Thompson yesterday was that its longtime client, the Marine Corps, is changing the theme line on its recruiting advertising back to ''We're looking for a few good men,'' after an eight-year absence.   It will replace ''The few.

headline: NICARAGUAN PAPER IS SILENCED
abstract: The opposition newspaper La Prensa did not appear Monday after 10 articles it planned to publish were censored by the Government.    Six of the articles concerned the announcement by an opposition presidential candidate, Virgilio Godoy Reyes, that he and his Independent Liberal Party were quitting the election campaign.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct. 29, 1984:  MONDAY Airborne FreightGeorgia-PacificArmstrong World IndKentucky UtilsBrown & SharpeKoppers CoBurndy CorpUnion CampFoster Wheeler   TUESDAY Amer BrandsPalm BeachBorden IncPneumo CorpBucyrus-ErieTenneco IncDenny's IncTexas-New MexicoDuke PowerWarner LambertMcDonald InvestWendy's Intl  WEDNESDAY Amer Business PrdtsLee EnterprisesBethlehem SteelMissouri Pub SvcCelanese CorpPapercraft CorpChevron CorpPublic Serv IndExxon CorpSCOA IndusFreeport-McMoranScientific-AtlantaGrainger (WW) IncTRW IncGt Northn NekoosaUnifirst Corp Hercules IncWestinghouse ElecLafarge CorpZero Corp  THURSDAY   Ahmanson (HF) & CoNabisco BrandsAmer StandardRanco IncAvon PrdtsRexnord IncChemed CorpRobins (AH) CoCleve-Cliffs IronStandard Brands PaintCoastal CorpStride RiteDart & KraftTaft BrdcstgMontana-Dak UtilWyle Labs  FRIDAY Florida SteelSterling DrugMorrison-KnudsenWash Water PwrOakite Products

headline: BRAZIL'S RULERS AWAIT DEFEAT IN VOTE
abstract: Five weeks before Brazil's indirect presidential election, the departing military Government seems to have accepted the anticipated defeat of its candidate and has begun working to insure a smooth transition to opposition civilian rule.    Although the opposition candidate, Tancredo Neves, has long been favored to win the vote Jan. 15 in the Electoral College, there had been speculation that the Government might alter the succession rules in a last-minute effort to gain an official victory.   But over the last three weeks, the Government of President Joao Baptista Figueiredo has seemingly abandoned the Democratic Social Party's candidate, Paulo Salim Maluf, with leading officials now openly referring to his defeat as unavoidable.   The Supreme Electoral Tribunal has also blocked moves to require Electoral College delegates to vote along party lines. The ruling party held a 36- seat majority in the Electoral College, but a large group of its congressmen who opposed Mr. Maluf's candidacy will be permitted to support Mr. Neves.

headline: Continental Group To Sell Florida Gas
abstract: The Houston Natural Gas Corporation of Texas said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Florida Gas Transmission Company and its 4,300- mile natural gas system from the Continental Group for about $800 million. Florida Gas is the only natural gas supplier in most of the state.

headline: RESHAPING O.E.C.D.'S OIL-SHARING PLAN
abstract: Energy policy makers are currently enjoying seemingly comfortable    times. The world oil glut persists, prices are falling and the once- mighty Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has been humbled - compelled again last week to cut its production in an effort to keep prices stable. And even if another oil crisis breaks out, government officials seem convinced that the International Energy Program - a plan to share oil among the industrialized countries - will cushion any economic hardship.   Such confidence is misplaced. In the event of an oil crisis, the oil sharing plan as it stands would exacerbate the international economic disruption. For the United States, adhering to the program would result in higher oil prices and lower real income.  And it would take no more than a successful attempt by Iraq or Iran to disrupt the flow of Persian Gulf oil to bring the program into operation.

headline: Insider Reports
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange issued this week its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.   The report of changes follows:  NEW YORK EXCHANGE      AMCA INTERNATIONAL LTD.

headline: Treasury Bill Rates Ease
abstract: Interest rates on Treasury bills fell more than a tenth of a percentage point yesterday, as prices rose on speculation that the Federal Reserve will foster lower interest rates in the future.     Three-month Treasury bills were traded at a rate of less than 9 percent for the first time since early February.    But in the note and bond market, hopes that the Federal Reserve will encourage lower interest rates were not enough to offset the effects of a heavy supply of new Treasury issues and waning investor demand.    ''There was not much follow- through buying after the big run-up this week,'' one Treasury note trader said, referring to gains of about 1 1/2 points in bond prices during the first two days of the week. ''But,'' he added, ''there was not much selling either.''

headline: BRIEFS ;  Common Stock
abstract: Bolar Pharmaceutical Co.  filed for an offering of 500,000 shares, through Lehman Brothers.     *  Cannon Group Inc.  is offering 70,000 units at $1,000 a unit, through E. F. Hutton & Co.     *  Crescent Silver Mines said it filed a registration statement relating to an initial public offering of 2 million shares between $6 and $7 a share, through Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.     *  Duquesne Light Co.  filed for an offering of 2,250,000 shares, through First Boston Corp.     *  Math Box Inc.  is offering 750,000 shares at $8.75 a share, through Blunt Ellis & Loewi Inc.      Debt Issues    *  Bank of Tokyo, Cura,cao, N.A., is issuing $100 million of 12 5/8 percent seven- year Eurobonds at par, with warrants to buy a similar 12 3/8 percent bond, through Tokyo International Ltd.

headline: Market Place ; Arco as Proxy For Oil Stocks
abstract: Money managers, individuals and securities analysts spend endless hours trying to fathom the potentials and pitfalls of energy stocks. But Joseph A. Feshbach, chief technical analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities, has discovered a quick way for assessing investment opportunities in the oils.    ''Over the past two years, energy stocks have proven to be excellent trading vehicles,'' he said. ''Atlantic Richfield is my key surrogate for this group, because it has been in a very definable base for this two-year period.''

headline: Oil Pricing
abstract: To the Editor:   Messrs. Salant and Smith in their article ''Reshaping O.E.C.D.'s Oil- Sharing Plan'' (Forum, Nov. 4, ) maintain that the Reagan Administration should work with the International Energy Agency in setting the price of emergency oil transactions at spot market levels.

headline: Stock Prices Weaken; Dow Off 3.20
abstract: Stock prices weakened yesterday in the slowest trading this month after advancing in the preceding two sessions.    The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow price range throughout the day, closed off 3.20 points, to 1,175.13. In the general market, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored those that rose by 806 to 676.

headline: COMPUTER DOWN ON THE FARM
abstract: Dave and Cheryl Kalsem, who farm 540 acres of corn, and move 1,000 head of cattle annually through their feedlot operation in central Iowa, got an International Business Machines Personal Computer this spring. They thus joined a select group of Iowa farmers who are test-marketing a computer service being developed by Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc., the nation's leading seed company.    Pioneer, based in Des Moines, plans to introduce its Farm Information Management System early next year. The company got into the business, according to Thomas N. Urban, Pioneer's president and chairman, as a result of its extensive use of computers in seed development.

headline: South African Troops Break Up 3 Black Groups
abstract: Soldiers and policemen who moved into black townships south of Johannesburg today broke up three separate crowds of youths who were boycotting their segregated schools, the police said.   A police spokesman, Lieut.

headline: STORAGE TECHNOLOGY LOSES LOAN
abstract: The Storage Technology Corporation, which filed for protection from its creditors under the Federal Bankruptcy Act on Oct. 31, said yesterday that it had lost a commitment for a $150 million loan from the Chemical Bank.     Analysts said the loss of the commitment immediately reduced the company's chances of emerging from bankruptcy as a viable business.    Their first question, however, was whether Storage Technology, once one of America's leading makers of data-storage devices for large computers, would have to shut down at once. The company's credit has been cut off by many suppliers, and experts expressed fear that it might not be able to meet its 14,500-employee payroll next Friday.

headline: Executive at Manville Promoted to President
abstract: John A. McKinney, who has been acting as chief executive, chairman and president of the Manville Corporation, yesterday announced that the president's position will be taken over on Dec. 1 by J.T. Hulce, a 42-year-old lawyer who has been one of the company's senior vice presidents for the last two years.    Mr. Hulce, who is known as Josh, will oversee the company's production, marketing, sales and staff functions.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1984   Companies    Caterpillar Tractor said it would cut its dividend , freeze hiring, accelerate plant closings and pare manufacturing capacity. The company, one of the world's largest makers of heavy equipment, linked the cost-cutting efforts to increased competition, the industry's overcapacity and high interest rates. Caterpillar also predicted a loss for the fourth quarter; it had earlier forecast losses for the third quarter and full year. (Page D1.)    The Government will drop some charges against a former reporter for The Wall Street Journal. The charges were based on the novel legal theory that the reporter breached his duty to his readers by failing to disclose that he traded in the securities about which he wrote. The reporter and two others, however, still face Federal charges of securities fraud and conspiracy. (D1.)

headline: U.S. PRAISES TONE OF SOVIET LEADER
abstract: The White House said today that it welcomed ''the constructive tone'' of Konstantin U. Chernenko's remarks in an interview Tuesday on the possibiity of improved Soviet-American relations. But it rejected the Soviet leader's contention that the Administration was to blame for the lack of progress in arms control.   In a statement to The Washington Post that was also published by the Soviet press agency Tass, Mr. Chernenko repeated a seven-month-old list of Soviet proposals. He said acceptance of them, in full or part, ''would mean a real shift both in Soviet-U.S. relations and in the international situation as a whole.'' The previous reaction of the Administration, he said, ''was simply to shirk responding to our proposals.''

headline: AFRICANS DIFFER ON OTHER SEAT
abstract: The General Assembly named four new members to the Security Council today but was deadlocked over a fifth seat.    The four nations named to the 15- member body were Australia and Denmark, replacing the Netherlands and Malta; Trinidad and Tobago in place of Nicaragua, and Thailand for Pakistan.   An impasse developed over a replacement for Zimbabwe, however, when the African bloc was unable to agree on a candidate. After several ballots, Ethiopia, a Soviet ally, had 83 votes and Somalia had 72, both short of the two-thirds required.

headline: REAGAN FOREIGN POLICY: SHIFTING AIM
abstract: From the beginning, President Reagan's national security policy has been to talk loudly, act cautiously and construct a big economic and military stick.     Building that stick was the overwhelming priority. The goal of Administration officials, as they acknowledged all along, was to get that internal process well under way before turning to the external diplomatic goals. To them, that was the only way to provide the strength to stem what they saw as the tide of Soviet power.    To Administration critics, Mr. Reagan has built a house of cards - on tough rhetoric, an untried and extravagantly expensive military and an economy that could quickly turn sour.

headline: STAMFORD PROJECT: THREE OFFICE BUILDINGS AND A HOTEL
abstract: The office construction boom in Stamford, Conn., took off early in the 1970's when the F. D. Rich Company put up One Landmark Square, a 22- story tower in the heart of the city. Other builders followed, taking sites downtown in the vicinity of Atlantic and Broad Streets, along Summer Avenue and on Tresser Boulevard. Together, they created eight million square feet of office space.   Then, just when it seemed that most development parcels had been taken and the 15-year-old surge of growth in this former industrial town had peaked, a new team broke new ground by jumping to the south side of the Connecticut Turnpike (I-95), the unofficial boundary of downtown Stamford. With the exception of Harbor Plaza, a 500-square-foot office park on Long Island Sound, all of the downtown development had been confined to the north side of I-95.

headline: ANALYSTS CITE OPEC SPLIT ON SHIFT IN PRICING
abstract: The failure of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to reach a unanimous agreement on a crucial pricing arrangement will probably mean a further decline in world oil prices in the face of shrinking demand, analysts said today.    Eleven OPEC countries committed themselves late Saturday night to the pricing agreement, which is intended to narrow the gap between the official prices for OPEC's heavy crude and lighter grades of oil. But as the ministers boarded planes in Geneva today to return to their home countries, few seemed in a hurry to implement the controversial agreement, which is to take effect Wednesday.    Two of the organization's major members, Nigeria and Algeria, broke ranks with their partners and refused to sign the agreement.

headline: ECONOMIC GROWTH FELL TO 1.9% RATE IN THIRD QUARTER
abstract: Economic growth slumped to a 1.9 percent annual rate in the July-September quarter, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the poorest performance since the current expansion began in late 1982.   The revised calculation of the gross national product - the nation's total output of goods and services - was significantly lower than the 2.7 percent estimated a month ago and confirmed the view of an growing number of analysts that the country may already be in a ''growth recession.''    Such a recession is characterized not by an actual decline in output but by growth so skimpy that the economy cannot absorb increases in the labor force, and by a consequent rise in unemployment.

headline: SPAIN'S SOCIALISTS RATIFY NATO ROLE
abstract: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, after a tough fight, won approval from his governing Socialist Party tonight to keep Spain in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.    Delegates to the party's national convention voted several times, each time roughly by a 2-to-1 margin, against proposals for withdrawal from NATO. The votes cleared a crucial hurdle in attempts by the Government and NATO nations to keep Spain in the alliance and confirmed Mr. Gonzalez's party leadership.    The convention, approving a platform to guide the Government for the next two years, also backed the Government's policy of maintaining a continued but reduced American military presence in Spain. The party's left wing had proposed closing American bases.

headline: Food Lion in Bid
abstract: Food Lion Inc. said it had agreed to acquire Giant Food Markets Inc. Terms were not disclosed. Giant operates 25 supermarkets and 23 convience stores in eastern Tennessee and has annual sales of about $130 million. Food Lion, which operates a chain of 248 supermarkets in North Carolina, South Carolina, Virginia, Georgia, Tennessee and Maryland, said the transaction is scheduled for completion on Dec. 31.

headline: Ex-Braniff Executive Returns to Help Airline
abstract: Financially troubled Braniff Inc. said yesterday that Ron Ridgeway, who left the airline last year, is returning to take the post of president, effective immediately.    Mr. Ridgeway, who is 38, succeeds William D. Slattery, 41, who resigned last week after less than a year on the job to become president of Air Via, a carrier based in San Jose, Calif.   In making yesterday's announcement, Patrick Foley, Braniff's vice chairman, made much of Mr. Ridgeway's past association with the airline, saying that it ''should be an enormous asset in leading the company in its new direction.''

headline: Marcos Daughter Calls The Palace a 'Snake Pit'
abstract: A daughter of President Ferdinand E. Marcos who represents her family's district in the National Assembly today called the presidential palace ''a snake pit'' and said abuses had been committed by people close to her family.   But Imee Marcos Manotoc, 29 years old, said it was difficult for her father to end the abuses, saying, ''It is not easy to fire all these people.''

headline: Chile Forces 21 Exiles Back into Argentina
abstract: The Chilean police forced 21 exiles back into Argentina after they tried to enter Chile, a spokesman for the exiles said today.

headline: Morse Shoes
abstract: Morse Shoe Inc. said its agreement to operate 180 shoe departments in Wal-Mart Stores will not be renewed when it expires on Feb. 1, 1987. Wal- Mart plans to take over shoe operations in half the stores in 1986, and the rest on the expiration date, Morse said. The current arrangement accounted for about 7 percent of Morse's 1983 sales of $523 million.

headline: GENERAL DYNAMICS' NAVY CONTRACT UNDER ATTACK
abstract: The chairman of a House committee has demanded that the Navy take control of two General Dynamics Corporation shipyards because the company gave gifts to Adm. Hyman G. Rickover in 1977 when he was head of the Navy's nuclear submarine program.     In a letter to Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr., made public today, Representative John D. Dingell called for ''immediate termination'' of General Dynamics' contracts for the Trident ballistic missile submarine and the 688-class attack submarine, the ''smooth transfer'' of management of the shipyards to the Navy or a new contractor and a ban on new Navy contracts for General Dynamics. The yards of the company's Electric Boat division are at Groton, Conn., and Quonset Point, R.I.

headline: SEPTEMBER FACTORY ORDERS FELL
abstract: New orders to factories for manufactured goods tumbled 1.8 percent in September, the second monthly decline in a row, the Government reported today.   The Commerce Department said orders for manufactured goods declined $3.6 billion last month from their August level, to a seasonally adjusted total of $189 billion. Orders were off eight-tenths of 1 percent in August after rising 1.8 percent in July.

headline: ADVERTISING ; ; Lewis, Gilman & Kynett Elects Unit President
abstract: John K. Kaiser, 41-year-old Detroit native, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the advertising division of Lewis, Gilman & Kynett, Philadelphia's largest ad agency.

headline: THE DREAMER BEHIND ECUMED IDEA
abstract: The people who beat the drum for Ecumed are hardly shy about dropping the names of its blue-ribbon board, some of the leading lights in health care. One name that gets lost, though, is Robert Weneck.    Mr. Weneck is a cherubic-faced man given to dreaming. When he was growing up in Kansas City, Mo., his father used to complain: ''Stop dreaming. You don't make money by dreaming.''

headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS ; Copper Sharply Higher In Very Active Session
abstract: Copper futures advanced sharply amid heavy trading today on the Commodity Exchange in New York, while gold and silver futures posted modest gains.   Analysts attributed the gain to expectations that physical demand for copper is increasing and to heavy buying by the large Chicago-based trader, C&D Commodities.

headline: CORESTATES FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RELIEF OFFICIAL ACCUSES ETHIOPIA OF 'BITING THE HAND' THAT FEEDS IT
abstract: The head of the United States food relief program said today that Ethiopia was ''biting the hand'' that feeds it by blaming Western nations for the extent of the famine devastating it.    The official, M. Peter McPherson, head of the Agency for International Development, was asked at a news conference to respond to charges made Tuesday in Addis Ababa by Dawit Wolde Giorgis, head of Ethiopia's Relief and Rehabilitation Commission, and he said: ''We reject them. It is absurd.''   In his news conference and in a speech earlier in the day before the United States Chamber of Commerce, Mr. McPherson defended the American relief effort, calling it the largest in the world, and criticized Ethiopia's handling of famine relief.

headline: Lord & Taylor Keeping Chief Joseph E. Brooks, chairman
abstract: Lord & Taylor, has renewed his   employment contract for five   years, according to the Associated Dry Goods Corporation,   which owns the 40-store chain.   Recent trade reports had indicated he planned to leave Lord   & Taylor at the end of 1985. Joseph H. Johnson, Associated's chairman and chief executive officer, confirmed the renewal and added, ''Mr. Brooks   and I get along just fine.'' Mr. Brooks, 56 years old, said   the new contract had an option   ''allowing me to retire after   1985 should I choose to do so.''

headline: Japan Output Up in Month
abstract: Japan's industrial output and car exports climbed in November, but steel shipments fell, the latter due to United States-Japan talks on voluntary restraints for steel exports, the Government and industry groups said today.   The Ministry of Trade and Industry said, in a preliminary report, that production at Japan's factories and mines rose 10.8 percent in November from a year earlier, down from a revised 12 percent year-to-year gain in October.

headline: WEST GERMANY WARNS IT MAY LEAVE UNESCO
abstract: Foreign Ministry officials said today that the Government had told Unesco that West Germany might withdraw from the United Nations agency if changes were not made.   They said Foreign Minister Hans- Dietrich Genscher, in a letter sent this week to Unesco's general secretary, Amadou Mahtar M'Bow, said West Germany would remain a member of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization for at least another year. But it said the Government would review its membership in 12 months and might withdraw if the agency did not become less ideological and more efficient, the officials said.

headline: TERRORISM CHANGES THE WAY WORLD'S LEADERS LIVE
abstract: When Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher attended the funeral of Indira Gandhi in New Delhi today, she was accompanied by armed guards who had flown to India with her.     In Paris, tourists are no longer permitted to stand on the sidewalk in the Rue du Faubourg St. Honore and gaze into the courtyard of Elysee Palace to watch the official comings and goings at the presidential residence. The heavy green doors of the palace, which used to be open, are now chained closed at all times.   A few hours before Oscar Luigi Scalfaro, the Italian Interior Minister, held a news conference in Rome last week, two plainclothesmen minutely inspected the meeting room. Mr. Scalfaro arrived for the session with five or six bodyguards.   No Longer in Doubt      As those three episodes suggest, world political leaders are finding it more and more necessary to adopt rigorous measures to protect themselves against terrorists and assassins. Some European security people still think the United States Secret Service is heavy-handed and occasionally almost hysterical - the Irish police were appalled by some of the measures taken during President Reagan's European trip last summer - but they no longer question the need for elaborate protective arrangements.

headline: Philippine Inflation
abstract: The Philippines' inflation rate slowed to 60.57 percent last month, from 63.8 percent in October, and is expected to continue to decline, Economic Planning Minister Vicente Valdepenas said today.

headline: Coffee Gets New Accord
abstract: Forty-eight countries that produce coffee and 25 countries that consume it agreed today on price and quota goals for the next 12 months. They are members of the International Coffee Organization, accounting for 99 percent of all the world's coffee exports and 90 percent of imports.

headline: DOW OFF 9.72 POINTS TO 1,218.97
abstract: The stock market closed out an up- and-down week yesterday with another substantial drop in the Dow Jones industrial average.    The Dow fell 9.72 points yesterday, to 1,218.97, bringing its loss for the last three days to more than 25 points.   For the whole week, however, the average climbed 2.32 points.   ''Profit taking weakened the market for the third consecutive session following its run-up in anticipation of the Reagan landslide,'' commented James G. Joyce, co-director of research of Prescott, Ball & Turben. The Dow had gained almost 40 points in the seven sessions before the President's victory.

headline: S.E.C. Backs Mutual Fund
abstract: A divided Securities and Exchange Commission voted today to permit the Vanguard Group of investment companies of Valley Forge, Pa., to market a mutual fund that intends to invest all of its investors' dollars in other Vanguard funds.   The commission's 3-to-2 vote exempts the new fund from a regulation limiting the extent to which one mutual fund can invest in other funds.

headline: Product Introductions
abstract: Product introductions in the areas of grocery products and health and beauty aids continued strong in November after a lusty comeback in October, the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News has reported.

headline: Yamani Sees Oil Price Spurt
abstract: Saudi Arabia's oil minister predicted today that there would be a strong rise in oil prices over the winter and said some OPEC nations were exceeding production limits.   ''The prices of oil will jump and go up sharply,'' Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani told a news conference in Kuwait, where leaders of six Arab countries were meeting this week.

headline: Sumatra Mine Delayed
abstract: A World Bank-financed project to expand the Bukit Asam coal mine in south Sumatra will be delayed by more than a year because of rail construction problems, a mining executive said today. The project will be finished in late 1986, he said.

headline: LEVITT STARTS $2 BILLION PROJECT
abstract: William J. Levitt, the developer whose name came to symbolize inexpensive tract housing in the postwar years, announced yesterday that he would build a $2 billion planned community of at least 26,000 residential units in the Orlando, Fla., metropolitan area.     Mr. Levitt said the dwelling units, to be built as both single-family homes and attached town houses over the next seven years, would initially sell for from $39,900 to $59,900.    He said that he would also build 13 shopping centers, elementary and secondary schools and recreational facilities, and that he had set aside land for churches and synagogues.

headline: Eurobond Offering Set by Procter
abstract: The Procter & Gamble Company, in its first public borrowing since 1975, is offering $150 million of 10 7/8 percent extendible Eurobonds due in 1994 with warrants attached to buy another $150 million of bonds during the next three years.

headline: Holiday Inns
abstract: The Communications Satellite Corporation and Holiday Inns Inc. said they had approved a joint venture to provide satellite television programming and teleconference programming to Holiday Inn's 1,500 domestic operations.

headline: DOLLAR ALSO SLUMPS
abstract: Both the dollar and the British pound were battered in the foreign exchange markets yesterday. The dollar's slump led some to believe that the extraordinary rise in its value against the major foreign currencies has finally ended.     But the most dramatic event was the plunging value of the British pound, which hit another record low - $1.1820 - before recovering slightly to close in London at $1.1865. On Wednesday, the pound fell to the then record low of $1.1905 before closing at $1.20007. For the week, the pound has lost almost 6 cents.

headline: Wien Air Halts Its Operations
abstract: Wien Air Alaska Inc. said it plans to suspend all scheduled flight operations for 25 days beginning Nov. 17 to restructure its scheduled operations.

headline: EAST-WEST DOCTORS' GROUP WINS PEACE PRIZE
abstract: An organization founded by two physicians, one Soviet, the other American, has been awarded a United Nations peace prize here.    The award, the Unesco Peace Education Prize, was given Tuesday night to the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, which was formed in 1980. The two physicians are co-presidents of the group.

headline: AGENCIES STEP UP RELIEF FOR ETHIOPIA
abstract: As a major airlift began yesterday to send food to the drought-stricken northern regions of Ethiopia, a consortium of four relief agencies said they had developed a plan to distribute 200,000 tons of food in the East African nation over the next year.    Separately, the head of the Agency for International Development announced that the United States had signed its first direct agreement with the Ethiopian Government to send an additional 50,000 tons of food, worth $12 million, to the country, where it is feared that more than 6 million people may face starvation.    Previously, the Administration has sent food only through private relief organizations, saying it feared that the Marxist Government of Ethiopia would not deliver the food to areas held by rebel factions. Some Democrats have charged the Reagan Administration has not provided sufficient relief.

headline: Marriott Is Expanding Scali, McCabe's Tasks
abstract: Scali, McCabe, Sloves Direct, which has been working for the Marriott Corporation for a year, will now be working for Marriott Lifecare, residences for the elderly that the corporation is now building. Billings will be more than $1 million.    The assignment that the Ogilvy & Mather unit already is working on is Courtyard by Marriott, a new division that is putting up moderately priced hotels.

headline: ASSAD ENDS VISIT TO MOSCOW AMID SIGNS OF DISAGREEMENT
