abstract: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria ended a three-day visit to Moscow today, and the two sides called for Palestinian unity.    Western and Middle Eastern diplomats said they saw signs of some disagreement between the Soviet Union and Syria, its closest ally in the Middle East, on this and other matters.   One subject of Syrian concern, they said, was a series of Soviet overtures to moderate Arab governments.  Another possible matter of disagreement, they said, was Moscow's increasing support for Iraq in its war with Iran, a nation supported by Syria.

headline: Steel Output Off Last Week By The Associated Press Steel production fell to 1.364
abstract: million tons in the week ended   last Saturday, the lowest production so far this year and a   decrease of 6.7 percent from   the previous week's 1.462 million tons, the American Iron   and Steel Institute reported today.

headline: ALLEN-BRADLEY IS UP FOR SALE MILWAUKEE, Oct. 19 (AP)
abstract: The Allen-Bradley Company, which makes computerized   controls and electrical equipment used in factory automation, has decided to put itself up   for sale.

headline: Chief for 19 Years Resigns at Purex
abstract: William R. Tincher, the longtime president, chief executive and chairman of Purex Industries who was instrumental in taking the company private in 1982, has resigned, the company said.    Mr. Tincher, who is 58 years old, tendered his resignation, effective immediately, at a regularly scheduled stockholders meeting Thursday.    ''I've been chief executive officer for 19 years this week, and this got me thinking about it,'' Mr. Tincher said.

headline: SOHIO IS DOWN BY 17.5.%
abstract: The Mobil Corporation, the nation's second-largest oil company, reported yesterday that its net income for the third quarter fell 41.1 percent, to $238 million, or 59 cents a share, from $404 million, or 99 cents a share, in the period a year ago. Revenue, however, rose to $15 billion from $14.2 billion.    The earnings were in line with some others reported by major oil companies for the period. Industry specialists have noted that the third- quarter reports generally reflect the global oil surplus and a drop in United States pump prices during the important summer driving season.

headline: NBD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: No Headline
abstract: Frank B. Hall Ends Its Underwriting    Frank B. Hall & Company announced yesterday that it was disposing of its direct underwriting operations, and would charge a $16 million after-tax loss to the third quarter for the disposition. But the company added that it would terminate its pension fund, and take the surplus assets, so that the net third-quarter loss was expected to be about $5 million.

headline: CUBAN ORGANIZING A GUERRILLA UNIT
abstract: A Cuban exile leader says he has begun organizing a permanent Cuban exile detachment to fight alongside Nicaraguan rebels seeking the overthrow of the Sandinista Government.     The exile leader, Huber Matos, a close associate of Fidel Castro in the Cuban Revolution who later broke with him and spent two decades in prison, said in a telephone interview Friday that ''we are undertaking an effort to assure a permanent presence of Cuban combatants from our movement at their side.''   He added, ''This is also our war, since they, like us, are fighting against Castro and the Russians.''

headline: Warsaw Rights Panel Called on the Carpet
abstract: The authorities called in organizers of Warsaw's new human rights committee today and told them they could face five years in jail if they persist in their activities.

headline: Poles Warn Reporters On Watchdog Groups
abstract: The Polish Foreign Ministry warned Western reporters today that they risked prosecution if they attended news conferences given by illegal civic watchdog groups that have been set up to monitor police brutality.   Ministry officials said journalists could face the same charges as organizers of the meetings.

headline: CHINESE ANNOUNCE SWEEPING CHANGES IN THEIR ECONOMY
abstract: China announced plans today for sweeping changes in its urban economy that will introduce capitalist-style market forces and reduce Government control.   The plans were incorporated in a major decision on the changes in China's economic structure that were adopted today at a meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee.   The new measures will give greater independence to a million stateowned enterprises and make them compete to survive. In addition, the program will separate Government functions from purely economic functions, which will be left to plant managers operating within guidelines. The decision will also mean that China will limit central planning, phase out extensive consumer subsidies and leave the prices of many products to be determined by supply and demand.

headline: Ferry and Tug Collide In Hamburg Harbor
abstract: A chartered ferry carrying more than 40 people on a birthday cruise sank tonight after a collision with a tug towing a barge in rain-swept Hamburg harbor.

headline: HOMEOWNERS' INSURANCE IS REVISED
abstract: Insurance companies have begun to introduce a new homeowners' insurance policy nationwide, the first major revision in the standard policy in eight years.    The new policy, referred to in the industry as the Homeowners' Program, raises some areas of coverage and lowers others, but keeps premium payments unchanged. Homeowners who buy the new policy will find, for example, that the basic deductible amount they must absorb before receiving anything for their claims has risen, effectively reducing their benefits. But they will also find that coverage for personal liability and medical expenses has risen and that the dollar limits for some common items in the home, such as jewelry, has also been increased.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: END MAFIA CODE OF SILENCE, POPE EXHORTS ITALIANS
abstract: Pope John Paul II issued one of his strongest condemnations of organized crime today, urging listeners in a southern Italian town to break ''the tragic chain of vendettas'' and end organized crime's code of silence.    The Pope specifically used organized crime's traditional word ''omert a'' in referring to the code of silence.   Speaking in the Calabrian coastal village of Paola, the Pope told a crowd ''to have the courage to wipe out omert a, which binds so many people in a type of squalid complicity dictated by fear.''

headline: Farm Bank Sale
abstract: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation, which provides financing for the Federal Farm Credit System, is offering $703 milloion of 12 percent bonds due Oct. 20, 1986, and $605 million of 12.45 percent bonds due Oct. 23, 1989. Both issues are offered at a price of 100 through various securities dealers.

headline: About Real Estate; 2 New Tenants Signed by Trade Center
abstract: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is making progress in its marketing campaign to lease some two million square feet of space at the World Trade Center. The authority, which is trying to lease space in the 23d through 74th floors of Tower Two at the center, recently signed two agreements for some 300,000 square feet with Marine Midland Bank and the Aetna Life and Casualty Company.   Marine Midland agreed to take four adjacent floors encompassing about 160,000 square feet. The bank is seeking to ease a space crunch at its headquarters at 140 Broadway. The specific divisions to be located there have not been selected, but Marine Midland hopes to be in its new space by March.

headline: FULL HOUSE IN BAHAMAS: TOURISTS AND A TEMPEST
abstract: Ismael Nun, general manager of the new Cable Beach Casino, is sitting behind his desk. Croupiers at the gaming tables wear tuxedos, but Mr. Nun is dressed less formally, in green sunglasses, black jeans and a black shirt, wide open at the chest.    ''In 10 months of operation,'' he said, ''we have built up our base of customers very well. We have a very good trade originating from cruise ships. We have also been tried and liked by a lot of high rollers.''

headline: K Mart Plans Financial Units
abstract: The K Mart Corporation said it plans to open financial-services departments in 10 of its San Diego-area stores. The new services will be provided by First Nationwide Savings, a California-based savings and loan association, and will include money market accounts, Individual Retirement Accounts and certificates of deposit.

headline: BEIRUT HOSTAGES' FAMILIES SPEAK OUT
abstract: On separate occasions last spring, three Americans - a journalist, a diplomat and a minister - were kidnapped off the sidewalks of Beirut by gunmen.     Little has been said or written about the missing men in the months since, either by the Reagan Administration, the victims' families or the press. The silence has stemmed largely from fear that statements might further endanger the hostages' lives.    But now, the families of two of the hostages have decided to speak out in an effort to draw attention to the continued detention of their relatives, in hopes of creating pressure for their release.

headline: PACT ON MARC RICH LEAVES LOOSE ENDS
abstract: A Settlement.  The negotiated settlement of a huge tax case against commodity trading companies associated with Marc Rich does not end the matter. Mr. Rich's giant commodity firm, Marc Rich & Company, and its former American unit, Clarendon Ltd., which the Government claims was sold in an attempt to cloud the case, agreed to pay about $200 million in fines and back taxes on the criminal charges of fraud and tax evasion. In return for the windfall, the Government released the tens of millions in American assets of the companies. The Government would still like to get its hands on Mr. Rich and his partner, Pincus Green, who face criminal tax charges here. But both men are living in Switzerland, which does not recognize the charges for extradition purposes.      Banking on Profits.  In the wake of First Chicago's announcement of an expected $70 million loss because of bad loans, most analysts had expected lower earnings at other big banking companies. But several major banking companies, which increased their loan reserves and strengthened their capital bases, showed surprisingly strong results in the quarter. Manufacturers Hanover's net income was virtually unchanged . . . Chemical Bank rose 1.2 percent . . . Security Pacific gained rose 11 percent . . . J.P. Morgan surged 19.1 percent . . . Irving Trust rose 11.1 percent.

headline: INDIANS FLEE CITY AS CHEMICAL PLANT PLANS TO RESTART
abstract: By the tens of thousands, Bhopal residents fled the city today after an announcement that the Union Carbide plant here would be started up again Sunday to neutralize what remains of a toxic chemical that killed at least 2,000 people.    By train and bus and car and plane, by auto rickshaw and two-wheeled tonga and on foot the citizens left, abandoning jobs and homes, crippling many services and business activities.    No count of those leaving was possible, but informed estimates were that at least 100,000 of the city's 900,000 people had fled in the last 24 hours, joining another 100,000 who left immediately after the deadly escape of methyl isocyanate gas on Dec. 3.   Refugees Delay Trains      Prudence rather than panic seemed to be the governing mood. There was no headlong rush, though in the middle of the night anxious residents stopped and delayed trains until they, too, were aboard.

headline: INQUIRY AT UNITED TECHNOLOGIES
abstract: The United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that members of its board of directors are investigating accusations stemming from the recent resignation of Robert Carlson as its president.    The company refused to expand on its brief release, in which it did not specify the nature of the allegations. A spokesman did acknowledge, however, that the principal charges were allegations by Mr. Carlson that Harry J. Gray, the company's chairman and chief executive officer, ordered that Mr. Carlson's home and office be wiretapped or bugged.

headline: Reagan Denounces Apartheid as Repugnant
abstract: President Reagan, responding to criticism from Bishop Desmond Tutu of South Africa, said today that the United States finds that country's racial policies ''repugnant,'' but prefers to try to change them quietly.   ''Perhaps he isn't aware of all that we are doing,'' Mr. Reagan said of Bishop Tutu, an Anglican who won the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize on Oct. 16 for his decades of nonviolent struggle for racial equality in South Africa.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA TO GIVE STUDENTS A SMALL VOICE IN THE SCHOOLS
abstract: South African authorities announced plans for a democratization of the nation's troubled schools today in what seemed an ambivalent concession to the thousands of students who have been boycotting classes since May.    Meanwhile, army units that have been helping police patrol black townships for four days were reported today to have withdrawn. But the Law and Order Minister, Louis Le Grange, said they would be deployed again ''if it becomes necessary.'' Sporadic violence continued in townships near here and outside Johannesburg.

headline: CONTEMPT CITATION IN DYNAMICS CASE
abstract: Senator Charles E. Grassley signed today a contempt of Congress citation against Attorney General William French Smith for failure to turn over files on an investigation into Navy shipbuilding.     But the Justice Department and the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee immediately questioned the procedural correctness of the move by Mr. Grassley, an Iowa Republican and chairman of a Judiciary subcommittee.    Senator Grassley signed the one- page citation using authority an aide said was granted by the subcommittee. The signing came four weeks after Mr. Grassley had subpoenaed records of a Justice Department investigation of cost overruns in submarine contracts held by the General Dynamics Corporation. In 1981, the department ended nearly four years of scrutiny of the company's Electric Boat division in Groton, Conn., without prosecution.

headline: Advertising; Ebony's Search for Attention
abstract: IN 1981, Ebony magazine, among   others, was having problems. It   cut its staff to save money on payroll. It trimmed its size to save money on paper.    Considering all that, things look rosy this year (one year after Ebony made the list of hottest magazines) - the year its parent company, the Johnson Publishing Company, was ranked the No. 1 American black- owned business, and the year its founder/president, John H. Johnson, can trace his life with pride ''from the Chicago welfare rolls to the Forbes 400.'' That's the list of wealthiest Americans.

headline: Kentucky Bonds In Heavy Demand
abstract: A $217.8 million issue of Kentucky Turnpike Authority revenue bonds met with strong investor demand yesterday, and it quickly attracted orders for far more bonds than were available.    In response to the demand, which was particularly great for long-term bonds due in 2010, underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets raised prices slightly during the afternoon.

headline: CHRYSLER'S NET JUMPS IN QUARTER
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation, still benefiting from not having to pay Federal income taxes, said today that it earned $261.6 million, or $1.88 a share, in the third quarter, up sharply from the $100.2 million, or 72 cents a share, earned in the third quarter of 1983.    Without the tax-loss carry-forwards that are the result of the huge losses the company piled up from 1979 through 1981, the company's profit would have been $148.2 million, or $1.19 a share.   Analysts said Chrysler's earnings were within the range generally expected. ''I was forecasting $1.10 a share on a fully taxed basis,'' said Ann C. Knight of Paine Webber Inc. ''They must have sold a few more cars with vinyl roofs.''

headline: ARMAND HAMMER WILL MEET CHERNENKO ON U.S. RELATIONS
abstract: Konstantin U. Chernenko has asked Armand Hammer, the American industrialist, to go to Moscow for a discussion of Soviet-American relations, Administration officials said today.   The officials said they expected Mr. Chernenko to use the meeting to prepare the way for scheduled talks between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko in Geneva on Jan. 7 and 8.   Mr. Hammer, whose dealings with Soviet leaders go back to Lenin's times, is chairman of Occidental Petroleum. He was used by President John F. Kennedy in 1961 for a mission to meet with Nikita S. Khrushchev. The industrialist was also close to Leonid I. Brezhnev, who gave Mr. Hammer a Moscow apartment for his use.

headline: DOING BUSINESS WITH DISTANT BANKS
abstract: TRADITIONALLY, most people have chosen   their bank because it has an office near their   home or job. Yet, proximity is diminishing in importance as the broadening of banking services makes it easier to do business with a bank far from home and office.   Thus, no matter where you live, the big money- center banks can often be the best place to make large deposits, while for the more mundane banking needs, such as checking accounts, a small-town bank may offer a better deal.   In depositing funds, there are often advantages in moving time deposits from a small-town bank to a distant money-center bank because its interest rates are higher. Recently, while the Northwestern National Bank of Duluth, Minn., was paying 9 percent interest on a six-month, $10,000 certificate of deposit, major New York banks were paying about 1 1/4 percentage points more.

headline: HUSSEIN, IN EGYPTIAN PARLIMENT, CONDEMNS CAMP DAVID ACCORDS
abstract: King Hussein of Jordan reiterated his criticism of the Camp David accords today in a speech to the Egyptian Parliament.    President Hosni Mubarak, who addressed Parliament after the King, did not defend the 1978 accords, which led to Egypt's peace treaty with Israel. Instead, he said that Jordan's political reconciliation with Egypt would help the Arabs in ''protecting their land from aggression and in liberating what the aggressors have stolen.''

headline: Wall St. Veteran Moves Up
abstract: The offices of Albert Frank-   Guenther Law were a shambles   Friday, as the Little Old Lady of Adland prepared to make its second move in 112 years - from 61 to 71 Broadway, 90 feet to the north and that much closer to all those old friends in Trinity churchyard.    Amid 100 people packing for the move, Stephen J. Witt, chairman, was relaxed and more than a bit nostalgic. He may have been at the shop only four years - having been brought in by Foote, Cone & Belding, the parent, to resuscitate the operation - but he has steeped himself in the lore of what he chooses to describe as the oldest combination of advertising and public relations firms in the country, younger only by three years than N.W. Ayer, the oldest agency.    And just outside his office is a painting of the old offices at 131 Cedar Street - four small, attached buildings that served as home for some 99 years. And he has the brass name plaque showing the old logotype, which has survived until today, despite the image-changing mania that grips corporate America. Other memorabilia of the old days - such as the brass parts of stair railings - now serve as paper weights.

headline: CAPTAIN DENIES SHIP WAS SPYING ON CUBANS
abstract: The captain of the Seaward Explorer, the Miami-based ship towed today into the Port of Miami after being incapacitated in Cuban waters last Thursday, said his 105-foot vessel had been out on a routine ocean mapping operation, not ''a secret mission.''    The incident led to the dispatch of the 90,000-ton aircraft carrier Nimitz because of what a senior Defense Department official said was concern that the Seaward Explorer could be seized by the Cubans for political reasons.    ''We were mapping the depths of the seas between Haiti and Cuba,'' said Capt. Peter Skipp, who is also a co- owner of the vessel. ''This was a nonclassified Navy operation. We had no Government equipment aboard and no equipment of highly sensitive nature. This was not a secret mission.''

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: Citicorp Overseas Finance N.V.'s 12-year floating rate note has been increased to $300 million from $250 million at a price of 99.80 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.     *  Montgomery Ward Credit Corp., a unit of Mobil Corp., has filed for a shelf offering of up to $200 million in debt securities on terms to be determined by market conditions at the time of sale.      Common Stock    *  Hexcel Corp . is selling 600,000 shares of common stock at $25.375 per share through underwriters led by Kidder Peabody & Co. and Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: PATENTS; ENHANCING PHONE CIRCUTS
abstract: WASHINGTON  A DIGITAL communications system designed to transmit 63 simultaneous conversations over one standard circuit - while maintaining voice quality - was patented this week by Elliot L. Gruenberg, president of Broadcom Inc., which is based in New York. Patent 4,477,900 was assigned to Broadcom.

headline: JAPAN RESISTING U.S. LAWYERS
abstract: As far as Japan is concerned, it has acceded to more than enough United States trade demands over the years, from importing beef and oranges to restricting its auto exports. But the Japanese are sending clear signals that one commodity urged on them by Washington is something they would rather do without: American lawyers.   Amid all the other trade issues that the two countries have to deal with, the desire of American lawyers to enter the virtually closed Japanese market may not rank near the top.   It has been pressed nonetheless by United States officials, in response to pressure from a small but highly influential lobbying force. In principle, the Japanese Government agrees that the legal-services industry should be ''liberalized,'' as does the country's chief business group, the Japan Federation of Economic Organizations.

headline: WHEN MANY CHIEFS THINK AS ONE
abstract: ''I can't say enough for it,'' remarks Joseph   Jones, the chairman and president of Armstrong World Industries. Abraham Zaleznik, a Harvard Business School professor, calls it ''an intellectual wasteland.'' Aetna Life and Casualty probably wishes it had never heard of it. ''We don't want to comment on it,'' an Aetna spokesman said. ''We want to downplay the experience.''    What gives rise to these accolades and fulminations is one of the more curious and long-standing management experiments to be tried by the nation's major corporations - the group executive office. The concept, which has acquired such labels as the office of the chairman, the office of the president, the executive council and the council, typically involves bunching three or four senior executives into a body that roosts atop the company and indulges in group thinking.

headline: Lone Star to Sell Florida Properties
abstract: Lone Star Industries said it and Tarmac P.L.C. had signed an agreement for Lone Star to sell its aggregates, ready-mix concrete and concrete-block plants in Florida for about $80 million, plus inventories. The accord also covers the sale of aggregates reserves.

headline: WITH TULLY OF MERRILL LYNCH
abstract: BOCA RATON, Fla.    The individual investor has been fleeing the stock market for nearly a year and a half now, and the result has been a squeeze on profits at the big securities firms that cater to the public.   The largest of these firms is Merrill Lynch & Company, with its 10,200 retail brokers across the country. Recently, it has been laying off some support personnel and trying to sell other products to bolster its depressed bottom line.

headline: INSURER'S CAPITAL RAISED BY AMERICAN EXPRESS
abstract: The American Express Company said yesterday that it had added $200 million to the surplus of its Fireman's Fund Insurance unit, most of which was to comply with a ruling by the California Insurance Department.    In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, American Express stock was the most active, with about 1.3 million shares changing hands as the price fell $1.125 a share, to $34.625. On Tuesday, when the company reported the infusion in a periodic filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the stock had dropped 62.5 cents.

headline: Petrie Debentures Are Exchangeable
abstract: The Petrie Stores Corporation is offering $200 million of 8 percent exchangeable debentures at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: Multimedia Sees An Earnings Drop
abstract: Multimedia Inc. said it expects third-quarter earnings to be below the results a year earlier because of greater-than-expected losses at its Sports Time cable television unit, which is a joint venture with Anheuser-Busch Companies and Tele-communications Inc.    The company said operating losess from the Sports Time division are now estimated at 20 cents to 30 cents a share, compared with earlier estimates of 5 cents to 10 cents a share.

headline: MORE HOPEFUL OUTLOOK SEEN
abstract: The number of deaths occurring each day at Bhopal's major hospital has dropped for the first time since the escape of lethal gas from the Union Carbide insecticide plant here last Monday, the hospital's superintendent said today. At the same time there were signs that medical consequences for survivors might not be so devastating or widespread as had been predicted.    ''The worst is over,'' said Dr. N. R. Bhandari, the superintendent of Hamidia Hospital. ''The situation is much better with deaths, and therefore we are much relieved.''

headline: KREMLIN LETS FACTORIES REACH OUT TO THE EAST BLOC
abstract: The Soviet Union, in a move aimed at closer economic contacts with its allies, has authorized factories to establish ''direct links'' with their counterparts in other Communist countries.   The contacts could speed the infusion of advanced technology into the Soviet economy and erode the sweeping powers of the Foreign Trade Ministry.    Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, has generally been viewed as reluctant to pursue changes in economic organization begun by his predecessor, Yuri V. Andropov. But the new factory-to-factory dealings appear to be part of a continuing effort to relax controls and to endow industrial managers with more initiative.

headline: Arco Loses Alaska Plea ANCHORAGE, Nov. 8 (AP)
abstract: Alaska's North Slope Borough has rejected a request   from a unit of the Atlantic   Richfield Company for permission to build a gravel causeway   into Prudhoe Bay to help develop a huge oil reservoir. The borough is concerned   that construction of the two-   and-a-half-mile road would disrupt fish migrations, and that   development of the Lisburne   oilfield would harm the water   quality, the borough's planner,   Tom Barnes, said Wednesday.  A request by the Sohio Alaska   Petroleum Company, a unit of   the Standard Oil Company   (Ohio), to build a causeway   was also rejected recently by   the borough on similar   grounds.

headline: TRADE PACT WITH INDIA REPORTED
abstract: The United States and India have tentatively reached a trade agreement that would allow India greater access to American high technology exports, a State Department official said tonight.   The official said the pact had already been initialed by the United States and awaited final approval by India.

headline: Krupp-Kl"ockner Stake Purchased
abstract: In a major move into the European steel industry, Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd., the giant raw materials concern, has agreed to pay $175 million for a 35 percent share in a new steel company, to be formed from a merger of the steelmaking operations of Kl"ockner-Werke A.G. and Krupp Stahl A.G..   In a statement, the companies said the planned combination, to be called Stahlwerke Krupp-Kl"ockner G.m.b.H., will begin operating Jan. 1, pending approval by Common Market and government authorities.   The companies said the new combination would have a crude steel output of 9 million metric tons a year, and sales of $3.3 billion a year, making it Europe's second-largest private steel company, after Germany's Thyssen.

headline: Danish Retail Prices Up
abstract: Denmark's consumer prices rose seven-tenths of 1 percent last month from August and 6.2 percent from a year ago, the Government said today.

headline: MOROCCO QUITS O.A.U. OVER POLISARIO
abstract: Morocco, a founding member of the Organization of African Unity, quit the organization today over the seating of guerrillas who are fighting the Moroccans in Western Sahara.     The action, which came here as the O.A.U. opened its 20th summit meeting, marked the first time that a member of the organization had withdrawn.    ''While we wait for wiser days, we will bid you farewell,'' the Moroccan representative, Ahmed Reda Guedira, said at the meeting.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Advertising; Discover Competing On Rates
abstract: -year-old, floundering Time Inc. science magazine, is going to cut its ad rates considerably, its trade advertising budget completely and go into the advertiser marketplace to offer the biggest publication of its kind with the lowest ad rates.    It is going to be good, old-fashioned price competition.   The circulation rate base will be trimmed, subscription and cover prices increased, a less expensive paper used and three of the 13 ad salespeople are moving elsewhere in the company.    And right at the top on the editorial side, James B. Hayes, publisher, disclosed yesterday that he was bringing in Gilbert Rogin, his former associate at Sports Illustrated, where he is managing editor, to replace Leon Jaroff, the managing editor of Discover and the man given much credit for its concept. Yesterday Mr. Jaroff was named to the new post of science editor of Time magazine.

headline: PUBLISHER IS OBJECT OF G.&.W. BID
abstract: Gulf and Western Industries said yesterday that it would make a $70- a-share tender offer for all the outstanding common stock of Prentice- Hall Inc., its first big acquisition attempt after two years of divestitures.     The offer would have a total value of about $700 million.    Gulf and Western, already a strong presence in the publishing industry through its ownership of Simon & Schuster, said it would become ''a major force in virtually every important segment of the book publishing business'' by joining forces with Prentice-Hall, the nation's leading publisher of college textbooks.    Gulf and Western is ''already in children's and elementary school books, and bingo,'' said Edward Atorino, a publishing analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. ''This gets them into college and professional publishing.''

headline: 2 SEIZED IN SICILY IN DRIVE ON MAFIA
abstract: Two leading Sicilian businessmen were arrested today in a continuing drive against organized crime in Sicily. The drive has been spurred in part by the confessions of Tommaso Buscetta, a former Mafia leader.     The arrests came a little more than a week after the arrest of a former Mayor of Palermo, Vito Ciancimino, a leading political figure in Sicily who was linked to the Mafia by Mr. Buscetta.    Mr. Buscetta, who was on the losing side of a gang war in Sicily, has given investigators a detailed picture of the Mafia and set off arrests and interrogations both in Italy and in the United States, Canada and Brazil.

headline: Indiana Utility Loses Rate Bid INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 27
abstract: The Indiana Court of   Appeals struck down a rate increase granted to the Northern   Indiana Public Service Company to recover the cost of its   abandoned Bailly nuclear   power plant. In a 2-to-1 decision, the appeals court set aside the rate increase granted by the Public   Service Commission that allowed the Hammond-based   utility to recover its $190.7 million investment in Bailly over a   15-year period.

headline: Advertising; Merger Set Of Mower And Gore
abstract: FOR the two years that his Sycracuse-based agency has had a New York office, Eric A. Mower, 40 years old, has been looking to connect with a New York shop to supply him with a larger base of operations.    For longer than that, Chester A. Gore, 66, has been looking for a way of insuring an orderly succession of ownership for his own shop.    Both men, one the president of the 25-year-old Silverman Mower agency, the other the president of the 29- year-old Chester Gore Company, confided in Harry Paster, the knowledgeable and respected executive vice president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies. He brought them together last July 10.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1984   Companies    Arthur Andersen agreed to pay Marsh & McLennan $19.9 million to settle a suit arising out of losses recorded at the insurance- brokerage concern. Only last month, the accounting firm settled a similar suit by paying Chase Manhattan over $45 million. (Page 29.)   Visicorp will merge with a small start-up company headed by a former Visicorp manager. The one-time star of the personal computer software industry, through its Visicalc spreadsheet program, thus becomes the largest example of the industry's shakeout. (29.)

headline: Top Grumman Lobbyist Retiring in February
abstract: Gordon H. Ochenrider, who for the past 10 years has defended the Grumman Corporation's interests in Washington, plans to retire in February as vice president of Grumman and will establish a private consulting business in Washington.   As Grumman's chief lobbyist, Mr. Ochenrider also was responsible for disbursing funds from the company's Political Action Committee, which was set up five years ago and developed into one of the largest and most effective such corporate committee in the country. In the past two years it has contributed more than $350,000 to candidates for local and Federal office.

headline: Zeta Laboratories
abstract: International Signal and Control Group P.L.C. said it intended to acquire Zeta Laboratories Inc. for about $35 million and 600,000 new International Signal shares valued at $2 million. Zeta, based in Santa Clara, Calif., produces microwave subsystems and parts for defense electronic communications. It is a subsidiary of the Computer and Communications Technology Corporation.

headline: LEBANES LEADER URGES CHANGES IN POWER-SHARING ARRANGEMENTS
abstract: President Amin Gemayel, marking the 41st anniversary of Lebanon's independence, called today for a new national charter governing coexistence between Christian and Moslem communities.     Under such a charter, Mr. Gemayel said, citizens would rise above sectarian or partisan considerations to owe allegiance only to their country.    The President, who is a Maronite Christian, said he believed that ''a bright new era'' was about to dawn for this country, which has been torn by years of civil war and an Israeli invasion.    He spoke at the beginning of a military parade near his residence in the Beirut suburb of Baabda. He was flanked by the country's two most senior Moslem officials, Prime Minister Rashid Karami and the Speaker of Parliament, Hussein al-Husseini.

headline: Red Brigades of Italy Say They Are Back
abstract: An anonymous caller said today that the leftist Red Brigades terror group was ''alive and well'' and would follow two foiled holdups in Rome and Bologna with new operations.   The Florence cell of the Red Brigades, previously thought crushed in a wave of arrests after the rescue of kidnapped Gen. James L. Dozier in January 1982 in Padua, ''will make itself felt in the coming months,'' the caller said.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Oct. 1, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Working Group on Drafting Convention of Rights of Migrant Workers and Familites - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Legal Committee - 3 P.M.

headline: BROKERS' HOLIDAY SPIRITS RALLY
abstract: On Wall Street, the spirit of Christmas had to wait for a stock market rally.   The third annual fund-raising drive on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange had met with a Scrooge-like reception - until this week. With the burst of trading, the drive has taken off. Yesterday, check after check was being pressed into the hand of Arthur D. Cashin Jr., a Paine Webber Inc. floor broker who heads the effort, which buys turkey dinners with all the fixings for needy families.    Of the $44,000 raised so far - still far off last year's $70,000, which fed 1,000 families - some $10,000 poured in Tuesday and yesterday.

headline: SAKHAROV'S STEPDAUGHTER SAYS SHE HEARD FROM THE COUPLE
abstract: The stepdaughter of the Soviet dissident Andrei D. Sakharov said today that she had received a photograph of her mother and the Nobel Prize winner along with a note saying it was sent ''to convince you at last that we are alive.''   ''I think it is a real picture of them,'' the stepdaughter, Tatiana Yankelevich, said. ''It doesn't seem to be retouched.''

headline: Second Bid For Register
abstract: A bidding war may be evolving for the purchase of the Des Moines Register and Tribune Company with news of a second offer to buy the company.   David Kruidenier, chairman of the company's board, said on Saturday that he has received an ''unsolicited'' bid that exceeds the $112 million offer made Nov. 5 by Dow Jones & Company and four investors.

headline: GTE Sprint Pact
abstract: The GTE Corporation's GTE Sprint Communications subsidiary said it had concluded an agreement with British Telecom International to provide long-distance, discount telephone service to Britain. GTE Sprint said that the new enterprise would be its first trans-Atlantic service and that it expects to announce agreements soon with other major countries.

headline: F.T.C. Approves Chevron-Gulf Deal
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission today approved the biggest corporate merger in United States history - the Chevron Corporation's $13.2 billion takeover of the Gulf Corporation.   By a 4-to-0 vote, the F.T.C. accepted a tentative agreement it reached with the oil giant in April that will double Chevron's oil reserves to 3.9 billion barrels and make it America's third-largest oil company, behind Exxon and Mobil.

headline: Greece Bans Airliners From Northern Aegean
abstract: The Foreign Ministry today banned commercial air traffic over the northern Aegean Sea for 36 hours, saying that a Turkish jet fighter taking part in NATO exercises flew into the area and could have caused an accident.   Deputy Foreign Minster Yiannis Kapsis said the closing of the international air corridor, which is used for 300 flights daily from Europe and the Middle East, would last from 2 P.M. today until 2 A.M. Wednesday.

headline: Utility Debt Appeal Set
abstract: The United States Supreme Court will be asked to review court rulings in Washington State that freed utilities from having to pay their debts to the Washington Public Power Supply System, officials of the Chemical Bank said today.    Plans for the appeal were announced a day after the state's highest court reaffirmed its 1983 decision that left the system unable to make payments on $2.25 billion worth of bonds sold to finance two nuclear power projects.

headline: EXECUTIVES CHANGES
abstract: *  Beverly Enterprises, Pasadena, Calif., a company whose principal business is in health care facilities, has promoted Larry B. Cornish to senior vice president and secretary.     *  Cushman & Wakefield Inc., a commercial real estate firm, has promoted Raymond T. O'Keefe Jr. to executive vice president and New York regional director.     *  Delta Air Lines, Atlanta, has elected Olin Galloway and R. H. Heil senior vice presidents.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Mortgage Agency Sets Offering of $556 Million
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation is offering $556 million of collateralized mortgage obligations through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The obligations, backed by more than $630 million of conventional home mortgages, are also backed by the corporation.

headline: Smith May Call Off Its Bid for Gearhart
abstract: Smith International Inc., which has been pursuing Gearhart Industries since last spring, said that it was conducting negotiations with the concern that could lead to ending its bid.   Smith, an oilfield services company based in Newport Beach, Calif., made the announcement in a statement released yesterday.

headline: BUYOUT EFFORT AT DIVERSIFOODS
abstract: PAN pizza turned out to be trouble for the Godfather's pizza chain and its parent, Diversifoods Inc. The chain rolled out the new product - some call it deep dish pizza or Sicilian pizza - earlier this year with inadequate market research, according to some analysts, and the new dish was poorly received by pizza fans.    In addition, it was ''operationally a nightmare,'' said one analyst, with high food and labor costs. The program had to be reformulated to bring the expense ratio down, he said.    The experience took the zing out of the growing Godfather's chain and was said to have disillusioned many of the franchise holders. It also caused lower earnings prospects for Diversifoods, disenchantment with the company on Wall Street and a drop in the stock.

headline: U.S. Embassy in Lisbon Attacked With Grenades
abstract: Four grenades exploded today at the United States Embassy here, damaging three cars but causing no casualties.

headline: BRITISH TELECOM'S STOCK PLANS
abstract: The British Government today disclosed most details of its plan to sell just over half of British Telecommunications, the state-owned telephone company, to private investors next month. The proceeds are expected to make it the world's largest stock sale ever.    The key missing detail was the price, which will be set with the issuance of the final prospectus Nov. 16. The draft document was consistent, however, with predictions that the more than 3.01 billion shares, or 50.2 percent of the total outstanding, will be priced at about 125 pence, or $1.52 at current exchange rates. That would raise around $4.6 billion.

headline: Jacob Butcher Indicted Again MEMPHIS, Nov. 19 (AP) -
abstract: Jacob F. Butcher, the bankrupt   Tennessee financier, and a   longtime associate were indicted by a Federal grand jury   today on charges of defrauding   a Memphis bank of $1.5 million.

headline: I.B.M.-Korea Link
abstract: The Finance Ministry has approved a plan by a unit of the International Business Machines Corporation to set up a company in South Korea next year, ministry officials said. They said the unit, I.B.M. World Trade Americas/Far East Corporation, would make and sell personal computers and parts. I.B.M. wants to invest $15.4 million in establishing the I.B.M. Korea System Corporation, the officials said. They gave no further details.

headline: ALL 108 ON HIJACKED JET ARE FREED IN ETHIOPIA
abstract: The hijackers of a Somali airliner seized on Saturday released their 108 hostages unharmed today and were given the choice of political asylum or safe passage to a country of their choice by Ethiopia.    The hijackers, led by a Somali military officer, had been threatening to blow up the plane and kill the people on board, including one American, identified today as Lieut. James Dell, 30 years old, of Orangeburg, N.Y., if their demands for the release of 21 political prisoners in Somalia were not met. Seven of those prisoners are students who, the hijackers said, were to have been executed in Somalia the day after the hijacking.

headline: EGYPTIAN COURT SAYS AUTHORITIES TORTURED SUSPECTS
abstract: Egypt's Supreme Court has accused the security forces of having tortured more than half of the 281 Moslem fundamentalists whose protracted trial on charges of sedition and murder ended a month ago.    The accusation by the court, regarded here as highly unusual, appeared in the Saturday issue of Al Ahram, Egypt's semiofficial Arabic daily, which published portions of the court's 677-page report on the trial.   Al Ahram said the report called for a prompt inquiry to identify individuals responsible for the torture.   ''Contrary to the Middle Ages,'' Al Ahram quoted the court report as stating, ''torture to extract confessions is unacceptable in modern times.''

headline: Gain at Texas Instruments
abstract: Texas Instruments Inc., the big electronics and military contractor, reported yesterday that earnings in the three months ended Sept. 30 rose to $85.8 million, or $3.54 a share, in contrast to a loss of $110.8 million in the 1983 period. Sales came to $1.42 billion, compared with $1.01 billion.

headline: U.S.-HANOI TALKS ON AMERASIANS
abstract: A White House aide met this week with Vietnam's Foreign Minister to discuss details on how to carry out the Administration's offer to accept tens of thousands of Vietnamese immigrants, State Department officials said today.    The United States has said that it is prepared to take in all of the Asian- American children in Vietnam and 10,000 of the current and former prisoners from its re-education camps.

headline: U.S. IS SAID TO BE STUDYING WAYS TO INCREASE PRESSURE ON NICARAGUA
abstract: The Reagan Administration, concerned about what it says is an increased flow of Soviet bloc weapons to Nicaragua, is considering placing greater diplomatic and military pressure on the Nicaraguan Government, senior Administration officials said today.     They said the moves being discussed at high levels of the Government included the recall of the United States Ambassador to Nicaragua, the Navy's interdiction at sea of arms shipments to Nicaragua, an increase in the frequency and size of United States military maneuvers in Central America and, Congress willing, a resumption of aid to Nicaraguan rebels.    The intention, they said, is to intimidate the Nicaraguan Government without the direct use of United States military force inside Nicaragua. The proposals, they said, could range from shadowing ships and harassing them to a full naval quarantine of Nicaragua.    Although the Administration has not recently made public aerial reconnaissance photographs or other raw intelligence information about the military buildup in Nicaragua, Pentagon and State Department officials said recent shipments from the Soviet bloc included surface-to-air missiles, attack helicopters, sophisticated antiaircraft guns and radar equipment and high- speed patrol boats. Some United States military officers have described the arms as primarily defensive.

headline: 3,500 TO 4,500 LIBYANS ARE REPORTED STILL IN CHAD
abstract: A Western analyst here asserted today that Libya still had 3,500 to 4,500 troops in Chad despite Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's assertion this week that all of his forces had left the country.     This means, the analyst said, that Libya has withdrawn virtually none of its men since the meeting in Crete between Colonel Qaddafi and President Francois Mitterrand two weeks ago. At that time the Libyan leader reassured Mr. Mitterrand that the Libyans were leaving.

headline: Northeastern
abstract: Northeastern International Airways said it had laid off about 300 workers after a judge stopped the airline from renting five planes from Braniff Inc. Northeastern said the laid-off employees included pilots, flight attendants, mechanics and ticket agents. The layoffs reduced the airline's work force to 747, from a high of 1,444 in August, said a Northeastern spokesman, Wally Knief.

headline: Iran Now Puts Toll at 7 In Attack on Gulf Tanker
abstract: Iran said today that the death toll from the Iraqi air attack on the supertanker World Knight on Monday had risen to seven and that two of eight wounded crewmen were in critical condition in a Teheran hospital.   The Iranian national press agency report received in London said the wounded crewmen, who were taken by helicopter to Teheran's Motahhari Hospital, were suffering from severe burns and most of them were unable to speak.

headline: CONOVER TO ACT ON BANK UNITS
abstract: C. Todd Conover, the Comptroller of the Currency, said today that, because the 98th Congress had failed to act on the controversy over ''non-bank banks,'' he would begin acting on applications for limited-service, interstate banking offices within the next few weeks.    Other financial officials said Mr. Conover would probably not act before Election Day, Nov. 6, to avoid any risk of putting the Administration on the defensive in the campaign.    Banks are not allowed to open branches in states other than where they are chartered. To avoid falling within the statutory definition of a ''bank,'' the facilities proposed would either not take deposits or not make commercial loans.

headline: Iran Presses Charge Of Red Cross Spying
abstract: Iran published documents today that it said supported its accusations against the International Committee of the Red Cross of espionage and of violating its traditional neutrality.   Kamal Kharazi, head of Iran's War Information Bureau, also confirmed that six Iraqi prisoners of war died in a clash at a camp at Gorgan in northern Iran last month.

headline: MURDOCH BUYS 12 ZIFF PUBLICATION
abstract: Rupert Murdoch yesterday announced his purchase of the 12 trade publications of the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company for $350 million.     Acquiring the publications, which primarily deal with the travel and aviation industries, further diversifies Mr. Murdoch's American media holdings of daily newspapers and magazines.   The sale announcement came one day after CBS Inc. said it would acquire Ziff-Davis's 12 consumer magazines for $362.5 million, believed to be the highest price every paid for a group of magazines. The total price realized by Ziff-Davis exceeds estimates made when the 24 publications were put up for sale last month.

headline: SPY PHOTOS' SALE LEADS TO ARREST
abstract: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it had arrested a United States naval analyst and charged him with selling classified satellite photographs of a Soviet ship to a British weekly defense publication.   A spokesman for the F.B.I. said Samuel Loring Morison, a civilian analyst at the Naval Intelligence Support Center in Suitland, Md., was arrested Monday evening at Dulles International Airport.   Mr. Morison, 40 years old, of Crofton, Md., is the grandson of Samuel Eliot Morison, a well-known naval historian. An affadavit filed in Federal Court in Maryland said Federal agents obtained evidence in the case by analyzing his office typewriter ribbon to decipher a letter he had written to a British editor.

headline: State Bonds for Syracuse Hospital
abstract: A $37.4 million bond issue of the New York State Dormitory Authority, on behalf of the Crouse Irving Memorial Hospital, Syracuse, was tentatively offered yesterday with a maximum yield of 10 1/2 percent for bonds due in 2014 through underwriters led by L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin. For shorter-term maturities, yields ranged from 7.5 percent for bonds due in 1988 to 9.75 percent in 1999 and 10 1/4 percent in 2004.

headline: Bethlehem Mines
abstract: More than 900 coal miners will be out of work Friday when a mine and two repair shops in the Bethlehem Mines Corporation's Cambria division shut down, company officials said. Mine 33 and the Conemaugh and Mine 32 repair shops will close indefinitely, Art Roth, a company spokesman, said.

headline: Nigeria Signs Deal To Buy 12 Soviet MIG's
abstract: The Nigerian Government has signed an agreement to buy 12 MIG-21B jet fighters from the Soviet Union.

headline: SOVIET JEWS IN ISRAEL SPLIT ON U.S. RADIO PLAN
abstract: A United States request for permission to set up a transmitter in Israel to relay Voice of America broadcasts to the Soviet Union has set off a debate here among Soviet Jewish emigres.    Some emigres said they feared Moscow would retaliate against Jews in the Soviet Union who want to come to Israel. Others argued for the transmitter, saying the only way to get anything from Moscow was by assertiveness.   The Israeli Government has not replied to the State Department's application, but the Minister of Communications, Amnon Rubenstein, said the Government could not refuse, considering Israel's dependence on Washington for economic survival. ''Beggars can't be choosers,'' the minister said.

headline: WALL ST.'S MERCHANT BANKERS
abstract: After years of urging investors to take a stake in American business, a great many Wall Street firms have decided to follow their own advice.     Increasingly, investment bankers in the United States are acting like their merchant banking counterparts abroad. They are investing their firms' capital in the leveraged buyouts of established companies. They are funnelling seed money into venture capital fledglings. And they are becoming real estate tycoons in their own right.    Indeed, large firms such as Merrill Lynch & Company, the First Boston Corporation, Morgan Stanley & Company and Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., as well as a fast-growing number of smaller outfits, are going well beyond the traditional risk-taking of market making and underwriting, where, if firms buy a company's shares, they do not hold them long.

headline: NICARAGUA SAID TO GET SOVIET ATTACK COPTERS
abstract: Nicaragua has received a number of Soviet-built attack helicopters in recent days, a senior Administration official said Tuesday night. He said the White House viewed their delivery as a ''very serious development.''     In addition, Administration officials said they were concerned about a Soviet freighter apparently headed for Nicaragua that intelligence reports indicated was carrying crates that could contain MIG fighter aircraft.

headline: Paiute Oil Filing
abstract: The Paiute Oil and Mining Corporation said it had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

headline: U.S.-ISRAELI TALKS TO STRESS ECONOMY
abstract: The Reagan Administration plans to hold detailed talks next week with Prime Minister Shimon Peres and other senior Israeli officials on ways of dealing with serious problems in Israel's economy, a senior Administration official said today.    Mr. Peres, who became the head of a national unity Government last month, has already begun an austerity drive in Israel to bring down inflation, which is running at more than 400 percent a year. He has said Israel will look for long-term American help in its efforts toward economic recovery.   But before Mr. Peres's arrival on Monday for three days of talks that will include a White House meeting on Tuesday, Administration officials said today that there were no plans for any announcements of stepped-up American aid, beyond the $2.6 billion for the current fiscal year just approved by Congress.

headline: U.S. LONE DISSENTER IN U.N. VOTE ON LISTING OF RESTRICTED PRODUCTS
abstract: Over the sole objection of the United States, the United Nations General Assembly voted today to continue to publish and to expand a directory listing 500 potentially dangerous products that are banned, restricted or have failed to win approval in any one of 60 countries.    After a debate that generated considerable controversy in the last week, the Assembly vote was 147 to 1.    A United States delegate said the American vote reflected the Reagan Administration's belief that the $89,000 expenditure on the publication was ''wasteful'' because the information was generally available elsewhere, although not all in one place.   The delegate, Dennis C. Goodman, said the United States agreed in principle with the idea of protecting one country from products restricted by another, adding, ''We are more open on this subject than anyone else.''

headline: POPE AUTHORIZES LIMITED USE OF LATIN MASS BANNED IN '63
abstract: The Vatican announced today that Pope John Paul II would allow limited use of the Latin- only Tridentine Mass, which was banned worldwide two decades ago.   However, the Pope imposed restrictions that prohibit regular parish use of the mass, in which the priest does not face the congregation and the laity has no part in reading the Bible, the anouncement said.   The Tridentine Mass, established by Pope Pius V in 1570, was banned in 1963 by the Second Vatican Council of 1962- 65 in an effort to modernize the Roman Catholic liturgy and allow more participation and understanding of the mass by the congregation.

headline: Indonesia Raises Official Toll To 18 Dead in a Moslem Riot
abstract: The Indonesian Government has doubled the official death toll to 18 in a Moslem riot in northern Jakarta last month, and has blamed agitation by extremists.

headline: Danube Dam Protested
abstract: More than 14,000 people took to the streets of Vienna today to protest construction of a dam on the Danube that they say will destroy one of Europe's last primeval forests, the Auwald.

headline: Thousand Trails
abstract: Thousand Trails Inc.'s stock plunged after the company said that preliminary talks on its possible acquisition had been terminated. In over-the-counter trading yesterday, Thousand Trails fell $7.625, to $16.625, on a volume of 726,200 shares. The company, a Seattle-based outdoor recreation concern, said last week that it was holding talks with a suitor it did not identify.

headline: Deere-Sperry Pact
abstract: Deere & Company, a major maker of farm and construction machines, signed an agreement valued at about $90 million annually to purchase construction machines and farm implements from the Sperry Corporation's New Holland subsidiary, industry sources said. New Holland reportedly agreed separately to buy all of its diesel engines used to assemble self-propelled harvester combines from Deere.

headline: ALLIED: CENTER OF ATTENTION
abstract: The name of the Allied Corporation, which swallowed the Bendix Corporation last year in perhaps the wildest and woolliest of takeover battles, crops up often when Wall Street professionals start to spin acquisition stories.    According to analysts, recent rumor has had it that Allied was looking at the Control Data Corporation, that the Signal Companies was going to buy Allied or that Signal and Allied were putting together a consortium to go after the ITT Corporation.    Allied has also been mentioned in other people's battles. It was rumored to be a suitor this year for the St. Regis Company, before Champion International made its proposal, and for the Gulf Oil Company, before the Standard Oil Company of California took it.    Then, last month came the report that Edward L. Hennessy Jr., Allied's highly visible chairman and chief executive, had approached the United Technologies Corporation several times this year to suggest a takeover of Allied by United Technologies.

headline: Economic Scene ; Reagan's Tax Strategy
abstract: With the Presidential election just two and a half weeks away, signs are increasing that the United States economy is slowing down faster than most economists expected.   Industrial production fell six-tenths of 1 percent in September, the first drop since the end of the recession in November 1982. The Commerce Department also revised the gain in August down to one- tenth of 1 percent.   Interest rates are moving downward. Housing starts rose last month, but applications for building permits fell. Britain's cut in oil prices by $1.35 a barrel seems likely to push energy output down both here and abroad.

headline: U.S. GROUPS HELPING GET OUT THE VOTE IN GRENADA
abstract: Two Washington groups, one closely associated with the Republican Party and the other with the A.F.L.-C.I.O., have contributed more than $25,000 for campaigns to encourage Grenadians to vote in elections Monday, according to group officials here and in Washington.   Partly as a result of these campaigns, a high turnout of 80 to 85 percent of the 48,000 registered voters is expected in the elections, the first the island has held in eight years.    Foreign diplomats and many Grenadians say the main beneficiaries are expected to be members of a centrist coalition party that is favored by the Reagan Administration and the leaders of many neighboring islands.    No reliable polls have been conducted, but many diplomats and Grenadians say they expect the coalition, the New National Party, to win a majority of the 15 seats in the House of Parliament that are being contested. But members of the three other competing parties and four independents say they remain optimistic and some analysts say there is a slim possibility that a coalition may emerge.

headline: Iran Says It Seized an Agent Of Iraq With Explosives in Car
abstract: A man described as an Iraqi agent was arrested after parking an explosives- laden car outside a mosque in Teheran, Iran's capital, the official Iranian press agency reported today.    The agency, monitored on Cyprus, quoted a statement by the Iranian Information Ministry as saying that the car was packed with 200 pounds of high explosives and was parked outside the Imam Khomeini Mosque, next to a bazaar.

headline: Pakistanis Say Afghans Are Massing on Border
abstract: Afghanistan has concentrated troops on its border with Pakistan's southwestern province of Baluchistan, the Pakistan Press International news agency reported today.   The report, carried by the Government-controlled Pakistan Times and other daily newspapers, also spoke of ''intensive Afghan military activity'' in border areas of Afghanistan's southern province of Kandahar.   No official confirmation of the report was immediately available, but the Soviet press agency Tass said Afghan troops had eliminated several groups of anti-Government rebels in regions bordering Pakistan.

headline: U.S. Seeks More Data On Rolm-I.B.M. Deal
abstract: The Justice Department yesterday requested more information about the proposed acquisition of the Rolm Corporation by the International Business Machines Corporation, a move that could delay the $1.25 billion acquisition.     The Justice Department, which must approve the merger under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act of 1976, made its request on the last day possible under the act. Had it not acted yesterday, the acquisition would have been approved.

headline: PACT GETS MIXED RESPONSE IN CHILE AND ARGENTINA
abstract: Details of a Vatican-mediated border treaty between Chile and Argentina have been made public in the two countries, prompting mixed reactions.   The response ranged from lukewarm acceptance from opposition politicians to condemnation from nationalists who accused the Governments of selling out.    The terms of the treaty, published Friday, were initialed in the Vatican on Thursday.

headline: FORMER GRENADIAN ENVOY APPEALS FOR U.S. PULLOUT
abstract: The former Ambasssador of Grenada to the Organization of American States appealed yesterday for the withdrawal of American and other foreign troops from the Caribbean island and the ''restoration of normalcy'' based on justice and sovereignty.     Now head of a group known as the Grenada Foundation, former Ambassador Dessima Williams declared that what the Reagan Administration termed a rescue mission to Grenada last year was an invasion and denounced the continued ''U.S. occupation'' of the island.    Ambassador Williams presented a report entitled ''Grenada One Year After'' at a news conference at the Omni Hotel in Manhattan. The conference was called in response to a ceremony held by President Reagan yesterday to mark the anniversary of the United States invasion of Grenada.

headline: G.E. Contract
abstract: The General Electric Company's Space Systems division received a $423 million contract from the Air Force for six communications satellites as part of the Defense Satellite Communications System III Program, the Defense Department said.

headline: Results Mixed for Tool Orders
abstract: United States machine tool orders, a gauge of business plans to increase production, rose 40 percent in October, to $283.5 million, from $202.6 million a year earlier, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association reported yesterday. But the figure was down nine-tenths of 1 percent from September's level of $286.2 million.

headline: CLOSING OF NEWSPAPER IN MANILA IS REVERSED
abstract: The Philippine Supreme Court today condemned the 1982 closing of an opposition newspaper and ordered the military to return all seized items to the publisher.   In a 12-0 ruling, described by opposition lawyers as a rebuff to President Ferdinand E. Marcos, the high court did not specifically say the closing of the newspaper We Forum was illegal.

headline: Key Portion Sold Of Gulf Trade Unit
abstract: The Gulf Oil Corporation said it had sold the principal trading business of the Gulf Oil Trading Company.

headline: People
abstract: *  Ben Benya has joined Carlson, Liebowitz & Olshever, Los Angeles, as a senior vice president, media director.     *  Yustin Wallrapp appointed senior vice president/director of public relations at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston.     *  Nan Elmore named advertising director for Record magazine.

headline: More Jobless in France
abstract: France's unemployment rate edged up to 10.2 percent in October from 10.1 percent the previous month, the Labor Ministry said today. The agency said the number of unemployed people, adjusted for seasonal variations, rose to 2,467,300. That was up three-tenths of a percent from the previous month and 16.4 percent from October 1983.

headline: NEW ERA IN SERVICE EXPORTS
abstract: Buried in the trade bill that President Reagan is expected to sign in the next few days are several provisions that experts say mark a coming of age for service exports. The bill gives services, long the poor cousins of goods in international commerce, equal status in several critical areas.   The provisions in the bill, and path- breaking discussions that the United States is holding with Israel and Canada to liberalize trade in services bilaterally, are viewed as a breakthrough for service exporters. They have been lobbying hard for the changes.   ''Over the next three years we'll see more bilateral agreements on services, as with Israel. In the longer term, three to five years, there'll either be new codes or changes in the codes or new agreements on the multilateral front,'' said Harry Freeman, a senior vice president of American Express, a major trader in services.

headline: Bank Rates Mostly Down
abstract: Continuing a three-week downward trend, average annual yields on all but two deregulated accounts declined in the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.   Although two products - one-year and two-and-a-half-year certificates of deposit - showed slightly better yields, the yields on other deregulated accounts continued to slide further, said Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN PRODUCTS FOR THE AGED; MARKETING WITH SENSITIVITY
abstract: MARKETING to older consumers is a Catch 22 situation.  ''We're trying to say that older people are just like everybody else,'' said Dennis R. LaBuda, an executive with the American Association of Retired Persons. Yet older people often do have physical limitations. And non-age-related products - home appliances, dinnerware, even breakfast cereals - as well as items designed with older customers in mind can miss the mark for reasons other than intrinsic value.

headline: CONTINENTAL BANK'S STOCK
abstract: LOTS of stock market players want the big play, and with turnarounds such as Chrysler and International Harvester in mind, apparently they are now looking at Continental Illinois, the big Chicago bank rescued from failure last summer by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. But some analysts think buyers are being premature in such enthusiasm, if not misguided.   In particular, analysts are skeptical about the current price of the so-called new Continental. Its stock began trading late last month on a when- issued basis, with certificates deliverable after they become valid, and has gone as high as $7.25. Yesterday it closed at $6.375, unchanged.

headline: American Vision
abstract: A proposed sale of 50.1 percent of the shares outstanding of American Vision Centers Inc. to Channel Industries Ltd. has been terminated, the companies said.

headline: Storage Technology
abstract: The Storage Technology Corporation reported a third-quarter loss of $64.7 million, compared with a loss of $5.2 million in the third quarter last year. The company, which filed for protection under the Federal Bankruptcy Code earlier this month, had revenues of $145.5 million for the quarter, up 20.8 percent from revenues of $120.4 million for the third quarter last year. The maker of data storage devices for large computers had been one of the more spectacular success stories of the computer industry with annual sales at one time of $1 billion, but it faltered as competition grew more intense.

headline: WEST BANK SCHOOL CLOSED BY ISRAELIS
abstract: The Israeli military authorities today ordered a West Bank university shut down until Monday after three days of intermittent campus rioting.    The disturbances at Bethlehem University were touched off by a rocket attack on an Arab bus in Jerusalem Sunday that killed one passenger and injured 11.

headline: SOVIET SAID TO DEPLOY A NEW MISSILE
abstract: Western intelligence analysts say they have received reports that the Soviet Union may have begun deploying a new land-based intercontinental ballistic missile comparable to the United States Minuteman.     The analysts say that according to the reports, which they said came from a variety of sources, the missile, known as the SS-25, is being installed in the western military districts of the Soviet Union.    According to a senior European intelligence source, the SS-25's are being deployed among established sites for SS- 20's, which are medium-range missiles. The SS-25, like the SS-20, is a mobile missile. and some intelligence sources say its deployment would increase the likelihood that the Soviet long-range missile arsenal would survive an attack.

headline: Foreign Investment Declines
abstract: Foreign investment in the United States declined in 1983, for the second consecutive year, restrained by sluggish economies abroad, high interest rates and the strong dollar, the Commerce Department said today.   In an annual report, the department identified 751 foreign direct investment transactions in 1983, down from 913 in 1982.

headline: Citgo Petroleum
abstract: The Citgo Petroleum Corporation cut the price it will pay for West Texas Intermediate crude oil, the most common grade in the United States, by 85 cents, to $26.90 a barrel.

headline: PUNITIVE COSTS: INSURANCE ISSUE
abstract: UNION CARBIDE, the owner of the plant in Bhopal, India, whose gas leak last week killed 2,000 or more people and injured thousands of others, has said that it has adequate insurance to compensate all the victims. But the company still faces a serious financial threat - huge punitive damage awards.    As the term implies, punitive damages are intended to punish the maker of a faulty product who has recklessly disregarded safety. And traditionally, courts have felt that to protect the public, they must forbid insurance against punitive damages.

headline: Editor From New York Goes to Ireland Digest
abstract: The traditional dream of the big city newspaperman who has spent a lifetime meeting unremitting daily deadlines has been the editorship of a small-town weekly. Martin O'Shea, after spending a majority of his 50 years in the man-eating New York milieu, is giving it a try, but with a twist.

headline: Unions Consider Frontier Buyout
abstract: Preliminary talks between Frontier Airlines' union representatives and management are contining on plans for the employees to buy out the financially troubled airline. Lorraine Loflin, chairman of the Denver local of the Association of Flight Attendants and spokesman for a coalition of five unions, said a price had not been set.

headline: Agricultural Options Set
abstract: Farmers and ranchers will have a new marketing tool available on Tuesday when trading in options on agricultural futures opens at five commodity exchanges.   Final approval for establishing such contracts was given today by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: A $75 million issue of Hawaii general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 7.4 percent for bonds due in 1987, to 9.2 percent in 1994 and 10.3 percent in 2004, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.    The bonds were rated Aa by Moody's and AA by Standard & Poor's. Analysts at S.& P. noted that the state had an estimated general fund balance of $105 million for the year ended June 30, with an $84 million balance projected for the current year.

headline: AFTER A BUYING SPREE, CAN HE MOVE THE COMPANY AHEAD?
abstract: VEVEY, Switzerland    Last September, Helmut Maucher,   chief executive of Nestle S.A.,   the Swiss-based food giant, stunned the business world with his rapid-fire move to acquire the Carnation Company, the profitable American food concern. In an intense three-week period, the chief executive initiated negotiations from Switzerland, flew to New York to assemble a massive financing package, dispatched his top subordinate to hammer out details with Carnation's board and chief stockholders, and then flew to Brazil himself to line up support of Nestle's own board, which happened to be gathered in Sao Paulo, upholding a Nestle tradition of meeting once a year in a major overseas market.    Back in Vevey less than a month after it all began, Mr. Maucher announced Nestle's spectacular offer to pay $83 apiece for Carnation's 34.8 million outstanding shares, in what would be - once the Federal Trade Commission approves the deal - the largest non-oil merger in American corporate history.   ''He's a long-distance runner, but the Carnation deal showed he can sprint when he has to,'' commented a banker at Frankfurt's Dresdner Bank, who has observed Mr. Maucher over the years.

headline: KOHL AIDE TO REPLACE HOUSE SPEAKER LINKED TO PAYOFF
abstract: A close aide to Chancellor Helmut Kohl was designated today to become the next Speaker of the West German Parliament, succeeding Rainer Barzel, who resigned Thursday after being accused of receiving more than a half million dollars in payoffs from the giant Flick concern.    The new Speaker, Philipp Jenninger, 52 years old, is a minister of state charged with handling relations with East Germany.    The selection of Mr. Jenninger by the governing Christian Democratic Party enabled Mr. Kohl to avoid a Cabinet shuffle that would have arisen if he had picked an incumbent minister. Another leading candidate had been Heinrich Windelen, the Minister for Intra-German Relations.

headline: Coca-Cola Opens 3d Plant in China
abstract: The Coca-Cola Export Corporation, a division of the Coca-Cola Company of Atlanta, said it had opened its third bottling plant in China.

headline: GTE Accepts
abstract: Phone Decree STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 21   (AP) - The GTE Corporation   today accepted a judge's consent decree that requires the   company to keep its long-distance and local telephone networks separate in return for   the acquisition of what are now   called GTE Sprint and GTE   Spacenet. Judge Harold H. Greene of   the United States District Court   in Washington then signed the   decree, which he issued Dec.

headline: 'Personal Loss' for Galbraith
abstract: John Kenneth Galbraith, a former American Ambassador to India, said today that he felt a ''personal loss'' at the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India. ''My first reaction is one of personal loss,'' said Mr. Galbraith, who met and became friends with Mrs. Gandhi in 1956 before she was elected Prime Minister.

headline: Magazine Ad Pages Up
abstract: Advertising revenues for magazine members of the Publishers Information Bureau have exceeded $4 billion this year. And that is just through November, so there is still a month to go. Total ad pages for members of the bureau were up 2.2 percent in November, from the same month last year, to 15,631, while revenues climbed 12 percent, to $503.7 million.

headline: Oil and Supplies
abstract: To the Editor:     ''Reshaping O.E.C.D.'s Oil-Sharing Plan,'' (Nov. 4) is based on a fundamental misconception about the role of the International Energy Agency in an oil-supply emergency. The authors wrongly state that the governing board of the I.E.A. ''would determine price through a weighted voting system that favors crude-poor countries.''

headline: Fuels Post
abstract: The Synthetic Fuels Corporation put one of its new directors, Representative Tom Corcoran, on the payroll today at $83,300 a year by appointing him acting vice chairman, a new post.   Mr. Corcoran, a Republican from Illinois who lost a primary challenge to Senator Charles H. Percy last spring and could not run for another term in the House, thus assumes a major role at the organization he has frequently criticized. It is expected that Mr. Corcoran will be elected vice chairman in January.

headline: U.N. Calls for Renewal Of Talks Over Falklands
abstract: The General Assembly approved a resolution today calling on Britain and Argentina to resume negotiations over the Falkland Islands.

headline: U.S. SAYS IT WOULD HELP ALLIES REPEL SANDINISTAS
abstract: The Department of Defense said today that the United States would respond ''with whatever assistance was necessary'' if Honduras or El Salvador asked for military help in repelling an invasion from Nicaragua.    At the same time, a White House official drew a parallel between a buildup of military forces in Nicaragua and the deployment of Soviet forces, including nuclear missiles, to Cuba in 1962, which he said created a permanent Soviet military presence in the Western Hemisphere.    In a briefing for reporters at the Pentagon, the chief spokesman, Michael I. Burch, was asked whether the United States would fulfill treaty commitments under the Rio pact by sending troops to help defend Honduras or El Salvador against a Nicaraguan invasion.

headline: Oil Venture Set in Sudan
abstract: The Sudanese Government and a company owned by the Saudi billionaire Adnan Khashoggi announced plans today for a joint venture to explore and develop oil in the Sudan.    The Sudan and Mr. Khashoggi's Triad Group will form the National Oil Company of the Sudan, which will manage the country's oil and gas holdings, Triad said.

headline: Seagram Profit Edges Up 1.7% By The Associated Press The Seagram Company Ltd.
abstract: said yesterday that net income   for its third quarter, ended Oct.   31, edged up 1.7 percent despite   the declining profitability of   the distiller's spirits and wine   operation.

headline: Oxford Dons Are Assets To Nixon-Era 'Plumber'
abstract: Ten years ago, the outlook was not bright for David R. Young Jr. A promising New York lawyer, he had gone to work in the Nixon White House as an aide to Henry A. Kissinger and had ended up as one of the co-leaders of the group known as ''the plumbers.''    As part of the investigation of the Watergate scandal, the House Judiciary Committee found that Mr. Young and Egil Krogh Jr. had overseen the burglary of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist, Dr. Lewis J. Fielding, in retaliation for Mr. Ellsberg's leaking of the Pentagon Papers, and there were accusations of other illegal activities as well. Although he had played only a bit part in the drama, Mr. Young's name was mud in many American legal and political circles.

headline: BRIEFS ;  Debt
abstract: *  Chock Full o'Nuts opened a $20 million credit with National Westminster Bank U.S.A.
