Common Stock     *  Commercial Federal Corp.  is offering 1,761,442 shares of common stock at $8.50 a share, through underwriters led by E. F. Hutton & Co.     *  Western Health Plans filed for an initial public offering of 875,000 common shares, through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.      Ratings     *  Freeport-McMoran Inc.'s convertible sinking fund debentures due in 2014 were assigned a rating of Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service.

headline: U.S. ANGOLAN TALKS UNDER WAY
abstract: The United States has sent an official to Angola for talks on southern African issues and on the withdrawal of Cuban troops, the State Department said today in Washington.   Flying here for a meeting, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said ''there certainly is some motion'' in southern Africa, but he cautioned that ''we don't believe it is wise to say there is any major development until you have got that development.''   The American official, Frank G. Wisner, who is a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, flew to Luanda to discuss the Angolan response to proposals in August by Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs.

headline: 5 Japanese Crewmen Lost
abstract: Five Japanese crewmen were missing after their vessel collided with an Indian- registered cargo ship in rough seas off central Japan today, the Maritime Safety Agency said. Agency officials said a helicopter had rescued one of the crew of six Japanese aboard the 496-ton Tensho Maru after the ship sank off Izu Peninsula, southwest of Tokyo. All 49 Indians aboard the 14,261-ton Andhra Pradesh were safe, they said.

headline: BANKERS TRUST SEEKS FED BACKING FOR COMMERCIAL PAPER UNIT
abstract: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation plans to ask the Federal Reserve Board if it can transfer the bank's commercial paper activities into a non-bank subsidiary, a bank spokesman said yesterday. The move appears to be an attempt to establish a backup defense in case Bankers Trust loses a longstanding legal battle over its commercial paper role.     And it follows by only one day the news that Citicorp is seeking a similar go-ahead from the Fed on the placing of securities activities in a nonbank subsidiary.    ''This will give us additional options for the future,'' Thomas Parisi, the Bankers Trust spokesman, said. The application, which the bank expects to file early next year, will ask the Fed to permit the bank to transfer its commercial paper activity to the BT Commercial Corporation, a unit now engaged in asset-based lending.

headline: INDIAN MOSLEMS FEAR MOBS MIGHT PICK THEM NEXT
abstract: Many Moslems in this southern Indian city say they fear that widespread attacks against Sikhs in the aftermath of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's assassination are an indication of a larger problem. They say this is the inability of the Hindu-dominated Government to rein in effectively the right-wing Hindu groups that are openly challenging Moslems and other minorities in many parts of India.     ''Our hearts go out to our Sikh brothers,'' said Abdul Aziz, who heads an organization here called Jammat- e-Islami. ''But if one minority group is subjected to this kind of terror, then can other minorities in this vast land truly be safe?''

headline: RETAIL SALES OFF IN OCTOBER
abstract: Retail sales dipped one-tenth of 1 percent in October, the third monthly decline since June, the Commerce Department reported today.    The decline raised concern about how good a Christmas merchants would have, with some analysts saying the economy is mired in a period of sluggish growth.   The drop in retail sales from September, to a seasonally adjusted $107.7 billion, would have been a full 1 percent had it not been for the first increase in auto sales since June.   Since a June peak, retail sales dropped 1.7 percent in July and one-tenth of 1 percent in August before rising in September. However, the department revised the September figure today to show a 1.2 percent increase, less than the 1.6 percent gain originally reported.

headline: RESEARCHER AS AGENCY THERAPIST
abstract: ROBERT J. WERLIN equates an advertising agency with the human mind.    The creative people are the id: artistic but not overly rational. The account management folks are the super ego: always conscious of what should be done, the rules.   The two forces are at war, and in between is the ego, trying to bring them together.

headline: Aquino Case Is Sent To Tribunal for Review
abstract: The case against several members of the Philippine armed forces, including Gen. Fabian C. Ver, the Chief of Staff, for plotting to kill the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. was handed to a Government ombudsman today for investigation and prosecution.    The head of the ombudsman's office appointed a three-member tribunal that will review the findings of the citizen commission's two reports and decide what indictments, if any, should be handed down.

headline: SHAKEOUT IN COMPUTER STORES
abstract: The corner of Devonshire and Water Streets, in the midst of this city's cramped financial district, is a kind of heaven for the computer shopper.    Computerland and Businessland are at the end of one block, across a narrow street that wends haphazardly toward Boston Harbor. In the other direction, the Wang Computer Center is two doors away from a computer store called Execom. At the corner, in an old iron-facade building, stands the I.B.M. Product Center, and farther on are three more stores selling personal and small business computers.   Supplies Are Abundant    About a dozen computer retailers jam within four blocks of the Old State House, the site of the Boston Massacre. The historical precedent is not lost on the dealers here. With computers suddenly abundant on dealers' shelves and with price-cutting rampant, nearly everyone expects several competitors to be mowed down within a year.

headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS ; Uncertainty on OPEC Sends Oil Prices Down
abstract: Prices of crude oil, heating oil and gasoline fell to new contract lows in trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange today, reflecting anticipation that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will be unable to regain control of the oil pricing system at its year-end meeting in Geneva. In related developments, the British pound fell to new lows at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and precious metals were flat.   One of OPEC's key goals, narrowing the differential between the price of its best grades and its lesser grades of crude oil, would be insufficient to relieve the pressure that has undercut the group's pricing system, according to Andrew Lebow, a petroleum analyst in New York with Shearson Lehman/ American Express.

headline: Laura Ashley
abstract: To the Editor:    The article, ''Laura Ashley: Old Style, Modern Profits'' (Oct. 28) raises speculation about the efficacy of advertising. In contrast to ''a national average of $155 a square foot (in sales) for all specialty stores,'' these stores ''average $500 a square foot, with some stores peaking at $1,000 a square foot.''

headline: ;  Apollo to Mullen
abstract: Mullen Advertising in Beverly Farms, Mass., has become agency for Apollo Computer of Chelmsford, Mass. The agency said the billings would be between $3 million and $6 million. The client, a maker of 32-bit work stations for the scientific and engineering communities, formerly had its account at Clarke Goward Fitts for about nine months.

headline: VIOLENCE IN INDIA: SEVERAL INTERTWINED ROOTS
abstract: Students of Indian culture see complex motivations behind the waves of violence that periodically rock this society.    Such an outbreak of killing in several cities followed the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi last month. That episode was finally brought under control by the police and military, but not before more than 1,000 people were slain, according to newspaper estimates.    It does not take a shocking event like the slaying of Mrs. Gandhi, India's Prime Minister for 15 of the last 18 years, to set off a major outburst of killing, looting and burning. In the past, relatively trivial incidents have set whole sections of India aflame.

headline: Gavilan Filing
abstract: The Gavilan Computer Corporation, a closely held manufacturer of lap-model personal computers, said that it filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws in San Jose, Calif.

headline: Market Place; Behind Revco's Profits Setback
abstract: REVCO D.S. INC., operator of the nation's largest drugstore chain, may be suffering from too much diversification. The company announced on Tuesday that the earnings prognosis for its second fiscal quarter was indeed unhealthy.   Revco, which has more than 1,800 stores and annual sales of nearly $2.3 billion, said it expected earnings in the three months ended Nov. 17 to plunge 45 percent because of a number of factors, including the cost of opening new stores, slower growth in sales and increased interest costs.   But analysts agree that the greatest contributor to the financial ills of the company, which is based in Twinsburg, Ohio, was the unexpectedly poor performance of its Odd Lot Trading Company subsidiary, which it acquired last May.

headline: U.S. SAID TO STOP LIBYA NUCLEAR DEAL
abstract: The Reagan Administration appears to have blocked an attempt by Libya to acquire nuclear expertise from Belgium and other West European countries, according to diplomats and officials involved in the negotiations.    Under United States pressure, these informants said, Belgium has agreed privately not to accept a $1 billion Libyan contract under which it was asked to help the Soviet Union with the construction of two nuclear-power reactors in Libya. Other West European countries with the necessary expertise have also said informally that they would not take over the contract Belgium has turned down, these sources said.    Although Libya says it wants these reactors for peaceful purposes, the Reagan Administration strongly opposed any Western aid for the project, diplomats said. This is partly because of its general hostility towards the Libyan Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, which it accuses of fostering terrorism and subversion, and also because it fears Libya might use the reactors to develop a nuclear weapon, these sources said.

headline: French Couple Reported Held in New Caledonia
abstract: Two French vacationers are being held hostage by an anti-independence group in the French Pacific territory of New Caledonia, the police said today.

headline: Warner-Lambert Gain
abstract: The Warner-Lambert Company said today that its net income for the third quarter rose 12.3 percent, to $56.6 million, or 71 cents a share, from $50.4 million, or 63 cents, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales increased 3 percent, to $798.5 million, from $773.2 million. The income gain resulted from an improvement in the company's tax rate through Federal legislation enacted during the period, and by strong performances by its prescription drug and confectionery businesses, the company said.

headline: DEAK & CO. FILES FOR CHAPTER 11
abstract: Deak & Company, the holding company for one of the country's oldest and largest foreign exchange and precious metal dealers with branches worldwide, surprised the investment community yesterday by filing to reorganize under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code.    R. Leslie Deak, the company's president, described the filing as the result of a ''classic run'' on the company's Latin American offices that caused a severe liquidity squeeze.   Two subsidiaries, Deak-Perera Wall Street Inc. and the Deak-Perera International Banking Corporation, also filed for bankruptcy.

headline: Hughes in Korean Deal
abstract: Hughes Helicopters Inc. has reached an agreement with Korean Air to import Korean-made parts for Hughes-designed helicopters beginning in 1985.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 12, 1984:  MONDAY Amer Brdcstg CosGifford-Hills & CoCompugraphic CorpMeredith CorpFischbach CorpZurn Ind  TUESDAY AMF IncMickelberry CorpFoote Cone & BeldRobertson (H H) CoHeileman (G) BrewSears Roebuck & CoHousehold IntlStaley (AE) MfgInter North IncTracor IncMcCermott IntlTyco Labs  WEDNESDAY Avnet IncMorse ShoeCBS IncNatl StandardCSX CorpRealty Refund TrColt IndusSafeguard Business SysCurrent Income ShsU S Air groupLouisiana Genl Svc   THURSDAY   Air Prdts ChemsFruehauf CorpAm South BncrptnGenl BancsharesBlair (John) & CoGreyhound CorpCarson Pirie ScottHalliburton CoChampion IntlInsilco CorpChesebrough-Pond'sLone Star IndusCombustion EngineManhattan IndusContinental CorpOgden CorpDresser IndusPerkin-ElmerFlorida ProgressSterling Bancorp  FRIDAY Amer SterilizerGlobal MarineBarnes GroupKan City South IndusCampbell SoupLevi Strauss & CoControl DataSouth Jersey IndusDonaldson CoTexas UtilsGeneral Electric

headline: Inmates on West Bank Give Up Hunger Strike
abstract: A 10-day hunger strike by 800 Palestinian inmates of a West Bank prison ended tonight after prisoners reached an agreement with jail officials over improvement of their conditions, a spokesman for the Israeli-run Jail Authority said.   The spokesman, Shimon Malka, said Minister of Police Haim Bar-Lev met representatives of the prisoners Monday and heard their complaints, which concerned the quality and quantity of food, overcrowding of cells and the amount of time spent in the fresh air.

headline: A Late Blue-Chip Rally Cuts Dow's Loss to 4.31
abstract: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in heavier trading, as year-end factors apparently outweighed favorable economic news.    At the close, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered those that rose by 963 to 621. Volume on the Big Board expanded to 101.3 million shares, from 93.2 million shares the day before.

headline: Tandem-S.E.C. Accord
abstract: Tandem Computers Inc. of Cupertino, Calif., said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Securities and Exchange Commission that ends an S.E.C. investigation in connection with the company's restatement of earnings for the fiscal year 1982.     The S.E.C. had accused Tandem and three officers of engaging in a scheme to overstate its earnings in an effort to show increased profitability.    The company and the three officers, while neither admitting nor denying allegations, consented to a judgment enjoining them from violations of Federal securities laws.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
abstract: A $400 million issue of New York City general obligation bonds, the largest such sale by the city since 1974, was tentatively offered yesterday through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The issue has a maximum yield of 11 percent for 10 7/8 percent bonds due in 2014, which were offered at a price of 98.9, or $989 per $1,000 bond.    For shorter maturities, yields ranged from 6 1/4 percent in 1985 to 9 percent in 1989, 10 percent in 1994, 10 3/4 percent in 1999, 10.93 percent in 2004 and 11 percent in 2005 through 2009.

headline: ESTRANGED DAUGHTER-IN-LAW CONDEMNS THE ASSASSINATION
abstract: Maneka Gandhi today condemned the assassination of her estranged mother- in-law, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, as a ''frightening act of violence.''   Maneka, who was married to Sanjay Gandhi, broke with the Prime Minister in 1982.

headline: Tax-Exempt Pattern Varies In the tax-exempt market, the pattern of rates was different from that in the Treasury sector, mostly because state and local governments unleashed a flood of new issues in the last quarter of the year.
abstract: In October and November, for example, yields on long- term tax-exempt bonds rose even though Treasury yields were falling. The Bond Buyer Index of long-term revenue bonds rose to 10.62 percent on Nov. 29, from 10.56 percent on Aug. 30, while 30-year Treasury bond yields fell to 11.42 percent, from 12.57 percent.

headline: A SCANDAL IN BONN CASTS A SOFT SHADOW ON MADRID
abstract: Spaniards call it the Flick case, and it can be viewed as a corruption scandal, cynical politics, overzealousness by the press or just a big national joke.   However it is viewed, the unsubstantiated allegations that Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez received a suitcase full of money from Flick, the West German industrial conglomerate, has angered, divided and entertained the country for more than a month.    And that the furor has been over a lot of smoke but little fire says much about the best and the worst of Spain's seven- year-old democracy.   ''Democracy here is still pending,'' said Eduardo Martin Toval, a spokesman for the governing Socialist Party, ''and all that is feeding leaks and rumors is not helping to resolve the problem.''

headline: Short-Term Rates In Slight Decline
abstract: Short-term interest rates fell slightly yesterday, while yields for notes and bonds rose modestly.     In light trading, prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose early in the day, dropped back to about unchanged by midday, and weakened in the late afternoon to close with declines of about 1/4 to 5/8 of a point.    The 12 1/2 percent bonds due in 2014, which are a frequently used trading vehicle for speculators, rose to as high as 101 23/32, but closed with an offered price of 100 7/8, down about 5/8 of a point, to yield 12.39 percent. Much of the late decline was in response to selling at the Chicago Board of Trade, where the December Treasury bond futures contract closed at 66 20/32, down from a high price earlier in the day of 67 9/32.

headline: Continental Group To Sell Georgia Mill
abstract: The Continental Group said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its bleached paperboard mill in Augusta, Ga., and related operations to the Federal Paper Board Company for about $305 million.   Continental said the sale includes four chip and saw mills, two folding carton plants and two paper-plate plants.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Bangladesh Lawyers Back National Strike
abstract: The Bangladesh Supreme Court Bar Association announced today that it had extended its ''support and solidarity'' to a national strike on Dec. 22 and 23 called by major opposition parties to force President H. M. Ershad to restore democracy.   Two opposition alliances called for the strike after a 24-hour work stoppage Saturday in which 30 people, including four policemen and six press photographers, were hurt.    The lawyers criticized what they described as a ''brutal attack by the police on the working journalists during the peaceful observance of'' the strike.

headline: Fake Apple Computers Lead to Indictment of 2
abstract: An indictment was unsealed yesterday charging two Silicon Valley computer importers with smuggling counterfeit Apple computers into the country, according to the United States Attorney's office in San Francisco.    The indictment, handed up Sept. 25, appears to mark the first time that Federal officials have brought criminal charges for violations of the copyright code. Until now, virtually every copyright action has taken the form of a civil suit, in which the copyright holder seeks damages for infringements.

headline: GRIM OUTLOOK FOR HUNGRY MOZAMBIQUE
abstract: In Inhaouza, a village on a dirt track even bumpier than the main track leading out of this provincial capital, Graca Alfandega said, ''Hunger has already entered this house.''    In the hut that she shares with four of her children, she showed the basket for the traditional staple food, millet. It contained only a dried, prune-like wild fruit that is a local staple for the bad season, when the last of the last harvest has been eaten and the new crop has not yet been reaped. This year it has not even been sown yet and there is nothing left in the village larders.

headline: PERES SAYS ISRAEL WILL DEFER ACTION ON REPORTED U.S. OFFER ON DEBT
abstract: Prime Minister Shimon Peres said today that the Government had decided for now against taking up what Israel has described as an American offer to defer a $500 million debt payment.    In a speech to Parliament in Jerusalem opening the winter session, Mr. Peres said that if there were no unforeseen economic developments, ''we shall be able to meet all our financial obligations on time, as we have done until now.''   The country's foreign-currency reserves have declined in the last few months to a level described as perilously low, a result of a run on the shekel by Israelis who anticipate a currency devaluation and of the payment of debts to the United States.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Delaware Hopes to End Use of Bond Certificates
abstract: The State of Delaware is continuing to press for the sale of its tax-exempt bonds through a book-entry system that would avoid the expense of issuing bonds in printed form.    Under a book-entry system, records of bond ownership and semi- annual interest payments are kept electronically.

headline: Santa Fe's Net Up a Bit
abstract: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation said today that its third-quarter results were virtually steady. The railroad holding company earned $137.4 million, or 73 cents a share, up slightly from $137.3 million, or 73 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose to $1.7 billion from $1.6 billion.

headline: Note Offering By Leader Federal
abstract: Leader Federal Savings and Loan Association, a Memphis thrift unit, offered $100 million of seven-year secured notes.

headline: OPEC Visit By Marc Rich
abstract: Marc Rich, the fugitive oil trader, made a cameo appearance today at the meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, but he refused to comment on tax-evasion charges pending against him in the United States.   It was Mr. Rich's first known appearance in a public forum in at least a year.

headline: West German Trade
abstract: West Germany's current account was balanced in September, in contrast to a revised deficit of 1.5 billion marks in August, the Government said today. Germany's current account - a measure of all international transactions in goods and services - posted a 700-million-mark deficit in September 1983. The mark is equal to 33 cents in United States currency.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Chief of Harrah's Unit Named by Holiday Inns
abstract: Philip G. Satre has been named president and chief executive of Harrah's Hotels and Casinos, the gambling subsidiary of Holiday Inns Inc.    Mr. Satre, 35, will assume his new position Monday, Holiday Inns said. The gambling subsidiary, which in 1983 accounted for 40 percent of Holiday Inns' profits, operates hotel-casinos in Atlantic City; Reno and Las Vegas, Nev., and Lake Tahoe, Calif.    He replaces Richard J. Goeglein, who became president and chief operating officer of Holiday Inns in September.

headline: RCA POSTS 28.9% GAIN IN QUARTER
abstract: The RCA Corporation, aided by strong gains by its electronics, broadcasting and transportation operations, said yesterday that its third- quarter earnings soared 28.9 percent on an 8.8 percent increase in sales.    RCA said that net income in the latest three months increased to $78 million, or 74 cents a share, from $60.5 million, or 53 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose to $2.47 billion from $2.27 billion.

headline: Economic Scene ; Is a Recession Coming in '85?
abstract: The huge budget deficit threatens to paralyze   fiscal policy after the election, no matter who   is elected. A recession could cause the deficit to soar to $300 billion to $400 billion; a deficit of such size would inhibit fiscal action to combat the recession by increasing spending or cutting taxes further. And fear of recession may prevent the White House and Congress from acting decisively to cut the budget deficit.    A steep United States recession would have dangerous implications internationally. It would cause a slowdown or reversal in foreign investment in this country, due to the combination of falling profits here and a falling dollar. The shrinking of capital flows would mean a shortage of funds to finance both the United States budget deficit, the trade deficit and private investment in new plant and equipment. The shortfall of savings from abroad would keep real interest rates high.

headline: P.L.O. FACTION PICKS JORDAN FOR KEY PARLEY
abstract: Al Fatah, the largest faction within the the Palestine Liberation Organization, has decided to override objections from P.L.O. rivals and hold a much-delayed meeting of the Palestine National Council here later this month, a senior aide to Yasir Arafat said today.    The aide said Amman had been chosen in an effort to end the inertia that he said was allowing Syrians to make efforts to control and reshape the P.L.O.    Syria, he said, has been ''blocking the door'' and trying ''to prepare a new P.L.O.''   ''We had to stop waiting and letting the Syrians advance,'' Khalil Wazir, who uses the code-name Abu Jihad and is the deputy commander of the P.L.O.'s forces, told reporters at his home in Amman today. ''They are,'' he said, ''trying to destroy the P.L.O. politically and militarily.'   Al Fatah, the largest and most powerful faction in the P.L.O., has quarreled with Damascus since last year, when Syria supported P.L.O. factions opposed to Mr. Arafats leadership and rebels within Al Fatah, when they tried to take over the P.L.O.  Syria later expelled Mr. Arafat and his followers from the country and from the Syrian-controlled areas of Lebanon, such as the Bekaa, Lebanon's eastern valley, where the rebellion against Mr. Arafat had begun.

headline: SCOVILL: STRENGTH IN DIVERSITY
abstract: Scovill Inc., which is now on center stage in Wall Street's latest takeover drama, was not always such a sought- after property.     The company had humble beginnings as a maker of brass buttons for Civil War uniforms. It spent a century as a brass fabricator in Waterbury, Conn., and a decade ago was floundering with others in the brass industry. It was then that Malcolm Baldrige, who is now Secretary of Commerce, shook it out of its lethargy and redirected it as a diversified manufacturer.

headline: DEPENDENCE ON AID IS VILLAIN
abstract: Infant bellies swollen by want and pale deserts haunted by thin- cloaked people and dead cattle: In Africa, the images seem to recur, cyclical emblems of dispair that bring stirrings of guilt to outsiders and then are forgotten until the next tragedy in a distant world.     When the images flicker and fade, the tragedies do not stop. Even aid from well-intentioned relief agencies and the concern of the West, some specialists say, are deepening the problem and leading to criticism by African Governments that aid projects are ill-conceived and sometimes reflect the commercial interests of donor nations.   Western consciences dictate that people should not be allowed to starve; but the specialists contend that by saving them, without finding a key to greater food production on fragile lands, too much pressure is placed on that land and it dies while dependence on outsiders increases.    300,000 Said to Die      Since the early 1970's, up to 300,000 people are said to have starved to death in Africa because of drought that first spurred international attention in the sub-Saharan region of Africa.

headline: LEBANON SUSPENDS TALKS WITH ISRAEL ON TROOP PULLOUT
abstract: The Lebanese Government, under fierce pressure from Islamic fundamentalists, announced today that it had suspended negotiations with Israel on a withdrawal of Israeli troops from southern Lebanon.     The talks, which had been expected to go on for months, had opened only last Thursday in Naqura, Lebanon, under United Nations auspices.    Arrests Are Cited    The Lebanese said the reason for the suspension was the Israeli arrest of 13 Shiite Moslem officials of the Amal militia, which has been in the forefront of armed resistance to the Israeli occupation of southern Lebanon. Lebanon said the talks could not be resumed until all the officials were freed.

headline: COLLAPSE OF DEAK & COMPANY
abstract: In the world of foreign exchange and precious metals, no name glitters like Deak-Perera.    Founded in 1939 by a Hungarian immigrant, Nicholas L. Deak, the company grew into prominence by making markets in currencies no one else would touch and in later years, by aggressively promoting private investment in gold. Today, it is the largest nonbank foreign exchange and precious metals operation in the United States.   Two much-less-prominent subsidiaries of Deak & Company, however, helped blacken the family's name and sour its fortunes. The two units, operating somewhat like banks, drew allegations from a Federal commission on organized crime that they had been used to launder tens of millions of dollars in drug money. It was these units and these allegations that drove parts of the Deak empire into bankruptcy court last Thursday, the company acknowledges. The Deaks have denied the allegations.

headline: HOTELS ARE HIT HARD AS TOURISTS SHUN HAITI
abstract: -AU-PRINCE, Haiti - In the last 18 months six tourist hotels here have closed and at least three others are in trouble with the banks, according to an official of Haiti's Hotel and Tourist Association.   A handful of hotels that have been aggressively catering to repeat business travelers have managed to operate at an average of about 40 percent capacity for the year, Joel Thebaud, the vice president of the Hotel and Tourist Association, said in an interview in September.   But, he said, most of the 35 or so others are barely surviving, with occupancies averaging 20 to 25 percent. A few hotels, he said, have gone weeks without a guest.

headline: Goldblatt Purchase
abstract: Household International Inc., based in Prospect Heights, Ill., announced that its merchandising subsidiary, Household Merchandising Inc., had agreed to sell its furniture operations to a unit of Goldblatt Brothers Inc. of Chicago. A spokesman for Goldblatt's said the purchase price was ''between $35 million and $40 million.'' According to a Household International statement, the furniture operations, with sales of $167 million in 1983, include 35 stores in four chains: Huffman-Koos in New Jersey and New York, Colby's in the Chicago area, Barker's in the Los Angeles area and American Furniture in the El Paso, Tex., area.

headline: Separatists Still Offering Talks on New Caledonia
abstract: Jean-Marie Tjibaou, leader of the separatists, said today that, despite the slaying of 10 Melanesians last week, including two of his brothers, he was willing to negotiate with the French.

headline: Swiss Trade Gap Wider
abstract: Switzerland's foreign trade deficit widened to 938 million francs, or about $384 million, in October, from 592 million francs in September and 488 million francs a year earlier, the Customs Office said today. It said imports totaled 6.632 billion francs, or about $2.72 billion, in October. Exports were 5.694 billion francs, or about $2.33 billion.

headline: IN MOSCOW, OPEN ARMS TO WAYWARD
abstract: For Turgenev, a Russian away from his homeland was like a slice cut off from the loaf.    The Russian word for the feeling is ''toska'' - melancholy, a longing. For those away from home, it is an anguished yearning for the motherland that, Russians say, few other people can appreciate.   Throughout history, Russians have left their homeland. By most accounts, few have escaped toska.

headline: Schlumberger Ltd.
abstract: Schlumberger Ltd.'s acquisition of Sedco Inc. has been completed, the companies said.

headline: HUSSEIN SCORNS ISRAELI CALL FOR TALKS AS A 'SUBTERFUGE'
abstract: King Hussein of Jordan said today that a recent Israeli call for Jordan and other Arab governments to join in peace negotiations was ''an exercise in subterfuge and deception.''     The King, speaking at the opening of the Jordanian Parliament's new session, indicated that he would refuse to join any negotiations until Israel demonstrated its ''seriousness'' about achieving peace in the Middle East.    Hussein, who was attired in formal military dress - a white jacket, red sash, ribbons and medals - also reiterated his disappointment with United States policy in the Middle East, which he said had been marked by ''procrastination and hesitancy'' and had ''provided Israel with further cause for intransigence.''    In his 40-minute speech, delivered before an audience that included some 90 members of Parliament and more than 300 diplomats, military officers, journalists and guests, the King also repeated his approval of the Soviet Union's call for an international peace conference on the Middle East, a proposal rejected by Israel and the United States, and again urged the holding of an Arab summit meeting.

headline: SHORT-TERM RATES OFF SLIGHTLY
abstract: Interest rates were mixed yesterday, as short-term rates fell slightly and note and bond yields rose.     The decline in short-term rates was linked to the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market, which fell to about 8 3/4 percent, from just under 9 percent the previous three business days.   Many analysts expect the overnight rate to fluctuate between 8 1/2 percent and 9 percent in coming days, down from the 9 1/2 percent level that prevailed in the two weeks ended Nov. 21, and well below the 11 1/2 percent level of August and much of September.    Note and Bond Rates    But in the note and bond markets, the lower Federal funds rate was not enough to lift prices and reduce yields.

headline: U.S. AIDES BROADEN WARNINGS TO NICARAGUA
abstract: Senior Reagan Administration officials, recalling the Monroe Doctrine, today broadened the assertion that United States security interests in the Western Hemisphere would be seriously threatened by the delivery of high-performance combat planes to Nicaragua.     The State Department spokesman, John Hughes, said, ''I don't think there is any question about the United States concern in such an area very close to our own borders. We have compelling national interests in that area.''

headline: A Dealer for Harvester Awaits Sale to Tenneco
abstract: For weeks Robert P. Corley, an International Harvester Company farm equipment dealer near Decatur in central Illinois, has heard rumors about the impending sale of Harvester's agricultural equipment division to Tenneco Inc.   Mr. Corley now awaits the official announcement of the transaction, expected today. Later this week, he will join other Harvester dealers at company-sponsored meetings in Dallas to learn the terms of the combination.

headline: THE COLLISION OF BULLS AND BEARS
abstract: IN a report issued early this month, Joseph C.   Generalis, vice president of technical analysis   at the First Boston Corporation, told clients that he was expecting a ''bounce'' in the stock market. In fact, he even predicted that this would begin last Monday, Dec. 10.   As it turned out, the Dow Jones industrial average climbed nine points that day and six on Tuesday. But Mr. Generalis, like some other technical analysts these days, is mostly negative about the longer-term prospects for the stock market. He thinks that the market's climb to slightly more than 1,200 should last only four to seven days and will be over by Christmas. By April or May of next year, he said, the Dow should trade in the 1,020 to 980 range.

headline: Financial Corp. In Stock Sale Loss
abstract: The Financial Corporation of America said today that it had sold its stock in Walt Disney Productions back to Disney at a loss of $6.27 million.   The sale price was $58.75 a share for the approximately 900,000 Disney shares that Financial Corporation owned, according to Carol Schatz, a spokesman for Financial Corporation.

headline: MORTON TO SELL TEXIZE TO DOW FOR $256 MILLION
abstract: Heading off the threat of a takeover by the Dow Chemical Company, Morton Thiokol Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Texize household products division to Dow for an estimated $256 million.     As part of its payment, Dow is to turn over an 8.2 percent block of Morton stock that it had been building up since April. Dow had insisted it was buying the stock as an investment but many Wall Street traders thought otherwise.

headline: K-Tel Files Under Chapter 11
abstract: K-Tel International Inc., which distributes recorded music products, has filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.    K-Tel acted Friday after its primary lenders refused to extend more credit last week.

headline: FINANCING SNAG SEEN IN NORTHWEST SALE PLAN
abstract: Northwest Industries indicated today that its plans to sell the company to an investor group for about $1.1 billion were in trouble. In response, the stock plunged $6.62, to $48.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.   The announcement by the Chicago- based conglomerate said that the leaders of the investor group were continuing negotiations to finance the deal and were unable to predict the outcome. The leaders of the group are Kelly, Briggs & Associates and Oppenheimer Strategic Investment.

headline: SCHULTZ'S ADDRESS TOUCHES OFF STIR IN ADMINISTRATION
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz's speech on terrorism Thursday night produced sometimes conflicting or ambivalent statements today from President Reagan and other officials over whether the speech broke new ground in Administration policy,    With the Presidential campaign in its last two weeks, Administration officials sought to avoid an impression that they are divided over a key issue like responding to terrorist attacks.   But their public statements as well as private comments underscored that Mr. Shultz's speech had not resolved their differences.   Crucial to Act, Shultz Says    In his speech Thursday in New York, Mr. Shultz said it was crucial to act against would-be terrorists and to retaliate against attacks.    ''There will not be time for a renewed national debate after every terrorist attack,'' he said.

headline: THE MUCH-ALIGNED U.S. TRADE GAP
abstract: NO economic statistic is reported more dolefully these days than the country's trade balance.  Ever on the alert for signs of impending economic disaster, the press routinely couples reports of record monthly tade deficits with the warnings of experts and Government officials about the dangers of the deficit.  News reports sometimes even provide estimates of the number of jobs lost owing to every billion-dollar in crease in the trade deficit.  Heaven only knows how these estimates are made, but presumably they are based on the assumption that imports deprive unemployed Americans of jobs that could have had producing domestc substitutes for the imports.

headline: Grubb & Ellis Names 6 Regional Presidents
abstract: The Grubb & Ellis Company, the largest publicly held independent real estate services company in the nation, yesterday announced a major reorganization, naming six regional presidents.   The new presidents, who will assume their positions on Jan. 1, will have considerable leeway in making a broad range of decisions, the company said.   ''The regionalization program will bring the decision-making process closer to our local offices, thus improving our responsiveness to changes in the local marketplaces,'' said Harold A. Ellis Jr., 53, chairman and chief executive of the company. The six presidents will report to him.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Warner Computer Systems to AC&R Advertising.

headline: MALTA PRIME MINISTER SELECTS A SUCCESSOR AND STEPS DOWN
abstract: Prime Minister Dom Mintoff, one of Europe's longest-ruling heads of government, resigned today, saying there was ''now someone capable'' of taking his place.   Mr. Mintoff, 68 years old, was succeeded by Carmelo Mifsud-Bonnici, who had been Education Minister and the deputy leader of Mr. Mintoff's socialist Labor Party. Mr. Mintoff had been the leader since 1971 of this former British colony, an island situated between Sicily and Libya that became independent in 1964.    Mr. Mifsud-Bonnici, a 51-year-old lawyer, was sworn in immediately after Mr. Mintoff's announcement.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM REPORT ON MAKING NUCLEAR WAR LESS LIKELY
abstract: Following are excerpts from a report, ''Managing East-West Conflict,'' made public today by the Aspen Institute International Group:        The undersigned have been involved in international relations for most of the atomic age. Our experiences have taught us that neither East nor West can be secure when the other is insecure, particularly with respect to nuclear weapons. There can be mutual security or mutual insecurity, but it will be mutual in either case. What can be done?

headline: 30 Revelers Die in Turkey
abstract: Thirty people were killed and 24 injured today when a truck and a passenger bus carrying wedding revelers home collided head-on in north central Turkey, the state-run Turkish radio reported. The newlyweds were among the dead in the accident near Ilgaz, 90 miles north of Ankara in Cankiri province, according to the semiofficial Anatolia press agency.

headline: Bangladesh Police Fire on Protesters
abstract: The police fired on demonstrators during the first hours of a planned 48- hour nationwide strike today, and local sources said three people, including a student leader, were killed.   The clash in Rajshahi, 220 miles northwest of here, occurred when the police tried to remove barricades set up by students on the railway track near the Rajshahi University train station.

headline: South Africa Steel Curb
abstract: South Africa may extend its voluntary restraint on steel exports to the United States to five years from three years, a Government spokesman said today. Under American pressure, South Africa has cut such exports by 22 percent, to 5.5 million tons, for the year ending next March 31.

headline: BRAKES ON LEVERAGED BUYOUTS
abstract: Republicbank Dallas used to be one of the most active Southwest banks funneling money into the leveraged buyouts of corporations. But nowadays, when John R. Bunten, vice chairman of the bank, listens to deal makers present him with such written proposals he said he usually has the same reaction: ''I throw the piece of paper in the air and say, 'No way; adios, boys.' ''    Mr. Bunten is not alone among bankers in his attitude, as the growing number of aborted leveraged buyouts in recent months makes clear. Washington's tougher stance on bank loan portfolios and the slowing economy have led bankers to put the brakes on the previously frenzied pace of leveraged buyouts.   Bankers still look longingly at the high profit margins on these deals, but they are now scrutinizing the proposals much more closely and insisting that investors put up more of their own money.

headline: FRONTIER AIR PRESES UNIONS
abstract: Frontier Airlines Inc. has warned its union workers that they must give further wage concessions or the airline and its holding company will be liquidated. Thus the carrier has begun to follow the lead of other financially troubled carriers such as Continental, which have used bankruptcy laws to aid their transformations into more viable, low-cost airlines.     Three of Frontier's largest unions have already given concessions of about 20 percent in wages and benefits this year to help stem the losses of the carrier, which has its headquarters and hub in Denver.   The company has stressed that at least for now it wants to remain independent. Robert L. Schulman, director of public relations, said that the board of directors at its meeting last week had rejected an outside offer to acquire the company and instead chose to see if could make the carrier viable.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * First City Financial Corp.  of Vancouver, British Columbia, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its stake in First Executive Corp. to 2.88 million shares, or about 6.8 percent of the total outstanding.     *  Heldor Industries of Morristown, N.J., a maker of prefabricated swimming pools and a distributor of pool products, said it had agreed to buy the assets of Molded Plastics Inc., Tupelo, Miss., which makes spas and whirpool tubs.

headline: Investors Trust Obligations
abstract: Investors G.N.M.A. Mortgage- Backed Securities Trust is offering $300 million of collateralized mortgage obligations through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Mortgage Securities.    The financing, backed by 12 percent mortgage pass-through certificates of the Government National Mortgage Association, is divided into four maturities.

headline: SOCIAL SECURITY: A PROGRAM AT RISK
abstract: WHAT does Ronald Reagan really understand about Social Security, and what will he do about it?    Four years ago, President Reagan promised to increase military spending, cut taxes and balance the budget. Even without the subsequent personal computer revolution, it was apparent that this arithmetic didn't work. Something had to give, and we all know that it was the balanced budget that ceded the ground to the largest deficits this country - or the world - has ever known.

headline: Four Maturities For Canada Bonds
abstract: The Canadian Government's Finance Department announced the pricing on its new $1.05 billion issue of noncallable bonds. The issue will come in four maturities.   The 11 3/4 percent bonds due in 1988 will be offered at 99.75 to yield 11.83 percent, the 12 percent bonds due in 1990 will be offered at par, the 12 1/4 percent bonds due in 1995 will be offered at 99.25 to yield 12.37 percent, and the 12 1/2 percent bonds due in 2006 will be offered at par.

headline: Bonn Sees Export Rise
abstract: West German exports are expected to rise by 9 percent this year as world recovery continues and the prices of German goods remain competitive, the Economics Minister, Martin Bangemann, said today.

headline: 47 Said to Die in Iran Battles
abstract: The Iranian opposition group called People's Mujahedeen said today that its guerrillas killed at least 47 Revolutionary Guards in clashes in northwest Iran last week.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

headline: Byelorussian Denies He Said Sakharov Can Leave Soviet
abstract: The visiting President of Soviet Byelorussia, Ivan Y. Polyakov, denied today that he had told Danish legislators that Andrei D. Sakharov, the banished physicist, was free to emigrate.   The denial, in a statement issued through the Soviet Embassy here, referred to a remark purportedly made through an interpreter in a brief exchange with Bjorn Elmquist, a Liberal legislator, during a reception.   Mr. Elmquist passed Mr. Polyakov's words on to reporters, but in the denial Mr. Polyakov said his remark must have been inaccurately translated.

headline: British Plan Bank Review
abstract: The British Government today announced a full review of banking supervisory arrangements following the collapse of Johnson Matthey Bankers and its subsequent rescue by the Bank of England.   The Bank of England was forced to take over the company after Johnson Matthey Bankers, the banking arm of the metals and chemicals company of the same name, reported bad loans estimated at $187.4 million, but its action subsequently drew sharp criticism from the business community.

headline: Sterilizer Suits
abstract: The American Sterilizer Company said five additional lawsuits had been filed by shareholders against the company, First Boston Inc., Kelso & Company and certain other defendants in connection with a tender offer for American Sterilizer.

headline: Airport Lets Capitol Stay Capitol Air said yesterday
abstract: that it had reached an agreement with the Port Authority of   New York and New Jersey to   let the airline keep operating at   Kennedy International Airport   in return for higher payments.  Lou Garcia, a spokesman for   Capitol, said the agreement   had been worked out by Port   Authority officials and John A.   Catsimatidis, vice chairman of   the carrier, which has been suffering from a cash shortage.

headline: A STERN FORUM FOR A BUDDING ENTREPRENEUR
abstract: MICHAEL BERGELSON admitted that he had no inventory, no sales force and no customers. But if he had $1.4 million, he was telling a recent gathering at the Harvard Business School Club in New York, his nascent company would have profits of $1.7 million on $16.5 million in sales in three years.     Mr. Bergelson, a 46-year-old Russian emigre with a doctorate in computer science and an eye to the main chance, was making his pitch at the club's ''new venture workshop,'' a monthly, two-hour forum at which would-be entrepreneurs are invited to send up their trial balloons - usually to see them shot down by experts. The workshop's purpose is to give entrepreneurs such as Mr. Bergelson free professional advice, access to venture capital and a salutary dose of realism.

headline: REHABILITATION IN THE GARMENT DISTRICT
abstract: To many people, the towers standing side by side on the corner of Seventh Avenue and 37th Street in the heart of New York's garment district were long known as the Bridal Buildings because they were occupied almost exclusively by wedding fashion showrooms.   Bridal companies suffered through the 1960's and 1970's, however, and now they occupy only 30 percent of the 198,000 square feet of space in the two buildings at 491 and 499 Seventh Avenue. The rest houses women's sportswear showrooms, some garment manufacturers and other small stock and shipping companies that were attracted by the buildings' low rents and premier location.   Now another round of change has begun. The two buildings have been sold, and the new owners are putting more than $1 million into bringing them back to high standards.

headline: ISRAELIS BAR BEIRUT-BASED PRESS FROM SOUTH
abstract: The Israeli military authorities have established a new policy of refusing to allow Beirut-based Western correspondents to enter occupied southern Lebanon.     Under the policy, only correspondents accredited to and traveling from Israel will be allowed into southern Lebanon. The Israeli practice has been that such correspondents need military permission and must travel with an Israeli military escort officer and that their dispatches are subject to military censorship.    At least twice in the last 10 days, groups of Western correspondents trying to travel south have been rebuffed by Israeli officers, in one case being taken into custody by armed militiamen and driven out of the Israeli zone.

headline: Hearst Papers
abstract: The Hearst Corporation said it had agreed to buy three newspapers from the Jefferson-Pilot Corporation.

headline: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: THE HOPE IS PEACE, BUT FEARS OF WAR PERSIST
abstract: ''Shanti,'' said the khaki-turbaned Sikh police sergeant, who sat on a rough wooden bench surveying knots of his co-religionists, barefoot and subdued, entering the golden-domed Bangla Sahib temple for prayer. ''Peace.''   Four of his men, all Hindus, sat with long staves on another bench. They seemed to avoid looking at the Sikh sergeant, whose brooding eyes suggested something other than the single word he spoke.    On a low cement wall leading up to the lovely shrine, slogans painted months ago in sonorous English suddenly took on the ring of prophecies.

headline: PRUDENTIAL DENIES THAT ITS BACHE UNIT IS FOR SALE
abstract: Asserting that the synergy expected from the 1981 acquisition of Bache Group Inc. is working well, the Prudential Insurance Company of America yesterday strongly denied reports that the big Wall Street firm - now known as Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. - is for sale. Prudential-Bache recently reported a third- quarter operating deficit of $21.l million, bringing its nine-month net loss to $104.8 million.    Robert A. Beck, chairman and chief executive of Prudential Insurance, said: ''The continued speculation about Prudential's supposed plans to sell Prudential-Bache mystifies me. We have no such intention, and never even discussed such a course.'' Prudential acquired Bache in June 1981 for $385 million, in what was the first of several giant mergers in the financial service industry.

headline: CRISIS MANAGEMENT AT CARBIDE
abstract: The other day one of the dozens of reporters who have flocked here asked Warren M. Anderson, the Union Carbide Corporation's beleaguered chairman, whether he really cared about anything besides profit and loss. Mr. Anderson sighed a weary sigh.    ''During the last week, I haven't been able to give profits much thought,'' he said.   Maybe not. But in their response to the gas tragedy at Bhopal, India, and in the effort to manage a crisis that may be the worst ever faced by an American corporation, Mr. Anderson and his colleagues at Union Carbide's headquarters here are certainly aware of how much is at stake. They have been trying to strike a difficult balance between the instincts of human compassion, the demands of public relations and the dictates of corporate survival.

headline: MULRONEY SAYS CANADA SEEKS 'TRUE PARTNERSHIP' WITH U.S.
abstract: The new Government of Canada issued its first major policy statement today, pledging closer relations with the United States and a heightened commitment to military spending.     ''My Government has taken the initiative to restore a spirit of good will and true partnership between Canada and the United States,'' Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said in a speech read to Parliament by Governor General Jeanne Sauve.   Canada's Governor General is the representative of the British Queen, who is still the country's titular head of state. In the Queen's absence, Mrs. Sauve delivered the Prime Minister's remarks in the form of what is called the Throne Speech, which traditionally gives a Government's legislative agenda at the beginning of each year's parliamentary session.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Suffolk County Offers $136.8 Million in Bonds
abstract: Suffolk County, L.I., which has been hurt by the Long Island Lighting Company's refusal to pay real estate taxes on the Shoreham nuclear plant, is offering $136.8 million of general obligation bonds to refund bonds it previously sold to finance the Southwest Sewer District.    Bonds with maturities from 1986 through 1997 are backed by the county's real estate tax collections, and were rated Baa by Moody's and BBBx by Standard & Poor's. Principal and interest payments on bonds due in 1998 through 2008 were insured by the Ambac Indemnity Corporation, and were rated Baa by Moody's and AAA by Standard & Poor's.

headline: PEUGEOT CHIEF FIGHTS STATE'S EMBRACE
abstract: PARIS     At first sight Jacques Calvet, the   new head of Peugeot, seems a   typical member of the French corporate elite. Tall, elegant and polished in manner, he is a product of the country's finest schools, not to mention a former banker and a high-flyer in the civil service when the right- wing Government of Valery Giscard d'Estaing still reigned.   But a closer look at the squashed nose and puffy lips brings boxing to mind. Mr. Calvet has never been a boxer, but he definitely is a fighter.   Since he joined Peugeot in 1982, he has taken on the Socialist Government and the unions, firing workers in a country where such actions are considered anathema. And he has gone head-to-head with his own boss on matters of strategy - and won.

headline: SOUTH KOREA SAYS NORTH BOLSTERS ITS ARMED FORCES NEAR TRUCE LINE
abstract: As North Korean ships continued to deliver relief supplies to his country, South Korea's President charged today that the North at the same time was strengthening its military forces near the demilitarized zone.    President Chun Doo Hwan said there had been ''unusual movements in the North, as they have deployed large tank units, long-range guns and guided weapons in the forward areas along the truce line.'' The North Koreans also have ''intensified the training of their 100,000 commando troops,'' he said.

headline: A Bid for Early
abstract: Early California Industries Inc. said it had received notice that the ECI Acquiring Company will make a $10-a-share tender offer for any and all Early California shares.

headline: QADDAFI HAS 'AMICABLE' TALKS IN SPAIN
abstract: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, said today that his meeting with Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez on Wednesday night had been amicable and had dealt mostly with developments in northwest Africa.   At a separate news conference, Mr. Gonzalez acknowledged that the United States would probably be critical of the secretly planned meeting, which took place on the Spanish resort island of Majorca. But he said that while he would inform Spain's allies of the meeting, Madrid would follow its own policies.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1984
abstract: The Economy    A bipartisan approach to tax simplification may be in the offing, Administration officials said. The idea would be to seek a compromise with Democrats earlier rather than later. One official noted that various proposals for a flat tax rate are already drawing interest in Congress. (Page A1.)    The trade deficit set a record in the third quarter by widening to $33.3 billion, the Government reported. Imports were up 9.9 percent, while exports rose only 0.7 percent. The deficit for the full year is expected to be nearly double the record set in 1983. (D25.)

headline: 30 FEARED DEAD IN NEW CLASHES IN SRI LANKA
abstract: About 30 people were feared killed in separatist Tamil guerrilla attacks on three majority Sinhalese villages in northern Sri Lanka, a Government official said today.   The official said several people were known to have died in the attacks but full details were not immediately known.    A Government official said the National Security Minister, Lalith Athulathmudali, would give details of the latest attacks at a news conference later today. Meanwhile, a curfew in the island's Northern Province had been extended for 24 hours.

headline: JAPAN SEEKS A 6.9% RISE IN ITS MILITARY SPENDING
abstract: Government leaders have agreed on a 1985 budget that would increase Japan's military spending by 6.9 percent above this year's level.    As in the past, the Japanese decision Friday night was made with an eye on the United States reaction, a familiar practice that acquired a certain urgency this time because Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone will meet with President Reagan in Los Angeles in four days.   While technically the two matters are unrelated, this country's military program is linked to its economic policies by many Americans who believe Japan has failed to carry its weight militarily while accumulating large trade surpluses against the United States. For several years, as a result, the Japanese Government has shaped military spending in the hope of placating American critics and yet not straining its hard-pressed treasury.

headline: ANGOLA TALKS END IN JOHANNESBURG
abstract: South Africa held out the possibility tonight of three-way talks with the United States and Angola on the withdrawal of Cuban soldiers from the former Portuguese colony.   But after two days of discussion with a senior United States envoy, Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha gave no indication of whether significant progress had been made in long-running, American-sponsored negotiations designed to secure a Cuban withdrawal in tandem with independence for neighboring South-West Africa.   Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, arrived in Johannesburg Thursday to hear Mr. Botha's response to Angolan proposals that are reported to offer a reduction and redeployment of the 30,000 Cubans in Angola in return for South Africa's withdrawing its forces and relinquishing control of South-West Africa, or Namibia.

headline: Some people think Adalberto Rosas Lopez is crazy.
abstract: It is not so much that the 42-year-old agricultural engineer has done things such as spend more than a month last year crossing the Mexican farming state of Sonora from one end to the other, ''on foot, like a nut,'' as he put it. It is more that Mr. Rosas, a member of an opposition political party, thinks he can become governor here.    History is not on Mr. Rosas's side. Since its founding 55 years ago, the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party has won every gubernatorial election in every one of Mexico's states, not to mention every contest for President. Mr. Rosas's party, the conservative National Action Party, holds a handful of municipal offices, making it a very distant No. 2.

headline: HONDURANS OPEN TO A NEW U.S. BASE
abstract: Senior Honduran officials offered today to allow the United States to build a permanent military base in their country.     ''A permanent United States military base in Honduras is possible, if this is mutually convenient to the security of both nations,'' said Col. Efrain Gonzalez, Chief of Staff for the Honduran armed forces.    Colonel Gonzalez, who spoke at a news conference here, has been in Washington this week with six other high-ranking Hondurans seeking greatly increased military and economic aid,    Colonel Gonzalez also said Honduras was negotiating to allow the United States to resume the training of Salvadoran troops at a regional training center in Honduras operated by the United States.

headline: Ted Bates Re-enlisted
abstract: The word got out yesterday that Ted Bates/New York had been reassigned the Navy recruiting business for three more years. The fee they will be paid, if capitalized, would approximate $20 million in billings.

headline: SIKH SEPARATION DATES BACK TO '47
abstract: After the June crackdown on armed Sikh extremists, an illusory lull seemed to come over the two-pronged campaign for Sikh rights and political autonomy for Punjab state, the Sikhs' prairie homeland.    Yet Sikh separatist fervor, which dates back to the partition of the Indian subcontinent in 1947 and spawned the campaign two years ago, remained smoldering. According to police officials, the assassination of Mrs. Gandhi yesterday was carried out by Sikhs among her personal guards.   Many of India's 14 million Sikhs - a hard-working, accomplished people and a volatile, resentful one - still feel they were cheated by being left without an independent nation of their own when the subcontinent was split into Moslem Pakistan and predominantly Hindu India.

headline: U.S. SAYS IT DIDN'T WANT SHIP CAPTURED
abstract: The United States sent the nuclear-powered carrier Nimitz to aid a Navy-chartered ship that drifted into Cuban waters because of concern that the Cubans might try to seize the ship for political purposes, a senior Defense Department official said today.   The Navy-chartered ship, the Seaward Explorer, drifted into Cuban territorial waters and the 90,000-ton Nimitz, on a port call at Charlotte Amalie, St. Thomas, the Virgin Islands, was ordered to sea so quickly Friday morning that about 1,000 of its 5,200 crew members were left behind, Pentagon officials said.   The decision to send the Nimitz and an escort ship, the nuclear-powered cruiser Arkansas, to sea was made when the Cuban authorities told the State Department that a Cuban boat might take the disabled ship to a Cuban port for repairs, a State Department official said.   ''We did not want the Cubans to take that ship,'' the senior Pentagon official said. ''The Cubans might have tried to make a political show of the whole thing and hold the crew and ship. We did not want that to happen. So we sent the Nimitz because its planes could get to the scene.''

headline: Shcharansky in Hospital, Soviet Tells His Family
abstract: Soviet authorities have told the family of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the jailed Jewish dissident, that he has been hospitalized but have declined to give details of his illness, his wife, Avital, said Friday.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1984   Companies    Phillips accused T. Boone Pickens of tipping friends, officers of Mesa Petroleum and others of his plans to acquire stock in major oil companies. The charge, which Mr. Pickens called without merit, is part of a barrage of litigation initiated by Phillips to fend off the takeover attempt. (Page D1.)   Plans to buy Northwest Industries are in trouble, the company indicated, sending its stock down $6.625, to $48.25. Northwest said the leaders of the group seeking to buy it - Kelly, Briggs & Associates and Oppenheimer Strategic Investments - were conducting financing negotiations but could not predict the outcome. (D1.)

headline: Lebanon Warns Ships On Using Illegal Ports
abstract: The Government today issued strict instructions to all ships entering the 12- mile territorial limit to call only at legitimate harbors and to avoid illegal ports operated by private militias.   A communique issued by the army command gave Saturday as a deadline for ships to abide by the new regulations or, it said, face destruction.

headline: Ex-Chairman of Ashton Named President of Ziff
abstract: David C. Cole, who late last month abruptly resigned as chairman and chief executive officer of Ashton-Tate Inc., one of the nation's leading computer software companies, yesterday was named president and chief operating officer of the Ziff Corporation, which has extensive holdings in information companies and computer publications.   Mr. Cole's appointment ends a period of speculation about where he would go.   At the time he resigned his posts at Ashton-Tate he said that he was leaving to join a major East Coast corporation that he had been talking with for almost a year.

headline: Nov. 1-10 Car Sales Fell by 4.7 Percent
abstract: Sales of new cars by the nation's six major auto manufacturers slipped 4.7 percent in the first 10 days of November, the companies reported here today.   Sales by the six companies totaled 188,775 in the period, which had nine selling days this year and last, down from 198,126 in 1983.   The decline was attributed to supply problems at the General Motors Corporation because of strikes against G.M. in September and October and to a shortage of parts needed for the 1985 models by G.M. supplier companies.

headline: Key Soviet Official Off to China Soon
abstract: China announced today that Ivan V. Arkhipov, a Soviet First Deputy Prime Minister, would visit China for official talks beginning Dec. 21.    Other than brief exchanges between officials of the two sides at the funeral in Moscow this year of Yuri V. Andropov, the visit will mark the highest-ranking direct contacts between Moscow and Peking in more than 15 years.    An official who discussed the coming visit last week made it plain that China did not expect it to lead to any breakthrough on the major issues.

headline: Jordan Gets Saudi Aid
abstract: Jordan has received $119.5 million from Saudi Arabia as the third and final installment of aid this year, official sources said today. Arab oil- producing states agreed in 1978 to give financial support to Arab countries that border Israel.

headline: TORIES BARELY WIN A VOTE ON WHO'LL RULE LONDON
abstract: Fresh from a large-scale Conservative Party revolt on cutbacks in aid to university students, the Government squeaked through another in-house rebellion this week on a bill that would do away with London's elected government.   In the House of Commons on Wednesday, the Government, which has a 141- member majority, defeated an amendment to the bill by a margin of only 23 votes. Eighteen Tories voted against their party, and as many as 60 are believed by their colleagues to have abstained to show their distaste.   The bill will abolish the Greater London Council, now controlled by the opposition Labor Party, in favor of the city's 32 boroughs. It will also do away with county councils in six large metropolian areas, also controlled by the Labor Party. This would leave the cities of Liverpool, Sheffield, Newcastle, Birmingham, Coventry and Leeds without locally elected administrations.

headline: SCRAMBLING FOR PROFITS IN A GAS GLUT
abstract: HOUSTON     OFFICIALS of the Transco Energy Company still shudder at the memory of that bitter 1976- 77 winter when, facing a harrowing shortage of natural gas supplies, they had to cut off service to as much as 45 percent of their pipeline's market.    Despite desperate attempts to make good on delivery commitments, scarcely any industrial customers of the company's Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation subsidiary were unaffected, and some had to shut down plants. Fears were rife that the shortage would spread to higher priority customers all along the East Coast - schools, homes, even hospitals. ''We were a prime example,'' recalled Brian E. O'Neill, the pipeline's president, ''of a pipeline that developed a substantial shortage problem.''    Eight years later, the situation is reversed. Transco and the rest of the industry face a prolonged glut - more technically described as ''excess deliverability'' - brought on by deregulation, recession and price-induced conservation of gas and oil. Competition and price have become dominant considerations, a change that has been beneficial to consumers, but that is causing upheaval throughout the gas industry, particularly for pipeline companies.

headline: S. & P. BEARISH ON GOLD NOW
abstract: IN common with economists and Wall Street analysts, advisory services change their minds   about investment opportunities, too. About a year ago, the Standard & Poor's Corporation took a positive view on the outlook for gold prices. Gold was then selling well above $350 an ounce, compared with this week's price of slightly above $330.    The price of gold was heading downward in November 1983, having dropped below the $400-an- ounce ''barrier'' just a month earlier. But S.&P. took the view that gold, along with other precious metals, seemed to have reached its ''final selloff'' stage.

headline: ARAFAT EXPECTED TO REJECT JORDAN PEACE PLAN
abstract: King Hussein's call for a Middle East peace initiative based on United Nations Resolution 242 has little chance of winning approval from Yasir Arafat's wing of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Palestinian sources and Western diplomats said here today.     ''We're going to ignore it,'' a Palestinian official said today. ''We'll refer it to the new executive committee and drown it in a sea of speechmaking and welter of detail.''    Resolution 242, adopted after the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, calls on Israel to withdraw from occupied territory in return for recognition of Israel's right to exist.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, DECEMBER 22, 1984
abstract: The Economy    The Federal Reserve Board cut its discount rate by half a point, to 8 percent, its lowest level in more than six years. The Fed said it was acting to bring the rate ''into alignment'' with money market rates. The statement also suggested that the Fed was seeking faster growth of the money supply and some decline in the value of the dollar against other currencies. Exactly one month ago, the board had cut the rate to 8 1/2 percent. (Page 1.)    Durable goods orders rose 8.3 percent in November, the biggest gain since September 1980. More than half the increase was attributed to a doubling in the volatile military orders category. But even with the military surge taken out, orders still rose 3.3 percent, a rate that is considered healthy and certainly far better than in recent months. The White House said the figures provide a ''bright horizon for next year's economy.'' (31.)

headline: Foes Blame Giscard For Sniffer Plane Scheme
abstract: A French parliamentary report published here today accused former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of responsibility for approving a fraudulent project involving planes that could purportedly sniff out oil deposits beneath the ocean.   The 644-page report was commissioned by Socialist and Communist members of the Parliament six months ago after revelations that from 1976 to 1979 a Government-owned oil company, Elf-Aquitaine, had paid $50 million for the development of the purported oil-sniffing technique.

headline: EX-C.I.A. EMPLOYEE HELD AS CZECH SPY
abstract: The Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday arrested a former Central Intelligence Agency contract employee in New York and accused him of having infiltrated the agency to channel national security information to the Czechoslovak intelligence service.    The man, identified by F.B.I. officials as Karl F. Koecher, a native of Czechoslovakia, was arrested a day after he and his wife, Hanna, had sold their Manhattan apartment and hours before they planned to leave on a plane for Zurich, Switzerland. Mrs. Koecher was detained as a material witness, but was not charged.    Mr. Koecher, 50 years old, was held overnight in the Metropolitan Correctional Center pending arraignment today in Manhattan Federal Court. He faces espionage charges that could carry a life sentence.

headline: Blast Near Iraq Embassy Kills Greek Bomb-Disposal Expert
abstract: A police bomb- disposal expert was killed today while trying to defuse a bomb placed under the car of an Iraqi diplomat in Athens, the police said. Two other time bombs placed under the cars of Iraqi diplomats were found and detonated by the police.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: *  Acro Energy Corp., Elk Grove, Calif., said it plans to offer to repurchase shares of its common stock held by owners of 99 or fewer shares.     * BP North American Trading Inc. , Houston, said it had changed its name to BP North America Petroleum Inc.     * Cohu Inc., San Diego, said it had agreed to acquire all the shares outstanding of closely held Broadcast Microwave Services Inc. in exchange for 50,000 Cohu common shares.

headline: Explorer Order
abstract: Texas Instruments Inc. said it had received an order for its Explorer Symbolic Processing computers from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. M.I.T. will acquire up to 200 machines for 1985 delivery and up to 200 for 1986 delivery and will become one of the first major recipients of Explorer machines. Texas Instruments developed the Explorer system using innovations licensed from M.I.T.

headline: 10 Killed as a Nighttime Fire Sweeps Manila Tourist Hotel
abstract: Ten people were killed when fire swept the seventh floor of a tourist hotel early today, authorities reported.    At least 20 people were treated in Manila hospitals, including two Americans.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM; THE ONLY HOPE: TAX MORE, SPEND LESS
abstract: GROWING our way out of the chronic budget deficit is not an impossible dream, but the odds against getting enough growth to balance the budget are ruefully long. I'm sorry to have to draw that conclusion, because we badly need the economic growth - for higher living standards, greater equality of opportunity, enhanced national security and other desirable goals, as well as for the additional wages, salaries and profits that would deliver the tax revenues to close the budget gap. But the budget chasm is too wide to succumb to growth alone.    We have to recognize the severe limitations on our ability to make accurate five-year forecasts for the budget and the economy. All past experience proves the validity of the old saw that forecasting is very difficult, especially if it's about the future. Nevertheless, in making their far- reaching decisions our political leaders will do better if they base those decisions on a reasonable set of long- term projections.

headline: PINOCHET FOILS OPPOSITION STRIKE CALL IN CHILE
abstract: President Augusto Pinochet's hard-line tactics undercut the opposition's call today for a national strike to protest against the 11-year-old military Government and the state of siege it imposed three weeks ago.    The strike was planned by a broad coalition of labor and political leaders.   But, with the exception of student demonstrations, and a large military presense in the streets, activity in the capital appeared near normal.   Opposition political leaders attributed the failure of the strike to the widespread presence of troops, threats against bus drivers and press censorship banning news of the strike.

headline: Gain in Service at A.T.& T.
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it completed orders for new special business line connections on schedule 50 percent of the time in September, up from 34 percent the previous month.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS ; Interest Rates Rise Sharply
abstract: Interest rates jumped yesterday as some bond market investors apparently took profits following the recent rally and girded themselves for a heavy schedule of Treasury auctions in the coming week.     Trading in the end-of-the-year market was light, however, and analysts said that the rise in interest rates was likely to be temporary.   In line with the rate increases, the price of long-term bonds fell nearly a point. The Treasury's 30-year, 11 3/4 percent bond was quoted late yesterday at 102 15/32 offered, down 31/32 of a point, for a yield of 11.46 percent, up from Monday's 11.43 percent.

headline: HONDURAS ASKS THE U.S. FOR A FLEET OF JET FIGHTERS AND A BIG INCREAS IN AID
abstract: Honduras has asked the United States for a fleet of F-5 fighter planes as part of a package of significantly expanded military and economic aid it is seeking to negotiate with Washington.    Officials said the Honduran request was for 12 of the F-5 planes, along with military aid averaging more than $100 million a year for the next four years and a doubling of economic assistance.    United States officials here say they are interpreting the request for increased aid as an indication that Honduran officials, contrary to recent public statements, are seeking a closer relationship with Washington.   But Honduran sources indicated that the request symbolizes continuing concern over the benefit that Honduras is receiving from its links with the United States as well as growing discomfort over the increasing military assistance being provided to neighboring El Salvador.

headline: Garden Tool Campaign From Burton-Campbell
abstract: To the confirmed gardener - backyard or rooftop - the spring of 1985 will be remembered as the Time of the Swoe.

headline: 2 DISNEY HEIRS HIRE AN ADVISER
abstract: The widow and one daughter of Walt Disney said yesterday that they had informally joined together and hired the Wall Street firm of Dillon, Read & Company to advise them about their holdings in Walt Disney Productions.    Analysts said the two might now seek to assert more control over the company.    In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington, Lillian B. Disney and her daughter Sharon Disney Lund said they held a 5.5 percent stake in the company. They said they had hired Dillon, Read to ''consider alternative means by which their interests may more effectively be represented in the policies and direction'' of the company.

headline: Pretax Profit Up for Bayer
abstract: Bayer A.G., the West German chemical group, said today that its pretax profit surged 62 percent in the first nine months of 1984, to 2.2 billion marks, or $719 million, from 1.36 billion marks a year earlier. The company did not divulge net profit or revenue figures.

headline: Northeastern Air
abstract: Northeastern International Airways said that it had laid off more than 100 of its 1,500 employees and had stretched out airport fee payments because of a seasonal slowdown in air traffic.

headline: Japan Payments Gap
abstract: Japan's balance of payments swung to a deficit of $2.03 billion in November, from a surplus of $1.08 billion in November 1983, the Finance Ministry said today. On a seasonally adjusted basis, Japan's balance of payments deficit narrowed to $680 million in November, from $737 million in October.
