headline: ISRAEL ARRIVES IN ETHIOPIA ON RELIEF MISSION
abstract: Citing an ancient connection between the Jewish and Ethiopian peoples, an Israeli philanthropist and fund-raiser has come here to build a fully equipped camp for famine refugees.     ''From the time of King Solomon, we are related,'' said the Israeli, Abie Nathan, referring to the traditional belief that Ethiopian history goes back to a union between King Solomon and the Queen of Sheba.   Ethiopia broke relations with Israel in 1973 under pressure from Arab nations. Before then, the two countries had close ties. Ethiopia is also the home of Beta Israel, an ancient group of black Jews also known as Falashas.

headline: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT FLAT IN OCTOBER
abstract: Industrial production in the United States was unchanged in October, the Federal Reserve Board said today. But a number of analysts attributed the sluggishness to temporary factors and predicted modest gains in coming months.   In September, according to revised figures, production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities declined a steep five-tenths of 1 percent, in the first setback since November 1982, which was the low point of the last recession. Many economists had expected the September decline to be erased by a strong gain in October.

headline: JAPAN INDEX PORTENDS SLIDE
abstract: Japan's economy is likely to soften soon, according to the leading indicator released today by the Economic Planning Agency.

headline: LEBANON THREATS ARE STEPPED UP
abstract: A caller who said he represented the terrorist group Islamic Holy War made a new threat today to ''blow up all American interests'' in Lebanon.    The shadowy organization, which has taken responsibility for twice bombing the American Embassy here and for blowing up the Marine garrison, made the threat in a telephone call to the Beirut Arabic-language newspaper As Safir at 1:20 A.M.    ''We, the Islamic Jihad Organization, warn on the re-election of Ronald Reagan to the U.S. Presidency, that we shall blow up all American interests in Beirut and any part of Lebanon,'' the caller said, using the Arabic word for holy war. ''We address this warning to every American individual residing in Lebanon.''   Last Sept. 20, a suicide truck bomber drove through the new American embassy building in a Christian suburb near East Beirut, killing what the Lebanese authorities now say was a total of 11 people. Islamic Holy War took responsibility for the attack.

headline: AUSTRALIAN WANTS TO REVIVE THE BLIMP
abstract: Alan Bond proved he has a taste for an unusual challenge when he sponsored the Australia II, the 12-meter yacht with the revolutionary hull design that stunned the world by wresting the America's Cup from the United States last year.   More recently, the Australian entrepreneur's attention has been diverted from his prosperous empire of brewing, retailing, media and property interests to an equally daunting task: selling the world, in particular the military, on a new generation of blimps.   Blimps have been on Mr. Bond's mind since he noticed one of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company's airships filming the America's Cup. His chance to get more involved arose last spring when Airship Industries, the only company in the world trying to market blimps, ran out of cash.

headline: GUERRILLAS ACCEPT DUARTE PROPOSAL FOR PEACE PARLEY
abstract: Salvadoran guerrilla leaders today formally accepted an offer from President Jose Napoleon Duarte to meet rebel representatives next Monday in northern El Salvador.     The unexpected diplomatic effort to end five years of civil war, which Mr. Duarte proposed Monday at the United Nations, was welcomed by diplomats throughout the region. They characterized Mr. Duarte's offer as a shrewd gesture intended both to blunt an expected guerrilla military offensive and to seize the political high ground as the Contadora peace talks enter their final phase.   The rebels' acceptance was confirmed by guerrilla officials here and broadcast by Venceremos, the rebel radio station in El Salvador, which said it was speaking in the name of the five military factions that make up the rebel Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front and for the Democratic Revolutionary Front, the political wing of the guerrilla opposition.

headline: ARMY COMMANDER IN SALVADOR DIES IN COPTER CRASH
abstract: The leading combat commander of the Salvadoran Army and three other senior officers died today when their helicopter crashed in a rebel-held area.    Their deaths appear to be the most significant setback the Army has suffered in five years of war here.   An army spokesman, Lieut. Col. Ricardo Cienfuegos, said at a news conference tonight that the commander, Lieut. Col. Domingo Monterrosa, died at about four o'clock this afternoon near the town of Joateca in Morazan Province, 120 miles northeast of the capital.

headline: Argentina Seeks Loans
abstract: Argentina has asked foreign banks for an additional $5.45 billion and a new schedule for repaying its $45 billion foreign debt, the country's Economics Minister, Bernardo Grinspun, said today.   Mr. Grinspun, in a statement to the official news agency Telam, confirmed the details of a published report concerning an Argentine proposal presented Wednesday in New York to a committee representing 320 private banks, most of them in the United States.

headline: Futures; A Bullion Seller's Guarantee
abstract: TO say that most investors in gold   bullion the last few years wished   they could get their money back would only be gilding the truth. After soaring to a record high of $850 an ounce on Jan. 21, 1980, the price of cash gold has sunk to $341 at last Friday's close.   Now the Mocatta Metals Corporation, one of the world's major bullion dealers, is offering gold bugs a three- year investment contract through brokerage houses under which it guarantees to buy back the metal at the original purchase price from now on.    ''What our Mocatta Guaranteed Value Bullion Units offer investors is in effect the right to get back their investment plus whatever they pay in brokerage commissions, if at the end of the three-year contract the price of gold is less than what they paid originally,'' said Terry Mayer, Mocatta's marketing director.

headline: Rehab Hospital Takeover Set
abstract: The Rehab Hospital Services Corporation of Camp Hill, Pa., said it had agreed to be acquired by National Medical Enterprises Inc. of Los Angeles in a transaction National Medical said was valued at about $120 million.   The merger agreement calls for the exchange of one share of National Medical common stock for each share of Rehab common.

headline: CHASE LAW FIRM BARRED IN BIG NEGLIGENCE SUIT
abstract: Lord, Day & Lord, a New York law firm acting as counsel to the Chase Manhattan Bank, has been disqualified from representing the bank in a $175 million negligence suit against six former officers of Chase.     The suit was filed last March in connection with the bank officers' handling of $200 million of oil and gas drilling loans to the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City, which failed in July 1982.   As a result of a special investigation conducted by Lord, Day & Lord, the bank brought charges of negligence and breach of duty against Richard Higgerson, William Hinchman and Robert Denner, former executive vice presidents; Wayne Hansen and James Harris, former senior vice presidents, and Richard Pinney, formerly chief of the central division of the institutional banking department.    According to an attorney familiar with the litigaion, however, Chase kept the suit secret by serving the complaint on the defendants without filing a copy in court.

headline: AIR ATLANTA PRESIDENT IS EX-T.W.A. OFFICER
abstract: Neil M. Effman, who was forced out as senior vice president of Trans World Airlines last August, when Richard D. Pearson was named its executive vice president and chief operating officer, has been named Air Atlanta's president and chief operating officer.    The Atlanta-based airline, which began operating in February, has a fleet of five Boeing 727-100 planes, and it serves New York's Kennedy International Airport, Miami and Memphis.    Mr. Effman, who is 49, began his career at T.W.A. in 1958 and rose to senior vice president for marketing and planning. He has been a consultant to Air Atlanta for the last two months.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1984   Companies    Two new offers emerged for Pabst, the nation's sixth-largest brewer, each valued at $63 million. One bidder, Paul Kalmanovitz, said he had a firm agreement, but Pabst said it was still considering the other offer, from Heileman Brewing. (Page D1.)    Chrysler plans to spend $10 billion in the next five years on new products and facilities, $500 million more than it had forecast. But officials said the company was unlikely to reopen plants closed during the company's financial crisis. (D1.)

headline: DEBATE SPONSOR: A DORMANT INSTITUTE WAKENS
abstract: As sponsor of the talks today between opposing sides in El Salvador, the Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions is stirring from a seven-year slumber.   Under the leadership since March of Allen Weinstein, an author and a professor of history at Georgetown University, the Center this year has adopted the crisis in Central America as a major focus, moving away from an ivory-tower role it once cherished into the hubbub of world events. In recent months it has conducted forums for the President of El Salvador, Jose Napoleon Duarte, and for the coordinator of the Sandinista junta in Nicaragua, Daniel Ortega Saavedra.

headline: CHINA TURNS TO PRIVATE MEDICINE TO HEAL SYSTEM
abstract: Each weekday morning when the traditional Chinese pharmacy on Zhangye Road opens, Kong Xianghe sits at a small desk inside the door and waits for customers to consult him about their ailments before buying the fragrant herbal medicines.   Dr. Kong, who is 62 years old, retired as physician in the clinic of the Lanzhou chemical plant five years ago. He went back to work for himself when the Government, to ease the shortage of doctors, let retired physicians set up private practice.   Now, Dr. Kong says, he sees up to 50 patients a day, charging the equivalent of 8 cents for an initial consultation and 6 cents for a subsequent session.

headline: ITALY HUNTING A NEW SUSPECT IN REPORTED PLOT ON EMBASSY
abstract: The Italian police are searching for another suspect in a reported plot to bomb the United States Embassy here.    The suspect, who has not been identified, is believed to have been traveling with a man whose arrest in Switzerland 10 days ago led to the uncovering of the purported plot.   The Italian police are also seeking to discover whether a man arrested in August was connected with the case. The man, identified only as an Arab, was carrying 15 pounds of explosives at the time of his arrest.

headline: Article 140861 -- No Title
abstract: Union Carbide India Ltd. announced today that it would contribute $830,000 to a special relief fund for the disabled survivors of the deadly gas leak from it pesticide plant in Bhopal.   It also said it was rushing in medical supplies, doctors and other experts and would soon set up an orphanage in the central Indian city.    The announcement came hours after Warren M. Anderson, chairman of the company's main owner, the Union Carbide Corporation of Danbury, Conn., left New Delhi for New York by private jet without making any public appearances.    A spokesman for the company's New Delhi office, S. Kumaraswami, said that Mr. Anderson had planned to disclose the relief measures when he was in Bhopal on Friday but that his brief house arrest by Madhya Pradesh authorities had prevented it.   First Relief Effort      The announcement of the relief fund, made from the Bombay-based subsidiary's office here, was the company's first public attempt to make ammends and to soothe feelings in India since a cloud of noxious methyl isocyanate escaped from the Bhopal plant, killing more than 2,000 people, according to official estimates. Tens of thousands were gravely disabled.

headline: MANILA JUSTICE IS STILL STUDYING AQUINO FINDINGS
abstract: The Government ombudsman said today that he had begun evaluating evidence against the armed forces Chief of Staff and others implicated in the Benigno S. Aquino Jr. assassination, but had not decided whether to hold public pretrial hearings.   The ombudsman, Justice Bernardo Fernandez, whose office investigates criminal complaints against Government personnel and prosecutes them before the courts, said he could not say how soon his office could make a ruling on whether there was sufficient evidence to bring the case to trial.   The Chief of Staff, Gen. Fabian C. Ver, who has gone on a ''leave of absence'' to prepare his defense, has waived his right to a preliminary investigation to speed up proceedings against him, the Philippine News Agency reported.

headline: Consumers Power Tells Of Inquiry by S.E.C.
abstract: The Consumers Power Company, the financially troubled Michigan utility, said yesterday that it was being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission for ''possible violations of the Federal securities laws.''     In a prepared statement from its Jackson, Mich., headquarters, the company said that the inquiry centers on the increase in its quarterly dividend to 63 cents, from 61 cents, in the fall of 1983, possible improper insider trading, and possible irregularities in disclosures about its Midland nuclear plant. The company suspended construction at the plant last summer after spending about $3.6 billion.

headline: Peace Corps Volunteer Is Killed in Philippines
abstract: An American Peace Corps volunteer on the central Philippine island of Cebu was shot and killed at his beachfront cottage during an apparent robbery this week, the authorities said today.

headline: E.E.C. Bond Issue in U.S.
abstract: The European Economic Community's commission said today that it had filed a registration statement with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission for a planned $150 million European Currency Unit bond issue to be floated on the American market later this year.

headline: Market Place; Bank Stocks And Write-Offs
abstract: TWO unrelated developments this week seem  to have raised old fears about money center  bank stocks. On Tuesday, they took a beating after one analyst lowered his earnings estimates for Citicorp, the bellwether of the group. And yesterday, investors ran scared upon hearing the surprise news that the First Chicago Corporation, another of the so-called money center banks, expected to report a loss of at least $70 million for the third quarter.  Bank analysts assumed that, since the news of First Chicago's write-off was so sudden, it was likely that bank regulatory authorities forced the issue. And that means, they said, that other large banks might have to write off more loans than they had planned as well. ''The regulators may well be operating with a sharper pencil,'' said William Welsh, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, a New York brokerage and money management organization.

headline: RETURN TO INDIA: ASHES AND MEMORIES
abstract: For a visitor who witnessed the cremation of the slain Mohandas K. Gandhi here nearly four decades ago, the similarities of the funeral Saturday of another Indian leader who had also fallen victim to religious and political passions left an eerie feeling.    But a visit Sunday to the same Hindu funeral grounds to view the still-smoking ashes of another, unrelated Gandhi - Indira - also left a sense of the profound change that has occurred here since Mohandas Gandhi was shot to death Jan. 30, 1948.    On Sunday, the scene on the flat western bank of the Jamuna River, where only a trickle of mourners for Mrs. Gandhi passed through the forbidding security cordon of rifle-carrying soldiers, was the faintest of reminders of the huge outpouring of people who had paid homage to first Gandhi, whom the world called Mahatma, or ''great soul.''  A Vivid Flashback      There was a more vivid flashback in the wholesale killing of Sikhs by enraged Hindus after the police said that Mrs. Gandhi, India's Prime Minister for 15 of the last 18 years, had been shot by two Sikh members of her bodyguard.

headline: AGCA SAID TO DETAIL PLAN OF 2D GUNMAN
abstract: Mehmet Ali Agca, the man convicted of shooting Pope John Paul II, told Italian investigators that a second gunman was expected to carry out the assassination if Mr. Agca was unable to get off at least five shots, according to a report filed today by the presiding magistrate in the case.     The 1,243-page report, filed by Judge Ilario Martella, included previously undisclosed details on the activities of a second gunman and of the involvement of three accused Bulgarians in the purported plot to kill the Pope. Sections from the report, obtained by The New York Times, included lengthy citations from testimony by Mr. Agca.    According to Judge Martella, Mr. Agca's alleged accomplice, a Turk named Oral Celik, actually fired on the Pope. Mr. Celik disappeared after the assassination attempt on May 13, 1981.    According to the report, Mr. Agca testified that he was not certain if Mr. Celik had been able to fire any shots.

headline: ENTICING BROADWAY'S ANGELS
abstract: The only thing that stands between ''Boo'' and    Broadway is $1,250,000, and Anthony Moyer, the   play's co-author and co-producer, was absolutely certain the other day that the show would go on. ''Boo'' has ''incredible subsidiary rights,'' he was saying. ''It will have incredible returns to investors.'' And finances aside, the play itself was - well, incredible. ''A lot of people have seen possession tales,'' he added, ''but in this, the demon jumps from nun to nun. So this provides an incredible piece of theater for four actresses.''

headline: DMZ DEFECTOR SAYS HE ACTED FREELY
abstract: A Soviet defector said today that he had acted of his ''own free will'' when he bolted from North Korea into South Korean territory, touching off a fatal gun battle here in the heart of the demilitarized zone.    Vasily Yakovlevich Matuzok, 22 years old, said that he had decided to defect two years ago and that he chose to act Friday while touring Panmunjom because it was his ''very first opportunity to go to the West.''    Mr. Matuzok has been kept in seclusion at a United States military hospital in Seoul. But American officers in Panmunjom showed a videotape of an interview they had held with him to counter North Korean charges that he had been taken to the south by force.

headline: Data Bank; December 16, 1984
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: MORTGAGE RATES DROP
abstract: Mortgage rates fell in October, marking the third straight month of decline, with fixed-rate mortgages dropping to the lowest point since May, the Government said today.   The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said the average conventional fixed-rate mortgage loan declined to 14.72 percent in early October, from 14.90 percent in September.

headline: NICARAGUAN VOWS TO RESIST U.S.
abstract: The Minister of Defense said today that Nicaragua would not alter its policies in the face of pressure from the Reagan Administration.   The official, Humberto Ortega Saavedra, characterized the flurry of news reports last week suggesting that Nicaragua was about to receive Soviet jet fighters as ''ridiculous and false.''

headline: Texas Eastern To Sell Unit HOUSTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -
abstract: The Texas Eastern Corporation said it would sell its Transwestern Pipeline Company   subsidiary to the Houston Natural Gas Corporation for $390   million. Transwestern operates a   4,395-mile pipeline that carries   natural gas from west Texas to   Oklahoma and California,   Texas Eastern said.

headline: Advertising Club Holds Breakfast Sessions
abstract: Walter J. O'Brien, vice chairman and director of multinational client services of the J. Walter Thompson Company, yesterday had the honor of leading off the series of ''breakfasts with'' sessions that have been started by the Advertising Club of New York.    And including the photographer there were 32 people in attendance in the Oval Room of the Roosevelt Hotel, which seemed to disappoint Mr. O'Brien a bit, but not Bob Johnson, acting executive director of the club, who felt it would be better for serious questioning.

headline: MONDALE'S BUSINESS EDUCATION
abstract: -1950's, law student Walter Mondale, his    friends recall, was a liberal firebrand who championed the cause of the blue-collar worker. ''He always landed on the side of labor rather than business in debates,'' said Douglas M. Head, a classmate at the University of Minnesota and former Republican state attorney general.    Some 20 years later, Vice President Walter F. Mondale took a less doctrinaire view of business when he worked to save the teetering Chrysler Corporation from ruin by helping persuade his union friends in the United Automobile Workers to swallow wage cuts. He also pushed Congress to provide $1.2 billion in loan guarantees that helped turn crippled Chrysler into the comeback company of the decade.   ''He was a very important bridge to all the groups involved,'' said G. William Miller, who served as Secretary of the Treasury during the Chrysler rescue mission. ''He argued that sacrifice shouldn't be borne more by one constituency than by another, but should be borne by all.''

headline: EXPERTS SEE SLOWING IN 1985
abstract: This year's schizophrenic economy, which paired a blistering first half with a lethargic second half, will give way to more even, but substantially lower, growth in the coming year, according to many economists. Most look for growth, after inflation, of about 3 percent - close to what traditionally has been viewed as the long-term growth potential for the American economy.   ''Nineteen eighty-five has the makings of a pretty good year,'' said Murray L. Weidenbaum, director of the Center for Study of American Business at Washington University in St. Louis. ''The only problem is that it pales in comparison to '84, which is likely to be outstanding in the long run. Every forecast I've come across is predicting much slower growth and a tad more inflation than this year.''

headline: COMIC'S WICKED WIT KEEPS RUSSIANS TICKLED PINK
abstract: A frail old man with hair swirling above his head in an incongruous white pompadour stands alone under a spotlight in the center of the stage and shrugs his shoulders with infinite weariness.    ''Oh, maybe it's not worth it,'' he says. ''Maybe we should just keep silent tonight. We're all so good at keeping silent, and they say silence is golden. I could, for instance, just keep my mouth shut tonight for three hours plus the intermission. That way, we won't take any risks.''   Another shrug. A supreme effort. ''Or maybe we could just talk about . . . no, better not to talk about that,'' he says. ''Or, let's say, about, about. . . . No, about that people are keeping silent these days on every street corner.''

headline: ETHIOPIA MOVING 1.5 MILLION PEOPLE FROM FAMINE
abstract: An armada of battered buses and trucks and modern Soviet helicopters and troop transport planes is carrying tens of thousands of hungry, destitute peasants from the famine-stricken areas of northern Ethiopia to more fertile lands in the west and south.    It is the opening wave of what may become one of the largest resettlement programs in recent history.   Over the course of a year, the Ethiopian Government plans to relocate 1.5 million farmers at a cost of $35 million, according to Birhanu Derressa, deputy commissioner of the Government's Relief and Rehabilitation Commission. If the plan is successful, many more will be moved the following year.    In the last two weeks, 70,000 have already been resettled, Mr. Birhanu said. Huge convoys that sometimes include more than 100 vehicles have carried up to 7,000 settlers southward at a time, he added.

headline: ISRAEL WELCOMES JORDAN'S MOVE ON TIES TO EGYPT
abstract: Israel said today that it welcomed the resumption of diplomatic relations between Jordan and Egypt as a potential contribution to peace in the Middle East.   The relations had been ended by Jordan after Egypt concluded a peace treaty with Israel in 1979.   The first official Israeli reaction to King Hussein's decision was contained in a statement by the Cabinet after its weekly meeting in Jerusalem. The statement said that Prime Minister Shimon Peres, responding to a question by another minister, had commented that the Israeli-Egyptian peace treaty was not intended to prejudice Egypt's relationship with other Arab countries.

headline: THE TOUGH JOB OF SELLING TRACTORS
abstract: ALGONA, Iowa    IT is 7 A.M. The cars and pickup   trucks out on Highway 18 still   have their lights on in the chilled darkness of the early prairie morning. But inside Ernie Williams's John Deere dealership here, another desperate business day is already under way. And the 78-year-old farm equipment dealer himself is pressing his assembled troops.   ''These sales don't come to you anymore, boys,'' he says in a now familiar pep talk in the conference room. ''We gotta be like coon dogs and go out and find the customers. You can't wait like you used to.''

headline: Korean Car Exports Up
abstract: South Korea's exports of cars and trucks climbed 47.6 percent in October from a year earlier, the Korea Auto Industries Cooperative said today. The 4,850 vehicles were worth $18 million, it said. For the first 10 months of the year, exports more than doubled from the year before.

headline: TAXES
abstract: To the Editor:     Bruce Scott contends that a 6-months holding period for long- term capital gains rewards ''speculators'' rather than ''investors.'' That's an old chestnut which I thought good economic analysis had put to rest.

headline: Ireland and Portugal In Accord on Market
abstract: Prime Minister Mario Soares of Portugal and Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald of Ireland, president of the European Economic Community, issued a joint statement tonight calling Portugal's progress toward entry in the Common Market irreversible and setting Jan. 1, 1986, as the date.   There can be no slippage on this date, Mr. FitzGerald said.   Mr. Soares said in a news conference afterward that it was possible that Portugal might enter the Common Market before Spain, although both nations still plan and want to enter at the same time.

headline: POLES SAY POLICEMAN IS HELD IN PRIEST'S ABDUCTION
abstract: A Warsaw policeman was arrested today in connection with the kidnapping of a pro- Solidarity priest, Polish television said.   He was placed under arrest for ''willfully absenting himself from his job'' and failing to provide an adequate explanation for missing work on Friday, the day the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko of Warsaw was abducted, the television report said.   (In Rome, Pope John Paul II appealed for the release of the priest and described himself as ''deeply shaken'' by the abduction.)

headline: BOMBAY SLAYING: ARAB LINK SEEN
abstract: British press reports today linked the assassination of a high-ranking British diplomat in India with the attempted slaying in London two years ago of Israel's ambassador by a Palestinian terror group.   The Times of London said British authorities feared the assassination Tuesday of Percy Norris, Britain's Deputy High Commissioner in Bombay, may be part of a campaign to force Britain to free three Arab gunmen serving long prison terms for the attack on the ambassador, Shlomo Argov.   In Bombay today, policemen searched hotels, airports, ports and railroad stations but reported no progress in the hunt for the killers. Witnesses told the police there was at least one assailant, and he was described as white. One police inspector said the Irish Republican Army might have been responsible for the killing, but police officials said today that they had ruled out that possibility.

headline: A SOVIET DESERTER IN AFGHANISTAN, LIVING IN U.S., WILL RETURN
abstract: A young Soviet soldier who defected in Afghanistan 18 months ago has decided to return to the Soviet Union from the United States. The State Department said today that it was satisfied he made the decision voluntarily.     Soviet Embassy officials brought Nikolai Ryzhkov, 20 years old, to the State Department this morning, and American officials questioned him about his decision.    Department's Comment    Later Alan D. Romberg, a department spokesman, said, ''We have held a meeting in the State Department with Ryzhkov at which he declared that he wished to return to the Soviet Union, and that he made that decision voluntarily.''

headline: MONEY FUND ASSETS UP
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds soared by $4.14 billion in the week ended Wednesday, with the bulk of the money apparently having flowed in on Wednesday.    Analysts were not sure what caused the huge inflow, although the best guess was that investors were trying to lock in relatively high yields in the expectation that short-term interest rates would decline.    The Investment Company Institute reported yesterday that assets in money market mutual funds climbed for the ninth consecutive week, reaching $199.75 billion, up $19.9 billion over the nine-week period.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Allied Corp.'s Industrial Fibers Group said it plans to expand its polyester plant in Moncure, N.C.; the move will add about 20 percent capacity.     *  Cable Advertising Systems Inc., Austin, Tex., said it had acquired Cable Metro Advertising of Birmingham, Ala., and Cable Marketing Systems of Montgomery, Troy and Prattville, Ala. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: BROWNSTONE LOOK RETURNING IN FORT GREENE PROJECT
abstract: The brownstone look may be considered a thing of the past in new- home construction, but a builder in Brooklyn will bring it to Fort Greene with 98 new condominiums to be sold at modest prices.    The builder is the Shnay Construction Company of Queens, and the architect is the firm of Beyer Blinder Belle of Manhattan. The units, in 13 buildings, will be erected on four sites on Fulton Street, Gates Avenue and Adelphi Street along the perimeter of the still largely undeveloped Atlantic Terminal urban renewal area. A groundbreaking is scheduled for December.

headline: Pabst-Heileman Link Advanced
abstract: A Federal judge refused a request to block the $70 million purchase of the Pabst Brewing Company by the G. Heileman Brewing Company and scheduled another hearing for next week. The Stroh Brewery Company had asked Judge John Feikens to issue a temporary restraining order, contending the takeover would violate Federal laws aimed at protecting competition.

headline: Israeli Freeze Gains Backing
abstract: Organized labor and employers' organizations gave final approval tonight to a three- month wage and price freeze intended to help curb Israel's soaring inflation.   Under the program, workers will accept cuts of up to 33 percent in cost-of- living increments, but will receive tax reductions later to compensate for losses in real income.

headline: U.S. BUSINESSMAN TRIES TO RAISE CASH FOR MODERATE GRENADA PARTY
abstract: With elections in Grenada three weeks away, a New Jersey businessman has pledged $2,500 to one of the leading political parties and says he is going to try to raise more money for the campaign from other businessmen in the United States.   ''It's imperative that Grenada survive as a free market because of the commitment the United States has made here,'' said the businessman, Noel J. Blackman, who owns an international seafood processing company in Fort Lee, N.J., and says he plans to open a plant here if the elections on Dec. 3 go the way he wants.   ''The intervention,'' he said, referring to the United States invasion of this island in 1983, ''will set a mold for the Caribbean. If we did something that didn't work out here, if the wrong party got elected, the whole thing would be seen as a colossal failure.''

headline: ANALYSTS STUDYING IMPACT ON WALL ST.
abstract: Wall Street securities analysts disagreed sharply yesterday about Union Carbide's prospects after the industrial accident in Bhopal, India. Although the price of Union Carbide shares has plummeted since Monday's disaster, some analysts said the market has overreacted.   All those who were interviewed agreed that the impact on the company will depend on whether legal liability is or seems likely to be established.

headline: POLISH TV CALLS U.S. SANCTIONS A FIASCO
abstract: Polish television said tonight that the withdrawal of United States objections to Polish membership in the International Monetary Fund was ''another proof of the fiasco of the American policy of sanctions.''   The report on state-run television reflected the disdain with which the Government of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski has sought to dismiss the consequences of the economic sanctions adopted by the United States after the proclamation of martial law on Dec. 13, 1981.    The Polish Government spokesman, Jerzy Urban, said he would have no official response to the action until after an expected formal announcement in Washington on Monday.    A senior Administration official said Friday that the United States had decided to withdraw its bar to I.M.F. entry for Warsaw, one of the last major sanctions and probably the most painful of the measures the Reagan Administration took to punish Poland after the imposition of martial law. The United States lifted the ban after the freeing of political prisoners.

headline: Margeotes Additions
abstract: Three new accounts have arrived within the last few days at Margeotes, Fertitta & Weiss. They are Oxford Industries' Merona Sport, makers of apparel for the whole family, whose former agency was Don Wise Advertising; Hearst's Harper's Bazaar magazine, formerly with Geers Gross Advertising, and Villeroy & Boch for both its tabletop division and bathroom fixture and tile division, formerly handled by the William B. Johns agency and the Siesel Company, respectively.

headline: UNITED TELECOM GAMBLES ON FIBER OPTICS
abstract: WESTWOOD, Kan.   At United Telecommunications  Inc.'s annual meeting last  April, Paul H. Henson, the company's 58-year-old chairman, announced that United Telecom was entering the long-distance communications business in a big way. Over the next decade, he said, it would wire the nation with 23,000 miles of optical fiber cable. ''Given the size of the market and the skills of the company,'' he said, ''we're convinced that we have a unique opportunity.''   United Telecom's announcement took the industry by surprise. Other long-distance carriers had announced plans to build regional fiber optic networks, but none had proposed a project as large as this one. And now analysts are questioning whether United Telecom, a $2.8 billion conglomerate that in recent years had been diversifying away from its basic telephone business, can pull it off.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: FUJI CITES BIG LOSS BY TRADER
abstract: Fuji Bank said yesterday that it had lost about $48 million through unauthorized foreign exchange trading by its chief currency trader in New York.   As a result, the directors of Fuji, Japan's second-largest commercial bank, after Dai-Ichi Kangyo, have agreed to forgo their annual bonuses. In addition, 14 top executives have accepted pay cuts of between 10 percent and 20 percent for six months, and Hajimu Nakazawa, the 32-year-old chief trader, was dismissed Tuesday.

headline: WORLD STEELMAKERS HOPEFUL
abstract: For several years, the world's steelmakers have felt that they were in a bottomless pit, dug by excess capacity and deepened by falling demand. But the dozens of steel executives who assembled here this week for the annual conference of the International Iron and Steel Institute, seemed to feel they had reached bottom and were coming up again.    The steelmakers at the conference, which ended today, are still plagued by worldwide overcapacity, which is depressing prices and decimating profits, and are concerned about protectionist pressures. But there was a distinct note of optimism at the gathering, which included steelmakers from both developing and industrialized nations.    ''I think we will find not too far away a new balance between supply and demand,'' said Jacques P. Michel, associate director general of Usinor, France's largest steelmaker. An optimistic estimate, he said, ''will be in just two or three years, but maybe it will take several more.''

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Executive Retiring From General Mills
abstract: Donald F. Swanson, vice chairman at General Mills Inc. since 1980 and a member of the company's senior management since 1969, said yesterday he plans to retire on Jan. 1.    ''After 35 1/2 years, it's time to get out and see a little bit else of the world,'' the 57-year-old executive said yesterday in a telephone interview.    Mr. Swanson, who joined the Minneapolis-based company in 1949 as a salesman in its grocery products division, said that beyond taking a vacation he had no immediate plans for the future. No successor has been named, but Dean Belbas, a General Mills spokesman, said the matter would be taken up ''in a few days.''

headline: Felec Contracts
abstract: Felec Services Inc. received two Air Force contracts totaling $278.8 million to operate early warning facilities, the Defense Department said. It said the company got $167.1 million for taking care of distant early warning facilities in Greenland, Canada and Alaska, and $111.7 million for ballistic missile early warning system facilities in Greenland, Alaska and Colorado. The department also said the Army had given the Thiokol Corporation $29 million to maintain a Government facility.

headline: Drive Against Illiteracy
abstract: RARELY does a public service advertising campaign come along that the media, ad agencies and advertisers can support with as much enlightened self-interest as the one introduced yesterday by the Advertising Council.   Intended to fight illiteracy by recruiting volunteer tutors, it has the theme ''The only degree you need is a degree of caring.''    What greater tragedy could befall the media, advertisers and agencies than having a population that cannot read or understand what the media and the advertisers are saying?

headline: Asarco, in Loss, Omits Dividend
abstract: Asarco Inc., which earlier this week reported a third-quarter loss of $10.1 million, said it would omit the dividend on its common stock in the fourth quarter. The producer of silver, copper, lead, zinc and other nonferrous metals had been paying a quarterly dividend of 10 cents a share since the second quarter of 1982.

headline: British Aide Is Slain in India
abstract: A British diplomat was shot and killed by one or more unidentified attackers as he walked to work in Bombay today, according to the British High Commission here, the equivalent of an embassy. Percy Norris, 56 years old, Britain's Deputy High Commissioner in Bombay, was shot in the head and the heart, a spokesman said. He was pronounced dead at a hospital.

headline: TEXAS WOES
abstract: To the Editor:     Texas is now becoming involved in the manufacture of high-tech products.

headline: POLISH SPOKESMAN GIVES ACCOUNT OF SLAYING
abstract: The three security officers charged with killing the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko were said today to have been stopped by highway patrolmen who routinely checked credentials as the pro-Solidarity priest lay in the trunk of the car.   The road check was described by Jerzy Urban, the Government spokesman, as he summarized the investigation into the case. The killing has shaken the Government and the ruling Communist Party as well as the Roman Catholic Church and the Solidarity movement.   As recounted by Mr. Urban, the three officers were not diverted either by the traffic check nor by the earlier escape of the priest's driver, Waldemar Chrostowski, from their car.

headline: Patents; Solar Power In Space
abstract: Two inventions that convert sunlight into electricity in space as well as on the ground were patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. According to a spokesman, the devices have proved out during computer tests, but have not yet been built.

headline: WEINBERGER CALLS U.S. SPACE-ARMS EFFORT 'VITAL'
abstract: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that it was ''vital'' that the United States pursue its program of research into a new generation of defensive space weapons.    He said that Europeans who felt such weapons would only defend the United States from Soviet attack and leave Europe vulnerable were wrong.   ''The strategic defense initiative of the kind we're planning will be equally effective and perhaps can secure earlier success in dealing with intermediate range missiles than strategic range weapons,'' he said at a news conference at the Foreign Press Center. ''There's not the slightest possibility that America would be decoupled from Europe by the pursuit of this vital initiative.''

headline: AN AFRICAN MENU GEARED TO THE FLIGHT SCHEDULE
abstract: It was Friday evening, so the man and the woman from France came to Le Safari restaurant, ordered a carafe of wine and then settled at their table, below the trees, relaxed and wafted by benevolent zephyrs.    ''A little patience, it won't be much longer,'' said the woman from France who runs the Le Safari. So they waited a little longer. And waited. And waited.   Then in the distance they heard it, all power and promise, a great roaring of jet engines that came closer and louder until the rumble of its reverse thrust signaled a landing.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: SHORT-TERM RATES OFF SLIGHTLY
abstract: Short-term interest rates fell slightly in quiet pre-holiday trading yesterday, while long-term bond yields were little changed.     Traders said the Federal Reserve's reduction late Friday in the discount rate, what it charges on loans to financial institutions, was widely expected and was not enough to encourage further rate declines.   ''Now the real question is whether or not the Fed will take another step in January toward monetary ease and lower interest rates,'' said one Treasury note trader.

headline: Debt
abstract: *  Higbee Co.  is offering $40 million principal amount of 15 1/4 percent subordinated debentures due in 1999 priced at 98.554 to yield 19.9 percent, through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.     *  Citicorp sold $100 million of 91-day commercial paper at 8.80 percent, down from 8.831 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at 8.993 percent, down from 8.995 percent.      Preferred Stock     *  Philadelphia Electric Co.  is offering 5 million depository preferred shares at $10 a share, through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: V-E DAY 1985: KOHL LOBBIES FOR AN INVITATION
abstract: Making elaborate diplomatic and domestic soundings, Chancellor Helmut Kohl and his closest aides are striving to insure that West Germany is conspicuously included in the 40th anniversary ceremonies next May marking the Nazi surrender and the end of the war in Europe.   ''What we want to avoid at all costs is another Normandy like last summer, with all the Allies on the beaches and us left out,'' one foreign policy adviser said, alluding to the ceremonies in France last June commemorating the 40th anniversary of the Normandy landings. Mr. Kohl was gently rebuffed when he sought to be included at Normandy.   Mr. Kohl is said to be deeply concerned about the May 8 anniversary in part because two days later a crucial election will take place in West Germany's most populous state, North Rhine- Westphalia. A Normandy-style humbling would not help the image of his Christian Democratic Party.

headline: Accountants' Fee Proposal
abstract: The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants has rebuffed efforts by some members to loosen professional guidelines to allow accountants to work on a ''contingency fee'' basis, as lawyers are allowed to do.    The governing council of the 218,000-member association also rejected proposals to drop the group's prohibition against accepting commissions from sellers of financial products or services, as many personal financial planners do.

headline: Loan Suit Dismissed
abstract: A Federal district judge today dismissed charges of negligent lending that were brought against a vice president of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company. The official, James D. Harper, who remains executive vice president in charge of real estate loans, had been charged in a shareholder's suit with making millions of dollars in negligent loans. Three weeks ago, the same judge, John F. Grady, dismissed insider trading charges that were brought against Mr. Harper.

headline: AMF Funds
abstract: AMF Inc. said it expects to recover about $100 million in excess funds from its salaried employee pension plan.

headline: AN ANNUAL REPORT ON 1984
abstract: NO other year was born with the burdens of 1984. Famed in literature, it was feared by many as a time when Big Brother - chillingly portrayed in George Orwell's novel and reviled in Apple Computer's popular commercial - would smother individuality.     But, from the start, the year refused to live up to its reputation. Individualism was rampant and nowhere more than in business. Free- spirited entrepreneurs continued to stun the establishment. And the spirit of capitalism, stirred by a conservative Administration in the White House, spread across the land.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: Albuquerque Federal Savings and Loan Association, a unit of Ameriwest Financial Corp., said it had filed a shelf registration for the sale of up to $100 million in collateralized mortgage obligations through underwriters led by Raucher Pierce Refnes.     *  Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railway said it intends to offer up to $70 million of railroad equipment trust certificates on a continuous basis through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Money Markets.

headline: SHARES OF PHILLIPS SURGE
abstract: The Phillips Petroleum Company's stock jumped $5.50 a share yesterday, to $53.50, in the wake of Tuesday's offer by T. Boone Pickens and his partners to pay $60 a share for nearly 10 percent of the Oklahoma oil giant.     The offer was Mr. Pickens's first step in a takeover bid valued at $9.3 billion.    Phillips, the nation's 11th-largest producer, with worldwide oil and gas reserves of two billion barrels, told stockholders yesterday that they would hear from directors ''soon.'' The company urged the holders not to do anything until then, amid sentiment that Phillips was mobilizing for full-scale war against Mr. Pickens, who is chairman and chief executive of the Mesa Petroleum Company of Amarillo, Tex.

headline: CAPITOL AIR PILOTS PUSH LOAN PLAN
abstract: A committee representing employees of Capitol Air has put together a plan that could provide the ailing carrier with $1 million in cash from a loan some time this week to help it keep operating.    The airline's management, meanwhile, has arranged with its insurance company in Britain to extend the insurance on its planes beyond midnight Saturday, when coverage was due to run out. Without insurance, the airline's six planes - four DC-8's and two Boeing 727-200's - would have been grounded.    An airline spokesman, Lou Garcia, said Friday that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey had warned Capitol that it must pay $2 million in landing and airport fees by Nov. 23 or its lease at Kennedy International Airport would be terminated. Mr. Garcia said Capitol planned to meet that deadline and stay at the airport.

headline: BRIDGING THE CULTURAL GAP
abstract: AS the commercial titans of the   postwar world, most United   States businessmen and women have tended to believe that everyone can - or should - speak English and understand American ways.   To correct that attitude among future managers, two graduate schools have developed intensive programs in what they call ''cross-cultural communications,'' or ''global management.'' They combine a study of the culture - the political system, religion, anthropology - and the language of a country or region, with traditional business school courses.   ''Historically, many international business courses spent most of their time speaking about international blunders by American businessmen,'' said Jerry Wind, director of the Joseph H. Lauder Institute of Management and International Studies at the University of Pennsylvania. ''Now, we are trying to develop a cultural sensitivity.''

headline: Article 060132 -- No Title
abstract: The Treasury will start a major $17.5 billion note and bond financing today with a three-year note auction, followed on Wednesday by 10-year notes and on Thursday with 30-year bonds.    Because the Federal Reserve Bank of New York will be closed on Election Day, the Government securities market will be largely dormant, though some participants will be on hand to prepare for securities to be traded later in the week.   As of late Friday, the three-year Treasury notes to be auctioned this week were offered on a when-issued basis with a yield of about 11.08 percent, while the 10-year notes were 11.61 percent and the 30-year bonds were 11.49 percent.

headline: CENTRIST PARTY SWEEPS TO VICTORY IN GRENADA VOTE
abstract: A centrist coalition party favored by the Reagan Administration swept to victory in elections here today, 13 months after a United States-led invasion put an end to revolutionary government on the island.   With the returns from 90 percent of the country's ballot boxes counted, election officials said that candidates of the moderate New National Party had won 10 of the 15 seats in Parliament and were leading in races for four others. Two of the four races seemed close, the officials said, but they reported that the moderates had substantial leads in the other two.   The election officials said the rival, right-of-center Grenada United Labor Party led by Sir Eric Gairy, a former Prime Minister, had won no seats, but was leading in one race.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Oct. 18, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: NOV. 11-20 AUTO SALES IMPROVED SHARP 28.8%
abstract: Automobile sales improved sharply in the Nov. 11- 20 period, the manufacturers reported here today. Sales by the six major companies jumped 28.8 percent in mid- November from the period last year.   Industry analysts said the seasonally adjusted annual selling rate of 7.9 million was near normal, following a strike-induced slump that brought the rate down to 6.9 million early this month and the same level for all of October.

headline: MARCOS, ABSENT FROM PUBLIC VIEW, IS REPORTED ILL
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos fell ill last week and continues to receive special medical treatment, senior Government officials said today. The President, they say, now seems to be recovering.    On the Government-controlled television newscasts this evening, a photograph of Mr. Marcos was aired, showing him seated, reading today's copy of the largest-circulation pro-Government daily, The Bulletin. In copies of the picture later issued by the presidential palace, Mr. Marcos's fingers appeared swollen.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Nov. 8, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 3 P.M. and 6 P.M.

headline: GHOSTS OF FASCISM INTRUDE ON COLOSSEUM'S SLEEP
abstract: ''The Colosseum Reopens After Two Millenniums,'' the Milan daily, Corriere Della Sera, said in a headline the other day. Now that's news.    A visitor can see immediately that something peculiar is going on. Scattered outside the 2,000-year-old structure are vintage Fiats, a railroad car and some Esso gas pumps from the 1920's - a kind of organized, appealing junkyard.   Perched up the side is an aluminum structure painted white and held together by metal tubes and nuts and bolts. It is designed to imitiate a section of the outer wall of the Colosseum, much of which collapsed ages ago.

headline: ISRAELI JETS ATTACK GUERRILLA BASES 20 MILES EAST OF BEIRUT, KILLING 7
abstract: Israeli Air Force jets attacked Palestinian guerrilla bases in eastern Lebanon today, and 7 people were reported killed and 10 wounded.   The raid, the first in about three months, came 48 hours after two Katyusha rockets were fired into Galilee in Israel.   It was the first Israeli attack in Lebanon under the Government of Prime Minister Shimon Peres, which took office in September.

headline: Czech Communist Party Lauds Nobel Laureate
abstract: The Czechoslovak Communist Party today congratulated the poet Jaroslav Seifert on winning the Nobel Prize for Literature but said the West had used his name to slander the country.   Mr. Seifert, who won the prize Thursday, has been a champion of civil liberties and was a signatory of the Charter 77 human rights declaration.

headline: Washington Watch; Freddie Mac Plan Opposed
abstract: WASHINGTON EDWIN J. GRAY'S plan to shift ownership of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, the quasi-public Government agency, to the nation's savings and loan industry, has hit heavy opposition from an unexpected Administration source: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan.    In an effort to strengthen the financial underpinnings of the thrift industry, Mr. Gray announced a plan Dec. 7 that calls for the distribution of 15 million preferred shares in the Mortgage Corporation to more than 3,000 thrift institutions. The stock would have a book value of at least $600 million.

headline: EGYPTIANS CANCEL FOOD-PRICE RISE AFTER RIOTS IN AN INDUSTRIAL TOWN
abstract: The Egyptian Government announced rollbacks in food prices today, a day after rioting swept a mill town near Alexandria.    Police sources in the town, Kafr el Dawar, reported one person killed, 13 injured and 40 arrested in the riots.    The protest Sunday was the first such incident since President Hosni Mubarak took power in 1981 after the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat.

headline: INDIAN ARMY GETS FREE HAND TO END VIOLENCE
abstract: Armored personnel carriers rumbled through the streets of the Indian capital today, and a senior army officer said the military had been given virtually a free hand to crush the violence.     ''We can shoot to kill and we intend to do exactly that if riots occur again,'' said the officer, who was commanding a unit of the Kumaon regiment at Trilokpuri, a shantytown in the eastern part of the city where scores of Sikhs were said to have been slain by a mob.    ''My orders today are that we no longer need to depend on civil authority to tell us what to do but can take action ourselves,'' said the commanding officer of the army column in Trilokpuri.

headline: PATENTS; ELECTRIC CAR SYSTEM FOR TWO KINDS OF ROADS
abstract: An electrified transportation system that would allow a motor vehicle to run on both conventional and electrified roadways was patented this week for the Chevron Research Company of San Francisco. The inventor, who obtained patent 4,476,947, is Jay D. Rynbrandt, the research scientist on the staff.

headline: Truck Sales Rise 12.9%
abstract: The Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association said sales of trucks in the United States in September increased 12.9 percent, to 271,953, from 240,773 last year. For the year to date, the trade organization said truck sales had risen 35.2 percent, to 2,660,824, compared with 1,968,695 vehicles in the period a year earlier.

headline: NO DANGER TO CHICAGO BANK SEEN
abstract: The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, William M. Isaac, said today that the First National Bank of Chicago was in no danger of failing. The bank announced Wednesday that it would report a third-quarter loss of as much as $74 million.    ''The bank's bitten the bullet, and they should be commended,'' Mr. Isaac said in an interview between sessions of a House banking subcommittee. The panel is inquiring into the Federal regulators' actions in rescuing the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company last May.

headline: Gillespie Agency Starts Division for Magazines
abstract: Gillespie Advertising in Princeton, N.J., has taken a number of its publishing clients and formed a new division called the Magazine Marketing Group.

headline: Dorsey in Move To Halt Investors
abstract: The Dorsey Corporation said it had asked in Federal District Court for a preliminary injunction to restrain a group of investors from acquiring more of its common shares.    It said that, in a related development, two publicly held corporations associated with a member of the investor group had settled another disagreement with Dorsey by agreeing to a permanent injunction against using the assets of the two companies to facilitate their tender offer.

headline: Bond Prices Increase Sharply
abstract: Bond prices rose sharply in active trading yesterday, buoyed by further evidence of an easing in monetary policy by the Federal Reserve.    The rally began early in the day, when the Fed did not drain the banking system of reserves after the closely watched Federal funds rate, the overnight rate on bank loans, fell below 8 percent. More significantly, the drop took the Fed funds rate below the discount rate, which stands at 8 1/2 percent, for the third consecutive trading session.    In conjunction with that plunge - Fed funds closed Friday at 8.26 percent, and averaged 8.55 percent for the five trading days last week - traders were further encouraged when Manufacturers Hanover Trust announced a cut in its prime rate to 10 3/4 percent from 11 1/4 percent.

headline: A DAILY OTTAWA RITUAL TESTS PRIME MINISTER
abstract: Imagine President Reagan and his Cabinet going to Congress every day to defend the Administration's record for 45 minutes before an array of hostile Democrats.   Such a political drama is played daily when the Canadian House of Commons is in session, in a tradition blending British ritual with North American bare-knuckle politics.   The House of Commons, with its elegant neo-Gothic stone arches, stained glass windows and black-frocked pages, offers an incongruous setting for the charges traded between Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, leader of the Progressive Conservative Party, and the opposition Liberal and New Democratic Parties.   Unseasonable Nastiness    In the days before Parliament recessed for Christmas, the adversarial relationship grew unseasonably nasty over a concept that the Canadians call ''universality'' - the extension of social welfare benefits to everyone regardless of income.

headline: Percy Planning to Visit India For a Bid to Mediate Dispute
abstract: Senator Charles H. Percy, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said today that he planned to visit India to try to mediate the internal dispute that resulted in the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.   The Republican Senator, who is in a tight re-election battle in Illinois, said he hoped to make the trip before the end of the year and planned to meet with Mrs. Gandhi's son, Rajiv, who was sworn in as her successor today.

headline: DISMANTLING THE INNOVATIVE D.R.I.
abstract: LEXINGTON, Mass.   FOR one brief shining moment, in   this town where the Minuteman   statue stands guard, there existed an economic Camelot of sorts. It was Data Resources Inc., whose economic forecasts were religiously followed by America's biggest corporations. At D.R.I.'s head was Otto Eckstein, the bright and charismatic Harvard professor who became a multimillionaire when he put his vision of the economy into a 1,200-equation computer model and sold it to corporate clients.   Young people flocked to work with Mr. Eckstein and D.R.I. economic forecasts were required reading from the White House to corporate board rooms. But that day is over: Mr. Eckstein has died and the Camelot he created is gone. D.R.I. is finding that its core business - selling the number crunching ability of its big Burroughs computer - is in trouble and the market for economic analysis is flooded with new entrants. D.R.I.'s profits have fallen, its attempts to switch to new businesses have floundered and the company's corporate parent - McGraw-Hill Inc. - recently carved D.R.I. into little pieces, which are being sprinkled throughout the publishing giant's domain.

headline: Treasury Rates Are Little Changed
abstract: Interest rates were little changed for Treasury issues yesterday as market participants said there were no substantial new developments pointing toward higher or lower interest rates.     In the tax-exempt bond market, however, yields rose as a heavy supply of new issues caused prices to fall by about half a point.   By late in the day, prices of Treasury notes and bonds were up by no more than 1/4 point, with the 12 3/4 percent issue due in 1989 offered at 101, to yield 12.44 percent, and the 12 1/2 percent bonds due in 2014 offered at 101 1/2, to yield 12.31 percent. Short- term interest rates were mixed with small changes.

headline: LATEST IN OIL DRILLING PLATFORMS
abstract: As one nestles down on the North Sea's newest oil production platform following a two- hour helicopter flight from Aberdeen, Scotland, the platform differs little to the untutored eye from its neighbors dotting the horizon here in the productive East Shetlands basin.    But unlike the platforms nearby or in offshore areas around the world, which rest on steel or concrete towers, Hutton is perched above a buoyant hull that is tethered to the seabed by long steel cables. The cables are stretched to hold the hull down in the water, limiting its horizontal movement and eliminating vertical bobbing.   Conoco, the oil company that operates Hutton, is convinced that it represents a design breakthrough that will lead the oil industry into waters far deeper than can be tackled with existing structures.    Hutton, which cost just under $1 billion, or one-third more than originally budgeted, has proved to be marginally more expensive than traditional designs would probably have been.

headline: Black & Decker
abstract: The Black & Decker Manufacturing Company said it would close its plant in Allentown, Pa., which employs 850 people, in early 1986. The plant, bought last spring by the Maryland- based home equipment company, makes toaster ovens and related products. It was acquired by Black & Decker as part of the purchase of the General Electric Company's housewares business.

headline: SURGE IN SAFE-DEPOSIT CENTERS
abstract: The Zurich Depository Corporation, a private safe-deposit company in Manhasset, L.I., will not mark its first year of operation until November. Unlike most start-up companies, however, Zurich has begun to register marginal profits, giving Robert D. Steinfelder, the company's executive vice president and one of the six private investors who pooled the initial capital four years ago, little worry that the venture will fail.    Mr. Steinfelder, whose company has no ties to any Swiss concern, is one of a growing number of entrepreneurs seeking to exploit what they see as a potentially big business: private safe-deposit centers outside of banks.    The centers, which appeared first in Florida, have sprung up across the country. Indeed, there are close to 100 private vault centers in operation nationwide, mostly in major metropolitan areas and more affluent suburbs.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: MONDAY, OCTOBER 22, 1984   The Economy    OPEC members are gathering in Geneva to plan a strategy to avoid an oil price war. The plan will be presented to a formal meeting next Monday. But analysts say that the organization's problems are more complex than the current price of oil. (Page A1.)

headline: Article 090272 -- No Title
abstract: 16 (AP) - Red Lion Inns Inc., a   52-motel chain, said it had   agreed to be acquired for $600   million by an investment group   led by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. Lamont Smith, senior vice   president of the chain, said the   deal could also include investments by the Washington State   Investment Board and the Oregon Investment Council as well   as banks and the Hillman Company of Pittsburgh.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; State Job Agency Offers Bonds to Finance Loans
abstract: The New York Job Development Authority, an economic development bank for businesses in the state, is offering $119.4 million of floating-rate bonds to finance loans to 398 businesses.    The bonds, which are backed by the full faith and credit of the state, are tentatively priced with an initial interest rate of 5.8 percent to Dec. 2, according to underwriters led by Chemical Bank.    Although the bonds have a final maturity of 1999, the interest rate will be adjusted monthly, and investors have the option to put, or redeem, their holdings after seven days' notice. If interest rates decline sharply, the authority has the option to convert the bonds to a fixed rate.

headline: Regan Is Said to Favor Equalizing Tax Burden
abstract: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan told a group of business lobbyists at a private meeting today that companies with the same profits should pay the same amount of taxes, according to someone who attended the meeting.   Mr. Regan, whose department has completed drafting but has not made public a set of proposals that would revamp the nation's tax system, was also quoted as saying that individuals with the same income should pay the same in taxes.   The Treasury's proposals are scheduled to be delivered to President Reagan by Dec. 1. The President has said he will rely on those recommendations in preparing legislation to simplify the tax code that he has promised to send Congress next year.

headline: Navy Plane Job For McDonnell
abstract: The Navy has awarded the McDonnell Douglas Corporation a contract for 300 new training planes, based on a British design, at a cost of $438 million, the Navy said today.    Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. said the award was nearly 50 percent below the originally estimated cost of $810 million because the contract was on a fixed-price basis rather than a cost-plus arrangement.

headline: 12 RELEASED BY SOUTH AFRICA, THEN 6 OF THEM ARE ARRESTED
abstract: Under pressure at home and abroad, South Africa lifted detention orders against 12 activist opponents of apartheid today but immediately charged 6 of them with treason and violating security laws.    Among those whose detention orders were nullified were three men who had stayed in the British Consulate in Durban for 89 days, eluding the police. They were said to fear arrest on new charges if they left.

headline: Solidarity Activist Seized On Broadcasts Charge
abstract: A Solidarity activist who was a witness in cases of reported kidnappings of members of the banned Polish trade union has been arrested and charged with making illegal broadcasts, the official press agency P.A.P. said today.   It said the police in Torun, 140 miles northwest of Warsaw, arrested the activist, Stanislaw Smigiel, an electrical engineer, on Nov. 4 and found he had a transmitter tuned to broadcast on the frequency of Poland's Channel 1 television network.   Underground Solidarity literature has named Mr. Smigiel as a key witness in cases charging that seven union activists were kidnapped and beaten in the Torun area earlier this year.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Alatenn Resources Inc. , Florence, Ala., a holding company involved in natural gas exploration, said that Jerry A. Howard had been named president, succeeding M.D. Prouty Jr., who has been appointed chairman and will continue as chief executive.     *  AMC Entertainment Inc. , Kansas City, Mo., appointed Robert L. Friedman president of its newly formed subsidiary, AMC international.

headline: Arafat Retracts His Offer to Quit
abstract: Cheering supporters carried Yasir Arafat on their shoulders to the rostrum at the Palestine National Council meeting today where he retracted a day-old offer to resign as chairman.

headline: AS DEATH TOLL CLIMBS, INDIA NOW FEARS EPIDEMIC
abstract: The death toll from the gas leak at the American- owned insecticide plant in this central Indian city was reported today to have risen to at least 1,200 and possibly as high as 2,000.     Medical authorities said a growing concern was the threat of epidemics and unanticipated health problems for the more than 50,000 people said to have been affected.   ''We are concerned about the chances of kidney and liver infections, which could begin any time, not once the first 72 hours are over,'' said Dr. N. R. Bhandari, a pediatrician and the superintendent of a hospital in Bhopal. He said he had been told that these were possible side effects and that ''this could lead to more fatalities.''

headline: DUTCH COURT ACTS ON 'RIGHT TO DIE'
abstract: The Netherlands Supreme Court asked an appeals court today to take another look at the case of a doctor who gave a fatal dose of curare to an elderly patient who had begged to die. Many here said they believed the request could result in a landmark case on the issue of euthanasia.     In its action today, the Supreme Court set aside the ruling of another appeals court that had reinstituted criminal charges against the doctor because Dutch law forbids euthanasia. The Supreme Court said medical ethics and standards also had to be considered in determining whether the doctor's actions were justified.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *  California Real Estate Investment Trust, San Francisco, said it had sold its Singer Co. Building in Sunnyvale, Calif., for $1.45 million in cash.     *  Coelco Ltd., Fountain Valley, Calif., said it had completed the acquisition of Synchem Inc. and its wholly owned subsidiary, Base Chemicals, for 1 million shares of Coelco common stock and other considerations valued at more than $3 million.

headline: People
abstract: *  Joseph McGlone has been named to the newly created position of executive vice president and director of creative services at BBDO Direct.     *  William D. Gurley has been appointed to the new post of vice president, marketing and planning at the Diesel Systems Group of Stanadyne Inc.

headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS ; Soybean Prices Gain; Wheat Shows Decline
abstract: Soybean futures prices rebounded today on the Chicago Board of Trade as persistent rain continued to raise concern about damage to crops, particularly in the south central states.   Wheat was lower and corn was mixed.   ''This weather is unbelievable; it continues to be a wretched harvest season,'' said Bob Lekberg, a grain analyst in Chicago with Shearson Lehman/American Express. ''There's no question that yields have been hurt.''

headline: E.E.C. Prices Advance 0.8%
abstract: Consumer prices in the 10 nations of the European Economic Community rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in October from the previous month, the community's statistical service said Friday. That compared with increases of five-tenths of 1 percent in September and four-tenths of 1 percent in August.   For the 12 months ended in October, consumer prices in the Common Market rose 6.7 percent, compared with an 8.4 percent rise in the comparable period a year earlier.

headline: Business Digest; TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 6, 1984
abstract: Companies    Equitable Life agreed to buy Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette for $432 million. Equitable is the nation's third-largest life insurance company and a major manager of money for pension funds. Donaldson, Lufkin ranked 12th in the securities industry. (Page A1.) For Equitable, the merger offers a healthy return on its money for now and a chance to expand its financial services. (D1.) Donaldson, Lufkin is known for its maverick trend-setting ways, but the decision to merge conforms to the trend on Wall Street. (D4.)    Gulf and Western will offer to buy Prentice-Hall for $70 a share, or a total of about $700 million. Prentice-Hall said it will respond later this week. Gulf and Western already owns Simon & Schuster, one of the largest publishers for general audiences. (D1.) Putting together Simon & Schuster and Prentice-Hall, a publisher of college textbooks, would create a major force in book publishing. (D1.)

headline: Marriott to Sell Essex House
abstract: The Marriott Corporation has agreed to sell the luxury Essex House hotel at 160 Central Park South, near Fifth Avenue, to Nikko Hotels International, the hotel division of Japan Air Lines.    J. Willard Marriott, chairman, told a class at Cornell University's School of Hotel Management Friday that his company was selling the Essex because Japan Air Lines ''offered a good price, and it'll be easier to market our new hotel.''

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; New Montefiore Bonds May Be Repaid Early
abstract: The New York State Medical Care Facilities Authority is offering $245.5 million of bonds on behalf of Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx.    The underwriters, led by Paine Webber, tentatively offered the bonds at a price of 100, with an 8 1/2 percent coupon for those due in 1994, a 9 7/8 percent coupon in 2004, a 10 percent coupon in 2009 and a 10 1/4 percent coupon in 2024.

headline: ;  Sports Illustrated
abstract: Mark Mulvoy, assistant managing editor of Sports Illustrated, has been promoted to managing editor by Henry A. Grunwald, editor in chief of Time Inc., replacing Gilbert Rogin, who Mr. Grunwald transferred to Discover as managing editor.

headline: CHURCH SAYS CIVIL RIGHTS IN CHILE ARE ERODING
abstract: Roman Catholic Church officials say that the Government's tactics against protesters this week illustrate what they assert has been a significant new erosion of human rights and civil liberties.     One official, Enrique Palet, executive secretary of the church's Vicariate of Solidarity, said he believed that the Government's respect for human rights and civil liberties had dropped to its worst level in six years.    He said this was evident in the Government's reaction to protests on Monday and Tuesday in which eight people were killed, 25 were wounded and more that 400 were arrested.  The demonstrations were small, but more policemen were on the street than in any days of protest since last year.

headline: SILICON VALLEY SECRECY DRAMA
abstract: It started with a simple clerical mistake at Mosher, Pooley, Sullivan & Henderson, one of the most successful firms in Silicon Valley's fast-growing legal community.    A busy lawyer, making a routine court filing for the National Semiconductor Corporation, neglected to ask the judge to seal a 12-page document. The slip-up was by no means trivial. The document described some of National's most precious trade secrets, the coin-of-the-realm in the cutthroat competition of the Valley.   To the horror of James H. Pooley, one of the firm's senior partners, seven of those trade secrets showed up two weeks ago in Microelectronic News, an industry newsletter whose subscribers include every important competitor of National. ''I can only say it was a shock,'' said Mr. Pooley, whose firm has been paid millions by such companies as Tymeshare, Itek and Verbatim to protect their trade secrets.

headline: 2D ARAB DEMONSTRATOR IN 2 DAYS IS SHOT DEAD BY ISRAELI ARMY FIRE
abstract: In the second such incident in as many days, Israeli soldiers shot and killed a young Palestinian demonstrator today in the occupied West Bank.    Israeli authorities asserted that the soldiers opened fire after the youth and other demonstrators had ignored warnings to stop throwing stones at Israeli vehicles in the town of Ramallah.   On Wednesday, one student was killed and six others were wounded when Israeli troops opened fire to disperse a large crowd of Bir Zeit University students who were pelting Israeli soldiers with rocks and shouting slogans in support of the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, Yasir Arafat.   Agitation Increases      With the Palestine National Council meeting beginning in Amman today, the West Bank has started to boil over with political agitation - partly from Palestinians who want to demonstrate solidarity with their compatriots in Amman and partly because of infighting between pro- and anti-Arafat factions.

headline: A PROFIT AT G.& W.
abstract: Gulf and Western Industries reported yesterday that in the fourth quarter, ended July 31, it earned $74.3 million, or $1.05 a share, in contrast to a loss of $401.6 million for the comparable period a year ago. Sales rose 16.4 percent, to $1.1 billion, from $945 million a year ago.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
abstract: Texas Utility Bonds    The San Antonio electric and gas system is offering $120 million of revenue bonds through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company with a maximum yield of 11.30 percent for 10 3/4 percent bonds due in 2014, which are offered at a price of 95.292. For shorter maturities, yields range from 9 percent for bonds due in 1990 to 10.90 percent in 2004 and 11 1/8 percent in 2009.

headline: GOVERNING PARTY IN SOUTH AFRICA FENDS OFF 3 ELECTORAL CHALLENGES
abstract: The governing National Party retained three parliamentary seats in special elections, fending off challenges by far- right candidates who said the white-minority Government favored sharing power with blacks.   At stake in the elections, held Thursday, were seats in George, President P. W. Botha's constituency east of Cape Town; Primrose, the seat of a former Minister of Cooperation and Development, Pieter G. Koornhof, and Parow, seat of a former Minister of Community Development, Pen Kotze.   In all three races, far-right candidates campaigned on platforms of backing white supremacy and opposing the National Party's nominal changes.   Changes Under New Charter      Mr. Botha switched from Prime Minister to President under a new Constitution that took effect in September and had to surrender his parliamentary seat. Mr. Koornhof and Mr. Kotze took up posts in the new President's Council and also had to leave Parliament.

headline: Northeastern Airways' Cuts Northeastern International
abstract: Airways said it had been forced   to suspend service to five   major cities because Braniff   Inc. had terminated an agreement to lease 10 planes and   crews.  The closely held carrier,   which is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., wanted the 727-200   planes to increase flights during the busy winter schedule.

headline: Scattered Violence Reported In South African Black Areas
abstract: Riot policemen fired tear gas, rubber bullets and birdshot today to disperse a crowd that hurled stones at police patrols in Soweto, South Africa's largest black township.   A police spokesman said one policeman was wounded in the township near here, in the latest flare-up of violence that has claimed more than 80 lives in the last two months.   In the township of Tsakane, east of Johannesburg, the police said they had used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse about 200 people throwing stones after a funeral.

headline: Resignation at Macy's
abstract: Philip Schlein, the chairman and chief executive of Macy's California and a corporate director of R.H. Macy & Company, has resigned in what the company is calling ''an amicable parting.''    Edward S. Finkelstein, chairman and chief executive of R.H. Macy, yesterday confirmed trade reports of Mr. Schlein's resignation that had been persistent all day.
