He also confirmed reports that Harold Kahn, president of Davison's, the Macy's division in Atlanta, would succeed Mr. Schlein at the California division's San Francisco headquarters.

headline: KEY SECTIONS OF ITIALIAN JUDGE'S REPORT ON SHOOTING OF THE POPE
abstract: Following are key sections of Judge Ilario Martella's report, filed today, on the shooting of Pope John Paul II in 1981, as translated by The New York Times from the Italian:      The attempt on the life of the Sovereign Pontiff, John Paul II, which took place in St. Peter's Square on May 13, 1981, represents a monstrous crime against all humanity, as it has offended the conscience of all those who, whether belonging to a religious group or not, recognize the basic Christian values of peace, brotherhood and solidarity for which the Pope seems the most logical standard bearer. Those principles which in fact are contained in every philosophical and historical ideology that does not propose as its end the destruction of man. We have here, therefore, a real act of war against the most authentic lasting values of the civilized world (today more than ever struggling for its own survival and conservation), offended and humiliated by a ''provocation'' that has no precedent in history.

headline: U.S. INVESTIGATING CONTRACTOR GIFTS TO RICKOVER
abstract: The Navy and the Justice Department are investigating evidence that four military contractors gave ''gifts and gratuities'' to Adm. Hyman G. Rickover while the admiral was the head of the Navy nuclear propulsion program, Navy Secretary John F. Lehman said in a letter made public today.    Mr. Lehman said the gifts raised ''the possibility of criminal action'' and could result in the military contractors bring barred from Government business.   Mr. Lehman made his disclosures in a letter to Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, chairman of a House subcommittee that has been investigating gifts to Admiral Rickover from the General Dynamics Corporation, whose shipyards have contracts to build attack submarines and Trident ballistic missile submarines. Mr. Dingell has demanded that the Navy take control of two General Dynamics shipyards because of the gifts.

headline: Huge Rallies Denounce Bangladesh Martial Law
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of people converged on the capital today from throughout Bangladesh to demand an end to two and a half years of martial law, the organizers of three rallies said.   Two alliances of opposition parties and the fundamentalist Jamat-e-Islami Party organized separate rallies in Dhaka, demanding that the President, Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, turn the Government over to caretaker rule until parliamentary elections are held Dec. 8.

headline: VOLUME 3D HIGHEST
abstract: The explosive upsurge in stock prices on Thursday lost much of its spark yesterday, but trading swelled to the third-highest level on record, fueled by heavy participation from pension funds and other institutions.    Prices, which soared Thursday after Norway, Britain and Nigeria disclosed oil price cuts, ended yesterday only slightly higher.   Volume rose to 186.9 million shares, from 149.5 million on Thursday. The total was surpassed only by the 203 million shares traded on Aug. 6 and the record turnover of 236.8 million shares on Aug. 3.

headline: SHULTZ, IN BRAZIL, URGES LATIN 'SECURITY SHIELD'
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States should counter the flow of Soviet arms to Nicaragua by arming Nicaragua's neighbors.    At a news conference just before he prepared to leave a meeting of the Organization of American States here, Mr. Shultz said, ''We have to help our friends put themselves in a capacity to resist the aggression that comes from those arms, and we have been doing so.''   He said the United States should provide other Central American nations with ''a security shield against the aggression that has been launched from Nicaragua against its neighbors,'' and declared that the program to do so ''is increasingly successful.''   Mr. Shultz also stressed that the United States ''has worked quite hard for quite a long time'' on negotiation of a regional peace treaty that he said would lead to disarmament.

headline: THE SOFTWARE TROUBLES AT MANAGEMENT SCIENCE
abstract: When Management Science America Inc. brought its brand-name marketing approach to the microcomputer software business, many analysts said the company had resources to make the strategy work. Last month, however, the company declared its three- year venture into the industry a failure and announced it would sell or spin off its personal computer software division, Peachtree Software Inc.   For Management, which with its mainframe software business will remain one of the nation's three largest independent software companies, the failure was a sobering experience that has at least slightly dampened expectations for its future. And among analysts, the development produced fresh evidence that it takes a smash hit, getting out a broad product line, to succeed in the volatile personal computer software business.

headline: Lonrho Sells Fraser Stake
abstract: Lonrho P.L.C. today abandoned one of the most bitter and longest takeover attempts in British history by selling its 29.9 percent stake in House of Fraser P.L.C., Britain's largest retailing group, to Alfayed Investment and Trust, the investment arm of an Egyptian family involved in oil, shipping, banking and property.   The $171 million sale marked the end of the relentless seven-year campaign by Roland W. Rowland, chairman of Lonrho, a large manufacturing, trading, mining, and property company, to gain control of Harrods, the well-known department store that is the crown jewel of the Fraser chain. The sale price left Lonrho with a tax-free profit of about $90 million, a company spokesman said.

headline: Main Office Of Crocker To Be Sold
abstract: The Crocker National Corporation said yesterday that the Prudential Insurance Company of America had agreed to purchase Crocker Center in downtown San Francisco for $358 million in cash.    Crocker, the holding company for the Crocker National Bank, the nation's 14th largest, said that the proceeds would be used to restructure and strengthen its balance sheet.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct. 15, 1984:  MONDAY Dana CorpJohnson & JohnsonEastern Utils AssocLilly (Eli) & CoFlorida Pwr & LtSouthern Co  TUESDAY Bearings IncInter First CorpBemis CoK Mart CorpCBI IndusScott PaperChase Manhattan Southern Ind G & EDonaldson Lufkin Stauffer ChemicalFleming CosTexas Commerce BancGt Western FinlTexas IndusHoneywell IncVF Corp  WEDNESDAY Alberto-CulverIntl Min & ChemBanc Texas GroupMagic ChefBarnett Banks FlaMelville CorpCessna AircraftNewhall Land & FarmConrac CorpPNB Mtge & RltyContinental GroupSunstrand CorpDow Jones & CoUnidynamics CorpEquitable GasWisc Pwr & LtHillenbrand Indus   THURSDAY   Alagasco IncNatl Can CorpArcher-DanielsNiagara Mohawk PwrArizona Pub ServOwens-Corning FiberBell & HowellPotomac Elec PwrBlack & DeckerPublic Serv N HCoca-Cola CoReynolds (RJ) IndCollins & AikmanSouthern UnionDiamond ShamrockStandex IntlFirst Wisc CorpTECO Energy IncGeneral SignalThomas IndusGillette CoTransamerica CorpIowa-Ill G & ETull (JM) IndusKollmorgen Corp   FRIDAY Acme ElectricIllinois Tool WksAmericana Hotels Mass Mutual InvestBundy CorpMay Dept StoresCentl Louisiana ElecMcNeil CorpFlowers IndusWachovia Corp

headline: Financial World Executive Changes
abstract: Mark J. Meagher has stepped up to the chairmanship of Financial World magazine and has moved Douglas A. McIntyre, 29 years old, into his former slot in the publishers pew. He believes he has the youngest publisher of a major American magazine.

headline: Soviet Prime Minister Pays Visit to Turkey
abstract: Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov of the Soviet Union arrived in Ankara today on a two-day visit to this NATO country in which he and Prime Minister Turgut Ozal are expected to sign agreements on trade and technology.    Mr. Tikhonov, who was accompanied by a 95-member delegation, is the first Soviet Prime Minister to visit Turkey since Aleksei N. Kosygin in 1975.

headline: A FILIPINO ON THE SPOT
abstract: For Gen. Fabian C. Ver, who has been at the side of Ferdinand E. Marcos since the two were toddlers, the position of Chief of Staff of the armed forces was earned as a result of unquestioned loyalty to the President.  The personal bond between the two men, who are cousins, became a nettlesome political issue for President Marcos today. General Ver was accused in the majority report by the panel investigating the assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. last year as being part of a military plot to kill Mr. Aquino.    General Ver immediately stepped down, taking a ''temporary leave of absence.'' The general declared his innocence and, clearly, was distraught and angered by the panel's accusations.

headline: INDIVIDUALS ARE BUYING BONDS IN RECORD NUMBERS
abstract: WITH bond yields remaining high, individual investors are diving into the bond markets in record numbers. Indeed, while high interest rates have been a bane to home buyers and other borrowers, as well as to economists concerned about the strong dollar, they have been a boon to individual investors. In the past few years, small investors, who normally have bypassed the bond markets, have decided the yields are too good to pass up.    Nowhere is this more evident than in tax-exempt municipal bonds. Once the domain of institutional investors, such as banks and insurance companies, that market is now inundated with small investors, who buy about three-fourths of all new tax-exempt bonds. The appeal of tax-exempt bonds, which are issued by states, local governments and local government authorities, is that the interest paid on them is free from Federal income tax.    ''Why invest in a money market fund earning 11 percent, when you have to give back half of it in taxes?'' asked Howard Brody, a New York City insurance broker. ''I'm better off buying New York Power Authority paying 10 percent.''

headline: 3d-Party Fees Spur Inquiries
abstract: Both the Securities and Exchange Commission, which has jurisdiction over money management organizations, and the Labor Department, which oversees the nation's pension plan system, are investigating the use of brokerage commissions to pay for third-party services.   Richard Wessel, associate director of the Division of Market Regulation at the S.E.C., said he was concerned about abuses where companies pay more than the lowest possible commissions.

headline: Insurance Merger In Canada Set
abstract: The Manufacturers Life Insurance Company said it had agreed in principle to buy the Lincoln National Life Insurance Company's 89 percent holding in the Dominion Life Assurance Company for about $157.50 (Canadian currency) a share, or about $140.2 million.

headline: CENTRUST OFFERS EUROBOND ISSUE
abstract: Centrust Savings and Loan Association, a $3.6 billion Florida chartered savings and loan formerly known as the Dade Savings and Loan ASsociation, is offering $1.2 billion face amount of zero coupon collateralized Eurobonds due in 25 years at a price of 5,995, or $59.95 per $1,000 bond, through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities. The idfference between the purchase price and the face value equals a semiannual yeild of 11.58 percent.

headline: Advertising; Revival at No Nonsense
abstract: WHEN you have a product lying dead in the water even though it is good and has adequate distribution, it is time to call on advertising superwomen.   At Grey Advertising that means turning to Judy Tabak, a copywriter, and Marzena Szczeniowska, an art director. Their ideas helped win back the No Nonsense Comfort Stride Support Pantyhose account in July after a two-year absence.    The results of their efforts will be seen today on all three commercial networks. The single 30-second spot caused Richard Kiernan, executive vice president and creative director, to say: ''We think it is the kind of breakthrough creative that is needed. But we're taking risks, and the client is taking risks because nobody has done this before.''

headline: Gunfight in Ulster
abstract: A police patrol killed a man suspected of being a guerrilla in the Irish National Liberation Army, a Marxist offshoot of the largely Roman Catholic Irish Republican Army, in a gun battle today after seven soldiers were wounded in a land-mine ambush near Armagh, the police reported.

headline: Life Sets Trade Ad Campaign
abstract: In the Time Inc. organziation, Time may be the weekly news magazine, Money America's financial adviser, Fortune for members of the business class and Sports Illustrated just what it says it is, but what is Life?    According to Charles A. Whittingham, the publisher, the now-monthly publication has for years defied attempts at simple positioning.

headline: Steel Accord Eludes E.E.C.
abstract: The nations of the European Economic Community failed today to agree among themselves about a proposed accord with the United States that would limit exports of community -produced steel tubes and pipes, a spokesman for the community said.   The members of the community. generally known as the Common Market, disagreed on how to divide a proposed United States market share for their tube and pipe exports, he said.

headline: RATE CUT SPURS 11.16 DOW RISE
abstract: The stock market celebrated Christmas a day early yesterday as prices advanced sharply, propelled by the Federal Reserve's cut in the discount rate late Friday.    However, it was anything but a merry Christmas for investors in Phillips Petroleum, which plunged 9 5/8 points, to 45 1/4, and topped the most active list. An investor group announced late Sunday that it had agreed to end its attempt to acquire the company. Shares of other oil companies rose, however.

headline: S.E.C. Cites Jake Butcher
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged Jake Butcher, whose Tennessee banking empire collapsed in 1982, with violating the antifraud provisions of Federal securities laws.    Michael K. Wolenski, administrator of the commission's Atlanta regional office, said the complaint was filed in Federal court in Little Rock, Ark., against Mr. Butcher, former chairman of the board of directors and chief executive officer of the failed United American Bank of Knoxville, Tenn.; George W. Ridenour Jr. of Knoxville, an attorney and former director and general counsel for the bank, and Jesse A. Barr of Knoxville, a banking and financial consultant to Mr. Butcher.

headline: RESENTMENT GROWS IN SPAIN ON E.E.C.
abstract: Resentment is growing in Spain as negotiations for its entry into the European Economic Community, though tantalizingly close after seven years, still drag on because of the Common Market's inability to set conditions.   Foreign ministers from the 10 member countries are scheduled to meet Monday in Luxembourg, their fourth meeting in a month on the Spanish question, amid fears that the resentment is stoking popular opposition to Spain's membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and, in a psychological way, membership in Europe itself.   The sinking of a Spanish fishing trawler Friday by Ireland's navy in Irish waters has further heightened the tension surrounding the negotiations. Fishing is one of the major unsolved issues, along with tariffs and Spain's huge production of wine and olive oil.

headline: Patents ; Palladium Coating Cuts Costs
abstract: WASHINGTON   A method of plating telephone and other apparatus with palladium, patented this week for AT&T; Bell Laboratories, is described as having saved millions of dollars annually since it was introduced three years ago.  The process, invented by Joseph A. Abys and Harvey S. Trop of the chemical process department at Murray Hill, N.J., permits electronic equipment to be plated with a ''gold- flashed'' palladium instead of pure gold.

headline: Greece Eases Stand On Enlarging Market
abstract: Greece lifted its objections today to European Economic Community terms of entry for Spain and Portugal, clearing the way for final negotiations.    But it still threatens to veto Spanish and Portuguese entry unless the 10 nations agree to a multi-billion dollar Mediterranean aid program.

headline: People
abstract: Charles P. Jacoby has been appointed vice president of marketing for the Fruehauf Corporation, Detroit.

headline: FOR SALE: REACTORS, CHEAP
abstract: Need a General Electric nuclear reactor? National Content Liquidators will sell one for a rock-bottom $350,000 - well below the original multimillion-dollar price tag.    The company, which is based here, specializes in selling things that companies no longer want. Traditionally, that has meant equipment from obsolete steel mills and the furnishings of aging hotels. But these day, NCL, as the company is known, is also unloading equipment from abandoned nuclear power projects.

headline: Ill Tunisian Leader Gaining
abstract: The condition of Tunisia's 81-year-old President, Habib Bourguiba, who was hospitalized a week ago, continues to improve, a medical bulletin said today. The bulletin, signed by three doctors, said Mr. Bourguiba ''passed a good night'' and this morning saw Prime Minister Mohamed Mazli for a briefing on national affairs. Mr. Bourguiba entered the hospital last Monday with heart trouble.

headline: ECONOMIC CRISIS IN ISRAEL MAY REMOLD THE COUNTRY
abstract: For the first time since the founding of the Israeli state in 1948, an economic crisis, much more than any immediate military threat, has come to preoccupy the nation.   ''Before, they used to say that every Israeli had to be a general,'' said Yaacov Fisher, senior economist at the Bank of Israel. ''Now they say that every Israeli has to be an economist.''    The crisis, economists say, has been produced partly by excessive military burdens but also by the peculiar structure of Israel's political system, the economic restraints of Zionism, years of living beyond the nation's means and sheer mismanagement by some of its governments.      A Different Israel to Emerge      The Israel that emerges from the crisis, the analysts here contend, will be a different place, with a lower standard of living for its citizens, a lower military budget, some very high unemployment or a combination of the three. It will also be an Israel that is much more dependent on foreign creditors, in particular the United States.

headline: COKE, PEPSI TO USE MORE CORN SYRUP
abstract: Pepsico Inc. and the Coca-Cola Company, the two giants of the soft- drink industry, said in separate announcements yesterday that they would significantly increase the use of a corn-based sweetener in their regular and caffeine-free cola drinks in the United States.     Analysts said the decisions underscore the long-building preference of the soft-drink industry for high-fructose corn syrup - which is less expensive than the traditional cane- or beet- based sweetener - as well as the shrinking market of the sugar industry.   Pepsico said it would exclusively use high-fructose corn syrup to sweeten its bottled, canned and fountain-drawn Pepsi-Cola and Pepsi- Free soft drinks. Since last year the company, whose headquarters are in Purchase, N.Y., had been using high- fructose corn syrup in 50- and 80-percent ratios in its regular products, a spokesman said.

headline: ALBANIA OPENING ITS DOOR TO BONN
abstract: In a year that has seen Albania move gradually toward expanding relations with other European countries, the Albanian Government is making slow progress in improving relations with West Germany, according to Western diplomats.    The negotiations have been conducted since last summer in Vienna and more recently in Bonn, the diplomats said, between an official of the West German Foreign Ministry and several Albanians described as being ''attached to the Foreign Ministry'' in Tirana, the Albanian capital.    For a number of years, the Communist leadership under Enver Hoxha has declared that West Germany, as the acknowledged successor state to the Third Reich, owed huge reparations to Albania. The issue has been the main obstacle to setting up of diplomatic ties between Bonn and Tirana.

headline: FRANCE'S NUCLEAR CUTBACKS
abstract: The French Government is taking an ax to its nuclear power program - the most ambitious in the world - because the country's appetite for electricity is growing less than planners had hoped.    After another in a series of cutbacks, France will build only one reactor next year and one in 1986. That schedule is a considerable comedown from the five or six reactors a year built during the 1970's when the country was hurrying to reduce its dependence on oil from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.   Today, the program is credited with having helped make France the world's leading seller of nuclear goods and services. But the program's very success has left the Government concerned that it may have gone too far, that by the 1990's France may be burdened with an expensive surplus of nuclear power unless it can increase electricity use inside the country and increase exports of nuclear- generated current to its neighbors.

headline: Denver Airport's $170 Million Issue
abstract: A $170 million issue of revenue bonds for the Stapleton Airport in Denver was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 10.504 percent for bonds due in 2000, according to underwriters led by Boettcher & Company.

headline: MURDER CHARGES IN PRIEST'S DEATH
abstract: An Interior Ministry official said today that murder charges would be filed soon against three security officers arrested in the killing of a pro-Solidarity priest.    As the official spoke, a pathologist appointed by the Roman Catholic Church began an autopsy on the body of priest, the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko. The body was found Tuesday in a reservoir in northern Poland 11 days after his abduction. The autopsy was conducted in the presence of a church-designated lawyer.

headline: Georgia Federal
abstract: Georgia Federal Bank said it had signed an agreement to acquire all of the stock of First Family Financial Services H.C. Inc., a subsidiary of the First Atlanta Corporation, for $36 million. First Family, a consumer finance company, operates in nine states and has total assets of about $150 million. Georgia Federal said it expected to complete the transaction by Jan. 2.

headline: Lebanese Soldier Killed
abstract: A Lebanese soldier was killed and three other people were wounded in fighting between army units and gunmen in Beirut today, military sources said. Three other people were wounded south of Beirut in fighting between the mainly Druse Progressive Socialist Party and the Christian Lebanese Forces militia.

headline: Insider Reports
abstract: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.   The reports of changes follow:  NEW YORK EXCHANGE      COMBUSTION ENGINEERING INC.

headline: BRANIFF ACTS TO RENT OUT PLANES
abstract: In an effort to improve its financial position, Braniff Inc. is negotiating the lease of eight of its planes and crews to Continental Air Lines.    Michael Cinelli, director of public relations at Continental, said in an interview yesterday, confirming the negotiations, that Continental needed the additional planes because ''we are fully utilizing our fleet, and there are no more aircraft on the line.''

headline: RENEWING A 1910 BUILDING ON MADISON
abstract: When the new owners of the 21- story office tower on the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and 42d Street scraped through layers of old paint last summer to check the condition of the windows, they made a discovery - the window frames throughout the 74-year-old building were made of copper.   They have since cleaned and refinished some of the frames and plan to redo them all as part of a general renovation that will bring back some of the classic features of the building, which was erected in 1910 as the headquarters for Union Carbide.        The building, whose address is 310 Madison Avenue, was purchased in June, along with three smaller adjacent buildings taking up the entire Madison Avenue frontage from 42d to 41st Streets, by Madison Plaza Associates, a limited partnership. The new owners intend to spend $3.5 million to renovate the building, restoring the lobby and public corridors and updating the heating, cooling, plumbing and elevator systems.

headline: Southland Financial Stake The New York investor Ivan
abstract: F. Boesky and a group of companies he controls increased   their stake in the Southland   Financial Corporation to   1,654,723 shares, or 9.9 percent   of the common stock outstanding, they told the Securities and   Exchange Commission. The holding includes 70l,000   shares purchased at $34.375 to  $38 a share between Oct. 1 and   Oct. 4, the filing said.

headline: U.S. ASKS UNESCO FOR MORE CHANGES
abstract: The United States expressed dissatisfaction today with proposals for improving the way Unesco operates drawn up by a special committee and said it would seek to strengthen them by making additional proposals of its own.    The United States delegate to Unesco, Jean Gerard, told the organization's Executive Board that the special 13-nation committee formed to consider Western criticisms of Unesco had failed ''to make the kind of far-reaching recommendations for which we saw most need'' or to propose ways of insuring that changes it did recommend get carried out.   As a result, Mrs. Gerard said, the United States will soon propose additional changes in several areas of Unesco's operations to its 51-member Executive Board.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: PRIEST REPORTED TO HAVE BEEN BEATEN
abstract: A pro- Solidarity priest was beaten, gagged and tied up before he was thrown into a reservoir, sources who attended his autopsy said today.   The sources said the post-mortem showed the priest, the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, was probably alive but unconscious when his body was dumped into the reservoir at Wloclawek, 80 miles northwest of Warsaw, where it was found last week. Some water was found in his lungs, they added.   The Government has blamed three members of the security police for the slaying.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1984   The Economy    New orders for goods and services fell in September for the first time since December 1982, according to a survey of purchasing managers. They said that the growth in new jobs also ended in September, as the group's composite index declined. (Page D1.)

headline: U.S. AND ISRAELIS IN WAR GAMES
abstract: Ships and aircraft of the United States and Israeli navies began a joint antisubmarine warfare exercise in the Eastern Mediterranean today, the Defense Department said.    Pentagon officials said that except for a medical evacuation drill last summer, it was the first time the two countries had practiced military maneuvers since President Reagan's agreement a year ago to increase military cooperation between the two countries.

headline: U.S. Lets Heileman Make Its Pabst Bid
abstract: The Justice Department said yesterday that it would not challenge the bid by the G. Heileman Brewing Company to acquire the Pabst Brewing Company for $63 million after Heileman said it would dispose of certain assets.    Pabst's board, which is scheduled to meet on Monday, has not yet taken a position on the Heileman offer or on a tender offer by Paul Kalmanovitz, a 79-year-old California investor. Both are offering $10 a share.

headline: IF THE SUN CO. WERE A TARGET
abstract: THE Sun Company, one of the nation's major   oil producers, apparently does not regard itself as a takeover target, but some Wall Street analysts do - at least potentially.    Theodore A. Burtis, Sun's chairman, told stockholders last April that, although there was ''no evidence that someone is interested in taking over your company,'' he felt that ''prudent steps are always in order.'' So he requested and won stockholder approval of an amendment to Sun's articles of incorporation.    ''On many occasions in recent years,'' he explained, ''shareholders of some companies have been badly treated because of hostile takeovers, which were made in two steps. In the first step, an acquiring company pays one price, usually in cash, to obtain a majority shareholder position. Then, in a second step it offers a different price, usually lower and often for a consideration other than cash and of questionable value, for the remaining outstanding shares.''

headline: MORTGAGE LOAN RATES DIP AGAIN
abstract: Interest rates on new home loans dropped for a fourth consecutive month in November, hitting their lowest level since last spring, the Government reported today.    Commitments for fixed-rate, long- term mortgages averaged 14.16 percent in early November, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said.

headline: Sunglasses Added
abstract: Calet Hirsch & Spector, a longtime agency for Corning Glass Works, has received an additional assignment, Serengeti sunglasses.

headline: DEBATE OVER TAX REFORM; THE PRIORITY IS STEMMING THE RED INK
abstract: IN the furor over tax reform, it   would be folly to lose sight of the  imperative need for added tax revenues to cut the deficits. Now that the White House has brought the true sizes of those deficits to light - $200 billion a year and up for years to come - the thin ranks of the no-tax- increase cult have been further depleted. This is as it should be in light of the mounting damage the deficit is inflicting on the economy and the impossibility of controlling deficits by budget cuts alone.   Clearly, ''growing our way out of the deficit'' is a non-starter. Martin S. Feldstein, former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, has pointed out that even with a wholly implausible 5 percent rate of real growth, the deficit would still hang at $150 billion by the fiscal year 1989; at the growth rates that prevailed in the 1970's, it would be more than $300 billion.

headline: TREASURY OFFERS SWEEPING REVISION OF U.S. TAX SYSTEM
abstract: The Treasury Department today presented its proposal to restructure the nation's tax system in a way that would affect the income taxes paid by nearly every person and company in America.   It received a noticeably unenthusiastic response from President Reagan and Congress.   The Treasury argued that its plan to reduce tax rates while eliminating many popular deductions and other tax preferences was fairer, simpler and more conducive to economic growth than the current system.   But the President took care to say that many changes might be made before tax legislation is submitted to Congress next year, and leading members of Congress expressed doubt that such a sweeping plan would be enacted.   A Comparison of Rates    Altogether, according to Treasury officials, taxes paid by individuals would be lowered by 8.5 percent, and taxes paid by companies would be raised by 25 percent. The total tax revenue received by the Government would be essentially the same as it is now.

headline: Sumitomo Trust
abstract: The Sumitomo Trust and Banking Corporation said it had signed an agreement with the Security Pacific Corporation of Los Angeles for a venture to offer mutual fund managment advisory services in both countries.

headline: Dow Drops 12.59, to Close at 1,206.60
abstract: Stock prices dropped yesterday in heavier trading, reflecting the weakness in bond prices and concern over the huge Government budget deficits and the slowing economy.    The Dow Jones industrial average, which opened lower and gradually increased its losses, closed off 12.59 points, to 1,206.60.   The overall market posted its fifth consecutive loss, with declining issues outnumbering those that rose by more than a 2-to-1 ratio as volume expanded to 69.8 million shares, from 55.6 million shares on Monday.

headline: Israeli Rate Information
abstract: Israel's Central Bureau of Statistics today announced that because of high inflation it would release figures on the skyrocketing cost-of-living twice a month instead of once, beginning later this month. With inflation now running at 800 percent a year, business and trade leaders need faster information, a spokesman for the bureau said.

headline: Stake Increased In Gulf Broadcast
abstract: A group of investors led by the American Continental Corporation told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its stake in the Gulf Broadcast Company to 10,822,846 common shares, or 24.7 percent of the shares outstanding. The group said it bought 2,460,000 shares on the open market for $27.8 million between Nov. 9 and Nov. 12.

headline: Union Planters To Stop Payouts
abstract: The Union Planters Corporation said that it had entered into agreements with the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis and the Comptroller of the Currency to raise its primary capital and that the agreements would prevent it from paying dividends.

headline: Mortgage Lending Off
abstract: Mortgage lending at the nation's savings institutions dropped 28 percent in September to $11 billion, the lowest level since last February, the United States League of Savings Institutions announced yesterday.   William B. O'Connell, president of the savings association, said the drop in mortgage lending volume to the level of last February was a ''further confirmation that the economy weakened in the third quarter.''

headline: MCDONALD'S DISPUTE ON COAST
abstract: McDonald's paid $4.7 million last week to Charles Griffis, a black franchise operator with four inner-city restaurants in Los Angeles. Mr. Griffis's lawyers say the money is in settlement of Mr. Griffis's charges of race discrimination.    McDonald's, however, characterizes the payment differently.

headline: IN INDONESIA, A WILDERNESS IS NOW HOME
abstract: It has been called the largest organized peacetime relocation of people in recorded history. But to a 42-year-old farmer named Sukardji, Indonesia's ''transmigration'' program has a more concrete definition: his own home, on his own piece of land; a kerosene lamp, a radio and a new life.    A year ago, Mr. Sukardji was a landless farm laborer in Java, living with more than a dozen people in a house he did not own. In February, he and his wife, Suhartini, and their three children were one of 600 pioneering families to open a settlement called Koya Timur, on virgin farmland carved from a relentless jungle here in West Irian, Indonesia's part of the wild, remote island of New Guinea.

headline: Stocks Still Weak; Dow Off 4.52 Points
abstract: Stock prices continued to weaken yesterday, on trader fears that the Federal Reserve might not loosen its monetary policy further.    The Dow Jones industrial average fell 4.52 points, to 1,188.94, bringing its loss for the week - most of it in the last three sessions - to 31.36 points. The Dow soared 32.36 points the week before.

headline: NICARAGUAN SAYS SOVIET SHIP CARRIED ONE OR TWO MILITARY COPTERS
abstract: A senior Nicaraguan official said today that a Soviet ship that docked at the Pacific port of Corinto Wednesday was carrying one or two helicopters for the Nicaraguan Army.     The official, who asked not to be named but who is one of the country's most important policymakers, denied that any advanced aircraft were either on the vessel or aboard any other ship heading toward Nicaragua.    ''We are not receiving planes of any type,'' he said. ''The one or two helicopters from that ship can hardly be considered strategic weapons that threaten the security of the United States or its allies. They are to defend ourselves against a war of aggression.''

headline: RELIEF SHIPS FROM NORTH DOCK IN INCHON
abstract: Four North Korean cargo ships loaded with relief supplies sailed into this port today, an unprecedented event that went unnoticed by virtually everyone who lives here.    Never before had a North Korean vessel entered a South Korean harbor for peaceful purposes. The four ships pulled up alongside a large cargo terminal in darkness early this morning, and then allowed dozens of South Korean laborers on board to unload 25,000 tons of cement intended to aid flood victims in nearby Seoul.   It was a landmark contact between countries that have been implacable enemies, maintaining a steady war of propaganda and mutual denunciation since their three-year shooting war ended in 1953.

headline: TEXT OF STATEMENT BY SHULTZ ON U.S.-INDIAN LINKS
abstract: Following is the text of a statement given to reporters today by Secretary of State George P. Shultz after he met with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi:      This is a sad day for India, the United States and people who stand for democracy around the world. Let it also be a day when India can be proud of the legacy of Indira Gandhi, who stood for India's commitment to democracy, peace and justice. I had the honor today to meet with India's new Prime Minister. I told him of President Reagan's personal sense of respect and admiration for Indira Gandhi and of the President's desire to continue the fruitful dialogue and renewed positive trend in Indo-American relations that have taken shape over the past few years.

headline: Iraqi Planes Said to Raid Town and Village in Iran
abstract: Iraqi aircraft raided an Iranian town and a village in a valley near the southern front of the Persian Gulf war today, killing at least 14 people and wounding nearly 100, the official Iranian press agency reported.

headline: NAVY ASKS G.E. TO SHARE CONTRACT
abstract: In an effort to introduce more competition into Pentagon procurement, the Navy has proposed that the General Electric Company be required to share with its chief rival, Pratt & Whitney, the technology for an aircraft engine that the Navy expects to buy for the next 20 years, according to an internal memorandum.    The proposal, made by Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr., is part of a continuing Defense Department effort to save money by moving away from single suppliers.    A spokesman for General Electric said in a telephone interview from Lynn, Mass., today that his company had been informed of the Navy proposal but had not yet agreed to it. It is not clear, the spokesman added, whether the Navy could legally force his company to share the technology for the F-404 engine. Until now G.E. has faced no competition in the sale of the F-404 to the Navy.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Empire Safe Co. to Eisenman & Enock.     * Data Clean Corp., Keyport, N.J., to Allen Consulting in Holmdel, N.J.

headline: PATENTS; ULTRASONIC GLAUCOMA TREATMENT
abstract: WASHINGTON  An ultrasonic instrument that has been used successfully in treating glaucoma, a sight- threatening disease, will be patented next week for the Riverside Research Institute and Cornell University Medical College in New York City.  The instrument, to be covered by patent 4,484,569, is an electrically driven transducer assembly for aiming ultrasound during the treatment of diseases of the eye and other organs.

headline: BRITISH COAL MINERS BATTLE AS STRIKE WEAKENS
abstract: Thousands of striking coal miners armed with firebombs and homemade spears fought with the police in northern England and Wales today while hundreds more broke ranks and returned to work. The police said 54 people were injured in one of the worst nights of violence so far.   Bands of miners - on strike for 36 weeks - rampaged through a dozen coalfield villages, tossing gasoline- bombs, ripping down concrete lampposts and setting cars afire, the authorities said.

headline: Pan Am's Plight
abstract: To the Editor:     In spite of the appearance of balance, ''Pan Am, Still Hurting, Now Tackles the Unions'' (Sept. 23) ends up being a brief for Pan Am management.    It is misleading to write that    ''of late  the Pan Am saga has soured.'' Pan Am almost went bankrupt as far back as 1973. Employees then rallied behind the blue ball. They not only lobbied Congress on its behalf but volunteered concessions before they were fashionable.

headline: 6 Solidarity Activists Are Said to Go on Trial
abstract: Six Solidarity activists have gone on trial on charges of disobeying a Government order to surrender printing equipment from one of the offices of the banned union, according to a lawyer following the case.   The lawyer, Jerzy Kurcjusz, said in a telephone interview Thursday that the six went on trial Wednesday on charges of ignoring an order to hand over typewriters and printing machines from the Solidarity office in the southern city of Katowice.

headline: Steel Output Rises by 4.8% By The Associated Press Steel production rose 4.8 percent, to 1.517 million tons, in the
abstract: week ended Oct. 27, from the   previous week's 1.447 million   tons, the American Iron and   Steel Institute said yesterday. The industry's production   amounted to 58.6 percent of capacity during the week, up   slightly from 55.9 percent in the   previous week. Estimated figures for the   year to date showed production   at 77.679 million net tons, a 15.2   percent increase from the   67.446 million net tons in the   previous year.

headline: West German Bankers Held
abstract: The three former managing partners of Schr"oder, M"unchmeyer, Hengst, the private bank that nearly collapsed last year because of excessive loans made to a failed construction machine group, have been detained by the police on suspicion of bankruptcy fraud, officials said today.   Reinhard Rochus, a spokesman for the Frankfurt prosecutor, said the police detained Count Ferdinand von Galen, 49 years old; Hans Lampert, also 49, and Wolfgang Stryg, 47, on Sunday.

headline: U.S. SYSTEM IS IN PLACE FOR CURBING DISASTERS
abstract: A highly organized Federal emergency response network now in place across the country could contain, but not entirely prevent, disasters of the kind caused by the leak of lethal gas in India, Government officials said today.    ''Any time you deal with chemicals there is a risk, but the chance of it happening here is much less than in India,'' said John J. Stanton, director of the Environmental Protection Agency's emergency response division. ''We are better able to respond quickly, to evacuate people and come in with cleanup operations.''   Under a national contingency plan prepared with the authority of the Federal toxic waste cleanup law, the E.P.A. and the United States Coast Guard operate a national response team, set up to deal with chemical spills and other environmental emergencies. The Coast Guard is responsible for emergencies in coastal areas and the E.P.A. for those in inland areas.

headline: HOUSING BUILT IN A FORMER PEEKSKILL RELIGIOUS SCHOOL
abstract: In a hallway of the old St. Mary's School, an ancient-looking, green-tinged copper door opens onto a small room about the size of a closet.     ''The historical group said we had to save the door, but the building code prevented us from actually using it, because it was too narrow,'' said Jerry Dyller, an engineer for PLK Associates, a New York-based developer's group.   Mr. Dyller points to the copper door as an example of what he calls ''serving two masters.'' In Peekskill, where several large tracts of land previously owned by religious groups have been sold for private development in the last few years, Mr. Dyller's use of such biblical phrasing is quite apt. From its inception, the rehabilitation project at St. Mary's has been caught up in a tangle of local and Federal requirements.

headline: ETHIOPIA SAYS U.S. AID WON'T HEAL RIFT
abstract: Ethiopia's leader said today that he was grateful to the people of the United States and Europe for ''bringing pressure to bear on their governments'' to send emergency famine relief to this country. But he said the American aid would not lead to a thaw in relations with Washington.     ''The differences that exist between Ethiopia and the U.S. do not emanate from the fact that we were not getting food aid,'' the Ethiopian leader, Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, said at a three-hour news conference at the end of the Organization of African Unity conference here.

headline: Rolm-I.B.M. Link
abstract: Shareholders of the Rolm Corporation approved an approximately $1.25 billion acquisition bid from the International Business Machines Corporation. The shareholder vote, which took place at the company's annual meeting, clears the way for I.B.M. to complete its buyout of Rolm, a leading maker of telephone switching equipment. I.B.M., the world's largest computer company, already owns 23 percent of Rolm. I.B.M. said on Tuesday that it had obtained Justice Department antitrust clearance for the buyout on the condition that it divest itself of Rolm's military-computer division.

headline: Allen-Bradley Bid
abstract: The Allen-Bradley Company, a closely held maker of computerized controls and electric equipment, said a management group intends to make an offer for the company and had selected Forstmann Little & Company as sponsor of the proposal.

headline: STOCKS OFF BROADLY IN SLOWER TRADING
abstract: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday in slower trading despite announcements by many major banks that they were cutting their prime lending rates.   The Dow Jones industrial average ended the session down 6.07 points, to 1,204.95, bringing its loss for the week to 20.98 points. In the preceding week, the average gained 35.23 points, helped mainly by lower oil prices.   In the general market, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumered those that rose by more than a 2-to-1 ratio, with semiconductor issues the main casualties for the second consecutive session.

headline: NORWEST, FARM BELT'S BANKER
abstract: While dozens of other banks are pressing to get into interstate banking, the Norwest Corporation, long resident in that promised land, is finding that it is not all milk and honey.   In the third quarter, Norwest, a long-respected Minneapolis-based bank holding company that owns 82 banks in seven states, shocked the investment community by announcing a $24 million loss - its first quarterly loss ever.   Its mortgage finance subsidiary, which was targeted for extra-fast growth, was humbled by a surprisingly large loss of $36.8 million in the quarter. And Norwest's banking group charged off $49.5 million in bad loans, much of them to the hard- pressed farm sector. In addition, Moody's Investors Service has just lowered its ratings on Norwest's senior debt to A-1 from AA-1. And after the bank disclosed troubles in its mortgage division in August, the stock price slid from 28 at the time to 22 5/8 in October. (On Tuesday the stock closed at 23 7/8, down 1/2.)

headline: U.S. SHIPS MET BY SOVIET ALERT OFF MAJOR BASE
abstract: Two American aircraft carriers operating near Soviet bases around Vladivostok touched off a major Soviet military reaction several days ago, raising concern in the Japanese Government, Administration officials said today.     A Defense Department spokesman confirmed that American naval operations in the Sea of Japan ending last week had touched off an unusually heavy reaction involving at least 100 Soviet jet fighters, bombers and reconnaissance planes as well as surface vessels.   One civilian official quoted experienced military officers as describing it as ''the most vigorous Soviet reaction'' to any American military movement of its kind since World War II.   'A Response Was Expected'    ''When we operate in certain waters or in close proximity to foreign territorial waters, we anticipate a reaction,'' the Defense Department spokesman, Comdr. Fred G. Leeder, said. ''I would deny that those operations were intended to provoke a response, but a response was expected.''

headline: Petro-Lewis Reduces Value of Planned Trust
abstract: The Petro-Lewis Corporation, just days before it was to tally votes on its proposal to create a royalty trust for its limited partners, has notified investors that it has reduced the appraised value of the trust by 5 percent to 8 percent.    When the trust was proposed five weeks ago as part of a settlement of lawsuits brought by limited partners and shareholders, the trust was valued at $920 million. But in a letter mailed last week, the company said it had lowered the appraisal to between $874 million and $846 million.   Petro-Lewis specializes in buying and operating oil and gas properties for its own account and sells interests to limited partnerships formed to acquire producing properties.

headline: Business and the Law; Apportioning Liability
abstract: FOR the most part, civil litigation is meant   to assess who is at fault for an injury, and   make them pay.   But sometimes it is hard to know how to apportion the blame.    That has been a particular problem in the lawsuits involving diethylstilbestrol, or DES, which many pregnant women took between 1947 and 1971 to prevent miscarriage. It was later discovered that DES can cause cancer or reproductive difficulties in the daughters of women who took it.

headline: RETAILER STAKE MAY BE SOLD
abstract: An investor group led by Robert E. Strawbridge 3d, a director of Strawbridge & Clothier Inc. of Philadelphia, said yesterday that it might sell its 13.9 percent interest in the department and discount store chain to a third party.    In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group said it had retained Dillon, Read & Company, the investment bankers, to ''explore its financial alternatives.'' The group said it had had discussions with Dillon, Read involving the sale of its shares to an ''unrelated'' third party, which it did not identify.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1984
abstract: The Economy    Industrial production rose 0.4 percent last month, after a two- month slump. Economists said the increase - when considered with the gain in retail sales reported Thursday and the drop in unemployment reported last week - indicated that the economy was beginning to expand again after a two-month pause. (Page 1.)    Producer prices rose half a percentage point in November, the biggest increase since January. Beef prices soared at their steepest rate in five years. (41.)

headline: Jacobs Raises Stake in ITT MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 7 (AP) - Irwin L. Jacobs, the financier, said today that his stockbroker had been able to fill his order Thursday for 3.8 million shares of ITT stock despite an initial mixup on the New York Stock Exchange in handling part of the deal. That is about 3 percent of the ITT Corporation's common stock.
abstract: Jefferies & Company, Mr. Jacobs's broker, bought one block of 2 million ITT shares at 30 3/8 each Thursday, then a few minutes later thought it had purchased an additional 1.8 million shares at 30 1/2 each. That would have been a total purchase of about $115 million.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Waste Recovery Bonds Lead Tax-Free Market
abstract: Financings for waste resource recovery plants continued to dominate the tax-exempt bond market yesterday as issuers and securities dealers scrambled to complete their offerings before the end of the year.    A $395 million bond issue of the Irwindale, Calif., Resource Recovery Authority was offered through Ehrlich-Bober & Company as sole underwriter, while a $140 million issue of the Gulf Coast Waste Development Authority was offered through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. Before the end of the year, Smith Barney expects to offer another $300 million of resource recovery bonds for Palm Beach County, Fla., and $400 million for Detroit.

headline: Ms. Advertorial Insert
abstract: All-About-Travel Guide for Women will be the title of an advertorial insert to be carried in Ms. magazine in the April and October issues. The ads, priced at $10,700 for a four-color page and $7,960 for black-and-white, will entitle the advertiser to a mention in the advertorial material and also to 500 free copies of the insert.

headline: 2 Reported Dead in Raid By Iraq on Gulf Tanker
abstract: Iraqi jet fighters raided a Greek-owned supertanker today in the Persian Gulf, setting the engine room afire and killing two crew members, marine salvage executives said.    The tanker Ninemia was hit by a missile about 100 miles southeast of its destination, the Iranian oil terminal at Kharg Island, the executives said.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN OFFICE POLITICS?; THE 'FAVORITE SON' SYNDROME
abstract: EVERY now and then, someone  becomes a ''favorite son'' on  the basis of demonstrated achievement. But corporate politics being what they are, the road to the top often is strewn with squash games, well-placed flattery, attendance at the ''right'' lunches and dinners, or marriage to the ''right'' spouse.  It can be more than frustrating for the competent worker who must survive without benefit of a social connection to the boss. Gayle Gregory, an actress in Los Angeles, recalls being maneuvered out of a sales slot at a large organization by a woman who seemed to have more than a working relationship with the boss. ''He was always phoning her, going out to lunch and dinner,'' she said.

headline: Chesebrough Promotes Two Top Executives
abstract: Two top executives at Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. were promoted yesterday, the company announced.    George F. Goebeler, 43, was appointed president and chief operating officer, and Donald G. Wiesen, 56, was named to the new position of vice chairman at the diversified consumer products manufacturer. Both appointments are subject to board approval at its meeting Oct. 17.

headline: E.E.C. Nuclear Power
abstract: Nuclear power should provide about 40 percent of the European Economic Community's electricity in 1995, rising to about 50 percent by the year 2000, the European Commission said today. The Commission said in a statement that by 1990 electricity from nuclear power should meet about 14 percent of the Common Markets's total energy needs and 35 percent of its electricity production.

headline: Marcos Sees New Credits
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos, in dire need of loans to rescue the economy of the Philippines, said today that he is confident foreign banks will approve his Government's request for $1.65 billion in new credits.   On Saturday, Mr. Marcos announced cancellation of foreign exchange controls to receive a $650 million credit from the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Rail Collision in South Africa
abstract: More than 130 people were injured today when two trains collided in a suburb of Cape Town. Witnesses said that one of the trains was traveling to a black township and the other to mixed- race residential areas.

headline: Corcom Plans Employee Cuts
abstract: Corcom Inc. said it wascutting its worldwide work orce by about 21 percent, to 1,400, and imposing a salary freeze for employees in the United States, effective Tuesday.   The company, which makes radio frequency interference filters, said the action had been necessary because of weakness in its incoming order rate, which it attributed to excess inventories at domestic distributors. However, it said it remained confident that end-user consumption of its filters was holding steady.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: *  Brooks Fashion Stores Inc., a women's retail store operator, said stockholders had approved a leveraged buyout, making the company a unit of BR investors, a closely held concern whose shareholders include former officers of Brooks Dylex Ltd.     *  Consolidated Fibres Inc., a fiber supplier based in San Francisco, said it had sold its Brockton, Mass., hauling and reclaimed fiber plant to a subsidiary of Browning-Ferris Industries, a Houston-based solid waste company.

headline: SOFTWARE TO MANAGE PORTFOLIOS
abstract: NOT long ago, using a personal computer as an investing tool was still more art than science. Just ask Patricia Lehrburger. Bitten by the technical investing bug four years ago, Miss Lehrburger decided that she wanted a computer to draw her graphs with moving averages. But finding the software to do the job was tricky then. ''The situation was a lot different,'' Miss Lehrburger said. ''We had to hunt to see where we could get this program and where we could get that one. Today there is so much more software that it's bewildering.''    Investors today can choose from hundreds of software programs, much of it more sophisticated than the early programs. It is no longer necessary to patch together an investing system from separate communications and graphics programs, as Miss Lehrburger did. But this has created another problem: how to find the right software program.   ''The hardware exists, and the software is out there,'' said Thomas A. Meyers, president of the American Association of Microcomputer Investors, ''but the problem is that many people have trouble locating software that meets their personal needs or matches a particular strategy.''

headline: Yields Fall For C.D.'s
abstract: Annual effective yields on six- month certificates of deposit and money market accounts fell for the third consecutive week, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday. The Monitor's national index on money market aaccounts fell to 9.49 percent, from 9.56 percent, as the index of six- month C.D.'s slipped to 10.28 percent, from 10.55 percent.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  American Medical International, Beverly Hills, Calif., which owns and operates health-care facilities, has named R. Jeffrey Taylor, Charles R. Timpe and Jerome E. Weisman group vice presidents.     *  Argo Communications Corp., New Rochelle, N.Y., has elected William G. Mitchell chairman and chief executive officer.

headline: RISING STAR IN KREMLIN
abstract: Though Mikhail S. Gorbachev is no stranger to foreign travel, his visit to London is giving the West its first extensive chance to take his measure since his ascendancy in the Soviet hierarchy became evident.  Though formally he is leading a relatively low-level delegation of Soviet legislators on a visit to the House of Commons, Mr. Gorbachev, who visited Italy and Bulgaria earlier this year, came to Britain as the Russian widely believed to be next in line to lead the Kremlin.   Before his arrival Saturday, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher announced plans to give Mr. Gorbachev a reception more commensurate with his status as heir apparent than with the title he is using on the visit, Chairman of the Foreign Affairs Commission of the Council of the Union of the Supreme Soviet of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.   Mr. Gorbachev headed for London five days after he had offered some new clues to his standing in the Kremlin by delivering the keynote speech to a major party conference in Moscow. The speech itself attracted little attention, since it largely repeated standing exhortations and policies.

headline: LEADING INDICATORS UP BY 0.4%
abstract: The barometer the Government uses to try to predict changes in the course of the economy registered a bit of a rise last month, reversing three consecutive months of decline, the Commerce Department said today.    The index of leading indicators, which monitors such things as contracts to build factories, business formations and home-construction permits, rose four-tenths of 1 percent in the month. That was far less than the average monthly gains last year of 1.25 percent but close to the average of the first half of this year.    More Components Ready    Last month's rise would have been somewhat smaller if not for one of the 12 components of the index, a change in business and consumer borrowing, that usually arrives too late for inclusion in the initial monthly report.

headline: Louisiana Land
abstract: The Pioneer Corporation said it had sold to the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company 2,760,000 shares of Louisiana Land for $35 a share, or $96.6 million.

headline: SPACE ARMS: THE CHOICES
abstract: The Reagan Administration finds itself caught between two promises: its pledge to Atlantic allies and the Soviet Union to negotiate seriously on space- based weapons, and President Reagan's strong personal commitment to develop space-based defenses against nuclear attack.     A result, Administration officials acknowledge, has been confusion about how the so-called Star Wars defense will be handled in arms control talks, as a bargaining chip or something to be protected at all costs; and about how it will be presented to Congress, as a way of defending missiles or of defending people.    Few Concrete Decisions    Although Mr. Reagan has expressed his visions of space-based protection against nuclear attacks and of convincing Moscow that this is the way out of the arms race, he seems to have made few concrete decisions. It is a situation ready-made for subordinates to fill in the blanks, push for certain explanations and positions, and see which way the wind is blowing. That is exactly what has occurred in recent days.

headline: Y.&R. Group Chooses Klein to Be President
abstract: Young & Rubicam, the largest American ad agency, has promoted Arthur R. Klein, 47 years old, to president of its Y.&R. Direct Marketing Group, made up of three agencies.

headline: TAX PLAN CREDIT IMPLIES SHIFT TO ASSIST HIGH TECHNOLOGY
abstract: Buried in the Treasury's tax simplification proposal, amid recommendations to repeal dozens of business tax incentives, is a sentence advocating the continuation, on a modified basis, of a 25 percent credit for research and development.     Implicit in the continuation of the credit is a shift in the use of taxes to promote economic development and growth. From giving priority to aiding the so-called smokestack industries - whose 1981 tax breaks the Treasury now wants to repeal - the Treasury plan would change the emphasis to aiding the growth of high-technology industries.   Ronald A. Pearlman, Acting Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Tax Policy, said in an interview today that the Treasury proposal was meant to be economically neutral. The intent, he said was not to embody a particular industrial policy.

headline: DRUG REGION IN PERU BOOMING AGAIN
abstract: Less than half a mile from the headquarters of Peru's special antidrug police unit, sales of pickup trucks are booming, new bars and restaurants are opening daily and dollars are in such abundance that they fetch less than the official exchange rate.    Among the thousands of coca leaf farmers in the lush Upper Huallaga Valley that stretches north from this shabby trafficking center, there is also a new feeling of prosperity and security. ''Everyone is happy again,'' a priest who works in the area said. ''Business has never been better.''

headline: INVESMENTS TO BALANCE PORTFOLIOS
abstract: Where is the market headed? What strategies should an investor now follow? Three professionals - Leon G. Cooperman, partner of Goldman, Sachs & Company, Henry R. Kravis of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and Charles Flather, executive vice president of the State Street Research and Management Company, Boston - give assessments in a discussion with editors of The New York Times.    Q.HOW would you assess the investment climate at present? Is this a time to be fully invested, or would you counsel caution, heavy cash reserves?     COOPERMAN: My response would be somewhere between the extremes - closer to heavy cash than no cash. I don't think it's the time to be fully invested. In my view the stock market is still moderately overpriced relative to fixed-income securities, so the fixed-income markets offer a good alternative to common stocks. Secondly, we're at a time in the business cycle that has typically presented problems for the market - past the peak rates of growth in gross national product, in production, in profits. Also, the institutions' cash reserves are a bit low, and normally that's not been a good sign for the market.

headline: Careers; When Job Security Is Provided
abstract: A NEW study by the Work In America Institute offers a message: ''Providing employment security to workers is good business.'' Accordingly, at a time when American companies have grown very bottom-line conscious, the study makes timely reading.    ''Companies are beginning to realize that a stable, highly trained work force will help them attain higher productivity and product quality,'' the institute said. Furthermore, it said, by avoiding layoffs the companies can escape community opprobrium, which might affect their sales. They can also save on the cost of later replacing workers who have been laid off, and they can also win lower unemployment insurance costs.

headline: ITT LAYOFF OF 795 SET IN 3 STATES
abstract: NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF    The ITT Corporation, in another move to pare costs, said yesterday that it would lay off 795 employees in telecommunications plants in Tennessee, Pennsylvania and Mississippi, and make further cuts at the headquarters in New York and at the European headquarters in Brussels.   ITT said the cuts reflected sluggish demand for personal and business telephones. But analysts, who praised the reduction, said it also appeared to be a response to tougher competition throughout the technology industry.   The move follows ITT's decision in July to halve its quarterly dividend and reflects the streamlining of the telecommunications conglomerate being conducted by Rand V. Araskog, chairman.

headline: TREASURY CALLS PLAN SOUNDLY BASED
abstract: The chief architect of the Treasury's tax simplification plan, responding to concern voiced by tax accountants at a meeting here today, acknowledged that it was beyond the scope of economic science to accurately assess the plan's impact on the economy. Nonetheless, he said, he is confident that the proposal does not represent a risky step into the unknown.     Charles E. McLure, Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Tax Analysis, said the underlying philosophy of the tax plan was based on the economic principle that the economy is most productive when the nation's resources are allocated by free-market forces rather than by Government interference in the investment process through special tax incentives.

headline: 12 Die in Egyptian Collapse
abstract: Twelve people died when an old five-story apartment house in Tanta, a Nile Delta city 52 miles north of Cairo, collapsed Friday afternoon while most of the residents were watching a soccer match on television, municipal officials in Tanta said today. The officials said by telephone that 17 people were treated at a hospital for injuries.

headline: BRIEFS ;  Debt
abstract: *  Banque Nationale de Paris is lead manager of its own issue of $400 million of 15-year floating-rate Euronotes paying 1/8 point over the six- month mean of the London interbank bid and offered rates.     *  I.C.H. Corp.  plans to offer $200 million of fixed-rate senior subordinated debentures.     *  Meridian Bancorp filed an offering of $75 million of floating-rate subordinated capital notes due in 1996 through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Co.

headline: PACT TO DELAY VOTE ELUDES NICARAGUANS
abstract: Nicaraguan Government and opposition leaders announced tonight that they had failed to reach agreement on postponing next month's general elections as a step toward insuring the participation of a leading opposition coalition.    A senior Sandinista commander, Bayardo Arce Castano, accused some sectors of the opposition alliance, the Democratic Coordinating Committee, of ''trying to sabotage the democratic process'' and said that elections would take place as planned on Nov. 4.   The coalition's proposed presidential candidate, Arturo Jose Cruz, expressed regret that the Nicaraguan Government had not allowed more time for an agreement to be reached. He said that he personally favored the draft agreement prepared here.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  Allied Corp.  plans to issue 10 billion yen of Euroyen bonds, the equivalent of $41 million, with a 6 3/4 percent coupon and a maturity of seven years, through underwriters led by Nomura International.     *  Easco Corp.  filed an offering of $25 million of convertible subordinated debentures due in 2009, through underwriters led by Alex Brown & Sons.

headline: PERU'S BISHOPS TOE THE LINE ON THEOLOGY OF LIBERATION
abstract: Peruvian bishops issued a brief statement today expressing ''full and total adherence'' to the Vatican's criticism on the theology of liberation, but apparently did not agree on a firm condemnation of the teaching that had been sought by some conservative church leaders.     The 44 bishops, who issued the statement after two weeks of meetings at the Vatican with Pope John Paul II and other church leaders, said they would issue a fuller commentary ''in the near future'' after they return to Peru.   In the statement, the bishops said they had reached unanimous agreement on a position on liberation theology. The agreement is expected to be a compromise between conservative and more left-of-center bishops.

headline: Montagu-Cordura
abstract: An investment group led by Montagu Investment Management Ltd., a London-based investment adviser, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had acquired 6.2 percent of the common shares of the Cordura Corporation for investment.

headline: Pakistan Protest Broken Up
abstract: The police used tear gas and nightsticks today to disperse students on the fourth day of anti-Government protests in the southern province of Sind, witnesses reported. Students said two people were wounded by tear-gas shells and two others arrested. There was no immediate comment from the police.

headline: FINANCIAL CORP. POSTS PROFIT IN TURNAROUND
abstract: The Financial Corporation of America, which came very close to failing in late August, according to its new chairman, today reported a profit of $1.2 million in the third quarter, following a loss of $107.2 million in the second quarter.   Financial Corporation's thrift unit, the American Savings and Loan Association, lost more than a fourth of its deposits, or $6.8 billion, in the quarter. But Financial was able to raise $11.1 billion through a combination of loans from the Federal Home Loan Bank system, asset sales and mortgage-backed borrowings from Wall Street brokerages. The money was used to meet the outflow of deposits and to fund new loans.

headline: Strong Dollar Forces ThaisInto Devaluation of the Baht
abstract: The recent rise of the United States dollar has forced Thailand to devalue and float its currency, the baht, Finance Minister Sommai Hoontrakul said today.

headline: ; Credibility Ratings For 750 'Personalities'
abstract: Would you like to know the type of person that Robert Redford appeals to? No, not just the information that it is likely to be a 25-year-old woman, but real demographic dope along with product-buying information.    That sounds like it would be pretty valuable to a marketer not only if he is picking an advertising time slot in a TV movie but also if he is looking for an advertising spokesman (if Mr. Redford would do such work).

headline: Keller's Bold Move
abstract: This time last year, George M. Keller probably did not expect to ring out 1984 as the head of the nation's third- largest oil company. But the Chevron Corporation's $13.3 billion acquisition of the Gulf Corporation showed that Mr. Keller and his company are prepared to go on the offensive against Exxon, the biggest oil company, and Mobil, which is No. 2.

headline: 40 EAST GERMANS ON HUNGER STRIKE
abstract: Forty East Germans who have occupied the West German Embassy in Prague for several months began a hunger strike today to dramatize their demand to be allowed to emigrate to the West.   In a petition printed today in the mass-circulation daily Bild, the refugees announced their action and accused West German officials of putting pressure on them to return to East Germany without guarantees that they would ultimately be allowed to resettle here.   Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government expressed regret and said the Red Cross had been asked to send a doctor and two nurses to Prague to care for the protesters.

headline: REAGAN CALLS SOVIET AFGHAN MOVE 'DAY OF INFAMY'
abstract: President Reagan, marking five years since Soviet forces joined the fighting in Afghanistan, said today that the event was ''a day of infamy'' reminiscent of Pearl Harbor.     ''There is no legitimate excuse for a great power like the Soviet Union that is doing what it is doing to the people of Afghanistan,'' Mr. Reagan said as he left Washington for five days of vacation here and at Palm Springs.   The President, recalling Franklin D. Roosevelt's characterization of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, said: ''A President once called a similar day 'a day of infamy.' I guess that's exactly what this is also, the anniversary of a day of infamy.''

headline: Troubled Bank In Chinatown Depositors lined up at the
abstract: United Orient Bank in New   York's Chinatown yesterday in   what Ivan Serchuk, an attorney   who represents the small, community bank, described as a   ''mini-run.'' Rumors had spread throughChinatown that the bank, which   had total assets of $89 million at   the end of June, was in trouble.

headline: LETTERS
abstract: CONRAIL'S SUCCESS        To the Editor:   Congressman Bob Edgar lists several reasons for Conrail's new-found profitability (''More Time is Needed to Study the Bids,'' Forum, Sept. 23). In doing so he continues several misconceptions about Conrail and the railroad industry.

headline: 2 NATIONS BALK
abstract: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries concluded a crucial pricing agreement today, but Algeria and Nigeria broke ranks and refused to endorse the pact.     The Indonesian oil minister and OPEC president, Subroto, said the organization's ministers had agreed to restructure its prices an effort to halt a deterioration in oil revenues.    The plan calls for narrowing the official OPEC price range by raising prices of heavy crude oil and lowering prices of light crude. Nigeria produces high-quality lighter crude oils.

headline: OCT.21-31 CAR SALES INCREASED 3.3%
abstract: Sales of new American-made automobiles rose 3.3 percent in the Oct. 21-31 period from the comparable period a year before, despite strikes against the General Motors Corporation's Canadian plants that held down G.M. sales. The daily combined selling rate of 27,184 reported by the six domestic auto companies today was the highest in the late October period since 1979.   Total sales for the period were 244,659, compared with 236,895 in 1983. There were nine selling days in each period.

headline: Fluor in China Accord
abstract: Fluor Engineering Inc. has signed an agreement to set up a joint venture with the China Foreign Nonferrous Metal Engineering and Construction Company, the New China News Agency said today. The venture will seek contracts for domestic and foreign projects, including designing and constructing mines, smelting, refining and transportation projects.

headline: Legislator and 2 Bodyguards Slain on a Guatemala Street
abstract: Santos Hernandez, a 56-year-old member of the Guatemalan Constituent Assembly, and two bodyguards were shot dead Friday as they walked along a street in the southern part of the capital, fire officials reported.

headline: SAKHAROV AND WIFE THOUGHT TO BE TOGETHER
abstract: Friends of Andrei D. Sakharov say several telegrams and postcards have been received from the Sakharovs in Gorky, and the messages suggest the exiled dissident is now living in his apartment with his wife.    The notes left intact many of the mysteries surrounding the Sakharovs in the more than five months since Dr. Sakharov began a fast to try to obtain permission for his wife to go abroad for medical treatment.

headline: KOHLBERG WILL BUY MOTEL 6
abstract: The City Investing Company, which announced only two weeks ago that it would sell all of its operations, said late yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Motel 6 budget-motel company to an investor group headed by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, a leading Wall Street investment house, for $565 million.    Insiders said the group would also assume Motel 6's $350 million in debt, bringing the value of the deal to $915 million.    It was the second major sale by City Investing since it disclosed plans to liquidate.

headline: S.E.C. Guides Proposed On Insurance Policies
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted today to propose new guidelines intended to help insurance companies design policies that avoid its regulatory sweep.   Under Federal law, many types of insurance policies technically also qualify as securities and therefore fall under the jurisdiction of the S.E.C. as well as of state insurance regulators. The draft guidelines propose specific tests that, if met by a particular insurance product, would exempt the product from the commission's purview.

headline: Italian Inflation Eases
abstract: Italian consumer prices rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in September from August, giving the nation a 12-month increase of 9.8 percent - the first time in a decade that inflation has fallen below 10 percent, the Government reported today. Inflation peaked at an annual rate of 23 percent in 1977.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: THE DEFICIT
abstract: To the Editor:     I am a local attorney. Recently one of my clients suggested the following: Levy a surcharge on each taxpayer, and dedicate the revenues to reducing the Federal deficit? I discussed this idea with various local businessmen and bankers.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Matsushita Names Head of U.S. Unit      Kiyoshi Seki has been named president and chief executive officer of the Matsushita Electric Corporation of America, the company announced last week.   Mr. Seki, who is 52 years old, succeeds Keiichi Takeoka, 69, who held the top posts at the company since 1980. Mr. Takeoka remains a senior managing director of the Japanese parent company, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, where he began his career in 1933.

headline: TAX-REDUCTION PLANS UP FOR VOTE IN 4 STATES
abstract: The taxpayer revolt is still alive, at least in California, Michigan, Oregon and Nevada, where voters have a chance next Tuesday to approve anti- tax measures reminiscent of California's Proposition 13 in 1978 and Massachusetts' Proposition 2 1/2 two years later.     The state ballot initiatives differ in detail, but their common thread is a desire to curb taxes. Proponents of the ballot initiatives have found widespread public acceptance for their assertions that the only way to trim the fat from government budgets is to take away from their source of funds.    Many state and local government officials, who must cope with shrunken revenues without equivalent cuts in demands for services if the anti-tax initiatives pass, warn that the proposals to reduce government budgets and taxes are not in their state's best interest.

headline: Continental Illinois
abstract: The Continental Illinois Corporation said it had agreed to sell its leasing operations to Sanwa Bank Ltd.

headline: Polaroid Sues E.P.A. on Secrets
abstract: The Polaroid Corporation has filed suit against the Environmental Protection Agency, charging that the Federal agency disclosed trade secrets about Polaroid's new chemicals.   The suit, filed in United States District Court here, contends that E.P.A. employees violated Federal law by passing information about Polaroid's chemicals to other Government agencies.
