Federal law requires companies to submit new chemicals to the E.P.A. for testing of possible environmental hazards, but requires the agency to honor the confidentiality of new products.

headline: Danish Jobless Rate
abstract: Danish unemployment rose to 9.8 percent in August, from 9.1 percent in July, but was down from 9.9 percent 12 months earlier, the Bureau of Statistics said today.

headline: DUARTE OFFERS A CHRISTMAS CEASE-FIRE
abstract: President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador said today that he is prepared to suspend military operations at Christmas if guerrilla forces agree.    Mr. Duarte, who met here with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, said at a news conference that he sent a letter Tuesday to Archbishop Arturo Rivera y Damas of San Salvador committing the Government to a Christmas truce if the guerrilla opposition also stops fighting. He said he had received no response from the guerrillas.   Mr. Duarte, while expressing frustration over the lack of progress in peace talks in El Salvador, said that he had ''not lost hope'' that the negotiations could eventually produce a political settlement to the five-year civil war.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Nov. 29, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Legal Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Committee on Palestinian Rights - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Consumers Halts Its Dividend
abstract: Directors of the Consumers Power Company voted to eliminate its fourth-quarter dividend of 10 cents a share on the company's common stock to save $35 million.   The directors also voted to cut their pay by 20 percent, the company said.

headline: Market Place; Bell Regionals Hold Up Well
abstract: THE seven Bell regional holding companies   created on Jan. 1, 1984, by the divestiture of   the American Telephone and Telegraph Company are faring handsomely in a year that, so far, has been disappointing for most other stocks. Shares of the Bell regionals, which now provide the bulk of the nation's local telephone service, are selling at close to their record levels.    At the same time, these issues are yielding about 8 percent, on average, to their stockholders.    Meanwhile, securities analysts expect heftier cash dividends next year. ''We look for increased dividends to be announced by all companies no sooner than February or March 1985, with higher payments to be made on May 1,'' said Charles W. Schelke of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. He forecast increases of 6 to 7 percent.

headline: Bank Money Accounts
abstract: Money6-monthMarketC.D.'s(%)(%)  Bankers Trust 10.0510.30 Chase Manhattan *9.80*9.96 Chemical Bank 10.0210.29 Citibank *9.8510.00 Manufacturers Hanover *9.5810.41 Morgan Guaranty 10.03n.a. Bowery Savings 10.5211.45 Dime Savings (N.Y.) 10.5011.00 Dollar Dry Dock Savings 10.0311.00 Goldome 9.4211.07 Metropolitan Savings 10.2411.07 City Federal (N.J.) 9.6510.50 First Fidelity (N.J.) 9.1110.00 Midlantic National Bank (N.J.) 9.14*9.75 United Jersey Banks 9.3810.51 Connecticut Bank & Trust 9.3810.47 Connecticut National 9.3810.40  People's Bank (Conn.) *9.6510.51 Bank Rate Monitor Index* 9.4910.28 **Annual effective yields offered by 50 large institutions in the five largest U.S. markets.     Source: Bank Rate Monitor, Miami Beach, 33140

headline: Kaiser Posts Deficit; International Paper Up
abstract: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, reflecting the impact of a $60.7 million charge for discontinued operations, reported yesterday that it had a deficit of $73.2 million in the third quarter of 1984.    The company said that the loss in the latest quarter compared with a deficit in the quarter a year earlier of $36.8 million, which included a loss from discontinued operations of $17.8 million. Kaiser, based in Oakland, Calif., is the country's third-largest integrated aluminum producer, after the Aluminum Company of America and the Reynolds Metals Company.

headline: Calvin Cooler Sets Campaign
abstract: Brooklyn, which in July introduced the Calvin Cooler - fruit   juices with a white wine base -   is going to be the major beneficiary of a new state law allowing such drinks made with New   York State wines to be sold in   supermarkets.

headline: OF KEOGHS, ROLLOVERS AND GINNIE MAES
abstract: Following are answers to some questions from readers of the Personal Finance column.     Q. I will be retiring soon and instead of receiving a monthly pension check, I want to take my pension in a lump sum payment that I can roll over into an Individual Retirement Account. But I have been told that I can do an I.R.A. rollover only with that part of my pension that represents my company's contributions to the plan, not the part that represents my own contributions. Why?  A. The reason is to protect your contributions from being taxed twice. In a contributory pension plan such as yours, the money that you put into the plan comes from after-tax dollars. In other words, your salary, after income taxes have been deducted, is further reduced by any contributions you make to the plan. But while your contribution remains in the plan it accumulates interest tax- free.

headline: ANTITRUST CHIEF WARY OF TRIPLE-PENALTY RULE
abstract: The Government's antitrust chief, J. Paul McGrath, believes the treble-damage penalty in private antitrust suits should be re-evaluated to determine whether it unfairly inhibits legal and efficient business conduct.    ''It's the single most troublesome antitrust rule,'' Mr. McGrath said of the historic provision, which dates from the Sherman Antitrust Act of 1890. Anyone injured by a violation of this law may sue and recover three times the ascertained damage from the offending party.    ''Our concern is that in areas other than clearly illegal activities, such as secret price-fixing, it may inhibit efficient conduct,'' Mr. McGrath said. ''If a company is worried about treble-damage liability, it may not do something that would be beneficial in terms of efficiency.''

headline: Delaware Bonds Use Book Entry
abstract: Delaware yesterday became the first state to sell long-term bonds that will be available to investors only in book-entry form, with no printed bond certificates.    Underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets offered the state's bonds, rated Aa, with yields ranging from 6.25 percent in 1986 to 7.5 percent in 1989, 8.6 percent in 1994, 9.3 percent in 1999 and 9.5 percent in 2002 through 2004.

headline: THE SUGAR INDUSTRY'S SLIDE
abstract: Americans are consuming sweeteners in near-record quantities - 133 pounds per person this year - but despite this vast craving for the taste of sugar, the sugar industry itself is languishing.    ''It feels like the spring of 1942,'' said John L. Bushnell, president of Holly Sugar, a Colorado beet processor. ''We've been under very serious attack. We need to gear up and fight back.''    Sugar, the refined sweetener from sugar cane and sugar beets, has become less and less prominent in American diets as non-sugar sweeteners with fewer calories and cheaper prices have taken over nearly half the market.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Chairman Retires At Campbell Soup
abstract: John T. Dorrance Jr., chairman of the Campbell Soup Company for the past 22 years, has announced his retirement. The announcement was made at the company's annual meeting at which Campbell's directors elected William S. Cashel Jr. as Mr. Dorrance's successor. The changes are effective immediately.

headline: Legislator Attacks Belgrade On Barring a Trial Observer
abstract: Representative Dante B. Fascell, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said today that a Yugoslav decision to bar a Congressional observer at a dissident trial this month might affect Yugoslav-United States relations.

headline: Pott Industries
abstract: Pott Industries, a unit of the Houston Natural Gas Corporation, said it was negotiating the sale of some of its shipyards and related operations in St. Louis and Caruthersville, Mo., to the shipyard's management.

headline: Bank Rates Fall Again
abstract: Annual effective yields on money market accounts and six-month certificates of deposit plunged for the 10th consecutive week, in the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported. Average yields on money market deposit accounts have fallen more than a point since August.

headline: HERITAGE BANCORP'S 2 NEW BIDS
abstract: The Heritage Bancorp announced yesterday that it had received two more unsolicited merger offers, this time from Midlantic Banks and the First National State Bancorporation.    Heritage said that it had received a letter from Midlantic proposing a merger at $45 a share for Heritage's 4.3 million shares of common stock outstanding. Under the plan, 40 percent of the Heritage shares would be exchanged for $45 in cash and 60 percent would be exchanged for $45 in market value of Midlantic common stock.

headline: NATIONAL INTERGROUP PROFIT FALLS
abstract: National Intergroup Inc. yesterday reported a 58.2 percent drop in earnings for the third quarter, while another steel company, Armco Inc., said its loss narrowed to $272.7 million in the quarter.     National Intergroup, based in Pittsburgh, said third-quarter net income fell to $7.6 million, or 18 cents a share, from $18.2 million, or 80 cents a share, a year earlier. The 1983 third quarter included a one-time gain of $12.6 million, or 63 cents a share, from the exchange of common stock for first-mortgage bonds.

headline: AN 'INDEPENDENT' FRANCHISE
abstract: To many small banks, the prospect of interstate banking is as comforting as an approaching cattle stampede. Many fear that Congress will soon deregulate the financial markets, pitting them directly against giants such as Sears, Roebuck & Company and Shearson Lehman/American Express, as well as the money-center banks.    ''We thought that with 10 years we could develop the kind of market penetration we needed to survive in that environment,'' said Richard D. Pauls, chairman of what, until August, was the Citizens Bancorporation, based in Sheboygan, Wis. ''But we realized that we had only a few years.''

headline: Bank Rates Continue To Decline
abstract: Annual effective yields on money market accounts and six-month certificates of deposit continued their ninth consecutive week of decline, in the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported. The Monitor's national index of money market accounts fell to 8.88 percent, from 9.01 percent, the first time the yield has been this low since last Feb. 22. The index of six-month C.D.'s declined to 9.31 percent, from 9.44 percent.

headline: Moscow Complains at U.N. Of Attacks on Its Diplomats
abstract: The Soviet Union has complained to the United Nations Legal Committee that attacks against its diplomats are taking place all over the world, including the United States.   Igor I. Yakovlev, a member of the Soviet delegation, urged the General Assembly during the committee meeting to insure that such actions against diplomats are halted. Mr. Yakovlev made his statement Wednesday during a discussion of a United Nations report dealing with the protection of diplomats.

headline: Swiss Unemployment
abstract: Swiss unemployment dropped to 1 percent of the work force in September from 1.1 percent in August, but was up from eight- tenths of 1 percent from 12 months before, the Federal Office of Industry, Trade and Labor said. The report said 32,234 people were jobless in September. In another area, the Federal Customs Office reported Friday that Switzerland's merchandise trade deficit in September rose to 578 million francs, or about $226 million, from a deficit of 404 million francs in September 1983.

headline: LEADERS OF OPPOSITION BACK APPEAL FOR END TO VIOLENCE
abstract: Opposition leaders joined tonight with Rajiv Gandhi, India's new Prime Minister, in an appeal for an end to the anti-Sikh violence that has spread through the country since Mr. Gandhi's mother was shot to death by assassins.     Mr. Gandhi also ordered the country's chief ministers and top elected state officials who have converged on the capital for his mother's funeral to return to their regions and try to control the rioting.    The moves by the 40-year-old new leader were seen as aimed at projecting an image of a strong and united leadership.   The tactic, some noted, was one Indira Gandhi might have used in a similar situation - courting and then co- opting political adversaries at a time of crisis. She did this successfully in June when she sent the army into Punjab to crush a separatist campaign by Sikh extremists.

headline: Dow Seeking More Of Morton-Thiokol
abstract: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it would request authorization from the Federal Government to increase its stake in Morton- Thiokol Inc. to 15 percent. But Dow continued to say that it was interested only in an investment, not a takeover.

headline: NEW TACTICS ALMOST HALT EXIT OF SOVIET JEWS
abstract: After four years of waiting, the scientist had despaired of emigration when the passport office called him in for a talk, something it had never done before.    The scientist, identified by a friend by the initial Z., was offered a deal: withdraw the application, and the authorities would see what they could do about getting him back the job he had lost when he asked to emigrate.   Z. said yes, and in his case the authorities kept their word. According to his friend, he now heads an office at a cultural institution.

headline: Market Place; Taking Losses To Save Taxes
abstract: NO investor enjoys buying a stock and watching it plunge in value, but the approach of the tax-loss selling season on Wall Street has the potential of easing that pain somewhat. The principle here is that selling some market losers - and there are plenty around these days - in a portfolio can ease a person's tax bite to the Internal Revenue Service.   For tax purposes, sales may be made to establish losses until the market's closing bell on Monday, Dec. 31. But the height of tax-loss selling will occur within the next few weeks as investors employ their various year-end strategies.

headline: Pastoral Letter
abstract: To the Editor:     In his article on the Pastoral Letter of the American Catholic Bishops (''A Plan for Spreading Misery, Not Wealth,'' Forum, Nov. 18) Norman Podhoretz found an irresistible opportunity to castigate liberals in a way that added nothing to the debate the bishops were asking for.   There are many liberals who agree that American capitalism is far superior to socialism but who are still troubled by evidence that: (1) the poverty class is growing while the middle class is getting smaller; (2) many in the middle range of the middle class have dropped to the lowest range of the middle class, and (3) unenlightened self-interest and greed are on the rise.

headline: U.S. PRODS BELGIUM AND NETHERLANDS TO ACCEPT MISSILES
abstract: The United States told Belgium and the Netherlands today that the chances for progress in forthcoming negotiations with the Soviet Union would be set back if they did not carry out commitments to deploy American cruise missiles.   American and allied officials said the message was conveyed by Secretary of State George P. Shultz in meetings here with Belgian and Dutch officials. An aide to Mr. Shultz said he had found the meetings ''positive.''   ''They told us they would do their best to do their duty, but they also pointed out the problems they have,'' the aide said.

headline: Big Stock Filing From EQK Realty
abstract: EQK Realty Investors I, a real estate investment trust, filed a registration statement for the sale of slightly more than 10 million shares to raise an estimated $181 million. The offering, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers, would be one of the largest initial public offerings ever by a real estate investment trust.

headline: Bendix Chassis Unit to Close SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 9
abstract: The chassis and brake   division of Allied Automotive   Inc. said it will phase out its automotive manufacturing operations in South Bend and lay off   more than 1,300 workers within   two years. The Bendix Chassis and   Brake Components division   cited high operating costs that   persisted despite efforts to increase productivity.

headline: 4 Blacks Are Killed In South Africa Clashes
abstract: Four blacks, including three teen- agers, were killed today in South Africa's segregated townships, and the police said dozens of black youths were arrested nationwide.   The violence came after two weeks of relative calm that followed rioting and clashes with the police that left at least 60 blacks dead in townships south and east of Johannesburg.

headline: Europe Ship Orders Up
abstract: New orders booked by Western European shipbuilders in the first half of this year surged to 1.3 million tons, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today. The total for all of 1983 was 1.9 million tons.

headline: TANDY OFFERS NEW COMPUTERS
abstract: The Tandy Corporation, seeking to bolster its shrinking presence in the personal computer market, today will introduce an inexpensive computer compatible with the International Business Machines Corporation's PC.    The Tandy 1000 will be priced at $1,200 for a model including a single floppy disk drive and 128,000 bytes of internal memory. The price also includes Deskmate, a program that combines six applications including word-processing, filing, calendar and a spreadsheet.

headline: JUDGES GIVER FREER REIN IN CASE IN ARGENTINA
abstract: Nine members of former Argentine juntas accused of murder and torture will be tried under unusual legal procedures that will open the proceedings to the public and allow judges freer rein in ruling on evidence, the chief judge in the case says.    The judge, Jorge Torlasco, said in an interview here that the civilian court would use the military code of justice.   Under the civilian code, he said, the proceedings would have been recorded and sessions would have been closed to the public. Moreover, the prosecutors would have had to present specific evidence to prove their case.

headline: 'MADHOUSE ECONOMICS' ASCRIBED TO MINERS' CHIEF BY TORY MINISTER
abstract: The Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher made a bitter attack today on the leader of the striking coal miners as the governing Conservative Party began its annual seaside conference here.    Peter Walker, the Energy Minister, denounced the miners' leader, Arthur Scargill, as ''a Stalinist'' who had robbed members of the National Union of Mineworkers of their right to vote on a strike, who had infiltrated and now ''totally dominated'' the opposition Labor Party and who ''advocates the economics of the madhouse.''   ''This strike has no possible industrial justification,'' Mr. Walker told a cheering audience at the Conference Center here on the Channel coast. ''This strike has little to do with the future of the coal industry. It has everything to do with a Marxist challenge to the roots of parliamentary democracy. It will not succeed.''

headline: Price-Deloitte Merger Backed
abstract: The British Government has given antitrust clearance to the proposed merger of Price Waterhouse and Deloitte Haskins & Sells, spokesmen for the two accounting firms said.

headline: CHILE EXPELS U.P.I. REPORTER OVER A DISPATCH
abstract: The Government today expelled a United Press International reporter, charging that he had filed a ''false dispatch.''    The reporter, Anthony Boadle, 31 years old and a British citizen, was the first journalist to be expelled since the mid-1970's. He was hired by U.P.I. in Brazil in 1982, and had worked in Chile for one and a half years.

headline: NORWEGIAN INTEREST IN PHILLIPS SEEN
abstract: Norsk Hydro A/S, the Norwegian industrial giant, has expressed interest in negotiating with the Phillips Petroleum Company, possibly to buy part of it, international investment bankers said yesterday.     Officials based in London said the Norwegian company's specific interest was unclear, but that Norsk Hydro already had major oil and gas operations in the North Sea and was thought to be interested in buying Phillips's Ekofisk oil operations to extend those holdings.    Norsk Hydro already has a 6.7 percent interest in the oilfield, Phillips said. Phillips owns 37 percent of the field, while other international oil companies control the rest.

headline: GROUP INCREASES STAKE IN ALEXANDER'S TO 35.6%
abstract: Alexander's Inc., one of the New York area's largest retailers, announced yesterday that an investment group including Interstate Properties and Robert M. Bass of Fort Worth and interests related to him had increased its stake in the company to 35.6 percent, from 27.8 percent.     Alexander's said the group had bought an additional 400,000 shares of the retailer's 4.5 million shares of outstanding stock at $23.50 a share, or a total of $9.4 million. This brings the group's total investment in Alexander's to 1.61 million shares, with a total current value of $35.4 million. The stock was purchased from the family of Robin L. Farkas, chairman and chief executive of Alexander's, and from related interests.

headline: ANALYSTS CUT RETAIL PROFIT ESTIMATES
abstract: Several of Wall Street's top brokerages yesterday lowered their earlier estimates of fourth-quarter earnings for the nation's largest retailers because of disappointing Christmas sales.    ''Fears that it might not be such a robust Christmas are turning out to be an understatement,'' Jeffrey B. Edelman, analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said. ''The two extra selling days we hear about this year will have to be stretched out to two weeks in order to bail out the season.''    Mr. Edelman and other analysts attributed the expected decline in earnings not only to reluctance by consumers to spend heavily, but also to heavy discounting by retailers that has hurt profits more than it has stimulated sales. ''The pace of markdowns has been accelerating, but still without much success,'' Mr. Edelman said.''We have made further earnings reductions, with the expectation that industry profits could decline about 10 percent on a sales increase of 7.5 percent.''

headline: Bird Inc. to Sell Some of Its Assets
abstract: Bird Inc. said it had agreed to sell certain roofing assets to the Genstar Corporation for about $50 million. Bird said the proposed sale would involve plants in Charleston, S.C., Shreveport, La., Portland, Ore., Glenwood, Ark. and Martinez, Cordova and Wilmington, Calif.

headline: Debt Offerings For This Week There are no significant corporate or tax-exempt bond offerings scheduled this week,
abstract: because of the New Year's holiday. The Treasury Department   will be the only large issuer of   new debt.

headline: OFFICIALS SAY U.S. PLANS TO DOUBLE SUPPLY OF ARMS TO AFGHAN REBELS
abstract: United States officials say $280 million has been earmarked in covert military aid for the Afghan insurgents this fiscal year, more than doubling the aid in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30.     This will bring total American aid to $625 million since Soviet troops intervened in Afghanistan in December 1979. This does not include additional aid of $100 million provided last year by Saudi Arabia and other Arab countries, China and Israel, according to official estimates.   Although all those interviewed agreed that the aid was substantial, there was disagreement over how much arms aid was actually reaching the rebels, whether the weapons were adequate and, above all, whether the guerrillas were winning or losing.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: At first glance, the Government's consumer installment credit figures for September, due out this Thursday, will suggest that Americans are becoming increasingly hesitant about piling on debt. But that's not necessarily so, according to Joel Popkin, a Washington economic consultant.  The September figure is expected to show a rise of only $2 billion or so, compared with $6 billion in August and $7.1 billion in July. ''But the decline occurred largely because of the sharp drop in auto sales that month,'' Mr.  Popkin noted, ''and not because the consumer is overburdened with installment debt.'' Continuing labor problems again depressed domestic auto output in October, causing sales to fall to an annual rate of 6.9 million units, from 7.9 million in September. As a result, Mr. Popkin expects sluggish growth in installment debt to continue in October. But the trend should reverse in the final months of the year. ''The recent decline in interest rates should stimulate sales of autos and other durables normally bought on credit,'' he predicted.

headline: AIR ONE'S MYSTERIOUS 'ANGEL'
abstract: Air One, a nine-plane airline based in St. Louis, was staring at bankruptcy two weeks ago. It needed money quickly, just to pay the fuel bill to keep its planes aloft.     That was why it snapped up the only offer it had - from a young man. So young, in fact, that school records show him to be 19 years old. The youth, Scot M. Spencer, promised to wire $350,000 to take care of the fuel bill and later to pump additional capital into Air One in exchange for stock.

headline: Gas Heat Ad Irks Utilities The full-page ad showing a
abstract: mother and daughter, with the   headline ''Gas heat makes me   nervous,'' that ran in The New   York Times last Thursday not   only raised some consumer   eyebrows but also raised some   hackles at the Brooklyn Union   Gas Company and the Consolidated Edison Company. At various points the copy   reads: ''If you need prompt   service from them, you have to   say 'I smell gas.'

headline: Economic Freedom Is Swedish Issue
abstract: Sweden's official unemployment rate is under 3.5 percent and both the industrial and service sectors of the economy are thriving. Why, then, is Olof Palme's ruling Social Democratic Party trailing its nonsocialist opposition in the public opinion polls as Sweden starts on the road to next September's elections?   ''The economy is going the Social Democrats' way, but not the undercurrents,'' said Carl Bildt, a leader in the Moderaterna, the conservative party that has overtaken the more middle-of-the-road Liberals and Center Party to become the dominant opposition party. ''Everything is going our way in terms of values, priorities and demands by the electorate.''

headline: AS GOLD NEARS $300, DOLLAR STILL POPULAR
abstract: Gold prices have been falling for months as the dollar has surged, and last week gold traded briefly under $300 an ounce in Sydney, its lowest since a cyclical dip in mid-1982. Few traders predict that gold will fall to the $100 mark last seen in 1976, but the precipitous drop from 1980's $825 level has raised concerns about whether gold will retain its reputation as a safe harbor during times of uncertainty. Indeed, more traders seem to be wanting dollars as the hedge, especially since the American inflation rate is staying so unexpectedly low. The relationship between the dollar and gold shifts occasionally as the world economy changes, and some investors apparently have greater faith in the continuing strength of the dollar than they do in gold. And traders note that gold is still high, both historically and when adjusted for inflation.      The improving American economy bolsters optimism at home and abroad, as did the 2.8 percent ''flash'' estimate of fourth-quarter economic growth. The G.N.P. estimate was a bit of a surprise; most predictions had put expansion at barely 2 percent. But because so many statistics have been substantially revised this year, analysts said it was too soon to say the recovery is galloping again. Still, the report was encouraging after a lackluster summer and fall.

headline: Coast Cable Sale
abstract: The Times-Mirror Company and Knight -Ridder Newspapers Inc. said they had agreed in principle to sell their jointly owned Long Beach, Calif., cable television system to Simmons Communications. The companies did not disclose terms of the agreement. They said the sale would not have a significant impact on the earnings of either company and was subject to approval by governmental bodies.

headline: U.S. SAYS STUDY FOUND MANUEL BROKE NO LAW
abstract: The White House announced today that two investigations ordered by President Reagan had found that there had been ''no violation'' of the law in the preparation of a Central Intelligence Agency manual for Nicaraguan guerrillas.     But the inquiries concluded there may have been ''lapses in judgment'' requiring disciplinary action. according to the White House statement.  It added that President Reagan concurred with the conclusions of the reports.     The White House said the three-paragraph statement represented the final word from President Reagan on the controversy over the manual.

headline: ANTITRUST VIEW FROM BRUSSELS
abstract: BRUSSELS THE luncheon of Brussels antitrust lawyers   last Thursday was the best attended in memory. Although there were plenty of places to get a better meal, this gathering catered to the local legal community's insatiable appetite for inside information about the suspension last August of the Common Market's antitrust action against the International Business Machines Corporation.    The I.B.M. case may have been the most internationally sensitive ever tackled by the European Commission's Competition Directorate, the arm that develops and administers the Common Market's antitrust policy. However, according to Colin Overbury, a luncheon speaker who was one of the directorate's leading lawyers on the case, I.B.M. was not the Common Market's biggest or most important case - just its ''most tiresome.''

headline: Market Place; Strong's Funds Set Basic Goal
abstract: NEAR the peak of Wall Street's bull market in the summer of 1983, the Strong Total Return Fund and the Strong Investment Fund - a pair of mutual funds based in Milwaukee - sold virtually all their stocks. The proceeds went into commercial paper to take advantage of rising interest rates. That proved to be admirable timing; shortly thereafter equities went into a tailspin.    In August 1984, with interest rates falling, the funds began buying common stocks again. ''Currently, our portfolios consist of 35 percent equities and 50 percent short-term and intermediate-term bonds, along with 15 percent in commercial paper,'' said Richard S. Strong, chairman of the investment advisory firm he founded 10 years ago. ''Our basic goal is to generate an annualized return of 5 percent above the inflation rate over a sustained period of time.''

headline: SENDS DUKE TO SAY SO
abstract: His Royal Highness Grand Duke Jean of Luxembourg - he has nine other given names and is also Duke of Nassau and Prince of Bourbon Parma - is head of state of what is arguably Europe's most unabashedly pro-American country.     The tiny Grand Duchy of Luxembourg - 270,000 citizens in 1,000 square miles - whose image is of a modern Ruritania, a land of deep forests, turreted castles and dashing nobility, cherishes this reputation for being Washington's best friend.     In the coming week, the world's last reigning Grand Duke will have an opportunity to demonstrate his country's good will when he begins his first official visit to the United States Monday. He will be the first head of state to be received by President Reagan since Mr. Reagan's re-election.

headline: A New Raid by Iraqis Is Reported in the Gulf
abstract: Iraq said its planes successfully attacked a ''large naval target'' in the Persian Gulf today.

headline: RANGEL PLANS TAX BILL BASED ON TREASURY PLAN
abstract: Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, said today he would submit a bill in Congress modeled on the Treasury Department's draft proposal for tax simplification.     He said his measure, however, would not include repeal of the deduction for state and local taxes on Federal income tax returns, as proposed in the Treasury plan.

headline: 2,000 Minks Freed In Britain
abstract: Animal rights campaigners freed 2,000 minks today from a fur farm near this north England village, the police said.    All but a few dozen minks were tracked down and recaptured by employees of the Nelson Fur Farm with help from the police and fire officials, a spokesman said.

headline: HOUSE PANEL CALLS C.I.A. MANUAL ILLEGAL
abstract: The House Intelligence Committee concluded today that the Central Intelligence Agency's guerrilla warfare manual for Nicaraguan rebels violated the law because it advised the rebels on how to overthrow the Sandinista Government.     But the committee, completing a two-month investigation of the manual, did not recommend specific actions against C.I.A. employees. That conclusion caused dissension, committee members said.    ''At least 7 or 8 times in the manual, there is a reference to overthrowing the Sandinistas,'' said Representative Edward P. Boland, the Massachusetts Democrat who is the committee's chairman. ''It was the opinion of the vast majority of the committee that there was a violation of the Boland Amendment.''

headline: Consumer Buying Plans By The Associated Press Confidence in the economy
abstract: remains strong and more families are planning to buy cars   and major appliances as consumers approach the Christmas season ''in high spirits,''   the Conference Board said yesterday. The business-sponsored research organization said its   monthly survey of consumer   confidence found that 30 percent of the consumers questioned said they were living   ''better'' than they were a year   ago.

headline: NEW THREAT OF RAID ON AMERICANS REPORTED IN A LEBANESE BROADCAST
abstract: A group that has taken responsibility for most of the terrorist attacks against American installations in the Middle East has threatened to hit United States institutions in the region within two days, the Christian radio station Voice of Lebanon said today.    A broadcast said the group, Islamic Holy War, had ''threatened to carry out an operation against American interests in the Middle East within the next 48 hours.''   The radio station reported that the organization also said ''the operation will surprise the Americans.'' The station gave no other details.

headline: SKEPTICISM GREETS NEW TAX PLAN
abstract: Imports still exceed exports, and although the gap narrowed a little in October, the merchandise trade deficit remains at a record high.  At more than $100 billion for the year so far, it may be double that of last year. In October, machinery and farm goods exports increased, and imports of manufactured goods decreased, but the gap was still $9.2 billion. Part of the problem is the continuing strength of the dollar, which surged again last week as interest rates in the United States dropped.      The tax revision plan was greeted with much skepticism, trepidation and uncertainty by members of Congress and special interest groups. President Reagan, who had ordered the study from the Treasury Department, immediately distanced himself from the plan. According to Treasury officials, most companies would pay more taxes - about 25 percent more on the average - but 56 percent of individuals would pay less.

headline: Trial of 6 Dissidents Recessed in Belgrade
abstract: A trial of six dissidents charged with conspiring to overthrow the Government was recessed today for 24 hours after a defendant objected to a ruling by the presiding judge.    Miodrag Milic, a writer, said the judge had denied him access to court documents for his defense.

headline: RADAR SIGHTINGS IN HONDURAS POSE A MYSTERY
abstract: United States and Honduran military officials are trying unsuccessfully to explain what appear to be a series of incursions by unidentified aircraft into Honduran airspace.   The sightings have been made by the United States radar facility here in recent weeks. What is mysterious about the incidents, according to officials familiar with them, is that there is no corroborating evidence that the incursions have actually occurred.

headline: Allis-Chalmers Credit Unit Talks
abstract: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation of Milwaukee, which makes agricultural equipment, said it had agreed with the Security Pacific Corporation to end the negotiations for Security Pacific to buy the Allis-Chalmers Credit Corporation.

headline: Medical Imaging Unit At Raytheon Gets Head
abstract: Apparently, the Raytheon Company sees something in the X-ray business that others cannot. The Lexingron, Mass., company has named John C. Kingery, 38, president of a new division of Raytheon, a leading manufacturer of electronic equipment and components.   Raytheon is also the largest independent manufacturer of components in the X-ray sector of the medical imaging industry, which includes not only X-rays but ultrasound and other diagnostics equipment as well.

headline: Futures/Options; Analysts See Sugar Deficit
abstract: IN the eyes of a chartist, swings in world sugar   prices look dramatic on paper - a record high   of about 65 cents a pound back in 1974 and bump- along prices of about 5 cents a pound or so now.    But analysts say, world sugar production is expected to be less than consumption for the first time in several years, thus tightening the supply and, the producers hope, raising prices.    Dennis C. Koutras, commodity research director at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., said the shortfall, called a deficit year, will be about 1.5 million metric tons in the crop year that began Sept. 1.    ''We finally have a deficit year for sugar, the first since 1980-1981, so I think that we will see higher prices eventually during this new crop year,'' he said. But Mr. Koutras added that there might be a temporary dip in prices before any rise.

headline: Altman Purchase Reported Near
abstract: A group of investors is nearing agreement with the Altman Foundation to buy the seven B. Altman stores, for a price that probably will be more than $100 million, according to a source close to the transaction.   The investors reportedly include Sanford J. Zimmerman, chairman of Cohoes Specialty Stores in Cohoes, N.Y.; Earle W. Kazis of Earle W. Kazis Associates, and Peter L. Malkin, a senior partner in the New York law firm of Wien, Malkin & Bettex.

headline: Brock, Americana
abstract: The Brock Hotel Corporation said that under a letter of agreement signed last week with the Americana Hotels Corporation, Brock will own 45 percent and Americana 55 percent of a new concern that will combine the hotel units of the two companies. Brock said the initial ownership arrangement would be subject to adjustment based on cash-flow contributions of the two hotel chains during 1985. Under the proposal, Brock said it would receive a 10-year payout equal to 50 percent of the development fees, royalties and initial franchising of its new Brock Residence Inns Inc. hotel chain.

headline: Chrysler Unit Offering Notes
abstract: The Chrysler Financial Corporation, a subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation, is offering $200 million of 12 3/4 percent notes due in 1999 at a price of 199.434 to yield 12.85 percent, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.    The notes, which may be redeemed by investors at a price of 100 in 10 years, were offered with a yield about 1.1 percentage points greater than 10- year Treasury notes.    The notes carry speculative-grade ratings of Ba-2 from Moody's and BB- from Standard & Poor's, though some analysts outside the major rating agencies have estimated the company's ratings might be raised in the future.

headline: Ralston, Cargill
abstract: The Ralston Purina Company said it had reached a tentative agreement to sell substantially all of its soybean processing operations to Cargill Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: ISRAELIS OUTLINE NEW SET OF TERMS ON SOUTH LEBANON
abstract: Israel is willing to consider withdrawing its troops from Lebanon in return for a ''nonwritten'' Syrian commitment to keep its forces where they are and to prevent infiltration southward by Palestinian guerrillas, Israeli officials said today.   The officials, speaking on the eve of Prime Minister Shimon Peres's visit to Washington, said that in exchange for a pullout, the Israelis would also insist on an expanded deployment of United Nations forces in southern Lebanon as well as a role for the Israeli-backed militia known as the South Lebanon Army.    But, in contrast to their previous proposals, the Israelis are no longer insisting that Syrian troops withdraw from Lebanon, that there be a formal signed withdrawal accord, or that Israel get political concessions from the Lebanese Government, the officials said.   U.S. Mediation Is Sought      The officials, who are involved in the formulation of Israeli policy, said they believed the Israeli proposals were a realistic basis for negotiations with the Syrians and that Mr. Peres would try to enlist the Reagan Administration's help in playing some kind of mediation role with Damascus. The Israeli Prime Minister, who was in New York today, is to begin talks in Washington with Reagan Administration officials on Monday.

headline: THE ASCENDANCY OF REAGAN
abstract: Donald T. Regan seemed contented Friday before his weekend departure for his vacation retreat in Florida. He sat in one of the wing chairs of his Treasury Department office, the portrait of Alexander Hamilton peering down from above the fireplace, a glass elephant filled with jelly beans on the coffee table. He looked crisp in a navy blue suit, polished black shoes and a navy blue tie emblazoned with little Santa Clauses.    Mr. Regan turned 66 that day, a year beyond the moment when the company he once ran, Merrill Lynch, would have retired him with a gold watch and a nest egg that he suggested a few months ago was worth about $30 million. But the septagenarian next door on Pennsylvania Avenue had other plans for his Treasury Secretary. ''The President suggested that if I tried to leave,'' said Mr. Regan, ''he'd shackle me to my desk.''  Man of the Hour      Donald Regan is the undisputed man of the opening hours of the second Reagan term. He is the author of a remarkable proposal to overhaul the nation's tax system that has brought wails from groups that think they would be hurt, such as major business organizations, charities and New York State. But it has found support among apolitical tax reformers, for its simplicity, and among many leading Democrats and economists, for its elimination of special preferences for business and the rich.

headline: TANK WITH FAULT WASN'T LEAKY ONE
abstract: The Union Carbide Corporation said today that a chemical tank that was in substandard condition as recently as June was not the same tank that leaked poisonous gas over Bhopal, India, on Dec. 3.     The company said that the deficient tank, described as a feed tank, was in a different part of the Bhopal pesticide plant and that there was virtually no chance that it could have caused the accident at the plant.   Problems with the chemical tank at the Bhopal plant were outlined in documents made public by Union Carbide on Monday. The documents described 10 potentially major safety problems that were found during an inspection of the Bhopal site in March 1982.

headline: GRIM IMAGES: HOW ETHIOPIA BECAME NEWS
abstract: Most Americans became aware of the famine in Ethiopia many months after it began, through television pictures.     Some of those who watched the network news broadcasts on Ethiopia have asked why they appeared only in late October and early November and why the famine was suddenly available for viewing in electronic images whose instancy belied the slow development of the Ethiopian pain and starvation.    Most of the answer lies in the difficulties the Marxist Government of Ethiopia put in the way of journalists who had become aware of the growing seriousness of the famine months before but could not get permission to enter the country to gather information, film and pictures.    A broadcast tape that appeared on television in Europe and North America late in October and led to an outpouring of charity apparently opened the Ethiopian gate to other journalists.

headline: CANADA'S LUCKY CAR INDUSTRY
abstract: Canada's car industry is one of the brightest spots in the country's economy - a triumph, as it happens, that is in large part a matter of luck.     The gradual erosion of the country's dollar to a level of about 76 cents in United States currency, although raising the cost of living, has made exports considerably more attractive. The bigger car models made here, which Canadians complained about five years ago when gasoline prices were skyrocketing, are now best sellers.    Even the country's militant United Automobile Workers union does not seem so menacing to American companies - despite the strike deadline faced by General Motors on Wednesday - when they consider the currency differential and the fact that the Canadian federal and provincial governments pick up the tab for medical benefits.   'In the Right Place'    ''The fact the companies are a success is the result of circumstances over which they've had no control,'' said Maryann Keller, an analyst with Vilas-Fisher Associates Ltd. in New York. ''They just happen to be in the right place at the right time.''

headline: ACTIVISM AFFIRMED BY CATHOLIC ORDER
abstract: The governing councils of Roman Catholic Maryknoll missionaries have given strong backing to the order's social justice aims, despite criticism of its policy of political activism.   Delegates from the various areas of the world where Maryknoll carries on missions ended two months of meetings Friday. Leaders said the direction the order has taken, trying to bring about social change, had been approved and renewed.    Such sessions are held every six years. Delegates meeting in separate chapters, one for priests and brothers and the other for nuns, review recent work and set goals for the future.

headline: JAPANESE TRADE PANEL LETS FOREIGNERS TESTIFY
abstract: In a step that may lead toward greater foreign participation in the advisory councils that help shape Japanese industrial policy, foreign businessmen were allowed today for the first time to testify before a council of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry.    During a closed-door meeting on a plan to encourage high-technology research and development, executives from chambers of commerce of the United States, Britain, France and West Germany urged that foreign companies be allowed to participate in research and development projects in Japan.   Such projects are of great interest to foreign companies in Japan. In an August report, new policies to encourage research and development were proposed by the ministry's industrial structure council, one of the key groups in forming Japan's industrial strategy.

headline: PHONE RATE CUT ORDERED TO OFFSET OVERCHARGES
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission today ordered the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its former operating companies to reduce interstate long-distance rates and other charges by $178.2 million next year.   The F.C.C.'s order grew out of a staff finding that A.T.&T.'s 1978 revenues exceeded by $101 million the 10 percent rate of return on interstate services allowed by the commission. The difference between $101 million and $178.2 million represents accumulated interest on the 1978 overcharges. A.T.&T. said that its total Bell System interstate revenues in 1978 were $12.9 billion.

headline: NICARAGUANS VOTE TODAY FOR PRESIDENT
abstract: More than a million Nicaraguans are expected to vote Sunday in national elections that have been criticized abroad and boycotted by several political parties at home, but hailed by the Government as ''the first free election in Nicaragua's history.''     Nicaragua is caught in a deepening economic crisis and also confronts a major guerrilla insurgency, in which more than 10,000 people have died in less than three years. Relations with the United States, which has cut off aid and has contributed millions of dollars to the rebels, are poor.    The Sandinista candidate for the presidency, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, is expected to win easily over five active opponents in Sunday's balloting. A sixth candidate, Virgilio Godoy Reyes of the Independent Liberal Party, quit the race two weeks ago to protest what he said was coercion of voters by the Sandinistas.

headline: Alcan Seeking Delay on Smelter
abstract: The Aluminum Company of Canada, a subsidiary of Alcan Aluminium Ltd., asked the British Columbia government to postpone further review of its application for a $3 billion (Canadian currency) smelter project at Kemano, British Columbia.    Alcan said it was taking the action because of the current poor market conditions in the aluminum industry and the difficulty of forecasting when new smelting capacity for export markets would be justified. The company said it was committed to the eventual completion of the project, which would have the capability of producing 375,000 metric tons of aluminum annually.

headline: Washington Watch ; A Pocketbook Vote Predictor
abstract: WASHINGTON    Economists have had a lot of trouble in recent years with their forecasting. Recessions have been predicted that did not occur.

headline: People
abstract: *  Harry Rubicam named promotion director of Discover magazine.     *  Jack Hill named vice president of research at the Cabletelevision Advertising Bureau.

headline: A.P. EMPLOYEES VANISH IN BEIRUT
abstract: Four Lebanese employees of The Associated Press disappeared today and are believed to have been kidnapped.   The chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, Terry Anderson, said the men did not appear at the A.P. office in West Beirut after one of them, Moheddine Habbal, a driver, left before 7 A.M. to pick up two of the others in East Beirut and a third in West Beirut.

headline: Swazi Ex-Official Detained
abstract: A former Swazi Finance Minister, Sishayi S. Nxumalo, was detained by the police for questioning Thursday, sources close to his family said here today. Mr. Nxumalo was dismissed as Finance Minister in June, shortly after he charged that unidentified prominent figures in Swaziland were implicated in a $10.4 million customs fraud.

headline: Argo Sets Deal With French The Argo Communications
abstract: Corporation, New Rochelle,   N.Y., announced yesterday   that it planned to initiate voice   and data transmission to   France by mid-1985, following   an agreement signed Saturday   with French postal and telegraph authorities.

headline: ARABS ON COSTA DEL SOL: NO HOLIDAY FOR ASSASSINS
abstract: It was 9:30 on a balmy evening and the outside tables of the Cafe Sport here were filled when a young man in blue jeans calmly walked up and shot a Saudi engineer dead.   The 32-year-old vacationing Saudi, Nasser Abdul, who was murdered Sept. 14, was the second Arab to be killed in 40 days in this Mediterranean resort on Spain's Costa del Sol, until recently a place known for its discretion as a hideout for European aristocracy.   The slayings, for which the Arab extremist group Islamic Holy War took responsibility, violently underlined how in the last seven years this resort of high-rises and whitewashed cottages along narrow Andalusian streets has quietly become a haven for Arabs.   Led by King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, who has built a palace copied after the White House, much of the Saudi royal family, as well as sheiks, government officials and business leaders from throughout the Middle East, have built more than 400 vacation mansions and retreats in the surrounding hills.

headline: HOW TO CORRECT FED POLICY; OPEN UP THE MONEY SUPPLY SPIGOT
abstract: HOW does the Federal Reserve Board do it? While Congress blames the White House for the red ink and the White House blames the Congress for too little spending cuts, the Federal Reserve escapes any culpability time and again. Few, with the notable exception of Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, have pointed out that a cooperative Federal Reserve would be able to eliminate much of the nation's budgetary red ink and that a bull-headed Fed will lead us to disastrous, irreparable troubles.   So far, the budget balancing act is seen in terms of a major tax increase, punitive spending cuts or a deep recession. But in fact, a balanced budget is possible provided the Fed cooperates with the White House on a unified Governmental program to provide the capital necessary to bring interest rates way down, cut in half the financing costs of Government, business and residential housing, and at the same time, increase the growth of production capacity to at least a 5 percent annual rate.

headline: Economic Scene ; Federal Deficit And Indexation
abstract: With the rise in the Consumer Price Index by four-tenths of 1 percent last month, making an increase of 4.2 percent over the preceding 12 months, the Government has announced how much taxpayers will save on their 1985 income taxes to adjust for inflation. Starting Jan. 1, income tax brackets, the zero bracket limit, the standard deduction and personal exemptions will all be raised 4.1 percent.   As welcome as the start of indexation will be for individual taxpayers, whether it means a net saving or only an offset to the statutory rise in Social Security taxes, it means a loss of revenues to the Federal Government in the face of widening budget deficits. How big the revenue losses from indexation will be depends on future inflation and the economy's rate of growth.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 31, 1984 :  MONDAY Cascade Nat Gas   TUESDAY Holiday   WEDNESDAY Carolina Freight CorpHouston Ind  THURSDAY   Clevepak CorpRite Aid CorpOrange & Rockld Utils   FRIDAY N Y State Elec & Gas

headline: Gemayel and Assad Confer on Security
abstract: President Amin Gemayel held talks in Damascus today with President Hafez al- Assad of Syria on security problems in Lebanon and the deadlocked negotiations with Israel, the Lebanese state radio reported.   Mr. Gemayel's trip to the Syrian capital came a day after he had presided over a stormy Cabinet meeting at which Moslem and Christian members failed to reach agreement on a security plan designed to deploy the Lebanese Army along the coastal highway linking Beirut with the Israeli-occupied south.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Andrew Corp., Orlando Park, Ill., said it had agreed in principle to acquire certain assets of the high-frequency antenna business of Granger Associates, a subsidiary of Digital Switch Corp. Terms were not disclosed.     *  Diamond Shamrock Corp., a Dallas-based oil and chemicals concern, said its Natomas of Canada Ltd. unit had sold 107 retail gasoline stations and certain other assets to Olco Oil Co., a division of Fiberez of Canada Ltd.

headline: HANOVER BANK SETS 10 3/4% PRIME
abstract: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company cut its prime lending rate yesterday by half a percentage point, to 10 3/4 percent, the lowest level since August 1983, when it stood at 10 1/2 percent. Although no other major banks immediately followed the move, it was widely believed most would do so shortly, probably today. Some predicted that the prime rate would soon drop even lower.

headline: Canadian Prices Rise
abstract: Canadian consumer prices rose one-tenth of 1 percent in September from August and were up 3.8 percent from 12 months before, Statistics Canada said today. The Government agency said food prices fell seven-tenths of 1 percent in September from August but rose 5.6 percent from a year earlier. Prices of non-food items were up three-tenths of 1 percent from August and up 3.3 percent from a year earlier.

headline: U.N. Again Demands Soviet Quit Afghanistan
abstract: The General Assembly reiterated a demand today that the Soviet Union withdraw its troops from Afghanistan. It was the fifth such measure passed by the Assembly since the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan in December 1979.

headline: NATIONAL INTERGROUP IN MERGER
abstract: National Intergroup Inc., in a transaction that would take it further afield from steel, yesterday announced plans to merge with the Bergen Brunswig Corporation, a fast- growing drug and electronics distributor.     Bergen Brunswig, which would be the surviving entity and be renamed the Bergen National Corporation, would acquire National Intergroup in a stock transaction valued at $550 million.   The agreement evoked surprise and some skepticism on Wall Street because the figure is a substantial discount from the book value of National Intergroup, which some put as high as $900 million. It is also lower than the current market value of the stock.

headline: Report on Bank Failures
abstract: Criminal misconduct by bank officers plays a part in roughly 25 to 50 percent of the banking failures in the country, a Congressional study charged today.    The report blamed the regulatory system for a failure ''to detect, investigate or penalize such fraud.''   Concluding a 15-month investigation, a House Government Operations subcommittee criticized Federal banking regulators and the Justice Department for not curbing what it termed a rising tide of insider abuse at the nation's financial institutions.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Nov. 6, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. headline: Rebels Said to Kill 9 Turks
abstract: Five women and four children were killed in eastern Turkey when Kurdish guerrillas bombed two houses, martial- law authorities said today. An official statement said the attack took place Thursday night at the village of Karagecit near the town of Eruh. Security forces said they killed one of the guerrillas.

headline: Northwest Group Awaits Financing
abstract: Northwest Industries said an investor group that had agreed to buy the company had not yet completed required financing for the transaction, which is scheduled to close Dec. 31. But Northwest said Donald P. Kelly of Kelly, Briggs & Associates Inc., one of the purchasers, said the group expects to have firm financing commitments before that date.

headline: O'Hare Bonds For United Air
abstract: A $320 million industrial development bond financing for United Airlines by O'Hare International Airport of Chicago was offered this week through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.    For $140 million of bonds that may be put, or redeemed, in six months, when the interest rate may change, the initial rate is 6.40 percent.

headline: Legal Fees
abstract: To the Editor:   My name was taken in vain by Stephen Case, whose law firm, Davis Polk and Wardwell, represents Manville Corporation, in his article opposing contingent fees for lawyers (''Lawyers Often Are Grossly Overpaid,'' Forum, Dec. 2). In quoting my published views out of context (page 128 of my ''Law, Lawyers and Laymen,'') Mr. Case seeks to imply that I am opposed to contingency fees for lawyers.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; District of Columbia Gets Highest Ratings
abstract: The District of Columbia, which plans to make its public debut in the tax-exempt market this week with a $150 million issue of tax and revenue anticipation notes due Sept. 30, 1985, yesterday received the highest rating of Moody's Investment Grade-1, or MIG-1. The District plans to issue long-term general obligation bonds before Sept. 30, 1985.

headline: DOW OFF 14.80
abstract: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday in slower trading, reflecting concern over the Treasury's tax proposals and the slowing economy, as well as weakness in the bond market.    At the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was off 14.80 points, to 1,205.39, after advancing almost 8 points Tuesday.   Declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored those that rose, 919 to 589, as volume on the Big Board slumped to 86.3 million shares, from 95.5 million the day before.    Proposals 'Too Extreme'    Bruce D. Radler, vice president of Pendrick Reeves Associates Inc., Southport, Conn., said that many market participants had concluded that the Treasury's tax proposals, announced Tuesday, were ''too extreme.''

headline: U.S. ISSUES TO TEST RATE DROPS
abstract: Recent declines in interest rates will be tested this week when the Treasury comes to market with a $5.5 billion issue of seven-year notes and a $8.8 billion offering of two-year notes.     The heavy supply - to be followed by another $28 billion or so of note and bond offerings by Nov. 8 - is a warning flag in the credit markets. But there are other developments suggesting that investors and securities dealers can absorb the new issues without substantially higher yields.    ''With monetary policy easing, there should be little concern over the supply of Treasury issues,'' said Herbert E. Neil Jr., a vice president and economist at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. He added that the Fed had fostered lower interest rates for a variety of reasons: low inflation, a sharp slowdown in the economy from the first half, and slow money supply growth the past three months.

headline: PATENTS ; Sniffing Device Detects Smuggled Farm Goods
abstract: A sniffing device was patented this week for the Department of Agriculture. Patent 4,478,096, granted Wolfgang K. Heiland and Paul Magidman, staff members, indicates that the device is to be used at ports of entry to detect agricultural contraband being smuggled into the country inside closed luggage.

headline: FIRE-GUTTED QUEENS HOUSING RESTORED WITH TAX AID
abstract: On the heels of a historic-district designation in Ridgewood, Queens, last year has come a housing rehabilitation that demonstrates the power of tax incentives to stimulate new investment in older neighborhoods.   The rehabilitation is in Siamese- twin, three-story town houses at 1821 and 1823 Madison Street in Ridgewood that were ravaged by fire in 1980. All 12 railroad-flat apartments had to be vacated.    The wrecked buildings surely would have been demolished, said Paul A. Kerzner, president of the Greater Ridgewood Restoration Corporation, without the availability of the tax credits. Market rents in Ridgewood were too low to justify the risk of an expensive rehabilitation.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: *  American Software Technology, Bay Harbor Island, Fla., said its board had approved the repurchase of up to 5 million common shares in the open market.     *  Dun & Bradstreet Corp., a provider of business information and related services, said it had purchased National Directory Services Inc., which publishes 11 Yellow Pages directories in the Houston area.

headline: Avon Purchase
abstract: Avon Products Inc. said its Mallinckrodt Inc. division had purchased Tronomed International Inc. and its associated companies for more than $14 million. Tronomed, which has offices in Costa Mesa and Carlsbad, Calif., produces disposable medical devices for intra-arterial blood pressure monitoring. The company will have sales of more than $11 million this year, Avon said.

headline: BRAZIL OPPOSITION LEADS IN RACE FOR PRESIDENCY
abstract: Despite the vocal disapproval of Brazil's departing military Government, new defections from the governing party have confirmed the opposition nominee, Tancredo Neves, as the strong favorite to win the indirect presidential election next year.    Just 11 weeks before the 686-member Electoral College meets to choose the country's first civilian President in two decades, a majority of state governors belonging to the official Democratic Social Party have backed Mr. Neves, a 74-year-old former Governor of Minas Gerais.   The latest endorsements, which President Joao Baptista Figueiredo called opportunistic, came amid charges that campaign managers of the party's official candidate, Paulo Salim Maluf, had tried to buy votes and were seeking a secret ballot in the Electoral College.   They also coincided with mounting evidence of nervousness among senior army officers at the prospect of an opposition victory. One Brazilian newspaper reported this week that plans had already been drawn up to declare an emergency in Brasilia when the college meets on Jan. 15 to prevent demonstrations and live broadcasts of the vote.

headline: 2 SIDES IN SALVADOR TO MEET AGAIN FRIDAY
abstract: Salvadoran Government and rebel officials will meet at a Roman Catholic Church retreat near the capital of San Salvador for a second round of peace talks on Friday, church and rebel spokesmen said today.    The meeting will take place in Government-controlled territory at the Sacred Heart Retreat of Ayagualo, 10 miles south of the capital, according to Auxiliary Archbishop Gregorio Rosa Chavez. He said the meeting would start at either 7 or 8 A.M. and last until 3 or 4 P.M.   When the Government and the rebels first met last month in La Palma near the border with Honduras the town was temporarily declared a demilitarized zone. This time, however, Government troops will guard the area around the church retreat while officials of the International Red Cross keep watch on the inner grounds, Archbishop Rosa Chavez said.

headline: CHAMPION WRITE-OFFS ON TIMBER
abstract: The Champion International Corporation intends to take write-offs in the areas of timber-cutting contracts and building materials that will reduce this year's earnings by $120 million to $150 million, the forest products company has disclosed.    Champion, based in Stamford, Conn., said in a statement late Sunday that the write-offs would be taken in preparation for its proposed acquisition of the St. Regis Company, a paper producer it plans to buy for $1.84 billion.    Analysts had suggested that a write-off was in the offing, especially in Champion's lagging area of building materials. ''I think the size of it was a little greater than I would have expected,'' said Gary Palmero, an analyst of the paper industry for Oppenheimer & Company.

headline: PRINCESS ANNE CUTS TRIP SHORT
abstract: Princess Anne will cut short a tour of India because security officials there are concerned about her safety, Buckingham Palace announced today.    Anne, the 34-year-old daughter of Queen Elizabeth II, will leave India after representing the Queen at the funeral of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi on Saturday, the statement said.

headline: Japan Leads Output Gains
abstract: Industrial production moved ahead faster in Japan than in the United States last spring, but dropped in West Germany and France, the International Monetary Fund reported today.

headline: NASA REFUSES TO COMMENT ON ITS FORMER OFFICIAL
abstract: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said yesterday that it would have no comment on the announcement that a former highly decorated space official had been linked to Nazi war crimes at a German V-2 rocket factory during World War II.   A spokesman for the agency said there was ''no policy'' on whether the former official, Arthur Rudolph, would be requested to return his NASA decorations. He was awarded the Exceptional Service Medal in 1968 and the Distinguished Service Medal, the agency's highest honor, the following year.

headline: MERRILL BID FOR TOKYO SEAT LOST
abstract: Merrill Lynch Capital Markets has lost out to a Japanese securities company in its effort to become the first foreign member of the Tokyo Stock Exchange.    In a surprise move, Daifuku Securities announced today that it would sell its seat on the exchange to the Utsumiya Securities Company, a Hiroshima-based firm with $15 million in assets and 355 employees. Utsumiya paid $6.6 million.   Most industry insiders were betting on Merrill Lynch, citing both foreign and domestic pressures.

headline: GRAY STILL DOGGED BY SOME CHARGES
abstract: Ten days after issuing a brief statement that appeared to clear Harry J. Gray, chairman of the United Technologies Corporation, of allegations that he electronically bugged the conversations of other senior executives, directors of the company are preparing a report on other charges against Mr. Gray.    The investigation was discussed by Mr. Gray himself, who said that a special committee of the United Technologies board had been presented with at least 20 allegations of improper or criminal conduct.   ''There isn't a shred of truth to any one of them, and I have denied every one,'' Mr. Gray said. Terming the charges against him ''ludicrous,'' he nonetheless said they were serious.

headline: Jacobs in Filing On Avco Stake
abstract: An investment group led by Irwin L. Jacobs, of Minneapolis, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it ''might at some point and under certain circumstances consider seeking control'' of the Avco Corporation. The Jacobs group said it bought 1,487,100 Avco common shares, or 6.5 percent of the total outstanding, ''to obtain a substantial equity position.''

headline: Soviet Grain Purchases
abstract: A Soviet grain negotiating team indicated to Agriculture Department officials today that the 22 million metric tons of corn, wheat and soybeans the United States has offered to sell them this year would be sufficient. They did not ask for permission to buy any more than that in the coming 10 months.

headline: A CENTER OF SOVIET POWER
abstract: In the Soviet Union, where the Communist Party holds ultimate authority, the party's Politburo is the nation's effective Cabinet, the arena in which final decisions are made.    But the workings of the political bureau of the Communist Party Central Committee, of which Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov was a key member, are a mystery outside the Kremlin walls.   The Politburo's regular Thursday meetings are announced in press reports so general that little substance is revealed. They are said to last from three to six hours. The late Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, once said decisions were reached by consensus, without a formal vote, 99.99 percent of the time.

headline: Washington Protests to Chile Over Expulsion of a Reporter
abstract: The United States said today that it sent a strong protest to Chile over its expulsion of United Press International's Santiago bureau chief for purportedly filing a false report.   ''We strongly object to any infringement of the legitimate rights of foreign correspondents by the Government of Chile,'' Alan Romberg, a State Department spokesman, said.

headline: Swedish Jobless Rate
abstract: Sweden's unemployment rate dropped to 3.2 percent in September from 3.4 percent in August and 4.1 percent a year earlier, the Government said today. It said 140,000 people were jobless in September, down from 153,000 in August and 177,000 in September 1983.

headline: Market Place; Union Carbide And Insurance
abstract: SHARES of the Union Carbide Corporation have come under heavy selling pressure since the middle of last week. In three trading days ended Monday, the stock plunged a total of 9 1/4 points, to 35 1/4, as apprehension mounted that the company could incur staggering claims for damages from the lethal gas leak at its plant in Bhopal, India. More than 2,000 people, it is estimated, died as a result of the leak.    During those same three trading sessions, the stock of Marsh & McLennan Companies, the holding company that owns the world's largest insurance broker, declined 2 3/8 points, to 51 3/4. Only last month, shares of Marsh & McLennan sold at a record price of 56 1/4.

headline: Cambodia Rebels Report Attacks on Vietnamese
abstract: The Pol Pot guerrillas said today that they had inflicted heavy damage on Vietnamese transport and supply links in Cambodia, and had ''crushed down'' more than 10,000 Vietnamese soldiers during fighting in the rainy season, from May to September.   The Pol Pot forces' radio, monitored in Bangkok, said they cut off railroads to the Cambodian capital of Phnom Penh from the seaport of Kompongsom and from Battambang Province.

headline: Meeting Recesses in Sweden After Russian Berates West
abstract: The 35-nation Stockholm conference on European security recessed for the year Friday after the Soviet delegate accused the United States and NATO of preparing for war.   The delegates from European and North American countries will resume discussions in mid-January.   The conference began Jan. 17, but only last month was it able to agree on an order of business.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM PRIMER FOR INSURGENTS
abstract: Following are excerpts from ''Psychological Operations in Guerrilla Warfare,'' a primer for Nicaraguan rebels prepared by the Central Intelligence Agency. The document was translated from the Spanish by the Congressional Research Service at the request of the House Select Committee on Intelligence.       Armed Propaganda Teams are formed through a careful selection of persuasive and highly motivated guerrillas who move about within the population, encouraging the people to support the guerrillas and put up resistance against the enemy. It combines a high degree of political awareness and the 'armed' propaganda ability of the guerrillas toward a planned, programmed and controlled effort.   The combatant propagandist guerrillas are the result of a continuous program of indoctrination and motivation. They will have the mission of showing the people how great and fair our movement is in the eyes of all Nicaraguans and the world. Identifying themselves with our people, they will increase the sympathy toward our movement, which will result in greater support of the population for the freedom commandos, reducing support for the regime in power.

headline: Merrill Lynch Insurance Accord
abstract: The life insurance subsidiary of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. has agreed to pay the state a $45,000 fine and to stop selling annuity policies offered by the financially troubled Baldwin-United Corporation, the state's top insurance official said.

headline: 500 Are Detained by Nepal
abstract: About 500 people were detained today for taking part in a meeting organized by the outlawed Nepali Congress Party in Bharatpur, sources in the party said. More than 150 were still being held late today, the sources said. All political parties are banned in Nepal.

headline: SALVADOR JAILING HAS U.S. BACKLASH
abstract: The case of a union official imprisoned in El Salvador without trial since 1980 has become an issue in relations between the United States and El Salvador, according to Administration officials.     United States labor leaders and members of Congress have recently pressed President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador to resolve the case, contending it is a test of his commitment to improve the human rights situation in El Salvador.    Many members of Congress voted to increase military and economic aid to El Salvador after Mr. Duarte's election in May, saying, in the words of Representative Clarence D. Long, Democratic of Maryland, that they wanted ''to give him a chance.''    They said Mr. Duarte's pledge to improve the Salvadoran judicial system and to curtail human rights abuses was a key factor in their support of the additional aid.

headline: GAS LEAK TOUCHES A NERVE IN EUROPE
abstract: The mass deaths from gas released by an insecticide plant in India on Monday have spread a sense of nervousness in Western Europe, where large chemical concerns produce vast amounts of highly toxic substances at factories that are often in areas with dense populations.    Disasters involving poison gases tend to touch a sensitive nerve among Western Europeans. Older people recall the disastrous use of such gases in World War I. Moreover, large quantities of poison gas, for military use, are stored in Europe by Soviet bloc and Western armed forces, and negotiations to reduce their amounts or ban them altogether have achieved little.   Bayer A.G., the giant West German chemical company that produces methyl isocyanate, the gas released in Bhopal, India, at two plants in Europe, ruled out the possibility of a similar accident and said it did not intend to halt production. The company produces the substance for use in pesticides at factories in Antwerp, Belgium, and at Dormagen, on the Rhine River about 50 miles north of here,

headline: CABLE GUIDE SHOWS SAVVY AND SUCCESS
abstract: Just over a year ago, Time Inc. folded TV-Cable Week, its ambitious television-listings guide that lost $47 million before taxes and won fewer than 400,000 subscribers.    By contrast, with its latest issue, The Cable Guide, run by an attorney and an accountant out of Horsham, Pa., reached a circulation of 5.8 million. Distributed in 700 cable systems, the program guide, which is aimed at people who buy cable services such as Home Box Office or Showtime as well as basic cable, is the nation's best- selling cable magazine.    That the four-year-old Cable Guide has succeeded where the nation's biggest magazine publisher failed suggests that survival in that business takes more than money or magazine experience. What is critical, analysts say, is an understanding of the cable industry.

headline: CREATING A CIGARETTE THAT PUTS ITSELF OUT
abstract: A self-extinguishing cigarette?   A patent for one was first issued in 1854 and about 100 others have been issued since then, according to Carlton Currens, an aide to Representative Joe Moakley, Democrat of Massachusetts. The problem, he added, is that ''they don't work, or they are impractical.''

headline: ITT SUSPENDS PUBLIC RELATIONS CHIEF
abstract: Edward J. Gerrity Jr., an executive vice president of the ITT Corporation and its most senior public relations official, said yesterday that he had been suspended ''because of an internal perception that I have been in disagreement with certain policies of top management.''     At the same time, it was learned that the Securities and Exchange Commission has begun a broad investigation of trading in the shares of ITT., which has risen sharply recently. The investigation was described as covering trading going back at least several months.    It could not be determined if there was any connection between the suspension and the S.E.C. investigation.

headline: INTEREST RATES DECLINE AGAIN
abstract: Interest rates fell again yesterday, and the question being asked in the credit markets was not whether rates would keeping dropping but how quickly and to what extent.     Market participants, meanwhile, debated whether the Federal Reserve System would cut its discount rate.    From the opening, the tone of the markets was positive, set by the report that the Producer Price Index fell two-tenths of 1 percent in October, for the third consecutive monthly decline. This tone was bolstered as the day wore on by a relatively low Federal funds rate and a prediction by Henry Kaufman, the Salomon Brothers economist, that the Fed would cut its discount rate.

headline: Russian Cigarettes
abstract: To the Editor:     In 1977 I spent half a year in the Soviet Union. While there I noticed that Soviet cigarettes tend to go out if they are not puffed constantly. It was annoying at the time, but after reading your article on efforts to develop a self-extinguishing cigarette (''What's New on the Cigarette Front,'' Oct. 28) I now realize that this is one area in which Soviets are ahead of Americans in consumer technology.  JUOZAS A. KAZLAS New York, Oct. 29
