headline: Searle's Net Drops 33.6%
abstract: G. D. Searle & Company, citing high levels of marketing and promotional expenses and an increased tax rate, yesterday reported a 33.6 percent drop in third-quarter profits.   Earnings fell to $44.6 million, or 90 cents a share, from $67.2 million, or $1.35 a share, in the comparable period a year earlier.

headline: Portec's Plans
abstract: Portec Inc., a maker of railcar and construction equipment, said it was considering a variety of actions to ''maximize value'' of its stock to shareholders, including the sale of some or all of its businesses, a leveraged buyout or a combination of alternatives. The company said it was working with its investment bankers, Kidder, Peabody & Company, to review its course of action. On the New York Stock Exchange today, Portec, which has about 3.7 million shares outstanding, jumped $2.50, to $17.75.

headline: MARCOS FOE SLAIN
abstract: A leading Philippine opposition figure was shot dead today in the Mindanao city of Zamboanga.    The victim, Mayor Cesar Climaco of Zamboanga, is the second prominent critic of President Ferdinand E. Marcos to be slain in the past month. On Oct. 19, Alexander Orcullo, regional secretary of an opposition party, was shot dead in Davao, also in Mindanao.

headline: C.I.A. MANUAL SENT BY BALLOON?
abstract: The Central Intelligence Agency distributed some of its manuals for Nicaraguan rebels earlier this year by attaching them to balloons and floating them into the country, Administration and Congressional officials said today.   The officials said the C.I.A.'s apparent purpose was to scare Nicaragua's Sandinista Government by creating the impression that the United States- backed insurgency was a more serious threat than it was.

headline: A.T.&T. Improves Phone Connecting
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, seeking to enhance its position in the highly competitive business telephone equipment market, announced enhancements to its flagship product in that market, the System 85 private branch exchange. Private branch exchanges, or P.B.X.'s, connect all the telephones within an office building or company.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Dec. 4, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: TREASURY PRICES FALL SHARPLY
abstract: Treasury note and bond prices fell sharply yesterday as securities dealers discovered that investor demand was waning in the face of the rapid rise in prices and decline in yields in the last two months.     Specialists in the Government securities market said there were no new economic or financial developments to explain the drop in prices. But they added that there was no additional good news to push up bond prices, which had increased about 8 1/2 points, or $85 per $1,000 bond, between the end of August and last Monday. The increase in prices since late August had reduced the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds to slightly less than 11 1/2 percent Monday from about 12 1/2 percent.

headline: BIG STAKE IN CROWN IS SOUGHT
abstract: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation, a large paper and forest products concern, last night said it had been notified by Sir James Goldsmith, the British industrialist, that an investment company he heads intends to buy enough stock to give it 15 to 25 percent of Crown's outstanding shares.    The bid would make Mr. Goldsmith's company, General Oriental Investments Ltd., by far the largest stockholder of the San Francisco based concern, and a threat to the company's current management.   In a statement, Crown said that Sir James's letter of intent, received yesterday afternoon, was ''unilateral,'' ''unsolicited'' and not in the best interests of the company.    Called a Surprise    A spokesman for Crown, Delos Knight, said Sir James's plan came as a surprise.

headline: Chileans Admit Mixup In Deporting Reporter
abstract: The military Government has acknowledged deporting the wrong correspondent for what it called an erroneous story, and it has allowed him to return.   The departure on Monday of another United Press International reporter, Daniel Drosdoff, and the return on Tuesday of the deported correspondent, Anthony Boadle, followed a week of negotiations between the news agency and the Chilean authorities.

headline: MUBARAK CONFERS WITH WEINBERGER
abstract: Senior Egyptian and United States officials disagreed today about whether a breakthrough was imminent in efforts to bring about the wihdrawal of Israeli forces from southern Lebanon.     The disagreement emerged after Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger held a 90-minute meeting with President Hosni Mubarak here.    Osama el-Baz, President Mubarak's senior foreign policy adviser, said that ''significant progress'' had been made in the last few days in American-sponsored efforts to reach an agreement between Israel, Syria and Lebanon on the withdrawal of Israeli forces.

headline: Stakes Disclosed By Boesky Group
abstract: Ivan Boesky, a New York investor, and a group of companies he controls told the Securities and Exchange Commission they had purchased a stake in Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. and raised their stake in ARA Services Inc. Mr. Boesky said the group had bought 1,153,400 common shares, or 9 percent of D.L.J., at prices ranging from $28.50 to $29.64 a share. The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States has made a tender offer of $30 each for D.L.J.'s shares.

headline: Aetna Names New Chairman
abstract: Aetna Life and Casualty today elected James T. Lynn chairman and chief executive officer, succeeding John H. Filer, who announced his retirement.

headline: Your Money ; Medigap Policy Costs, Benefits
abstract: On Jan. 1, 1985, the price of participating in the Federal Medicare program will rise because of higher deductibles and co-insurance for hospital insurance and greater premiums for medical insurance. It will become even more important, therefore, to consider a private supplementary policy known as Medigap insurance to help pay for the health care costs not covered by Medicare.   Medicare health insurance is available to individuals who are at least 65 years old and to some disabled people. Part A, financed through part of the Social Security payroll tax, automatically provides hospital benefits without charge to those who are eligible. Part B is optional medical insurance for which participants pay a monthly premium set at 25 percent of the total expected average expenses for this coverage.

headline: Baldwin-United
abstract: Citing the need for urgency, a Federal judge has rejected appeals and given the Baldwin-United Corporation permission to sell 19 Colorado banks to the Ameritrust Corporation of Cleveland. ''Time is of the essence,'' United States District Judge David S. Porter said after denying stays of execution of the sales. Baldwin-United, based in Cincinnati, is selling off assets while trying to reorganize under Federal bankruptcy laws.

headline: THE GRAND OLD MAN OF GERMAN STEEL
abstract: Essen, West Germany    Before Erich Honecker, the East German leader, bowed to pressure from Moscow last month and canceled a long-planned visit to West Germany, one of the places he had expected to visit was the Villa H"ugel, the elegant former home of the Krupps of Essen.   For some people, it must have seemed odd that the leader of the Communist German state, which came into being in part to smash the might of German industrial barons and capitalist cartels, should have wanted to see Villa H"ugel, from which Krupp is now run. After all, the Krupp family's role as gunsmiths to Prussian kings, German kaisers and Adolf Hitler made it, in the eyes of much of the world, an emblem of German expansionism and Prussian power - hardly an encouraging history in the view of East German Commmunism.    But the explanation for the curious link between the Communist and the Krupp empire is Mr. Honecker's old friend, Berthold Beitz, the 71-year old industrialist who has headed the $5.5 billion steel concern for the past 31 years.   A man who saved thousands of Jews and Poles from Nazi extermination camps during World War II, Mr. Beitz is today a national statesman and a Krupp strategist, trying to restructure his company's role in a deeply troubled steel industry, while traveling widely to establish or cement the contacts that have benefited Krupp and German industry during his long tenure.

headline: MANILA TRIBUNAL ACCUSES GENERAL
abstract: Government prosecutors today ordered Gen. Fabian C. Ver, the Chief of Staff of the Philippine armed forces, and 25 other people to answer the accusations of a board of inquiry that they were involved in the 1983 assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr.   The 26, all but one of them members of the military, have also been accused in connection with the death of Rolando Galman, who the military has maintained was a hired gunman who killed Mr. Aquino at the behest of Communists. Mr. Galman was killed by security men at the scene of the assassination.    The action today, which involves the issuance of subpoenas by a three-member Government tribunal, does not necessarily mean that charges will be filed against the 26 people. But it does indicate the Government prosecutors have determined that the accusations are worth investigating.

headline: Cease-Fire Eludes Nicaragua In Talks With Indian Leader
abstract: Nicaragua's Deputy Interior Minister said today that weekend talks with a Miskito Indian leader had failed to win a cease-fire but that the two sides would meet again in Bogota on Jan. 19 and 20.

headline: Pepsico Net Climbs by 24.3%
abstract: Pepsico Inc. reported yesterday that third-quarter earnings, buoyed by rising profitability abroad, jumped 24 percent on a sales gain of 8 percent.   Third-quarter net income was $118.3 million, or $1.24 a share, compared with $95.2 million, or $1 a share, in the comparable 1983 period.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Dec. 6, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 7 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Legal Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: BUSINESSMEN JOIN ANTI-MARCOS MARCH
abstract: About 20,000 people, including many businessmen and other professionals who said they were taking part in a street demonstration for the first time, marched peacefully through Manila today in protest against the Government of Ferdinand E. Marcos.    ''I have stopped trying to convince myself that I have more important things to do,'' said Jaime V. Ongpin, president of a large mining company, in a speech to the demonstrators. ''There is nothing more important than to stand with you today and to be counted.''

headline: Korea Vehicle Exports
abstract: Spurred by big sales in Canada, South Korea's car and truck exports hit a record 36,407 units for the first nine months of the year, up 146 percent from 1983, the Auto Industries Cooperative Association said today.

headline: Chile Banishes 9 Leftists; Rebels Kill a Conscript
abstract: The military Government announced today that it had banished nine leftist leaders into internal exile, and the Governor's office in Concepcion Province reported that left-wing guerrillas had killed a navy conscript.   In Santiago, thousands of Roman Catholics gathered in churches, work places and universities to pray for an end to Chile's political strife.   Archbishop Juan Francisco Fresno of Santiago had called for the ''day of fasting and prayer'' to ease tension after President Augusto Pinochet's declaration on Nov. 6 of a state of siege.

headline: Market Place ; A Caution Flag for Rail Issues
abstract: The nation's railroads have   reaped the benefits of sweeping   legislative and regulatory changes in recent years. Their stocks, in turn, have performed rather handsomely. For the five years ending in 1983, Standard & Poor's railroad index climbed 174 percent, more than double the 72 percent gain in Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.   Within a shorter span, price gains for some of the nation's largest rail systems have been even more impressive. Between the start of the bull market in August 1982 and the close of last year, Burlington Northern's stock tripled in value, and CSX more than doubled.

headline: Computerland Chooses Foote, Cone & Belding
abstract: Foote, Cone & Belding, San Francisco, has picked up the Computerland Corporation account, which could bill as much as $15 million in the United States. And it will also be working for the client in Canada, Britain, France, West Germany, Japan, Australia and China.

headline: 2 Start-Up Agencies Choose Novel Names -
abstract: It looks like the year of the uniquely named ad agencies.    How's Great Water Resources? And, Goldeneye Advertising?    The former has been started in Stockton, N.J., by a pair of veterans in health care advertising.

headline: Falkland Oil Survey
abstract: Firstland Oil and Gas P.L.C. said today that it is undertaking the first petroleum survey of the Falkland Islands since 1922. The company said a program of Landsat satellite imagery and photo-geological interpretation of the area's hydrocarbon potential had proved ''encouraging.'' ;  Singapore Tax Help SINGAPORE, Oct. 19 (AP) - Singapore's Government sent Parliament amendments to the country's tax law today that would provide tax incentives to certain service-oriented companies. Tony Tan, Minister of Trade and Industry, told Parliament the tax incentives would apply to research and consulting concerns such as engineering companies and private laboratories.

headline: Warner-Amex
abstract: The City Council unanimously approved the sale of the city's financially troubled cable television system by Warner-Amex Cable Communications to Tele-Communications Inc. for $93.4 million in cash and notes.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; G.M.A.C. Note Plan
abstract: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation today filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a shelf offering of $2.5 billion in medium-term notes due from nine months to five years from the date of issue.   Agents for the offering are Merrill Lynch Capital Markets and Salomon Brothers Inc.   The company, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, said it would use proceeds from the offering to purchase receivables or to repay debt, including the refunding of up to $2.24 billion in similar notes maturing within one year.

headline: NAKASONE REJECTS SPECIFIC TARGETS FOR U.S. PRODUCTS
abstract: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone said today that he did not want to commit Japan to importing specific amounts of American goods as a way to reduce its huge trade surplus with the United States.    Mr. Nakasone, who is to meet with President Reagan in Los Angeles next Wednesday, also said his country was strengthening its military ability, but was doing so ''for the sake of Japan, not for the sake of other countries.'' The matter of military spending is sometimes linked to the trade issue by Americans who feel that Japan enjoys a ''free ride'' at United States expense.   The Prime Minister made his remarks over a lunch at his official residence with 11 American reporters.

headline: Starts in Housing Off 9.8% in October
abstract: New housing construction fell by 9.8 percent in October, the Commerce Department reported today.   Housing was started at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.52 million units last month, down from 1.68 million units in September and the lowest level of residential building activity since December 1982. The decline marked the third time in the last four months that housing starts have dropped,   However, many analysts saw a glimmer of hope in recent drops in mortgage interest rates.

headline: HEARING SET ON C.I.A. MANUAL
abstract: The Senate Intelligence Committees hopes to hold a hearing next week on the origins of a primer on guerrilla warfare developed by the Central Intelligence Agency for use by the Nicaraguan rebels, a committee aide said tonight.   The aide said the panel has recently obtained a copy of a 1968 Army manual on guerrilla warfare.

headline: French Crack Down On Illegal Aliens
abstract: The French Government announced a new crackdown on illegal immigrants today but stressed the need to fight racism and to help foreign workers already legally settled in France.

headline: CHASE MANHATTAN PROFITS OFF 14.1%
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday reported a 14.1 percent decline in third-quarter net income, to $93 million, from $108.2 million in the comparable period of 1983. The decrease occurred despite a 15.8 percent rise in total average assets, to $91.7 billion, from $79.2 billion.     On a per-share basis, the decline was even steeper. Net income fell 38.4 percent, to $1.70, from $2.76. The difference reflected dilution caused by the issuance of new stock during the period and higher dividend payments on preferred stock.

headline: SHORT-TERM RATES DROP SHARPLY
abstract: Short-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday amid rampant speculation by traders and economists that the Federal Reserve had moved to ease monetary policy and encourage lower interest rates.     The drop in short-term rates, which amounted to more than a quarter of a percentage point for outstanding securities, spilled over into the note and bond markets, where yields fell modestly for Treasury, corporate and tax- exempt issues.   But the largest declines were in the short-term market, where rates on new Treasury bills fell more than half a percentage point from last week's auctions, with the three-month issue averaging 8.82 percent, down from 9.38 percent, and six-month bills at 9.07 percent, down from 9.59 percent.    Dow Advances 12.59    The surging credit market helped buoy the stock market yesterday, after its seesaw performance of last week. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 12.59 points, to 1,229.24. Volume slackened to 84.7 million shares.

headline: BRIEFS ;  Debt
abstract: *  IC Industries said its Pepsi- Cola General Bottlers Inc. subsidiary will redeem its 5 1/2 percent subordinated convertible debentures on Jan. 31.     *  Leader Federal Savings and Loan Association plans to offer $100 million aggregate principal amount of secured notes due Dec. 15, 1991, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Co.

headline: 7 AFGHAN REBELS ARE FLOWN TO U.S. FOR CARE
abstract: Seven seriously injured Afghan rebels, whose wounds could not be treated in Pakistan, were flown to the United States yesterday by an American relief organization for treatment at a hospital in Richmond, Va.   The hospital, Henrico Doctors' Hospital, had volunteered to treat the rebels' neurological and orthopedic injuries without charge after the relief organization, the Americares Foundation of New Canaan, Conn., appealed to American hospitals in August to help treat the Afghan rebels.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Several Detained in Attempt On a Lebanese Militia Leader
abstract: The Israeli-backed militia known as the South Lebanese Army detained several people for questioning today after it thwarted an attempt to assassinate its commander, a spokesman said.   The spokesman told reporters in Israeli-occupied southern Lebanon that unidentified detainees had admitted setting a remote-controlled bomb to kill the commander, Antoine Lahd, as he traveled to his headquarters in Merj'Uyun on Wednesday. The bomb was discovered and defused shortly before he arrived, the spokesman said.

headline: WHERE TO FIND A REFEREE IF CLIENT AND BROKER FIGHT
abstract: HAS anyone urged you to put your money into Alaskan oil properties?  Or how about into discount priced gold - for later delivery, of course? These and dozens of other get-rich-quick schemes are over the telephone.  Most investors suspect they are too good to be true - as they are - but far too many are taken in.   But outright chicanery is not the only pitfall awaiting investors today.  The number of new securities products has exploded in recent years, and the competition to sell them is fierce.  Even the discerning investor, or savvy broker, can become bewildered.  As a result, expensive disputes can arise even in dealing with a well intentioned broker, from a well known brokerage house.  The investor needs to know that when these problems arise, remedies can be pursued, and brokerages have an obligation to resolve problems.   ''Ten years ago, a stockbroker sold stock,'' Jonathan G. Katz, head of the consumer affairs department of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said.  ''Now they are financial advisers.  They handle all sorts of investment products, and some brokers can't keep up with it all.''

headline: FACE BY ARDEN...AND I.B.M.?
abstract: Ten years ago, researchers at   Elizabeth Arden decided that   computers could be used to analyze the human skin, just as they were being used in the nation's space program to analyze planet surfaces. The product of Arden's marriage of computers and cosmetics is Elizabeth, a computer and video system that may radically change the department store cosmetics counter. Without touching a customer, the computer simulates how different makeup will look and provides instructions on how to apply the products.

headline: photo of William Donaldson, Dan Lufkin and Richard Jenrette; DONALDSON, LUFKIN LONG A MAVERICK
abstract: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., a brokerage firm known for its maverick trend-setting ways, said yesterday that it would do what many of its Wall Street rivals have done over the last 10 years: merge.     For Donaldson, Lufkin it is one of the few times in its 25 years that it has followed the pack. After all, this is the firm whose three founders were portrayed on the cover of Business Week before a cracked facade of the New York Stock Exchange with the caption: ''They're changing the rules of Wall Street.''    From its inception, the firm was ready to flout tradition. It was started by three young Harvard Business School alumni - William H. Donaldson, Dan W. Lufkin and Richard H. Jenrette - in 1959 to pioneer research for institutional investors.

headline: RALLY GOES INTO A SECOND DAY
abstract: The powerful bond market rally that began Thursday was sustained yesterday, lifted by signs that the economy is weaker than had been thought and by heavy buying by some large investors who had been on the sidelines.     Long- and short-term interest rates fell, although not as sharply as they had on Thursday. The closely watched rate on Federal funds, reserves banks lend one another, slid to an average 9.80 percent, down from 9.92 percent Thursday, but then rose to 10 1/4 percent late in the session.    The decline in market rates spurred fresh expectations that banks will cut their prime lending rates again. Banks could move as early as next week to 12 percent from the 12 1/2 percent rate that prevailed after this week's cuts, several economists said. Although changes in the prime generally lag behind rather than lead the market, such a decline could act to bolster investor sentiment, according to analysts.

headline: Braniff Fare Cuts
abstract: For the first time since Braniff Inc. resumed flight service in March, American Airlines said it would not match Braniff's reduced fares. When Braniff's current introductory fares for a reduced service schedule expire Tuesday, the airline will set prices below previous levels but slightly above the promotional level - some $4 to $10 less each way than American.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Former HBO Chief Hired by Coca-Cola
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that Frank J. Biondi Jr., who resigned in October as chairman and chief executive officer of Time Inc.'s Home Box Office, had been named executive vice president of Coke's Entertainment Business Sector, a new position.   The division includes Columbia Pictures Industries and Coca-Cola's share of Tri-Star Pictures Inc., a joint venture of Columbia, CBS Inc. and HBO.   Mr. Biondi, 39 years old, said he had no ''predisposed philosophy'' about his new job. ''Coke is committed to being a larger factor in the entertainment industry,'' he said in a telephone interview. ''I guess the first goal will be to determine our game plan, devise a strategy of where we want to go and how.''

headline: SURVIVORS OF GAS HUNT FOR MISSING
abstract: As shops reopened in Bhopal today and survivors returned home, many people were still searching for missing relatives, four days after poison gas escaped from a chemical plant here.   Those overcome by the gas continued to arrive at hospitals on foot, on stretchers and in the arms of relatives. Doctors reported stillbirths and a chilling list of potential aftereffects.   The smoke of cremation fires still hung over the city of 900,000 residents, and relief workers were removing the carcasses of thousands of buffaloes, dogs, birds, horses and chickens from city streets.

headline: PEPSI'S DIET SOFT DRINKS SWITCHED TO NUTRASWEET
abstract: Pepsi-Cola U.S.A., the soft-drink unit of Pepsico Inc., said yesterday that it would stop using saccharin in its diet soft drinks and use only Nutrasweet. The reformulated products, Diet Pepsi, Diet Pepsi Free and Pepsi Light, will be available in some markets this month and be available nationwide by Jan. 1.     Roger A. Enrico, president and chief executive officer of Pepsi, said that the change was made to improve the taste of the company's soft drinks and give Pepsi an advantage against products that contain saccharin, an artificial sweetener whose aftertaste is disagreeable to many consumers.

headline: Aid for the Aged
abstract: To the Editor:    ''What's New in Products for the Aged'' (Dec. 2) was a timely piece, focusing attention on several important issues in this area. However, as manufacturers of ''Aids for Daily Living'' - products utilitzed by the elderly and handicapped - we must voice concern about some of the information in the article.    The availability of simple and inexpensive aids, designed or adapted specifically for the needs of the elderly and disabled, already is widespread and growing in the United States today. They are available through both the traditional medical- surgical supply stores, which your article correctly says that the elderly may want to avoid, as well as through several thousand pharmacies and drug stores.

headline: OILMEN JOIN WITH ECOLOGISTS
abstract: The oil industry has taken many of the environment's riches over the last 50 years, but on this curving wisp of sand in the Gulf of Mexico some of them are being given back.    For more than three years a small group of Texaco employees and students and faculty from Louisiana State University have been planting seedlings and erecting fences to build up sand dunes against the tropical storms that pound shoreward from the gulf at regular intervals.   Timbalier is a barrier island, and in the bay behind its nine-mile bowlike shape are protected a thousand small wooden oil wells that look like matchboxes from the air, and fragile wetlands along the Louisiana shore - breeding grounds for the largest commercial fishery in the United States.   Without the barrier, the wells and wetlands would be destroyed by the storms. Instead, the island, barely a half-mile wide, has absorbed the shock and is gradually being eroded. So with quiet intensity, little publicity and no fanfare, the highly unusual partnership of oil company officials and ecologists has been waging its own war against nature.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Chapman Energy Inc., Dallas, said it had completed the previously announced plan for it and two other companies to buy the assets of Bunker Exploration Co., a closely held oil and gas concern.     *  City Investing Co.  said it had completed the $1.251 billion sale of the assets of its World Color Press, Varco and Rheem Manufacturing units.

headline: THE REAGAN ECONOMIC LEGACY
abstract: Washington   No matter what history ultimately decides about his policies, Ronald Reagan has proved a successful merchant of free- market economics.    With unquestioned faith that less regulation and lower taxes would revive lost prosperity, the President has presided over a strong recovery and a moderation of inflation that would have been scarcely imaginable during his first years in office when the nation sank into a deep recession.    The Reagan legacy after nearly four years in the White House includes an inflation rate tamed almost to the inconsequential levels of the 1960's, a vigorous economic recovery now nearly two years old, rising employment, sharply lower individual and corporate taxes and - less happily - a huge budget deficit that helps keep interest rates up and the dollar overpoweringly strong. Above all, there's a new mood of confidence that leads some to assert that the world's mightiest economy, though battered in spots, stands on the verge of returning to the halcyon days of an earlier postwar era when recoveries were strong and inflation mild and of little concern.    ''There's a change in perception around the world from the United States being a lousy place to do business to it being the best place in the world to invest,'' says James F. Smith, chief economist for the Union Carbide Corporation. ''We are in a good position to replicate the glory years of the 1960's.''

headline: SUPPLIER BECOMES RETAILER
abstract: When a longtime supplier opens its own store in direct competition with the retailers it serves, a rather delicate situation can develop.     Witness Aquascutum of London Inc., the 113-year-old maker of raincoats and coats, which on Oct. 16 opened a new store - its first outside Britain - on Fifth Avenue at 54th Street.    The new store has been doing well, with sales running about 30 percent ahead of expectations, according to Barry Finnegan, head of Aquascutum, North America.   But sentiment among some of Aquascutum's 19 retail accounts in New York remains decidedly mixed.

headline: Deficit Rises $28.5 Billion
abstract: The Government spent $28.5 billion more than it collected in November, making the deficit in the first two months of the 1985 fiscal year 24 percent worse than last year, the Treasury Department said today.   The figures also showed that the cost of paying interest on the national debt, already the third-largest single Government expense, after social programs and the military, jumped 23.6 percent from a year before.

headline: Hong Kong Lawmakers Back Accord on Colony's Future
abstract: Hong Kong's Legislative Council formally endorsed the Chinese-British draft agreement on the colony's future today.   After three days of debate, a motion to endorse the agreement was passed by the 48-member council, the British colony's highest lawmaking body, with two abstentions from appointed nongovernment counselors, called ''unofficials.''   Under the agreement, signed in Peking last month, Britain agreed to hand over Hong Kong to China in 1997.

headline: British Banks Cut Base Rates LONDON, Nov. 6 (AP) -
abstract: Britain's major banks today   cut their base lending rates by   half a percentage point, to 10   percent, making the fourth reduction since August.

headline: PATENTS; CONTAINER FOR HOLDING RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS
abstract: A self-closing container for radioactive materials, patented this week for the Department of Energy, is designed to reduce the dangerous exposure of individuals handling such materials.

headline: Carter, K Mart Are Up; Wal-Mart Gains 37.7%
abstract: Three of the nation's leading retailers yesterday reported earnings gains for the third quarter.     The K Mart Corporation announced a 13.5 percent increase in net income, Carter Hawley Hale Stores a 57.9 percent increase and Wal-Mart Stores a 37.7 percent gain.   ''I think it's likely that when the rest of the retailers report we will see the adverse impact of some slowing of sales in the third quarter and signficant markdown pressure associated with the intense promotional atmosphere industrywide,'' said Jeffrey Feiner, retailing analyst at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith.

headline: Aid for Chinese Textiles
abstract: China's textile industry, providing 15 percent of the nation's output, seeks foreign technical help in spinning, weaving, finishing, dyeing, printing and garment processing, the official English- language China Daily said today.

headline: Prudential Issue Is Eurobond Record
abstract: A subsidiary of the Prudential Insurance Company of America is issuing $1.3 billion of securities in the largest fixed-rate debt financing ever made in the Eurobond market.    Underwriters led by Salomon Brothers are offering $386 million of 11 7/8 percent bonds due in 1992 at par, $546 million of 12 1/8 percent bonds due in 1995 at par, and $365 million face amount of zero coupon bonds due in 1999 at a price of 20.80 to yield 11.85 percent.

headline: THREE SETS OF ARMS TALKS
abstract: Following are the three areas of arms control that the United States and the Soviet Union are expected to hold preliminary discussions about during talks in Geneva in January 1985.  Medium-Range Missile Talks - The United States and the Soviet Union began talks in Geneva in November 1981 on limiting medium-range missiles in Europe.

headline: 1982 REPORT CITED SAFETY PROBLEMS AT PLANT IN INDIA
abstract: The Union Carbide Corporation said today that a 1982 inspection of its pesticide plant in Bhopal, India, revealed serious equipment and safety problems but that its Indian subsidiary had rectified most of the problems by June.    One of the problems remaining in June, the company said, involved the adequacy of a valve on a tank used in producing highly toxic gas. The valve was designed to relieve ''a runaway reaction.''   The gas, methyl isocyanate, was released from the plant a week ago, spreading across the city and killing more than 2,000 people, according to official counts, and as many as 2,500, according to other reports.

headline: INCREASE IN U.S.-CHINA TRADE IS SEEN
abstract: An organization of more than 400 American companies forecast today that trade with China would increase by $1 billion next year from the $6 billion estimated for 1984.    The National Council for U.S.-China Trade also said that American companies formed 31 ventures with Chinese partners in the first nine months of 1984 - more than the total of the preceding four years.    ''We're quite upbeat,'' Christopher H. Phillips, president of the council, commented in an interview.    ''Having lived with this thing for the last 12 years, we've learned to avoid extremes of euphoria and pessimism,'' he said. ''But because of what the Chinese themselves are doing, the situation now is more encouraging than it's ever been.''

headline: ITALIANS TO PRESS FOR CITIBANK TRIAL
abstract: A Milan prosecutor plans a new effort to bring to trial 11 present and former Citibank employees on charges that they violated Italian foreign exchange regulations, despite some speculation that he would give up the four-year- old case.    A senior official in the prosecutors's office insisted that the case would come to trial, but he complained that it was ''fragile,'' primarily because key United States documents relating to the case were unavailable to prosecutors. Under agreements between Rome and Washington, the Italians do not have the right to the documents because a case against the bank was not brought to court in the United States.   The official said that the Milan prosecutor, Luca Mucci, who earned a reputation for toughness investigating several financial scandals, including the spectacular 1982 collapse of Banco Ambrosiano, based his case on documents siezed from Citibank by Italian Treasury investigators. In its investigation, however, the Treasury concluded in 1982 that there had been no wrongdoing.

headline: U.S. Judge Dismisses China Bondholder Suit
abstract: A Federal judge in Alabama yesterday dismissed the claims of bondholders who held millions of dollars worth of old bearer bonds issued by the Qing dynasty that ruled China in 1911.     Three years ago, after the Chinese Government failed to appear in court to enter a defense against the claims, District Judge U.W. Clemon entered a $41.3 million default judgment for the bondholders. The Chinese, claiming sovereign immunity, felt this was unfair, and the case became what the State Department termed a ''major irritant'' in American-Chinese relations.

headline: PURCHASERS, CITING ORDERS, SEE SLOWED ECONOMY
abstract: The economy continued to be sluggish in November, with the rate of new orders virtually at a standstill, the National Association of Purchasing Management concluded yesterday in its most recent report. It is likely that December will similarly see little or no growth, the association said.   According to the trade group's monthly survey of purchasing managers at 250 of the nation's largest corporations, the slowdown was reflected in all leading indicators: Production levels edged lower, employment declined and inventory buildup halted.

headline: The Latest Saturday Review
abstract: The Saturday Review has   risen from its own ashes once   again, a shadow of its former self as far as circulation goes, but completely redesigned, restaffed and rejuvenated.    And having been published in New York, San Francisco and St. Louis during its 60-year lifespan under about 10 different owners, it is now trying Washington as its home base. That may reflect the political involvement of the new management:      - Paul Dietrich, publisher and editor in chief, has been president of the National Center for Legislative Research, a conservative organization with three publications. He is also the husband of Laura Jordan Dietrich, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights.

headline: Datapoint Holding
abstract: An investment group led by Asher Edelman, a New York investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it holds 10.8 percent of the Datapoint Corporation.

headline: Ex-IBH Head Found Guilty
abstract: Horst-Dieter Esch, the former chairman of IBH Holding A.G., the giant construction machine group whose collapse last year was at the heart of a bank crisis here, was convicted of fraud today by a court in Hanau, in Bavaria, and sentenced to three and a half years in jail.   Judge Josef Worms released the 41- year old Mr. Esch, who was jailed last March pending the proceedings, on $325,000 bail and ordered him to surrender his passport and report weekly to local police.

headline: UNEASY PERIOD FOR ANDERSEN
abstract: Every major accounting firm sporadically gets hit with multimillion-dollar lawsuits arising from audits they conducted on companies that later wound up in financial trouble. Shareholders and creditors of the company, hoping to recoup their losses, often hone in on the auditors, who tend to be the deepest pockets left in the financial rubble.    Sometimes the suits seem to come in waves, as they did in the 1970's for Peat Marwick, at the time the largest of the Big Eight accounting firms.    These days, Arthur Andersen & Company, which is now the nation's largest accounting firm, has been thrust into the uncomfortable spotlight, embroiled in a rash of multimillion-dollar lawsuits seemingly at once.    ''As long as it's sporadic, it's part of life, but I think Arthur Andersen has crossed that threshold,'' said Richard L. Kaplan, a former Arthur Andersen accountant and now a University of Illinois law professor and member of the Illinois Committee on Accountancy, a state regulatory body.

headline: Computerizing the Senate
abstract: Later than many institutions - but sooner, at least, than the House of Representatives - the Senate is being computerized. Three companies - Honeywell, Data General and Prime - have won the right to compete for the right to automate the senators' offices.

headline: Midland-Guardian And PSFS in Pact
abstract: The PSFS Credit Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the manufactured housing financing operations from the Midland-Guardian Company and the Midland-Guardian Investment Company for about $70 million.

headline: Philippine Court Orders Release of Journalist
abstract: The Philippine Supreme Court ordered the release today of a detained journalist who reported last year that the assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. was a high-level military conspiracy. A civilian panel said last month that it had found evidence of such a conpiracy.

headline: POISON'S DISPOSAL IS HALF COMPLETED
abstract: More than half the deadly methyl isocyanate remaining at the Union Carbide plant here has been neutralized by Indian engineers and scientists since the plant began operating again Monday and a top official said the detoxification process should be completed by Wednesday.     Arjun Singh, the Chief Minister of Madhya Pradesh, told reporters that the operation, in which the toxic chemical is being converted into a pesticide, should take only two more days if production continued without incident.   Mr. Singh said the storage tanks at the plant, one of which leaked on Dec. 3, killing at least 2,000 people, were ''normal and safe.''

headline: Cowles Denies Merger Rumors
abstract: Cowles Media Inc. said yesterday that it was ''not for sale'' and disassociated itself from rumors that directors were seeking a merger with the Des Moines Register and Tribune Company, which owns 14.3 percent of Cowles Media.   The Minneapolis-based newspaper publisher was responding to an announcement Monday by Kingsley H. Murphy Jr. that his family intended to sell its 17 percent stake. Mr. Murphy also said that some directors were seeking a merger with the Register company.

headline: Fedders Cleared by S.E.C. Staff
abstract: A House subcommittee has dropped an inquiry into the involvement of John M. Fedders, the Securities and Exchange Commission's enforcement head, in a corporate bribery scheme, after an S.E.C. staff report cleared him of any violations of federal securities laws.    But the report also said that the Southland Corporation, the Dallas- based owner of 7-Eleven stores, paid at least $1.84 million in dairy ''kickbacks'' between 1975 and 1977. It also said the company received $636,013 in ''questionably illegal'' payments, or ''rebates'' from diary suppliers during the same period.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Character Licensing, an ITT subsidiary, to Kolker & Gill to promote Raggedy Ann & Andy.

headline: A Heavy Slate of Corporate Issues
abstract: The only Treasury financings scheduled this week are today's regular auctions of new bills due in three and six months. Late Friday, outstanding three-month bills were bid at 8.33 percent, while the six-month issue was 8.60 percent.    In the tax-exempt market, the supply of new corporate-backed securities remains heavy, with many new issues offered in a form where investors may redeem their bonds periodically before maturity. Besides the familiar offerings of pollution control revenue bonds, there will be flurry of financings for resource recovery projects this week.

headline: Addenda
abstract: * The New York Times is increasing its advertising rates an average of 8.5 percent as of Jan. 1.     * Popular Science magazine is increasing its advertising rates 9 percent with the February issue.     * DYR has opened an office in Bangkok, Thailand.

headline: Preliminary Equimark Results
abstract: The Equimark Corporation of Pittsburgh, parent company of Equibank, said that preliminary unaudited calculations show the company was ''slightly profitable'' in the third quarter.

headline: LOSS TAKES INDUSTRY BY SURPRISE
abstract: At 7 A.M. yesterday, Barry F. Sullivan, chairman of the First National Bank of Chicago, and Richard L. Thomas, president, began calling the senior officers of about 20 of the nation's largest banks.     It was the standard ritual when a large bank is about to announce a major loss. ''We did it out of courtesy to let them know,'' Mr. Thomas said in a phone interview.

headline: FOR RENT: AN ENTIRE WORKFORCE
abstract: ON a Friday afternoon last year, Walter Klein, president of the Klein Meat Company, passed out pink slips to each of his 15 employees. He saved the last one for himself.   The following Monday the staff of the Fort Worth meat company returned to work as usual. But over the weekend they had become employees of Omnistaff Inc., a Dallas leasing firm, and the Klein Meat Company was leasing their services from Omnistaff.

headline: Holly Sugar Stake
abstract: Brookehill Equities Inc. and Moran, Moore, Grossman & Derose told the Securities and Exchange Commission that they had a combined total of 142,434, or 12.8 percent, of the shares outstanding of the Holly Sugar Corporation.

headline: 300 Reported Arrested In Peruvian Strike
abstract: The police clashed with demonstrators in several cities today, injuring dozens and arresting more than 300 during a nationwide strike called to protest the Government's economic policies, union leaders said.   News reports said the 24-hour strike, held despite a state of emergency declared Wednesday by the Government of President Fernando Belaunde Terry, was only partly successful.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE: CORPORATE NEWSMAKERS OF 1984 ; The Basses Stay Busy
abstract: The four Bass Brothers of Fort Worth have had a busy year, getting involved with the likes of Texaco, Walt Disney Productions, Conrail and Alexander's Inc.   In March, they agreed to sell their 9.7 percent stake in Texaco Inc. back to the company for $1.28 billion in a buyout intended to rid Texaco of any possible meddling from the Basses.

headline: Continental Illinois Strategy
abstract: -The assets of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company will shrink by $1.7 billion and the staff will be cut by nearly 2,000 employees next year, according to a strategic plan being circulated among Continental executives, it was learned today.   Continental officials refused to comment on the existence of the report entitled ''1984-85 Internal Tactical Plan'' that was dated Sept. 21, 1984.

headline: Asian Bankers To the Editor:
abstract: While I agree with the basic argument in William J. Holstein's article, ('Don't Underestimate the Asians Again,'' Sept. 30), it contains a number of factual and conceptual errors.   First, the Overseas Chinese Banking Corporation is one of the largest banks in Singapore. It is not a Taiwanese institution. Second, the Bank of Korea is Korea's central bank. It operates a very limited network of representative offices abroad, which is expanding only gradually. Other Korean banks are, however, opening foreign branches and offices at a brisk pace. Third, Daewoo, one of Korea's largest industrial groups, does not include a bank. There is no such thing as the Daewoo Bank.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Clorox Co., Oakland, Calif., said it plans a $24 million expansion of its Pleasanton, Calif., technical center.

headline: Profit Climbs At Goodrich
abstract: The B. F. Goodrich Company said today that its third-quarter profit jumped 80.9 percent from a year earlier, mainly because of a change in the tax law. Without this one-time gain, net income was up 23 percent on a 3 percent increase in sales.

headline: Dow and Celanese Post Gains; Monsanto and Carbide Off
abstract: Four of the nation's leading chemical producers yesterday announced mixed earnings results in the third quarter of 1984.    The Dow Chemical Company, helped substantially by two extraordinary items, reported a 76 percent increase in net income, the Union Carbide Corporation disclosed a slight decline, the Monsanto Company a 32.2 percent drop and the Celanese Corporation a 15.2 percent gain,    ''The strong dollar continues to have a negative impact on Dow, Carbide and Monsanto,'' said William R. Young, senior vice president and chief chemical industry analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ''First there was the translation of foreign earnings back to dollars, secondly there were reduced exports from the United States and thirdly there were increased imports into the U.S., which had to be met with reduced selling prices.''   Mr. Young said that there had also been a sharp economic deceleration in the third quarter, which aggravated overcapacity in certain commodity chemical lines and resulted in lower volumes and selling prices. ''Celanese is a special case because they have been buying back a lot of shares, which has been a big help and they are also in the midst of a big cost-cutting program,'' he said.

headline: G.M. Raises Car Prices By an Average of $296
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it would increase the base price of most of its passenger cars by 2 percent effective Jan. 2.     In addition, the nation's largest auto company said that prices for most optional V-6 and V-8 engines would go up by $75 and $100, respectively, and that other optional equipment would rise by an average of 2.5 percent.   The combined effect of the increases would mean that the price of the average G.M. passenger car would rise by 2.3 percent, or $296.

headline: WEINBERGER SAYS SOVIET ADDED SS-20'S
abstract: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said here today that the Soviet Union had substantially increased the number of SS-20 nuclear missiles trained on Western Europe. He declined to say how many more of the medium-range missiles had been deployed.    Mr. Weinberger made the comment in remarks to reporters at the close of the first day of a meeting of North Atlantic Treaty Organization defense ministers on nuclear strategy.    Mr. Weinberger said that United States intelligence had pinpointed the number of additional SS-20's deployed by the Russians this year, but that the figure would not be made public now. The most recent estimate by NATO, released last December, was 378 SS-20's.

headline: Scovil Stock Soars on Bid Scovil Inc.'s stock soared
abstract: $5.625, to $37.50, on the New   York Stock Exchange yesterday in response to an offer by   the Belzberg family of Canada   to buy the company. It was the   most actively traded issue,   with a volume of nearly 4.2 million.

headline: IZOD'S FALL FROM VOGUE A DRAG ON GENERAL MILLS
abstract: Yesterday General Mills was bitten by its little alligator.     The big Minneapolis company, home of such powerhouse brands as Wheaties, Cheerios, Gold Medal and Bisquick, disclosed that troubles at its Izod Ltd. unit, which makes the shirt with the alligator emblem, would cost it 45 cents to 55 cents a share this fiscal year.    Despite repeated management changes and futile efforts to reposition the brand, the chairman of General Mills, H. Brewster Atwater, said yesterday that Izod Ltd. would lose money in its 1985 fiscal year, which ends next May.    Off 50% From Peak    ''Izod's current-year sales prospects are down nearly 50 percent from the peak,'' he said. The peak came in 1982, when sales of the Izod knit shirts exceeded $400 million, according to analysts' estimates. - the fashion group that includes Izod contributes just 10 percent of the company's operating earnings - but the decline in Izod's performance has affected the entire company. General Mills stock has dropped at each new mention of Izod's troubles. Yesterday, the shares fell $2.25, to $51.625, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: AP REPORTER CHARGED ANEW
abstract: A reporter for The Associated Press said today that the Government had charged him with sedition, a crime that carries a maximum sentence of life in prison and a fine.   The reporter, Brahma Chellaney, is in the Punjab, where he has been questioned on earlier charges related to a report he filed in June on the Indian Army attack on the Sikh temple in Amritsar.

headline: SLUMS ALONGSIDE FACTORIES INEVITABLE, EXPERTS SAY
abstract: The industrial accidents in the third world in recent months, highlighted by the poison gas tragedy in India last week, point to the difficulty in isolating industrial plants from densely populated residential areas in third world countries, according to some development specialists.     ''No one lives at the other end of a smokestack unless he has no choice,'' said Anthony A. Churchill, an urban development specialist with the World Bank in Washington.    ''It's partly a failure of transportation systems,'' he said. ''Most people in the third world can't afford transportation. So they live next door to the factory. Move the factory and they will go with it.''

headline: Area Costs Up 0.6 Percent in Month
abstract: Increases in housing and school-tuition charges led prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area to a moderate increase in September, the regional Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.     The Consumer Price Index for the metropolitan area rose six-tenths of 1 percent last month, according to Jesse Benjamin, the bureau's assistant regional commissioner.    The seasonally adjusted index figure rose three-tenths of 1 percent, which matched the barometer's lowest rate of growth this year and was significantly below the gain of nine- tenths of 1 percent recorded in September 1983.

headline: DAUGHTER OF STALIN, BESET BY REPORTERS, HINTS AT PUBLIC TALK
abstract: Svetlana Alliluyeva, who returned from the West to Moscow last month, hinted today that she might hold a news conference. But she said it was not up to her to decide when that might be.    Miss Alliluyeva, who is Stalin's daughter, has avoided Western reporters since her return. She was surprised by two television camera crews outside the Sovetskaya Hotel, where she has been staying with her 13-year-old American-born daughter, Olga Peters.

headline: U.S. AIR FORCE TO TAKE FAMINE AID TO SUDAN
abstract: President Reagan has ordered a United States Air Force transport plane to fly famine relief supplies to Ethiopian refugees streaming into the Sudan, the director of the Agency for International Development said today.   The President's order is in response to a plea by a United Nations team working in the Sudan, the A.I.D. director, M. Peter McPherson, said. It marks the first time an American military aircraft has been used in the famine relief efforts.

headline: WORLD'S STOCK EXCHANGES EXPERIENCE A DIFFICULT YEAR
abstract: It has been a difficult year for most major stock exchanges, with Toronto and New York losing ground and minor gains on other exchanges offset by inflation and depreciation of their currencies.   There was improvement in the fourth quarter, with most exchanges registering some rise in average share prices. Because of the pickup, and the prospect of renewed economic growth in the United States and other industrialized countries, many analysts expect 1985 to be better.    The World Index, a measure of stock prices around the globe, rose about 1 percent over the year, according to David M. Gong, a vice president of the T. Rowe Price International Fund in Baltimore. Most of that gain came in the last three months, Mr. Gong said. The index is compiled by the Geneva-based Capital International Perspective.

headline: Iranian Oil Cited in Price Downturn
abstract: International oil traders and others will be keeping an anxious eye on the spot crude market Monday to assess Friday's collapse of oil prices in Europe.   The key type of crude in the spot market, North Sea Brent, traded Friday at $27 a barrel for January delivery, a drop of 75 cents from last Monday and the lowest since the market plummeted under the weight of surplus supplies in late July.   Traders said increased volumes of Iranian crude competing with other Persian Gulf grades in the Japanese market are mainly responsible for the latest drop in prices. They said Friday's downturn came in reaction to news that Iran was tempting customers with price discounts rumored to be up to $2.50 a barrel for light crude.

headline: Dow Up 2.65, Ending Losing Streak
abstract: The stock market advanced slightly yesterday, ending a four-session losing streak. Trading was slower.   The Dow Jones industrial average ended up 2.65 points, at 1,185.07, after losing almost 38 points in the preceding four sessions.

headline: AN INVASION RESULT: GRENADA SCHOOL PROSPERS
abstract: The American medical school here, the evacuation of which President Reagan said was one of his main reasons for sending troops to Grenada, has been riding a groundswell of publicity and enjoying new prosperity since the invasion more than 13 months ago.   Applications from potential students and faculty members have jumped, and officials of the school, the St. George's University School of Medicine, say they plan to expand into other fields of education and hope for millions of dollars in United States aid.   The once-obscure school, which has a largely American student body of about 750, about half from the metropolitan New York area, has been repeatedly mentioned in news reports about Grenada. In one of the most memorable photographs of the invasion period, an evacuated student was shown kissing the ground in the United States.

headline: People
abstract: *  William J. Case and  Edwin Mammen have been named senior vice presidents, group management supervisors, at W. B. Doner & Company, Detroit.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: People     *  Albert J. Martin named senior vice president of marketing and sales for Allnet Communication Services, Chicago.     *  Neil Vander Dussen, already president of the Sony Consumer Products Company, named to the additional post of president of the new Sony U.S. Marketing Group of which  Koichi Tsunoda is executive vice president.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Coast Thrift Unit Sets $235 Million Offering
abstract: The Far West Savings and Loan Association, of Newport Beach, Calif., said yesterday that it would offer about $235 million in collateralized mortgage obligations. Lead underwriters are Merrill Lynch Capital Markets and Drexel Burnham Lambert.

headline: WOMAN SAYS ISRAEL CAUSED HER DISMISSAL
abstract: The New York City Commission on Human Rights has determined there is probable cause to believe that a 45- year-old Israeli-born American citizen was dismissed from her job at the World Zionist Organization as a result of a policy of discouraging the emigration of Israelis to other countries.   The complaint, which was filed March 6, 1981, and is now being tried before the commission, has only recently come to light in a series of hearings after an investigation by the commission.   In the complaint, according to the finding of probable cause issued in February 1983, Ruth Kramer charges that she and at least four other employees were dismissed to ''effectuate a policy originating from Israel directing agencies, businesses and organizations affiliated with Israel to fire and not hire Israelis that have left Israel for an indefinite period or who have emigrated to other countries.''

headline: STALIN DAUGHTER BACK IN SOVIET AFTER 17 YEARS
abstract: Seventeen years after defecting to the West, Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's only surviving child, has returned to the Soviet Union and had her citizenship restored.   A brief announcement in the Government newspaper Izvestia and on Tass, the official press agency, and read on the evening television news said the Soviet authorities ''considered and complied with a request made by S. I. Alliluyeva, who has returned to Moscow, for restoring her to the citizenship of the U.S.S.R. as well as for granting Soviet citizenship to Alliluyeva's daughter Olga.''    Once Called Soviet a Prison      Miss Alliluyeva, who had been living in Cambridge, England, for the last two years under the name Lana Peters, could not be immediately located in Moscow, and there was no ready explanation for her decision to return to the country she once called a prison.    (Miss Alliluyeva's return left some Western acquaintances stunned and puzzled, but others who have been close to her expressed no surprise, saying she had been unhappy in the West in recent years. Page 4.)

headline: Foot, Cone Opens Direct Marketing Unit
abstract: Among Foote, Cone & Belding's domestic offices, only New York did not have a direct marketing facility.

headline: Payment To Venezuela
abstract: The World Bank has agreed to repay five years ahead of schedule about $252 million of a loan that the bank obtained from Venezuela in 1974, a World Bank spokesman said.   The spokesman, who requested that his name not be used, said on Friday that the loan agreement permitted early repayment.

headline: SUSPICION OF BUSINESS SEEN IN BONN
abstract: Gerhard Stoltenberg, the Finance Minister of West Germany, says that the investigations into business contributions to political parties are arousing ''emotions of anticapitalism'' and a ''general suspiciousness toward business'' in West Germany.    Many businessmen are also dismayed, Mr. Stoltenberg acknowledged in a wide-ranging interview last week, because of the swirl of allegations surrounding the Bonn Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl.   But the Finance Minister added: ''I do not see that this endangers the willingness of businesses to invest, nor does it endanger the Government's ability to act.''   Political Figures Toppled    The investigations have centered on allegations of bribery, tax evasion and influence peddling involving the giant Flick industrial group. The company has denied any wrongdoing, but several major political figures have already been toppled in the scandal, including the Economics Minister, Otto Lambsdorff, who resigned last June.

headline: THE PRIME RATE DROPS AGAIN
abstract: For the second time in as many weeks, major banks cut their prime lending rates. But this time, they were able to agree on a level. Morgan Guaranty led the way by cutting its by rate half a point, to 12 percent. Bankers Trust, which had settled at a 12 1/4 percent rate in the last round of cuts, joined in at the 12 percent level, and other big banks quickly followed.   The latest cuts were further indications of an easing of monetary policy by the Federal Reserve in light of what appears to be controlled growth in the economy. Even though investor optimism is high, analysts cautioned that interest rates remained volatile. In the Treasury market, where bond rates last week hit a low for the year, the short-term bellwether Federal funds rate was trading well under 10 percent. Bond prices fell late in the week after a report of a $1.8 billion rise in the money supply.

headline: Levy, Flaxman Adds Playboy Assignment
abstract: Levy, Flaxman & Associates has been named to do the trade advertising for Playboy magazine.

headline: Unitary Tax Is Repealed TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 7
abstract: (Reuters) - The Florida   Legislature today repealed the   state's unitary tax, which assessed multinational corporations with operations in Florida   on a portion of their worldwide   income. Critics of the tax, enacted in   1983 to benefit Florida's education system, claimed it hurt the   state's economy by discouraging investment by multinational companies.

headline: Milwaukee Firm Fined
abstract: Blunt, Ellis & Loewi Inc., a Milwaukee-based securities firm owned by the Kemper Corporation, has been fined $10,000 by the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Church Bans Sermons By Fiery Polish Priest
abstract: Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the leader of the Roman Catholic Church in Poland, today banned a priest from preaching in Warsaw churches, ruling that his anti- Communist sermons were ''alien to the spirit of the Gospel.''   Cardinal Glemp's ruling against the Rev. Stanislaw Malkowski was the first in the country to be made because of political views.   Father Malkowski has, in the pulpit, spoken of Moscow, saying ''this city that is dedicated to the devil should be razed,'' has called for the ''slaying of the Red Dragon'' and has called the Government spokesman, Jerzy Urban, a ''clown and a court jester.''

headline: Soviet Grain-Buying
abstract: Although the Russians are not admitting it publicly, all signs point to one of their worst grain harvests since 1975. Their misfortune is increasing American hopes of selling them more corn and wheat.

headline: FREED HOSTAGES AT ODDS ON ROLE IRANIANS PLAYED
abstract: The two surviving American hostages of the hijacked Kuwaiti airliner arrived here tonight with other freed passengers and said they had seen no evidence of Iranian complicity in their six-day ordeal.    But in Karachi, two Pakistani passengers said on their arrival there that Iranian authorities had supplied the hijackers with weapons, ropes and handcuffs, according to reports reaching here.   Later in the day, the Americans left Kuwait in a United States Air Force plane for West Germany, where the bodies of the two slain Americans were taken today from Teheran.   Comments From the Ayatollah      In Teheran, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini issued an evaluation of the whole affair, saying, ''In the hostage affair, which was condemned by all Iranian officials and which was solved in a satisfactory way, they still say Iran had a hand in it.

headline: O.E.C.D. OPTIMISTIC ON ECONOMY IN '85
abstract: The economies of the world's industrialized countries are doing better than expected and overall prospects are the best in a decade, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today.   That positive message, weighted down by caveats and concern about the persistent sluggishness of the European economies, forms the core of the new edition of the O.E.C.D.'s Economic Outlook, the highly regarded semiannual review of the economic scene in the non-Communist industrial world in general and in the 24 nations that are members of the organization.   ''The overall prospects for output and inflation now appear as good as, or better than, at any time since the watershed year of 1973,'' the report said.

headline: Accident in India Among the Worst
abstract: The poison gas leak today in the central Indian city of Bhopal is one of the worst industrial accidents on record.   In 1921, a chemical plant explosion at Oppau, Germany, killed 561 people.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
abstract: Pacific Gas and Electric In $400 Million Offering    In the largest non-telephone utility offering ever, the Pacific Gas and Electric Company yesterday offered a total of $400 million worth of first and refunding mortgage bonds.   The offering was made in two parts, the first a $150 million, 33-year issue that matures on Nov. 1, 2017.

headline: Norway Gas Find
abstract: Statoil, the state-owned oil company, has discovered large quantities of natural gas on a field at the edge of the Barents Sea near the northernmost tip of Norway, a Statoil spokesman said today. The field, unofficially called Snow White, could hold as much as 400 billion cubic meters, almost double the size of Norway's current biggest gas field. Statoil also found oil traces in Snow White but not enough to make it commercially viable.

headline: GOVERNING PARTY POSTS BIG VICTORY IN INDIAN ELECTION
abstract: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and his Congress Party scored a smashing triumph and appeared headed today for one of the biggest election victories since India became independent.    Returns from nationwide parliamentary elections indicated that Mr. Gandhi, who succeeded his mother, Indira, after she was assassinated on Oct. 31, had achieved a popular victory whose dimensions have not been seen since the Nehru era of the 1950's and early 1960's.    With results officially declared in 388 of the 508 parliamentary constituencies where voting took place this week, the Congress Party had won 310 seats in the lower house of Parliament. Mr. Gandhi's party was winning seats at a rate that would give him four-fifths of the seats in the house that is to convene next month.   Projection by Government TV    The official Government television network's computers projected that Congress would win 50 percent of the popular vote, the first time any party has done so. The Congress Party's computers projected that it would win at least 50 percent of popular vote, and perhaps as much as 60 percent, and would end up with 400 to 410 seats in Parliament.

headline: MARCOS WILL RUN IN 87, HE REPORTS
abstract: The Government announced today that President Ferdinand E. Marcos, who has ruled the Philippines for 19 years, would run for re-election in 1987.     The announcement, the first unqualified statement of Mr. Marcos's intentions, came from the Government press office, which quoted remarks the 67-year-old President made Monday to Cabinet members and regional leaders of his ruling party in a private session.    President Marcos was quoted as having told the group: ''I want you to know that I am running in 1987. I am healthy enough to run in 1987.''

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  Automatic Data Processing Inc.  has named John M. Gaven president of the Financial Services division.     *  Berry Industries, Santa Fe Springs, Calif., has named Dennis L. Breeden president, chief executive and chief financial officer, following the resignation of Jack H. Dekruif as chairman, president and chief executive.

headline: U.S. EXPORT AID FOR CENTRAL AMERICA
abstract: The Government announced a $300 million loan guarantee program today for Central American countries regarded as friendly. The program would help the countries finance imports from the United States and stabilize their economies.    The guarantee package represents a political decision by the Administration to underwrite with money appropriated by Congress private credits for exports to Central America.

headline: More Stores in Japan Get Poisoned-Candy Threat
abstract: Extortionists have sent letters to some stores in Osaka threatening to poison more candy if the stores do not stop selling Morinaga & Company sweets, officials said today.   The group declared in the letters that it had already poisoned 50 boxes of candy and planned to lace another 100 with sodium cyanide, because ''we are out to destroy Morinaga,'' said Takahiro Shinkai, a spokesman for Izumiya, a supermarket chain based in the western Japan city.

headline: Ex-Jewel Leader's Jobs Study
abstract: Donald S. Perkins makes it clear he is not looking for ink for himself.   The former chairman of Jewel Companies, who retired in 1980 after 27 years with the grocery and drug retailer, wants to talk instead about job losses in the Chicago metropolitan area and a commitment in the business community to do something about it.   For the last 18 months, Mr. Perkins was chairman of a Commercial Club of Chicago committee studying the job problem.

headline: PORTLAND GENERAL ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: VIRGINIA BEACH FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SONESTA INTERNATIONAL HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CASTLE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: American Savings Bank has appointed Robert D. George vice president, construction lending.     *  Bowery Savings Bank has appointed Thomas F. Nealon 3d senior vice president, general counsel and compliance officer.

headline: TRUST CHIEF FAVORS MORE JOINT VENTURES
abstract: The Administration's antitrust chief today encouraged businesses to form joint ventures as an alternative to mergers that eliminate competitors.   ''A joint venture between two parties may pass antitrust muster, where their merger would not,'' said Assistant Attorney General J. Paul McGrath, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division.   In a major policy speech, Mr. McGrath said:   ''An awareness of the role these valuable business arrangements play in creating efficiencies and bringing forth new products and technologies is replacing an attitude of suspicion born of ignorance. Joint ventures will play a vital role in promoting the growth and international competitiveness of the American economy.''

headline: RECESSION IS CALLED UNLIKELY
abstract: Despite languid production and declines in the index of leading economic indicators, few economists are expecting a recession soon.   Pessimists, who believe that the sharp slowdown in economic growth this fall meant that the nation was headed for another recession, had their position bolstered by Thursday's announcement that the index of leading indicators declined in October.   This index, intended to forecast the course of the nation's economy, has slid 2.8 percent since it peaked in May. Such a dip often portends a recession.

headline: Japan Plans Easier Trade GENEVA, Dec. 2 (Reuters)
abstract: Japan plans to announce a   trade liberalization package   before the end of this month   and many of the tariff cuts   being studied will interest   developing countries, a senior   Japanese official said today. Yoshiji Nogami, director of   the Foreign Ministry's Economic Affairs Bureau, said the   package was intended to ease   the way for a special meeting   of the General Agreement on   Tariffs and Trade next year to   prepare for a new round of   global trade talks, possibly in   1986.

headline: JAPAN GAIN REPORTED IN COMPUTERS
abstract: The first stage of Japan's ambitious 10-year project to build a new kind of computer enabled the Japanese to catch up with research in other countries but resulted in no scientific breakthroughs, according to interviews with more than a dozen American and European scientists here.   Three years ago, Japan's announcement of a project to create the so-called fifth-generation computers by the 1990's jolted the computer community. Japanese scientists aimed to develop computers that would have elementary reasoning abilities, be far easier to use and perform more sophisticated tasks than any machine available today.   Such computers could, for instance, accept spoken commands, translate languages, diagnose diseases and serve financial advisers. Furthermore, they could be used by the average person without the series of complicated commands now required.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Sports Executive Leaving ABC Post
abstract: John T. Lazarus, vice president of sports marketing and sales at the ABC Television Network, has resigned his position, the network said yesterday.    Mr. Lazarus, who is 43 years old, was responsible for virtually all sports programming and the sales of all the network's advertising time during those events, including the Summer Olympics.    According to Advertising Age, an industry publication, Mr. Lazarus's resignation was prompted by an internal investigation at ABC concerning the network's dealings with Robert Landau Associates, a New York advertising agency that supplied food and other provisions for ABC's Summer Olympics operations in Los Angeles. Mr. Lazarus and Mr. Landau are longtime friends, the publication reported. Landau Associates filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code on Sept. 14.

headline: 117 Said to Die of Starvation In Remote Area of Indonesia
abstract: At least 117 people have died of starvation in a remote district of West Irian province, the daily newspaper Sinar Harapan said today.

headline: Florida Cypress Dissident Move
abstract: Florida Cypress Gardens Inc. said Harold Lieberman, a Winter Haven, Fla., investor, had said that he would seek liquidation of the company and urge shareholder support for the action if the company's chairman, Dick Pope, does not sell his 43.9 percent interest to an investor group.

headline: 12 Cubans Quit Embassy Of Peru After 4 Years
abstract: Twelve of the 15 Cuban refugees who have spent four years in the Peruvian Embassy have left to resume normal lives here, diplomats said today.

headline: DISASTER DOMINATES A PARLEY
abstract: The deaths of more than 2,000 people from gas poisoning in the Indian city of Bhopal dominated the unofficial agenda at the International Organization of Consumers Unions conference here this week.   The organization, representing consumer, environmental and community action groups from 40 nations, met to discuss a range of topics of interest to developing as well as industrial nations, including food additives, hazardous drugs and exploitive advertising.

headline: Philips ECG Shift
abstract: Philips ECG Inc. said it will move its color picture tube manufacturing operation from Seneca Falls to Ottawa, Ohio, next year.

headline: Thorn Official to Head Joint Effort With HBO
abstract: Until three years ago, Nicholas P. Santrizos had spent his career in advertising and marketing. But then he left Madison Avenue to become president of Thorn EMI Video Inc., a video cassette distributor owned by Thorn EMI of Britain. And he is still selling.

headline: A LOW PROFILE FOR FED IN CAMPAIGN THIS TIME
abstract: The Federal Reserve, like a baseball umpire, is always happiest when nobody notices it. And in the current Presidential campaign, being waged partly over the level of interest rates, remarkably little is being said about the Fed. The nation's central bank has succeeded in avoiding criticism from either side.    This is in stark contrast to 1980, when the Federal Reserve drew loud complaints from President Carter after it raised its discount rate by a full point in late September. Indeed, not only were no questions asked about the Fed in Sunday night's debate, but neither President Reagan nor Walter F. Mondale even referred - favorably or unfavorably - to its performance.

headline: Heileman's Offer For Pabst Blocked
abstract: A United States District Court judge today temporarily blocked the G. Heileman Brewing Company's proposed $70 million purchase of the Pabst Brewing Company on the ground that the acquisition might violate Federal antitrust laws.   Judge John Feikens set a March 25 trial date in the case following his issuance of a temporary restraining order.

headline: Times Mirror Unit
abstract: The Times Mirror Company said it had agreed in principle to sell its Art and Graphic Products group to Brentwood Associates, a Los Angeles- based investment firm, for about $55 million.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Nov. 23, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: KIRKPATRICK'S VIEW OF U.N. JOB: LEADER OF A REVOLT
abstract: When she came to the United Nations in 1981, says Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, who has announced that she intends to resign as chief American delegate at the end of the year, ''the radical nations within the third world had achieved a dominant voice in the debates and decisions.''     In the face of constant attacks, there was ''silence and retreat by the West,'' she recalls, adding, ''The general understanding was that the third world was letting off steam and that it was 'bad taste' to notice it.''    As activities at the United Nations wound down this week, Dr. Kirkpatrick took an hour to reflect on her efforts during her four years as chief American delegate to ''restore the United States to a position of influence within the United Nations.''    In an interview at her office at the United States Mission, she took credit for reducing the level of polemics by third world countries against the United States and Israel. ''Israel has not been expelled, and the obsessive anti-Israeli attacks have significantly diminished,'' she said. ''Most countries no longer attack the United States at all in debates.''

headline: Washington Watch; Farm Exports Threatened
