abstract: WASHINGTON    A SENATE-PASSED trade bill, hitting, among other things, imports of Chinese shirts and European wine, could bring substantial retaliation against American farm exports.    ''Half of what China exports to us would be priced out of the market,'' an Administration trade official said, adding, ''The Chinese certainly will not take that lying down.''    Sir Roy Denman, the Common Market's ambassador to Washington, reacting to the wine provision that California grape growers got into the bill, commented:    ''We're not in the business of waving large swords. But the facts have to be faced. There is an old French proverb that says, 'A dangerous animal when attacked defends itself.' ''

headline: World Press Review Is Planning Changes
abstract: Marilyn K. Ginsberg, publisher since October of World Press Review, announced a number of changes last week.

headline: Baxter Labs Plans $116 Million Charge
abstract: Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc. said yesterday that it would report an estimated $116 million special after- tax charge against fourth-quarter earnings as part of a series of ''strategic measures'' to reposition the company. The charge will reflect the cost of the consolidation of the company's worldwide operations and the revaluation of assets.     The company, based in Deerfield, Ill., said that changes in the funding and delivery of health care, plus cost containment programs and lower levels of hospital activity, had reduced demand for certain kinds of medical care products.

headline: Aquascutum of London Gets New U.S. Head
abstract: E.T. Dick Catlett was appointed president of the American operations of Aquascutum of London, the 113- year-old maker of raincoats and coats.   Mr. Catlett, who is 53 years old, had most recently been president of the menswear division of Izod Ltd. He succeeds Barry Finnegan, who is returning to England to pursue other opportunities, Aquascutum said.

headline: MIDTOWN LURES SHOE COMPANIES
abstract: JUST as Seventh Avenue is known   as the hub of the garment industry, 34th street was for decades the center of activity for American footwear manufacturers.   The Empire State Building, at Fifth Avenue and 34th Street, and the Marbridge Building, 1328 Broadway at Herald Square, were major lessors to the footwear industry. Shoe companies still occupy space in these buildings as well as in other commercial structures in the neighborhood. Increasingly, however, an area of midtown from Fifth Avenue to the Avenue of the Americas between 56th Street and 58th Streets is emerging as a shoe industry showroom and office district.

headline: REPORT CITES CAMPAIGN OF TERROR SINCE SOVIET ENTERED AFGHANISTAN
abstract: A report on human rights violations in Afghanistan asserts that a campaign of organized terror, torture, imprisonment and execution has been under way since Soviet troops entered the country five years ago.     The 212-page report, ''Tears, Blood and Cries,'' was prepared by Helsinki Watch, a group founded to promote compliance with the human rights provisions of the 1975 Helsinki accords. The group describes the document, to be issued today, as ''the first comprehensive account of human rights violations in Afghanistan'' since the Soviet intervention in December 1979.

headline: Marathon Cuts Price For Crude
abstract: The Marathon Oil Company yesterday cut the price it will pay for the most common kind of American crude oil by 50 cents, to $28.50 a barrel. Although several small oil companies already post that price for West Texas Intermediate, most majors, like Marathon, have remained at $29 for the key grade.   ''You're beginning to break through the $29 line,'' said Joel D. Fischer, a petroleum analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert in New York. ''What's happening is the market is soft, and crude is following the market down.''

headline: REPORTED SALVADOR KILLING RAISES CONCERN OVER RIGHT'S INTENTIONS
abstract: The reported murder of the 14-year-old son of a leading Salvadoran trade unionist has raised concern among United States diplomats here that right-wing extremists may attempt to obstruct negotiations between the Government and leftist rebels.   As a mark of its concern, the United States Embassy here issued an unusually strong protest Tuesday night against the apparent death squad slaying. The reported killing came almost one year after a campaign of intimidation against trade union officials that included several similar murders.

headline: 43 Are Reported Killed In Argentine Crash
abstract: Forty-three people were reported killed and 22 injured today when a train slammed into a commuter bus at a suburban railroad crossing.    Wooden traffic barriers at the crossing in San Justo, 10 miles west of Buenos Aires, are designed to be operated manually by a railroad employee.    Railway officials said that the barriers at the crossing were down before the collision and that the bus driver went around them. Bus company officials said the barriers were raised,

headline: ITT Up $2.75; Trading Heavy
abstract: Shares of the ITT Corporation rose sharply yesterday, apparently fueled by conjecture that the giant conglomerate might liquidate or sell additional assets. The stock jumped $2.75, to $30.25, on a turnover of more than three million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: NEW FIGHT FOR TEXTRON BIDDER
abstract: For the third time in five years, Harvey Kapnick, the chairman of the Chicago Pacific Corporation, finds himself in the middle of an all-out fight.    The last two times, the energetic, 59-year-old executive was engaged in intramural battles, and he ended up getting ousted. In this battle, however, he is leading Chicago Pacific in an effort to acquire Textron Inc., a larger and much better known company, for almost $1.6 billion.    Mr. Kapnick, who became Chicago Pacific's chairman last June when it emerged from the reorganization of the bankrupt Rock Island Railroad, said he hoped that his company's $43- a-share offer would go forward ''in a united and cooperative way.'' But Textron, the industrial conglomerate based in Providence, R.I., is not being very cooperative - its management called the offer ''completely unacceptable'' - and Mr. Kapnick has discovered that he has another fight on his hands.

headline: U.S. MOVE PRAISED BY CONSERVATIVES
abstract: The announcement that the United States would withdraw from Unesco on Jan. 1 drew a favorable reaction from conservative and middle-of-the road American groups, but was criticized by United Nations officials and the Soviet Union.     Some of those who supported the move said they looked forward to the time when the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization adopts changes that would bring the United States back.   The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, said at a news conference yesterday, ''My position is very clear. If it is considered that something is wrong with our organziations, please stay inside and fight from inside. The United States is, of course, a sovereign nation which can take its own decisions, but I consider that the channels of the United Nations should always be used; they are the best way of providing any impartial solution to international problems.''

headline: NICARAGUAN, AT U.N., ASSERTS U.S. PLANS TO INVADE HIS NATION SOON
abstract: Nicaragua's head of state told the United Nations General Assembly today that the United States had plans to mount a military offensive against his nation on Oct. 15 to prevent elections set for Nov. 4. United States officials called the assertion nonsense.    ''The mercenary forces of the C.I.A. and the Pentagon are already concentrated in the areas bordering Nicaragua, in Honduras and Costa Rica,'' the Nicaraguan leader, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, said. In addition, he charged, United States forces were ready to be used for bombings, troop landings and direct incursions into Nicaragua.

headline: MANDATE RENEWED FOR CYPRUS FORCE
abstract: The Security Council extended the mandate of the United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus for six months today, acting against a backdrop of apparently successful negotiations between Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot leaders.    But a brief and pointed skirmish between representatives of the two groups after the 15-to-0 vote by the Council indicated that a tentative agreement their leaders reached after three months of talks may be fragile.   The new mandate for the 2,300-member force, which has sought for 20 years to keep the island's Greek and Turkish communities from fighting, will now expire next June 15. The troops are along a 113-mile-long border that cuts Cyprus in half.

headline: Congress Is Widening C.I.A. Primer Inquiry
abstract: Congressional sources said today that inquiries into the Central Intelligence Agency's primer for Nicaraguan rebels were being broadened to examine what was known about any actual assassinations carried out by the American-backed insurgents.   Initial reviews by the staffs of the House and Senate intelligence committees focused on who authorized production of the manual, which advocates ''selective use of violence'' to ''neutralize'' Nicaraguan officials.

headline: PAKISTAN OFFERS TO IMPROVE INDIA TIES
abstract: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq today offered India's new Prime Minister, Rajiv Gandhi, his full support in efforts to create an atmosphere of trust between their two countries.    Senior officials here said Mr. Zia was making conciliatory gestures in the hope that India's new leader, who took office shortly after the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, would be less hostile towards Pakistan than his mother.    Mr. Zia's statement was his second message to the new Prime Minister since Mrs. Gandhi was slain. The Pakistani leader, one of the first foreign leaders to respond after the assassination, telephoned Mr. Gandhi Wednesday night with condolences,    President Zia told Mr. Gandhi that he wished to assure him of ''the full support of the Government of Pakistan in efforts to build a relationship of trust and confidence between our two countries and create a secure and tranquil environment in our region.''

headline: EAST GERMANS SEEK REFUGE IN A PRAGUE EMBASSY
abstract: At least 43 East Germans have taken refuge in the West German Embassy in Czechoslovakia demanding to be released to West Germany, West German newspapers reported today.    Peter Boenisch, a spokesman for the West German Government, would not contradict the reports, which said that at least 43 East Germans entered the Prague embassy in recent weeks, refusing to leave and seeking permission to emigrate to West Germany. Mr. Boenisch said at a news conference that ''a statement would make the resolution of humanitarian questions more difficult.''    The incident is the latest in a series of such attempts by East Germans to flee through West German missions in Prague and East Berlin. They have been a source of embarrassment to Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government, which is seeking warm relations with East Berlin.

headline: Systems and Computer Inquiry
abstract: The Systems and Computer Technology Corporation said its results would be reduced because of questions raised about its license fee income by its independent auditors, Ernst & Whinney. The company said it expected that the revenues and income recognized in each of the first three fiscal quarters and in the year ended Sept. 30 would be affected.

headline: Stocks End Mixed After Late Gains
abstract: The stock market made a dramatic turnabout late yesterday in accelerated trading, finishing mixed after being down sharply earlier.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was off more than 12 points at 2 P.M., ended the day up 2.10 points, to 1,177.23, a swing of more than 14 points.   In the overall market, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored those that rose by 785 to 711. Earlier, losers were ahead of gainers by more than a 2-to-1 ratio.

headline: Hoover Plant
abstract: The Hoover Company said it plans to build an assembly plant in Juarez, Mexico, as part of efforts to compete more effectively with foreign manufacturers.

headline: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
abstract: Chevron Corporation $342,000,000  -32.8  Clark Equipment 4,700,000 x34.3  Commodore International 27,700,000  x14.0  Kaneb Services (51,400 ,000)  -  Kerr-McGee Corporation 21,600,000  -45.6  MidCon Corporation 16,500,000  x52.8  Ramada Inns8,800,000  -60.0  Texaco Inc.235,000,000  -29.0  Warner-Lambert 56,600, 000  x12.3  Wendy's International 18,800,000  x 16.8   See accompanying notes for special items.   (Loss)

headline: Chase Sets Expansion In London
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Corporation plans to purchase two large brokerage partnerships here - Simon & Coates and Laurie, Milbank & Company - as soon as the London Stock Exchange changes its regulations to allow it.    In its announcement today, Chase said the deals would help it become in general ''a global investment bank'' and in particular a primary dealer in British Government securities, known as ''gilts.'' The New York- based bank holding company is making an undisclosed interim investment that will give it a limited interest in the two London firms, pending completion of the acquisitions.

headline: WHAT'S NEW ON THE CIGARETTE FRONT; CUTTING CONSUMPTION BY RAISING TAXES
abstract: Both the cigarette industry and the anti-smoking lobby - along with academic and government observers - agree that higher taxes could reduce cigarette consumption.  Prof. Kenneth E. Warner, chairman of the department of public health planning and administration at the University of Michigan School of Public Health, summed up the findings in the title of his paper in The Journal of Public Health Policy: ''Cigarette Taxation: Doing Good by Doing Well.''   ''A 10 percent price increase would lead to a 4 percent decrease in consumption,'' Professor Warner said. ''The implications are that if the tax were to be increased, you would observe an increase in revenues because the increase in the price would not be outweighed by the decrease in consumption. Further, you would expect to see a decrease in consumption that ultimately would reduce deaths as well.''

headline: PATENTS ; A Method to Assemble Details of Family Trees
abstract: Complete charts of family relationships can be compiled with a method and apparatus patented this week by Louise A. Daly, a Seattle architect.

headline: PALESTINIAN STUDENTS RIOT IN BETHLEHEM
abstract: Palestinian students at Bethlehem University, angered by a rocket attack Sunday on an Arab bus in Jerusalem, stoned Israeli vehicles in the West Bank today. Israeli soldiers dispersed the students with tear gas and warning shots.    Arab sources said one protester was shot in the leg.

headline: WALL STREET'S LAST GENTLEMAN:Richard Jenrette; FORGING THE EQUITABLE CONNECTION
abstract: BACK in Raleigh, N.C., young Richard H. Jenrette got his first taste of business by selling insurance. He wasn't too successful - his customers kept saying they'd rather buy stocks. That lesson sent Mr. Jenrette to Wall Street, where he was one of three upstarts who founded Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., a trend-setting firm that rattled the industry with its maverick ways. Now, with the purchase of Donaldson Lufkin by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, Mr. Jenrette's career has come full circle and he's back in insurance again.     This time, he's operating on a much higher plane. Next January, Mr. Jenrette will resign as chief executive of Donaldson Lufkin and become vice chairman of Equitable. He plans to keep a foot in each world - he'll stay on as chairman of Donaldson Lufkin and spend the bulk of his time on the firm's matters. But, he also will work closely with Equitable, figuring out ways to draw the two financial companies together. ''No way am I going to be retiring,'' said Mr. Jenrette, 55, in his office furnished with early 19th century English antiques. ''I'll still be working full time.''

headline: ON A SAINT'S DAY IN MILAN, THE CITY HITS FULL STRIDE
abstract: St. Ambrose stared down from the ornate gold, red and blue tapestry, a whip in one hand and a bishop's staff in the other, as Milan's Mayor handed out honors to citizens of a city whose residents sometimes call themselves ''Ambrosiani.''    He had a stern look, this version of St. Ambrose, a glance that came naturally to the man who put the Christian Church in Milan on its feet in the fourth century. By some accounts, he was a kind of saintly organization man.   ''The Roman Empire was in the process of collapsing, the church was the one strong institution, and St. Ambrose set about getting organized,'' said Prof. Giorgio Rumi, a scholar at the University of Milan.

headline: Tariff Group Meets Today
abstract: The governing body for world trade opens an annual meeting of its 90 contracting parties Monday under a cloud of despondency over its failure to stem growing protectionism.   Bitter disputes among the United States, the European Economic Community and Japan, and between developed and developing nations, have prevented adherence to commitments made at a 1982 ministerial conference of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.    Delegates regard the outcome of this week's meeting, expected to last two or three days, as exceptionally important both for the future of the general agreement and the global trading system.

headline: 2 LEADERS IN P.L.O. GO TO MOSCOW TO DISCUSS WAYS TO AVOID A SPLIT
abstract: Two Marxist guerrilla leaders in the Palestine Liberation Organization, which has scheduled a crucial meeting Thursday, have gone to Moscow for talks at the invitation of Soviet officials.    Dr. George Habash, the secretary general of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, flew to the Soviet Union from Damascus, Syria, today. He was preceded there on Monday by Nayef Hawatmeh, the head of the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine.

headline: Gas Prices Up 2 Cents
abstract: Average gasoline prices in the United States are up 2 cents a gallon since Labor Day, while heating oil prices are down by the same amount in a reversal of the usual seasonal patterns, an analyst, Dan Lundberg, said today.   Gasoline prices still are rising unseasonably because of continuing strong demand for gasoline by motorists coupled with ''disappointing'' third- quarter refinery profits, Mr. Lundberg said.

headline: Japan Passes Phone Laws
abstract: Japan's Parliament gave final approval today to three bills that the Government said would give foreign companies a greater chance to enter the Japanese telecommunications market.   United States officials, however, have criticized the package as not doing enough to open up the market to foreign companies.

headline: Gromyko to Visit Next Year, A British Official Announces
abstract: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union will visit Britain next year, Sir Geoffrey Howe, the Foreign Secretary, said today.

headline: Nekoosa's President Named to 2 Top Posts
abstract: William R. Laidig, president of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation, was named chairman and chief executive yesterday, succeeding Robert Hellendale..    Mr. Laidig is taking over earlier than expected from Mr. Hellendale because, Mr. Hellendale said, he did not want to ''clog the wheels'' of the paper and pulp company.   ''I expected to retire Dec. 1,'' said Mr. Hellendale, who is 66. ''But I saw everybody was doing what they were supposed to be doing. They don't need me to clog the wheels.'' So at Mr. Hellendale's request, the directors yesterday promoted Mr. Laidig, who has been president since January, to the top position.

headline: NO MORE TALKS, THATCHER TELLS MINERS
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told the striking National Union of Mineworkers today that her Government was unwilling to engage in any further substantive negotiations.    Mrs. Thatcher, speaking in the House of Commons this afternoon on the eve of another round of talks between the union and the state-owned National Coal Board, said the settlement last week with the mine deputies' union, ''reached after long negotiation, must be the basis of an agreement with the N.U.M., and that agreement must be substantially unchanged'' from the terms of the earlier accord.   Her tough new stance appeared to reduce the already slight chance that the bargaining session Wednesday, which will take place under the supervision of the independent Abritration, Conciliation and Advisory Service, will bring an end to the eight-month-old walkout by almost three-quarters of the miners in Britain's deep-pit coal mines.   Urges Offer 'Be the Last'      Mrs. Thatcher made her statement in reply to a question from a Conservative backbencher, Peter Hordern, who urged her to declare publicly that the offer to the union on Wednesday ''should be the last.'' The settlement with the mine deputies' union last week involved some Government concessions on the terms under which uneconomic mines would be closed, but the terms have not been made public

headline: 81.5% of Bond Issues Backed
abstract: Voters across the nation approved about $3.78 billion of new bond issues, or 81.5 percent of the $4.64 billion of bond proposals on the ballots in Tuesday's election, according to The Bond Buyer, a daily newspaper specializing in tax-exempt bonds.    In nine states with slightly more than $3 billion of new bond proposals, voters approved about $2.65 billion of new financings.

headline: Court Upholds 'Insider' Case
abstract: The key legal theory that the Securities and Exchange Commission has relied on in a string of recent trading cases was upheld today by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.    Under the ''misappropriations theory'' upheld by the court, a trader violates Federal securities laws by trading on the basis of information ''misappropriated'' - or stolen - from his or her employer, whether it is the employer's own securities that are being bought or sold.

headline: PATENT ; Processes to Make Cocoa Butter
abstract: Processes for the preparation of fats and oils from microorganisms, such as yeast cells, to produce cocoa butter were patented this week for CPC International Inc., Englewood Cliffs, N.J. Dennis L. Gierhart assigned patents 4,485,172 and 4,485,173 to the company.

headline: IN NICARAGUA, THE LUCKY BUY PLENTY WITH DOLLARS
abstract: People are complaining these days about shortages of soap, toilet paper, meat, aspirin and tires. But for lucky Managua residents with dollars, there's no need to suffer the inconvenience.   The Government, in conjunction with a Panamanian company, has opened a well-stocked ''dollar store.'' Now diplomats, foreign journalists and Government officials have access to imported foods, liquors, appliances and clothes - items that have long since disappeared from the regular markets here. Visitors with experience in the Soviet Union and Cuba say the store is similar to hard-currency stores in those countries.

headline: THE APPEAL OF UNIVERSAL ACCOUNTS
abstract: LIKE many investors, John M. is lazy when it comes to finaancial affairs.  To be sure, he owns some stocks, has money in a bank or two and keeps a sum in a money market mutual fund that is managed by Merrill Lynch & Company. but it takes a lot to stir him to move his business from one financial institution to another, even when he knows he is being charged too much.  He is likely to procrastinate for months before closing an account and opening a new one to get a higher return.   But lately John M.'s financial life has become more organized by vertue of his asset management, or universal, account.  It is a single account that pulls together much of his financial business: stocks, bonds, checking and money market accounts, even his holdings of precious metals and a Visa debit card.  Most asset management accounts are offered by securities firms, but recently some banks have introduced their versions - the Bank of America through Charles Schwab, its discount-brokerage subsidary, citiband through its Focus Account and Chicago's Northern Trust Company through its Benchmark Account, among others.  But by far the most popular, with 1.2 million subscribers, is the Cash Management Account, which was something new under the sun when Merrill Lynch brought it out in 1977 and promoted it heavily during the high interest rate years that followed.

headline: FUNDS FOR HOUSING AND MEDICAID SEEN AS TARGET OF CUTS
abstract: President Reagan tentatively decided today on cuts in the projected budgets for Medicaid and Federal housing assistance, according to Administration officials.    He is also leaning toward a freeze on Federal salaries and on cost- of-living adjustments for all pension programs but Social Security, they said.   The officials described the President as going through a slow and difficult process of making his initial, tentative decisions on a new budget while attempting to hold overall spending next year at this year's level. The White House staff has used the term freeze, but officials said the term was more useful politically than technically.

headline: A FRAGRANCE EXPLOSION
abstract: Until recently, no self-respecting perfumer would have thought of introducing a new fragrance that cost as much as $150 an ounce by putting a whiff of it in a magazine ad. The upper end of the $2 billion women's fragrance market has always depended on sales at department stores where women could test the fragrance personally.   But a new technique may change the way fragrances are marketed. Called microencapsulation, the technique is better known as the ''fragrance burst sampler'' or ''scent strip.'' For the fragrance industry, which has been performing poorly in recent years, this new advertising and marketing tool may give fragrance marketers new opportunities to promote their products.

headline: Productivity At a Standstill
abstract: United States business productivity showed no improvement in the third quarter, returning to a standstill level not seen since early 1982, the Labor Department said today.   Between July 1 and Sept. 30, the output of workers showed no change or gain relative to the number of hours they worked in the nonfarm business sector, according to the report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

headline: Money Fund Assets Climb
abstract: The assets of the nation's money market mutual funds continued to climb in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. In the largest weekly jump since July 1982, assets increased $4.02 billion, to $189.24 billion, the institute said.

headline: Woodhead Stake
abstract: Nortek Inc. told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its holdings in Daniel Woodhead Inc. common stock to 365,118 shares, or 9.9 percent of the total outstanding. Nortek said its most recent purchases included 36,874 shares bought between Aug. 14 and Oct. 9. The shares of Woodhead, a maker of electrical specialty products, closed at $18 bid today in over-the-counter trading.

headline: PRESIDENT RESIGNING AT HOUGHTON MIFFLIN
abstract: Richard W. Young, the 58-year-old president of the Houghton Mifflin Company for the last two years, said yesterday that he would resign at the end of this year.    Harold T. Miller, 61, the publishing company's chairman and chief executive officer, will take over as president, a job he held from 1973 until Mr. Young took the job in 1982. Mr. Miller has held the top two posts at Houghton Mifflin since 1979.    Mr. Young came to Houghton Mifflin from the Polaroid Corporation in 1981 to work on plans to integrate electronic publishing into the company's overall publishing efforts.

headline: GANDHI TELLS CHEERING CROWD BULLETS WILL NOT SHAKE INDIA
abstract: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, speaking on the 67th anniversary of his mother's birth, told tens of thousands of his cheering countrymen here today that India in recent days had shown the world that ''this country is not shaken by bullets'' and that it ''cannot break so easily.''   He also drew a huge roar of approval when he said that ''we have to take revenge'' for his mother's killing. He quickly added that this should not be accomplished ''through anger or hatred,'' but ''only by all of us putting our full might to keep the country strong and united.'' This, he said, ''is how we should remember Indira Gandhi.''

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Nov. 30, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: A Prairie Option Granted to Placer
abstract: The Prairie Producing Company said its chairman, George F. Watford, had granted an option to Placer Development Ltd. to buy his 2,280,690 shares, or about 28.3 percent of the company's shares outstanding, for $17.68 a share, or about $40.3 million. The option expires on Dec. 3 and may not be exercised unless Placer, which is based in Vancouver, British Columbia, enters into a definitive agreement or takes steps to acquire all of Prairie's shares at not less than $17.68 each, Prairie said.

headline: China Harvest Forecast
abstract: China predicted today that its grain and cotton harvest for 1984 would reach record levels as a result of its contract farming system. A harvest of 400 million tons of grain this year, up 3.3 percent from 387.2 million last year, was forecast, along with a cotton crop of 5.5 million tons, up 20 percent from 4.5 Million tons.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Austin, Nichols & Co. and Saatchi & Saatchi Compton have terminated their relationship.

headline: Economic Scene; Arms Outlays And the Upturn
abstract: WASHINGTONA rapid increase in the military budget, which has been one of the most controversial elements of President Reagan's term, has produced a steady rise in Pentagon spending that could help buoy the economy next year if, as predicted, other sectors slow down.   But several economists contend that the pace of military spending is likely to slow and that the Reagan military buildup will not contribute as much to economic growth in the future as it has so far.   Some economists also contend that large Federal deficits, which were in part caused by the boom in military spending, will keep interest rates high next year, leading to slower growth in many industries and offsetting some of the impetus from arms outlays.    ''Defense spending was one element that pushed us toward a boom,'' said Roger Brinner of Data Resources Inc., an economic consulting firm. ''But now defense is part of the problem that is pushing us'' toward a slower expansion.

headline: INDIANS WORRY OVER POISON CHEMICAL STILL IN PLANT
abstract: Officials in this central Indian city expressed mounting concern today over how to deal with 30 metric tons of poisonous chemical stored at the American- owned insecticide plant, the site of the disastrous gas leak last week.    The remaining methyl isocyanate must be disposed of somehow, officials said, but they added that all possible courses of action carried the possible risk of a further escape of the chemical.   This ''delicate task'' is causing ''anxiety to all of us,'' said Arjun Singh, the Chief Minister of Madhya Pradesh, of which Bhopal is the capital.    One official reported that the process of neutralizing the remaining chemical had already begun, but Mr. Singh denied this and said that a method of disposal had not yet been decided on.   Some Said to Flee City      There was a report that some citizens were fleeing the city in panic at the prospect of what might happen during the disposal, but this could not be confirmed, and there were no signs of mass departures from the city.

headline: ABU DHABI WARNS THAT IT MAY CUT OIL PRICE
abstract: The oil minister of the United Arab Emirates says Abu Dhabi may act on its own to reduce oil prices to cope with intense competition for oil sales in a period of sluggish demand.   The warning was believed to be the first public statement about the possibility of a price cut from a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries since OPEC lowered official prices in March 1983.

headline: SALOMON HEADS UNDERWRITING LIST
abstract: In the race to bring stock and debt issues to market, Salomon Brothers Inc. continued its domination in the third quarter. It acted as lead underwriter for 51 offerings of securities totaling $6.56 billion.    For the nine-month period that ended with the market's close on Friday, Salomon also came out on top, with 115 issues totaling $16.23 billion, according to figures from IDD Information Services Inc.

headline: Hunger Strike in Pakistan
abstract: Thirty-one Pakistanis are staging a hunger strike to protest their trial on charges of plotting to overthrow the military Government, a lawyers' group said today. Six of the hunger strikers, who are part of a group of 54 people being tried by a secret military court in Lahore, are in serious condition, the Political Prisoners Release and Relief Committee said.

headline: OFFICE BUILDERS IN JERSEY ARE LOCATING NEAR MALLS
abstract: Lunch in the burgeoning corporate suburbs can often bring the workday's most trying moments. Isolated in sprawling new buildings surrounded by nothing but grass, trees and highways, many office workers search for something to do during their lunch periods. To travel to eat, and perhaps shop, means traffic and a hunt for a parking space. Staying in the building means the cafeteria again.    Anything that breaks the boredom, especially in speculative office buildings where such corporate headquarters amenities as fitness centers are usually not available, can give developers a distinct advantage in marketing their buildings.

headline: Sikh Temple Complex Now Free of All Troops
abstract: The Indian Government, trying to patch up relations with the Sikhs, returned control of the entire Golden Temple complex to the sect's leaders today and withdrew the last of its security forces, the United News of India reported.   An unspecified number of police and paramilitary troops left three buildings in the 72-acre temple complex in Amritsar, in the northern state of Punjab, during the afternoon, the independent news agency said.

headline: Mini-Programming With A Female Focus
abstract: For several years the Consumer Products division of the American Cyanamid Company fought the advertising clutter problem on television by supplying mini-programming of its own to run with its ads.   ''Mini'' is the important word here, since the snippets are only 30 or 60 seconds long.

headline: TIMES TO PRINT IN OHIO
abstract: The New York Times, citing continued growth, said it would begin printing its national edition next spring at the plant of The Lorain (Ohio) Journal.

headline: LTV Plant Sale
abstract: The Justice Department said it had approved the sale of the LTV Corporation's stainless steel cold-rolled sheet plant in Massillon, Ohio, to CDH Metals Inc., a steel service-center company based in Wynnewood, Pa. Robert Newstat is the chief executive and main owner of CDH. LTV is divesting itself of the plant under an agreement with the Justice Department allowing the company to acquire the Republic Steel Corporation.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Oct. 30, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 3 P.M.   Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Legal Committee - 3 P.M.   Meeting on U.N. Financing System for Science and Technology - 10 A.M.

headline: EVALUATING TELECOM'S OUTLOOK
abstract: Potential investors will learn on Friday how much it will cost to buy a piece of British Telecom P.L.C., the world's fourth-largest telephone enterprise. The British Government will sell control of the company to the private sector on Nov. 28.   Most analysts here are predicting a price in the range of 125 pence to 130 pence a share, which works out at current exchange rates to between $15.90 and $16.50 for Telecom's American Depository Receipts - each equivalent to 10 British shares - when they are traded in New York. Whether the world's largest-ever share sale will be a good deal at that price depends on what one makes of Telecom's assets and its prospects.   The approach analysts are taking follows the old adage that, ''if it looks like a duck, walks like a duck, and quacks like a duck, then it must be a duck.'' Telecom is not comparable to any company traded on London's stock exchange, but it bears a passing resemblance to America's telephone utilities, and analysts are using that as a starting point.

headline: IRAQI MISSILE HITS TANKER IN GULF
abstract: An Iraqi warplane fired an Exocet missile into a Bahamian-registered oil tanker in the Persian Gulf today, Iraq and marine salvage executives said. No casualties were reported.   An Iraqi military spokesman in Baghdad announced the raid on the 163,155-ton tanker, the B. T. Investor, which occurred south of the Iranian oil terminal at Kharg Island.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA WARNS U.S. ON ASYLUM
abstract: South Africa's Foreign Minister warned the United States and other Western governments today not to respond favorably to a request for sanctuary by six political fugitives.    The six, who have been in the British mission in Durban since Sept. 13, appealed for help and sanctuary Sunday in a telex message to American, French, Dutch and West German diplomats in South Africa. They cited unhappiness with the British response to their plight.    Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said in a statement made public here that ''any indication that such a request could receive favorable consideration would boil down to encouragement being given to a criminal act being committed in South Africa.''

headline: SYRIAN PRESIDENT'S BROTHER ENDS HIS 'EXILE'
abstract: The Syrian President's younger brother, whose departure from this country five months ago, apparently into exile, prompted speculation about a major struggle for power, returned here today from Paris.    The arrival of Rifaat al-Assad early this morning set off noisy street demonstrations by his supporters.    Only two months ago, Rifaat had been publicly declared persona non grata by this country's Minister of Defense, a move that suggested he had lost the support of his brother, President Hafez al-Assad. A spokesman for Rifaat said the Syrian Defense Minister had been misquoted.

headline: FLICK STRONG DESPITE SCANDAL
abstract: Politically, the affairs of Karl Friedrich Flick, the 56- year-old industrialist who is at the center of a political storm sweeping West Germany, could not be worse. But business - at least to the extent that it can be separated from politics - could hardly be better.    Mr. Flick's name has figured prominently in a widening bribery, tax-evasion and influence-peddling scandal that has toppled major political figures, including former Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff.   At the same time, buoyed by the German economic recovery, the Flick industrial group has been prospering. In 1983, the giant holding company's profits more than tripled from the previous year, to $97.3 million. In the first five months of this year, sales at Flick's three biggest subsidiaries rose between 3 percent and 19 percent. Awash in liquidity, Flick has announced plans for a huge investment program, totaling $106 million in 1984 alone.

headline: FULL CHAD PULLOUT REPORTED NEAR
abstract: France and Libya are about to complete withdrawal of the troops they sent to Chad to back opposing factions in the 20-year-old civil war, Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson said today.    ''The withdrawal will be completed in the coming hours,'' Mr. Cheysson said in an address to Parliament. ''Appeals have been made for reconciliation, which is undoubtedly possible. In this time of great misery, there are better things to do than fight a civil war.''

headline: PATENTS; MICROBES THAT FIGHT OBNOXIOUS WASTES
abstract: The Occidental Chemical Corporation, Niagara Falls, N.Y., received a patent this week on the use of microbes to change obnoxious wastes into innocuous materials. Patent 4,477,570 was assigned to the company by Joseph F. Colaruotolo, an industrial manager for Occidental, and two co-inventors.

headline: Attock Oil in Bid For Texaco Plant
abstract: Attock Oil, a company headed by Ghaith R. Pharaon, a Saudi Arabian businessman, is among the bidders for a New Jersey oil refinery being sold by Texaco Inc., a Texaco spokesman confirmed. The South Jersey facility, Texaco's 90,000-barrel-a-day Eagle Point refinery at Westville on the Delaware River, must be sold as a condition of Texaco's acquisition last summer of the Getty Oil Company.    Mr. Pharaon has acquired several American properties, including the National Bank of Georgia, formerly owned by Bert Lance, who headed the Office of Management and Budget in the Carter Administration. Mr. Pharaon also bought control in 1976 of the ailing Bank of the Commonwealth, a billion-dollar Detroit institution.

headline: ARCHBISHOP CENSURES THATCHER
abstract: The Archbishop of Canterbury has accused Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of pursuing ''confrontation'' politics and suggested that her economic policies hurt people more than they help.   The Archbishop, the Most Rev. Robert Runcie, was quoted today as having said, ''There seems to be a movement from consensus to confrontation.''

headline: Israel Fails to Settle Dispute in Cabinet
abstract: Israeli Government leaders tried without success tonight to settle a dispute between two religious parties in the unity Government.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Those Lagging Rates   Recent headlines have heralded the continuing fall in interest rates. But so far, the resulting glee has not extended to consumers - and is unlikely to do so for some time. Lending rates for consumers are sticking at high levels as market rates - including those paid on deposits - have declined.  ''Historically, consumer loan rates are more 'sticky' than market rates when they start to drop, but they are even more 'sticky' this time around,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist at Shearson Lehman/American Express. He said consumer rates are now one-half to three-quarters of a percentage point higher than they have generally been relative to market rates.    According to Mr. Sinai, the average cost of funds to banks - what they pay in the Federal funds market when they borrow from each other - has fallen by 2 1/2 points since early October. But the prime, to which many loan rates are tied, has slid just 1 1/2 points. Mortgage rates have slipped less than 1 percentage point. And a Shearson survey showed that 48-month auto loan rates have not dropped at all. Installment credit rates have also held steady. Citibank's Visa and Mastercard customers, for instance, pay 19.8 percent interest, a rate unchanged since 1981.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  BankAmerica Corp.  filed a shelf offering of up to $1 billion in debt securities. It said it would use the proceeds chiefly to finance investments of credit to its subsidiaries for lending and lease financing activities.     *  The Canadian Federal Government set the price terms of a four-part $950 million bond offering. Yields ranged from 12.45 percent on bonds due Nov. 1, 1989, to 12.92 percent on bonds due March 1, 2008.

headline: ROHATYN ASSAILS TAX PLAN
abstract: Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, yesterday assailed the Treasury's tax simplification proposal as ''lethal'' for New York and an invitation to regional conflict.     ''Like a croissant containing a poison pill, the Treasury plan looks good, but for New York it is lethal,'' he said. ''It is the most lethal Federal assault on the state and city since the Ford Administration told us to 'Drop Dead,' '' he added, alluding to The Daily News headline when Washington refused to help New York City during its fiscal crisis in 1975.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 17, 1984:  MONDAY Horizon BancorpPrimark CorpLilly (Eli) & CoRochester TelNBD BancorpSterchi Bros StrsPHH Group Inc   TUESDAY Ampco-PittsburshHydraulic CoBasix CorpJoy Mfg CoCPI IntlMontana PowerFedl Paper BoardRaytheon CoFirst Boston IncToledo EdisonHarsco Corp   WEDNESDAY Amer Natl ResourcesNatl Service IndCarolina Pwr & LtNorthn States Pwr MinnCox CommunicationsUnited Jersey BksHoover Universal  THURSDAY   CNA Income ShsNynex CorpCentl Maine PwrResearch-CottrellCincinnati G & ERexham CorpCoca-Cola CoSouthn Cal EdisonKnight-Ridder NewsViacom IntlManor Care   FRIDAY CTS CorpPac Telesis GroupCentl Hudson G & ESoutheast Banking

headline: Israel Is Said to Hold 6 For Plot on Americans
abstract: An American diplomat said Thursday that six people had been arrested for plotting to attack the United States Embassy in Tel Aviv.    News reports in the United States this week said Israeli security forces foiled a planned attack on the embassy and Israeli Government buildings in Tel Aviv three weeks ago when they arrested six Palestinians from the occupied Gaza Strip who were carrying grenades.

headline: PHILIPPINE ARMY: PROBLEMS AND POSSIBILITIES
abstract: The small band of armed men walking on a provincial road north of Manila recently was a rag-tag bunch, a Western diplomat recalled.     As he approached in his car, the diplomat noted that the men were dressed in T-shirts, jeans and sandals. Some were bearded, a few were smoking.   This, the Western military specialist figured worriedly, was to be an encounter with the Communist insurgents, the New People's Army.   No, his driver assured him, the scruffy men ahead were not Communist guerrillas, they were members of the Philippine Army manning a checkpoint.

headline: THE WORLD OF THE LONE-WOLF ENTREPRENEUR
abstract: Starting a business - it is never easy, always risky, and usually expensive. Partners and employees can share the risk and combat the loneliness and initial insecurity. But budding entrepreneurs rarely can afford a staff, and many start alone.

headline: 6 Leaders Will Gather To Urge Arms Accord
abstract: Six world leaders plan to meet in New Delhi in late January to keep pressure on the United States and the Soviet Union to reach an arms agreement, organizers of the conference say.   The six are from India, Mexico, Tanzania, Sweden, Greece and Argentina.

headline: Qaddafi Says Britain Wages A Campaign Against Libyans
abstract: Col.Muammar el-Qaddafi. the Libyan leader, in talks with a Church of England envoy, accused Britain of conducting a ''campaign of hatred and harassment'' against Libyans, the Libyan radio said today.   The Libyan report, monitored by the British Broadcasting Corporation in London, made no reference to four Britons held as political detainees in Libya since last April's siege of the Libyan Embassy in London.   Terry Waite, a personal representative of the Archbishop of Canterbury, said he met with Colonel Qaddafi late Tuesday and won a pledge from the Libyan leader to seek the release of the four Britons during the People's Congress, which starts Jan. 5.

headline: HEAD OF I.R.A.'S POLITICAL WING ARRESTED IN ULSTER
abstract: The president of Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army, and seven other members of the group were arrested in a predawn raid today and questioned about how a New York lawyer had managed to enter Northern Ireland illegally last August.     After six hours, Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein leader, and the others were released without charges.    Martin Galvin, publicity director of the New York-based Noraid, which raises money in the United States, entered the province despite a ban by the British Government. He appeared with Mr. Adams at a rally in Belfast on Aug. 12.

headline: SANDINISTAS HOLD THEIR FIRST ELECTIONS
abstract: Nicaragua held a national election today, the first since the Sandinistas took power five years ago after an insurrection.     Election officials said they expected to have early returns by Monday morning, with a final tally promised before the end of the week.   The Sandinista presidential candidate, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, and his running mate, Sergio Ramirez Mercado, both of whom serve on the provisional junta that has held executive power in Nicaragua since the 1979 revolution, are considered certain winners.    Although Nicaragua is torn by civil strife, there were no reprted clashes today. The Nicaraguan Democratic Force, the largest of the pro-American guerrilla groups fighting to depose the Sandinistas, had called a one-day cease-fire.

headline: BBDO Client
abstract: Did you know that BBDO has a special Business-to-Business Group? Well, it does, and it has just got a new client with a budget of $1 million.

headline: E.E.C. Fines 5 Companies
abstract: The executive commission of the European Economic Community today charged five chemical companies with conspiring to fix prices and supplies of three products for 19 years.   The companies were fined $6.7 million, the largest anticompetitive penalty in Common Market history.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1984   Companies    The Government forced two large banks to strengthen their credit policies and bolster their financial underpinnings. Directors of the Bank of America and the First National Bank of Chicago have been required to sign pledges to make specific changes. Analysts saw the move as part of a new strategy to keep banks healthy through preventive measures and market discipline. (Page A1.) The S.E.C. is investigating the possibility of securities law violations in connection with a $278 million charge-off for bad loans by First Chicago. (D4.) Continental Illinois said its nonperforming loans fell to $949 million in the third quarter. (D4.)    Morton Thiokol will sell its Texize division to Dow Chemical for about $256 million. Dow will give up its 8.2 percent holding in Morton, ending a takeover threat. (D17.)

headline: Of Eberstadt and Alliance
abstract: The fall-out has begun at New York's Eberstadt Asset Management. The $1.7 billion investment firm was acquired last month by Alliance Capital Management from Marsh & McLennan.

headline: STEEL RULE'S EFFECT MAY BE LIMITED
abstract: On its face, the trade bill approved by Congress makes protection of domestic steelmakers contingent on their spending to modernize plants and retrain workers.    If President Reagan signs the bill, as he is expected to do, the Government will be committed, in a limited way, to a national industrial policy, coordinating government policy with private business decisions. Mr. Reagan has repeatedly stated his philosophical opposition to such a policy; Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic presidential candidate, supports one.    But there may be less to the steel ''industrial policy'' than meets the eye.   'A Nice Political Gesture'    ''It's no more than a nice political gesture,'' said Robert G. Maloney, an analyst at Wood Gundy Inc., a Wall Street investment firm. ''They are already doing more than required, but that's not hard since they've been losing money and don't have much cash flow.''

headline: BALDRIDGE CRITICAL OF TREASURY BID TO END BUSINESS TAX BREAK
abstract: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today that he had serious doubts about a central provision of Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan's tax plan that would take away an important business tax break.    Mr. Baldrige was the first Cabinet officer to take public exception to part of the plan that his fellow Cabinet officer announced on Nov. 27. Because he is one of the President's senior advisers on economic matters, his objections raise the strongest doubts to date that the President will accept this part of the Treasury proposal.

headline: Chicago Issuing Mortgage Bonds
abstract: Chicago, which sold the first tax-exempt single-family mortgage revenue bonds in 1978, is offering $113.6 million of new bonds with a maximum yield of 10.583 percent for bonds due in 2010.

headline: Common Stock
abstract: *  American President Cos.  is offering 2 million common shares at $33 each, through Salomon Brothers Inc.     *  Collins Industries Inc.  is offering 12,000 units for $997 each, through Advest Inc.     *  Oce-Van Der Griten N.V.  is offering 1 million American depositary shares at $15.375 each, through Morgan Stanley & Co.     *  Policy Management Systems Corp.  is offering 3 million shares of common at $23.75 a share, through Alex. Brown & Sons Inc.     *  Restaurant Management Services Inc.  announced an initial public offering of 572,000 shares of common at $10.50 a share, through Interstate Securities Corp.     *  Sytek Inc.  said it filed a registration statement on the proposed initial public offering of 2 million common shares through Hambrecht & Quist Inc.     *  This Can't Be Yogurt Inc., Little Rock, Ark., said it filed for a public offering of 375,000 common shares, of which 250,000 will be sold by the company and 125,000 by a shareholder, through Chicago Corp.      Ratings     *  General Telephone Co. of the Midwest's commercial paper was upgraded from Prime 2 to Prime 1 by Moody's Investor's Service.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; G.M. Acceptance Corp. Sells Notes to Yield 12%
abstract: Encouraged by the recent decline in interest rates, several corporations tapped the debt markets yesterday.    The new issues were led by the General Motors Acceptance Corporation.

headline: BRZEZINSKI ASSAILS U.S. OFFICIALS
abstract: Federal officials have been ''unwitting or in some cases, perhaps, even witting tools'' of a Soviet campaign to divert attention from a purported plot to murder the Pope, Zbigniew Brzezinski, national security adviser to former President Jimmy Carter, said in an interview broadcast today.   ''What I find very troublesome over the past two years,'' Mr. Brzezinski said in the interview with the RKO Radio Network, ''was the frequency with which senior officials, in fact, participated in the campaign of pooh-poohing what turns out to be a very serious plot.''

headline: A SANDINISTA ON THE MOVE
abstract: Daniel Ortega Saavedra, who claimed victory today as this country's new President, has spent his life making revolution.     Nicaragua is a country where power normally changes hands only at gunpoint, where men of action have always guided national destiny. Nearly all of Nicaragua's most formidable historical heroes rose to power by overthrowing their predecessors, and Mr. Ortega is firmly within this tradition.    Born into a country that Nicaraguans say was ruled like a private plantation by the Somoza family, the son of parents who were anti-Somoza activists, Mr. Ortega marched in protests as a young student even before the formation of Sandinista National Liberation Front, which toppled Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle's Government in 1979.

headline: Irma Turtle Aided By Memorable Name
abstract: Irma Turtle finds that she is immediately memorable thanks to the name. And that happens to be handy when one has gone into business for oneself, as she has.    Irma Turtle of 251 East 51st Street is prepared to consult on the subject of direct response advertising in Latin America and even more prepared if you narrowed the query down to business-to-business direct response advertising in Brazil. That is what she had been specializing in for Ogilvy & Mather as director of O&M Direct Response's Sao Paulo office.

headline: 40 FRENCH, 40 U.S. JETS FOR GREECE
abstract: The Greek Government announced tonight that it had decided to purchase 40 American F-16G jet fighter planes and 40 French Mirage-2000's to meet the needs of its air force over the next decade.    Officials said negotiations would proceed on details of the additional services offered by the successful bidders - the General Dynamics Corporation makes the F-16's and Dassault makes the Mirages - before the signing of a contract.    The long-awaited announcement, made after more than two and a half years of talks, means that the Greeks rejected the F-18 fighter, manufactured by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.    Several months ago the Government committed itself to the French aircraft and rejected the Tornado fighter-bomber produced by Panavia, a European consortium of British, West German and Dutch concerns.

headline: Jet Crashes in Germany
abstract: A British jet fighter crashed today in Bavaria, barely missing a convent. Two crewmen ejected and were hospitalized with minor injuries, the police said.

headline: Firebombs Thrown in Britain As More Miners Quit Strike
abstract: Striking coal miners threw firebombs and put up burning barricades in northern England today as hundreds more miners quit the eight-month-old walkout.    The National Coal Board said 767 men abandoned the strike and returned to work this morning.

headline: People
abstract: *  Lou Mazzulli has been named a senior vice president at Lewis Advertising, Baltimore.

headline: People
abstract: *  Jack M. Maged appointed senior vice president, director of client services at Venet Advertising.     *  Cynthia Hull Hammett named vice president for communications at the Planned Parenthood Federation of America.

headline: Westpac Selling Commercial Paper
abstract: The Westpac Banking Corporation, the largest commercial bank in Australia, plans to begin selling up to $500 million of commercial paper through Merrill Lynch Money Markets.    The commercial paper, which has received the highest ratings of P-1 from Moody's Investors Service and A-1x by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, will be issued by the Westpac Capital Corporation, a Delaware company, and guaranteed by Westpac Banking in Australia.

headline: 1,000 FEARED DEAD AS INDIA PREPARES FOR GANDHI RITES
abstract: Violence ignited by the assassination of Indira Gandhi spread Friday, pushing the nationwide death toll close to 1,000, according to some estimates.    At least 500 killings were reported in the New Delhi area alone.   As this battered and fearful city prepared to receive more than 100 foreign dignitaries at Mrs. Gandhi's funeral and cremation today, her son and successor, Rajiv, was officially confirmed as Prime Minister on Friday.    Applauded by Party Members    To thunderous applause, members of Parliament from the governing Congress Party ratified his appointment by a party central committee. He was appointed Wednesday only hours after his mother was gunned down by assailants who have been identified by the police as two Sikh members of her security guard.

headline: Banned Polish Priest Celebrates Mass
abstract: A Roman Catholic priest who was banned from preaching by the Primate of Poland because of his political views took part in a church service today on the outskirts of the capital.   The priest, the Rev. Stanislaw Malkowski, celebrated mass, but said he had not been permitted to deliver a sermon as he had originally planned.

headline: FRENCH TROOPS MAY GO BACK TO CHAD
abstract: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson told Secretary of State George P. Shultz today that France was prepared to send its troops back to Chad if Libya did not promptly remove all its troops, French and American officials said today.   In several hours of discussion at the State Department, including a working luncheon, Mr. Cheysson acknowledged that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, had failed to keep his part of the bargain. As part of an agreement worked out in September, all French and Libyan troops were supposed to leave Chad.   While Mr. Cheysson was discussing the situation here with Mr. Shultz, Defense Minister Charles Hernu of France met in Ndjamena, Chad, with President Hissen Habre to discuss the possibility of the return of the French.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Nov. 2, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Comittee - 10:30 A.M., 3 and 6 P.M.   Decolonization Committee - 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Legal Committee - 3 P.M.   U.N. Council for Namibia: Symposium - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Futures/Options ; A New Dimension In Silver
abstract: With the opening of the silver options market on the Commodity Exchange last Thursday, trading in the metal took on a new dimension. For the first time, traders will be able to trade exchange-traded options on Comex's silver futures at prices determined by a continuing auction and not by dealer fiat.   But will the options benefit investors? Yes and no, according to specialists in precious metals markets such as Paul Sarnoff, senior vice president at Paine Webber Inc., who has written a score of books on the subject.   ''The advent of options on silver futures will afford speculators, hedgers and traders the same benefits that the Comex gold options have provided since they were introduced in October 1982,'' Mr. Sarnoff said. ''But whether they profit from the options depends as much on the behavior of the underlying cash and futures markets as on their full understanding of how these instruments are priced.''

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: *  Arizona Public Service Co., Phoenix, has named Dave Ellis vice president for research and development and alternative energy applications.     *  Cullum Companies, Dallas, a multiregional food and drug chain, has named Jack W. Evans, president, to the additional post of chief executive.

headline: Tri-Star Offering Withdrawn
abstract: Tri-Star Pictures, a motion picture company backed by three giants in the entertainment business, announced yesterday that it had withdrawn an initial public offering of 4.5 million shares of common stock because of market conditions.   Earlier, the expected price for the offering had been between $15 and $18 a share, with Morgan Stanley & Company heading a blue-ribbon syndicate of Wall Street underwriting firms.   ''We have withdrawn the offering because, under present market conditions, we were unable to realize a price consistent with the company's worth,'' Victor A. Kaufman, Tri- Star's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement issued in New York. ''The offering is being withdrawn rather than being postponed because we think it is important for the company to focus on its business operations. We will not consider renewing the concept of a public offering in the immediate future.''

headline: Action on Deak
abstract: Financial Secretary John   Bremridge petitioned the Hong   Kong Supreme Court today to   liquidate Deak-Perera Far   East Ltd., a subsidiary of Deak   & Company, the financially   troubled holding company   based in New York. Noel Gleeson, official receiver, was appointed provisional   liquidator of the company, a   Government spokesman said.

headline: INDIA POLICE SEIZE FACTORY RECORDS OF UNION CARBIDE
abstract: In preparation for an investigation into the catastrophe caused by the release of poison gas, the police seized records Thursday from the Union Carbide plant here and guarded the hospital room of an employee on duty Monday when the accident occurred.    The moves came as labor unions criticized India's industrial safety regulations and recrimination mounted over responsibility for the disaster, in which as many as 2,000 people died by unofficial count and tens of thousands were injured.   Union Carbide Chairman Arrested      Today, the police arrested the chairman of the Union Carbide Corporation, Warren M. Anderson, when he arrived in Bhopal to investigate the disaster, the Press Trust of India news agency reported.   The agency said he was detained at the airport on charges of ''negligence and corporate liability'' in connection with the gas leak. It said two of the company's Indian executives, Keshav Mahendra, chairman of Union Carbide of India, and the Indian company's managing director, V. P. Gokhale, were also detained. Five senior officials of the insecticide plant have already been detained for questioning.

headline: Hill, Holliday Account
abstract: The New York office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos of Boston has been tapped to handle the account of Cluett, Peabody's Colours by Alexander Julian.

headline: TOP SOVIET AIDE TALKS OF ARMS CUTS
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who is widely regarded as second-in-command in the Soviet Union, had his first substantive conversation with Americans two weeks ago and told them that Moscow was ready for reciprocal cuts in military spending with the United States.     President Reagan spoke of the possibility of such mutual budget reductions in a speech to the United Nations in September.    Mr. Gorbachev met in a Kremlin conference room Dec. 3 with Dwayne O. Andreas, the American chairman of the U.S.-U.S.S.R. Trade and Economic Council, and James H. Giffen, president of the council. The council, which has Soviet and United States co-chairmen, was established in 1973 by the two Governments to make trade easier. Its members include 220 American companies and 125 Soviet foreign trade concerns.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

headline: Smithfield Deal
abstract: Smithfield Foods Inc. said it had agreed to acquire substantially all of the assets and business, and to assume certain liabilities, of Patrick Cudahy Inc. for about $29 million. Patrick Cudahy, a subsidiary of the Prestige Foods Corporation, is a pork packer and processor based in Cudahy, Wis. Smithfield, which has headquarters in Arlington, Va., said Patrick Cudahy had sales of about $250 million in the last 12 months.

headline: THE QUEST FOR OFFSHORE OIL WANES
abstract: WASHINGTON     IT was as if the invited guests had   failed to come to a sumptuous dinner party, or - in the words of Thomas DeRocco, an Interior Department spokesman - ''like preparing for the opening of a Broadway show and then nobody shows up in the audience.''    In this case, the party was hosted by the Interior Department, which had invited the nation's oil companies to bid for leases off the New England coast, including the Georges Bank. Sixteen companies had indicated that they were interested in drilling in this part of the Atlantic and would bid. But on the day of the lease sale, Sept. 27, not one of them came forward with an offer to buy a lease.    That was a watershed in the Reagan Administration's much-debated program to lease vast areas along America's coasts for oil and gas exploration. By not bidding, the oil industry was in effect saying that it is losing interest in offshore exploration in domestic waters because of rising drilling costs and increasingly slim prospects of making a profit.

headline: Diversifoods Net
abstract: Diversifoods Inc. said that it expected a sharp decline in earnings for the fourth quarter and that a tentative agreement for a $525 million leveraged buy out of the company had been terminated.

headline: Spain Is Host to Talks On Fighting Terrorism
abstract: Antiterrorism specialists from 13 European nations met secretly in Madrid this week, the independent daily newspaper El Pais said today.    The meeting, the fourth of its kind since European nations began coordinating antiterrorist activities, took place Tuesday and Wednesday but was not publicized for security reasons, the newspaper quoted the Ministry of the Interior as saying.   Experts from Austria, Belgium, Britain, Denmark, France, Greece, Ireland, Italy, the Netherlands, Portugal, Spain, Switzerland and West Germany discussed the activities of terrorists from Middle Eastern nations and how to keep them from operating in Europe, the paper said.

headline: Albanian Leader Reappears in Public
abstract: Albania's Communist Party leader, Enver Hoxha, who had not been seen in public since May, has reappeared in public at a rally after months of speculation in the West that he was in poor health.   Mr. Hoxha, who was 76 years old this month, joined a rally of 24,000 young people in the National Stadium in the capital, Tirana, on Saturday, Albania's official press agency said.

headline: SOVIET LEADER CRITICIZES ECONOMY, BUT MILDLY
abstract: Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, has outlined an economic plan for the coming year that speaks of some shortcomings, but in terms much milder than those used by his predecessor, Yuri V. Andropov.     Mr. Chernenko's speech to the ruling Politburo, published in the nation's major newspapers today, characterized the economy as dynamic. But it criticized substandard work, a failure to meet economic goals, laziness and a shortage of consumer goods.

headline: TOY MAKER'S HOLIDAY SURGE
abstract: Each year, Christmas begins in the summertime in this small town on the moors of Jutland.   From late August to early October, the factories here at the headquarters of Interlego A/S - and their counterparts in central Europe, Asia and the United States - race to fill toy shops and department stores in more than 120 countries with what is probably the world's most widely known toy - the plastic Lego building block.    The company estimates that well over 50 million children around the world play with Lego building sets, most of which they get at Christmas.   The brightly colored little plastic pieces have turned out to be everything that increasing numbers of parents want from an indoor toy: They are durable, safe and expandable and they offer a way to help young children improve physical coordination while exercising their imaginations.

headline: IN CHILEAN SLUM, A RAID, THEN A VISIT
abstract: By midmorning today, Claudina Nunez had set up a wooden table behind the parish hall to continue taking the names of men who have not been seen since the armed forces swept through an impoverished neighborhood here Thursday morning and rounded up 2,000 people.     Government officials said that 227 were arrested in the sweep in La Victoria, and Mrs. Nunez, a community worker, had collected 162 names from family members who have searched local police stations for their children or husbands. She said she expected the total to far exceed the Government's tally, and there have been more arrrests since.   Soledad Araos arrived by 10:30 A.M. to help at the table and reported that on her way to work she had seen a police van full of men who had been picked up this morning.

headline: U.S. DENIES REPORT OF PLAN FOR LATIN EXERCISE
abstract: The Defense Department, responding to reports that United States troops would soon engage in maneuvers in El Salvador, asserted today that it had ''no plans to conduct exercises in El Salvador with the Salvadoran Army or Air Force.''    A report in late editions of The New York Times quoted knowledgeable sources as saying that some of the manuevers would take place at a Salvadoran naval base near the Honduran border.  They said the number of Americans involved would be relatively small but gave no specific figure.

headline: Occidental to Sell Geothermal Unit
abstract: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, in a move to concentrate on its main lines of business, said today it will sell its geothermal energy unit to the Kuwaiti-owned Santa Fe International Corporation for $350 million.   The move comes as Occidental is selling assets to raise cash for developing a major oil find in Colombia and to pay off debts from its $4 billion purchase of the Cities Service Company of Tulsa, Okla., in 1982.   As of Sept. 30, Occidental's senior debt was $2.7 billion.

headline: BOOM IN LUXURY CAR IMPORTS
abstract: For almost two decades, European car makers have nibbled away at the highly profitable American luxury car market with hardly any response from the Big Three.    Stressing high performance and engineering advances, the Europeans are fielding such makes as the Mercedes-Benz, Volvo, Audi, BMW and Saab to do battle with Detroit's traditional view of the luxury car: a big, lushly appointed highway cruiser with a large engine, like the Cadillac and Lincoln. In recent years, the Japanese joined the fray, exporting the Toyota Cressida and Nissan Maxima, among others.    The imports are increasing their market share at a time when luxury models of all kinds, including the traditional makes, have become more popular, accounting for about 10 percent of total sales this year.   Some American auto executives now concede that they were as unprepared to meet the Europeans at the top of the market as they were to take on the Japanese several years ago at the lower end. ''We didn't recognize as early as some other parts of the world that the market for luxury vehicles was changing in terms of what it wanted in addition to the traditional elements of comfort, image and prestige,'' said John O. Grettenberger, the general manager of Cadillac.

headline: INDIA SAID TO WIDEN INQUIRY ON SLAYING
abstract: The authorities investigating the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi have detained more than three dozen members of her personal security force, it was reported here today.    Indian intelligence sources told the Press Trust of India that they suspected the assassination conspiracy was part of a wider plot to kill President Zail Singh, Rajiv Gandhi, the slain Prime Minister's son and successor, and his family.   The news agency said more than three dozen police officers assigned to guard Mrs. Gandhi and some officers from other services underwent ''sustained questioning to find out whether they were part of the plot or had any inkling of the conspiracy.'' Officials could not be reached for comment on the report.

headline: SEX AND GREED IN THE FUTURES PITS
abstract: ''Limit Bid! Limit Bid!'' by Charles Baxter Clement. Jameson Books. Ottawa, Ill. 236 pages, $13.95.      Charles Baxter Clement, a futures trader and a director of the Chicago Board of Trade, wrote a well-received suspense novel about bond trading several years ago, ''The Fairy Godmother.''

headline: Productivity Gauge Rises
abstract: Production efficiency in American business advanced at an annual rate of 3.6 percent last year, the best showing in seven years, the Labor Department reported today.    This all-purpose productivity gauge, which measures the volume of money as well as labor put into American business enterprises, excluding farming, registered the strongest gain since 1976, when it gained 3.8 percent.

headline: THE HOUSE THAT BANKING BUILT
abstract: When Joel R. Wells Jr., joined the top management team at Sun Banks Inc. in 1975, he paid what he thought would be ''just a social call'' on Harry V. Keefe Jr., head of the stock research firm of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods. Mr. Keefe, however, was not about to pass up a chance to learn more about the troubles then afflicting the Florida bank holding company.    ''He didn't mince any words with me,'' said Mr. Wells, who recalls he was ''marched into a conference room and put on a speaker phone with a couple of institutional investors.'' The grilling, led by Mr. Keefe, ranged from questions about the current status of the bank to what was being done about past problems. ''He gave me a real going over. But I respected him for it,'' said Mr. Wells, now Sun Banks' president and chief executive officer.    Putting bank executives to the test of investor scrutiny has been Harry Keefe's trademark for nearly 30 years. The Wall Street firm that he has built is clearly the source, nonpareil, when it comes to critiquing and trading bank stocks, say institutional investors. And it has an equal presence among corporate treasurers, who rely on the firm's credit ratings of banks to choose where they should park short-term funds and maintain ongoing relationships.

headline: American Healthcare Notes
abstract: American Healthcare Management is offering $80 million of 15 percent subordinated debentures due in 2004 at a price of 100 through Drexel Burnham Lambert.   The notes, rated B-1 by Moody's and B by Standard & Poor's, may be put, or redeemed, by investors, in 1994 at a price of 100.

headline: Burundi Bus Plunge Kills 43
abstract: Forty-three people were killed and 18 seriously hurt when a bus carrying 60 passengers and the driver fell into a ravine on Friday 55 miles of here. The police said it was the worst road accident in the history of Burundi.

headline: ISRAEL BARS A MEMBER OF GERMAN GREEN PARTY
abstract: A West German member of the European Parliament was denied permission today to enter Israel with five other representatives of the Green Party because of her conviction four years ago on terrorist charges.   The Israeli decision, which came as the Green Party delegation was in Beirut on a Middle East tour, brought into relief a simmering controversy within the five- year-old party over the anti-Israeli tone of a working document prepared for the trip.   According to Israeli diplomats, the decision to ban Brigitte Heinrich, a 43- year-old member of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France, was made in light of a 21-month sentence imposed on her on gun-smuggling charges in Karlsruhe in 1980.    Testimony at her trial identified Miss Heinrich as a link for West German terrorists who received training in Palestinian camps in the Middle East. She was elected to the European Parliament last June as the Green Party picked up 8.2 percent of the popular vote in West Germany.

headline: Lyon Accepts Bid
abstract: Lyon Metal Products Inc. said it had agreed to be acquired by the Auron Corporation for $19 a share, or about $26.6 million.

headline: Accounts
abstract: World Press Review to Grossich & Partners for its first national ad campaign.

headline: Top Executive Chosen For Lone Star Steel
abstract: Northwest Industries Inc., which said yesterday that it had entered into a definitive agreement to be acquired by an investor group for $1.2 billion, has named a top officer for Lone Star Steel, a subsidiary that will be spun off.   Northwest said William H. Beasley 3d, currently president and chief operating officer of Northwest, would become chairman and chief executive officer of Lone Star.    The proposed acquisition of Northwest by an investor group requires completion of financing arrangements and approval by Northwest shareholders. The group is led by Kelly, Briggs & Associates, which plans to merge a company it owns with Northwest and take the new concern private. Kelly, Briggs is headed by two former top executives at Esmark Inc. - Donald P. Kelly, a former chairman and chief executive, and Roger T. Briggs, who was vice chairman and chief financial officer.

headline: Futures/Options ; Approach Of 'Farm Options'
abstract: If, as expected, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission approves the ''second wave'' of options on futures today, trading in options on soybeans, cotton, live cattle and several varieties of wheat futures will begin tomorrow for the first time on domestic exchanges.    The farm options, as the trade calls them, are considered the most important development in the futures and options industry since the Federal regulatory agency approved the ''first wave'' of options on futures in 1982. This experimental program produced the successful options on Treasury bonds and other financial debt instruments, foreign exchange and various stock indexes.    It also led to the first domestic exchange-traded options on a farm product, sugar, on Oct. 1, 1982.
