But the options on sugar futures have not done well because that market, and all those in basic farm produce, have been depressed in recent years.

headline: U.S. MAKES 2 BANKS VOW TO REINFORCE CREDIT OPERATIONS
abstract: The Federal Government, in an unusual move, has forced two of the nation's largest banks to strengthen their credit policies and bolster their financial underpinnings, the banks said yesterday in separate statements.    The two banks are the Bank of America, the largest in the United States, and the First National Bank of Chicago, the eighth largest.    Directors of both banks have been required by the Comptroller of the Currency, the arm of the Treasury Department that regulates federally chartered banks, to sign formal pledges to make specific changes.    If the banks do not comply, the Comptroller can take the signed statements to court to obtain removal of the banks' senior officers.

headline: Sandinistas Hold Lead; Vote Count Goes On
abstract: The governing Sandinista National Liberation Front maintained its wide lead over six other parties today as vote counting continued after the national election Sunday.

headline: 23 BLACKS HURT IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: Policemen firing rubber bullets, birdshot and tear gas clashed with stone- hurling black mourners during a funeral, leaving at least 23 people wounded, the authorities said today.    The clash took place during a funeral in the southeastern town of Port Alfred, where the police dispersed about 2,000 blacks, a police spokesman said.

headline: OCCIDENTAL RAISES OIL ESTIMATE
abstract: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation has sharply increased its estimate of reserves in its Cano Limon oilfield in northeastern Colombia, Armand Hammer, Occidental's chairman, said here today.   Occidental has long described the field, which it has explored for four years, as significant. It raised its reserve estimate to more than a billion barrels of recoverable crude oil, from 750 million barrels.   Dr. Hammer, speaking at a meeting of the Stockbrokers Society here along with other senior Occidental officials, said that the increase was based on preliminary results from the company's sixth exploratory well in the two-million-acre area. He said that Occidental expected to produce 100,000 barrels a day from the field by December 1985 and up to 250,000 barrels daily by June 1986.

headline: California Issue In Big Demand
abstract: A $310 million issue of California general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 5.75 percent for bonds due in 1986, to 8.50 percent in 1994 and 9.80 percent in 2008 through 2010. Underwriters were led by the Bank of America.

headline: Anta to Sell Unit
abstract: The Anta Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Nichols-Homeshield Inc. subsidiary for more than $30 million to a group of private Dallas investors. Anta, which is based in Oklahoma City, said the sale is expected to be completed within 60 days. Nichols-Homeshield, a manufacturer of aluminum products, is one of two units still owned by Anta, which is liquidating and disposing of its assets.

headline: Deutsche Bank In British Deal LONDON, Nov. 7 -
abstract: Deutsche Bank A.G., West Germany's largest commercial   bank, said today that it was acquiring a 4.99 percent stake in   Morgan Grenfell Holdings Ltd.,   one of Britain's leading merchant banks, for $17.8 million. The deal would give Morgan   Grenfell about 30 percent of the  $57 million it has said it needs   to reshape itself along the lines   of an American investment   bank, and it helps Deutsche   Bank build up its presence in   London.

headline: Injured Queens Dancer Sues South Africa Over Treatment
abstract: Barry Martin, a dancer from the Cambria Heights section of Queens, filed a $130-million lawsuit yesterday against the South African Government and Transvaal Hospital Services, a provincial agency, charging that he received discriminatory medical treatment that left him quadriplegic after he suffered fractured vertebrae in an automobile accident in that country Sept. 26, 1983.

headline: IC-Pneumo Link
abstract: IC Industries said its proposed merger of the Pneumo Corporation and an IC subsidiary had been oversubscribed. Pneumo shareholders who tendered their shares by Thursday will receive $38 for about 75 percent of the shares covered and 1.49 shares of IC common stock for each remaining share.

headline: MADRID AND LISBON FACE NEW HURDLE TO MARKET ENTRY
abstract: Greece today threatened to veto longstanding plans to admit Spain and Portugal as members of the European Economic Community unless the community agrees to pay poor southern European farmers up to $5 billion in special aid over the next five years.    As a result of this threat, issued by the Greek Prime Minister, Andreas Papandreou, a two-day meeting of Common Market heads of government ended in confusion and bitterness today, with other European leaders visibly angry at Greece's demands.    Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain said at a news conference that Greece's request was ''totally out of the question.'' Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany and France's President, Francois Mitterrand, also rejected the Greek demand outright, according to their spokesmen. Other officials openly accused Greece of blackmailing the community.

headline: Utah Agency Issue Offered
abstract: The Utah Housing Finance Agency is offering $150 million of single- family mortgage revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 10 5/8 percent for bonds due in 2008, according to tentative prices announced by Kidder, Peabody & Company, the lead underwriter.    Rated AA by Standard & Poor's, the financing also includes bonds yielding from 7.25 percent in 1987 to 10.40 percent in 1999 and 10 1/2 percent in 2004. Zero coupon bonds were offered with yields ranging from 10.25 percent in 1996 to 11 percent in 2004.

headline: Talks on Coal Strike Collapse in Britain
abstract: Talks intended to settle Britain's seven-month- old coal strike collapsed tonight. The miners' union leader, Arthur Scargill, said there was no hope for an end to the dispute soon.

headline: NICARAGUAN REBEL GROUP DISMISSES ONE OF ITS TOP LEADERS
abstract: The directors of the largest Nicaraguan rebel force have expelled from their ranks a top leader who had openly discussed and was critical of the Central Intelligence Agency's covert aid to the anti-Santinista group.    Adolfo Calero Porotcarrero, head of the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, said he and five of the other six members of the National Directorate had unanimously voted to remove Edgar Chamorro from his position for not being ''loyal.''    Mr. Chamorro, reached by telephone at his home in Key Biscayne, Fla., said that he was being dismissed because of his comments to various newspapers. He said Mr. Calero had contacted him several days ago and complained specifically about an article in The New York Times in which Mr. Chamorro disclosed that he and other rebel leaders had been coached by the C.I.A. on how to win Congressional support.

headline: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1984
abstract: The Economy    Budget officials forecast a deficit of $200 billion for the next fiscal year if no actions are taken to cut spending or raise revenues, Administration officials said. That is nearly $30 billion more than the projection made last summer. But even the new figure is based on assumptions being challenged as too optimistic. (Page A1.)   A plan for New York State tax changes focusing on income tax cuts has been drafted and will be presented to the Governor. (A1.)

headline: U.S. Home Ex-Chief Quits Other Posts
abstract: Guy R. Odom, chairman of the executive committee of the U.S. Home Corporation, the nation's largest home builder, resigned yesterday in a move that surprised analysts.   The company said that Mr. Odom, who also relinquished his directorship, resigned as part of a management succession program and would ''pursue other personal and professional interests.'' But analysts noted that U.S. Home has had three consecutive quarterly losses.

headline: Richard Burton Left A $4.5 Million Estate
abstract: The actor Richard Burton left an estate worth $4.58 million in his will, the bulk of it to his widow, Sally, The Sunday Mirror reported today. He died in Switzerland on Aug. 5.

headline: China's Foreign Trade
abstract: China posted a foreign trade deficit of $70 million in August, but the overall balance for the first eight months of 1984 showed a surplus of $803 million, the Government's statistical bureau said today. The agency said two-way trade totaled $4.09 billion in August. Countries posting a trade surplus with China included the United States, Japan, Britain, West Germany, Canada and Australia, it said.

headline: PATENTS ; Inventors Meet Feb. 8
abstract: The fifth annual National Inventors Conference will be held on Feb. 8 at the Marriott Crystal Gateway Hotel in Arlington, Va., it was announced this week. Sponsors are the Patent and Trademark Office, the National Council of Patent Law Associations and the Bureau of National Affairs Inc. Programs and registration forms may be obtained from Oscar G. Mastin, Office of Public Affairs, the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Nov. 16, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee - 3 P.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 10 A.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10:30 A.M.

headline: Article 067144 -- No Title
abstract: The Levitz Furniture Corporation's directors today approved a leveraged buyout offer of $39 a share, or about $318 million, from a group that includes some members of its management.   Also included in the group are Citicorp Capital Investors Ltd. and Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. A letter of intent that was approved provides that financing for the $318 million be delivered to the company within three weeks, Levitz said.

headline: Advertising; Top-Level Moves at Leber Katz
abstract: LEBER KATZ PARTNERS not only   has named Jonathan Adams   president and chief operating officer, but it also has named a vice chairman and two executive vice presidents.    While such top-level moves happen frequently at some agencies, management changes at 30-year-old Leber Katz are rare indeed.    Laurel Cutler, 57 years old, is moving up from executive vice president to vice chairman, joining Murray A. Valenstein, 64, on that level.

headline: Money Fund Assets Rise
abstract: The nation's money market mutual funds again reported record asset growth for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

abstract: LatestPreviousYearWeekWeekAgo  Monetary Aggregates M-1*as of Nov. 26  217,100 R 216,200 n.a. headline: South African Troops Seal Off a Black Area
abstract: SEBOKENG, South Africa, Tuesday, Oct. 23 (Reuters) - Thousands of South African troops and policemen sealed off this black township today in a predawn raid that the Government said was aimed at curbing ''criminal and revolutionary elements.''   In one main street of Sebokeng, 30 miles south of Johannesburg, troops with assault rifles and in full combat gear lined the road, with a soldier stationed every 20 yards and dozens of military vehicles patrolling the area.

headline: STATE OF SIEGE IS IMPOSED IN CHILE
abstract: President Augusto Pinochet imposed a state of siege in Chile today for the first time in six years.     He acted after months of political unrest and a day after his Cabinet resigned to give him a freer hand to deal with the situation.   ''It is precisely to save democracy and liberty that now more than ever it is necessary to be inflexible with respect to the institutional order that rules us,'' the President said at a ceremony at which he announced a new Cabinet.   Greater Powers for President    Minutes after the ceremony, a nightly curfew from midnight to 5 A.M. was imposed.

headline: BRIEF RISE IN RATES SEEN BY ANALYSTS
abstract: Short-term interest rates, which have been sliding steadily since August, may be in for a short-lived blip up this week, according to some money market economists.    Given the very positive fundamentals at work in the credit markets - an accommodative Federal Reserve, a low inflation rate and a somewhat faster rate of growth than in the third quarter - any temporary rise in rates should be viewed as an opportune moment to buy bonds, these analysts said.    ''There is a tremendous amount of potential for the market to improve and catch up to the Fed,'' said Philip Braverman, chief economist at Briggs Schaedle & Company. ''Unfortunately, it is going to take considerable time, perhaps into January, for that to happen.''

headline: Synthetic Fuels Appointments WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -
abstract: President Reagan appointed   three men today to the board of   the Synthetic Fuels Corporation, a move that ends a seven-   month period of immobilization   caused by lack of a quorum of directors.  ''We're back in business,''   A.T. Malloy,   a corporation spokesman, said.

headline: SYRIAN MEETS BEIRUT LEADER ON ARMY DEPLOYMENT
abstract: Vice President Abdel Halim Khaddam of Syria conferred today with President Amin Gemayel and senior Moslem and Christian officials on plans to deploy the Lebanese Army in the Beirut area and along the coastal road all the way to the Israeli lines in southern Lebanon.    The deployment of the Lebanese Army in strength in and around the capital was to have begun today but was delayed until midnight Sunday, an announcement said today.    The state-controlled Beirut radio said the purpose of Mr. Khaddam's talks with Mr. Gemayel, which were held at the President's mountain resort at Bikfeiya, 23 miles northeast of here, was to insure the political support needed to carry out the deployment.    In that respect, the most significant development was that Mr. Khaddam brought with him Walid Jumblat, the Druse leader, who has expressed reservatations about the plan.

headline: UNICEF: NOT SAME AS UNESCO
abstract: One of the casualties of the dispute between Unesco and the United States is another international organization that shares some of the letters in the Unesco acronym but none of its responsibilities or staff.   Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund, seeks to improve the health care, nutrition and general welfare of children.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Satellite Business In Another Change
abstract: Satellite Business Systems, the troubled communications company, yesterday named Marvin L. Mann as president and chief executive officer. It is the second leadership change in less than a year.    The company is a partnership of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, the International Business Machines Corporation and the Communications Satellite Corporation, but Comsat has agreed to sell its stake to the other two partners. When the transaction is completed later this month, I.B.M. will own 60 percent of Satellite and Aetna the rest.

headline: BUOYANT ZIMBABWE BEATING DROUGHT
abstract: In the last year, the third year of southern Africa's worst recorded drought, Zimbabwe's peasant farmers - those who through the ages have produced little more than what they needed for themselves - brought to market more food and other crops than ever before.    It was still a drought year, and one of black Africa's few food-exporting countries once more fell short of the needs of its eight million people. Zimbabwe will have to import, or get in aid, plenty of its staple food, corn, as well as most of the wheat for its cities' bread-eaters.   But as the beginning of the rainy season raises slight hopes for an end to the drought and a normal growing season for 1984-85, Zimbabwe can reflect on an accomplishment that sets it apart from the rest of a continent whose farmers every year produce less food for more mouths than in the preceding year.

headline: Westmoreland Coal Write-Off
abstract: The Westmoreland Coal Company said yesterday that it would take $57 million in fourth-quarter write-offs, consisting of certain metallurgical coal properties in West Virginia and the costs related to their disposition.   Westmoreland, based in Philadelphia, attributed the move to continuing operating losses from the properties.

headline: Fleet Financial
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board said it had approved the application of Fleet Financial Group Inc., of Providence, R.I., to set up new banks in Boston and Hartford. Before deciding to approve the proposal, the board said it had taken into consideration the views of Citicorp, which has challenged the constitutionality of the Massachusetts and Connecticut statutes under which Fleet Financial would be authorized to open the new banks.

headline: Japanese Gain Fishing RightsUnder Pact With North Korea
abstract: North Korea renewed a lapsed nongovernmental agreement today that allows small Japanese fishing vessels to use its 200- mile offshore economic zone freely for the first time in more than two years.   The expiration of the accord in 1982 had been a serious blow to the dozen or so Japanese ports along the Japan Sea coast that depend on the area off North Korea for their catch.

headline: Bombing of Pakistan Is Denied by Afghans
abstract: The Afghan Government today denied Pakistani allegations that Afghan planes had bombed a Pakistani border town, killing 33 people and wounding 48 others, the Kabul radio said.   According to the Afghan Government version, the heavy loss of life resulted from an explosion caused by Afghan insurgents settled in Pakistan.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Atlantic Gulf Airlines of St. Petersburg, Fla., which recently filed for Chapter 11 protection, has named Fred E. Luhm chairman and president as part of a reorganization.     * Avery International Corp., Pasadena, Calif., a manufacturer of self-adhesive labels and base materials, named William D. Froher 3d vice president of strategic planning.     * Dayton Power and Light Co., Dayton, Ohio, said Peter H. Forster, president and chief operating officer, would assume the additional post of chief executive, replacing Robert E. Frazer, who will remain chairman.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

headline: WORKERS IN SPAIN PROTEST CUTBACKS
abstract: Here on Spain's craggy northwestern coast, a fog-ridden area steeped in the lore of fighting pirates and building ships, the giant pieces of what would have been Ship No. 265 lie strewn across the yard of the Astano ship works.   Unwelded sections of the hull stand alone on a long ramp leading to the water, the bridge sits in a nearby yard and stilled cranes hang over all.   No. 265 was to have been a 148,000- ton bulk carrier, a supership. But shipbuilding at Astano, one of the largest and most modern yards in Europe, has been closed down, and the unfinished project testifies to Spain's efforts to streamline its industry in preparation for entry into the European Economic Community.   Left to itself, officials fear, inefficient Spanish industry would be overwhelmed by cheap imports from Common Market countries when the tariff walls finally fall, which will occur in just two years if all goes as scheduled.

headline: CBI Industries
abstract: A $100 million issue of 10-year notes from CBI Industries was priced for offering today. The notes, which mature Dec. 15, 1996, carry a coupon of 12 1/8 percent at a price of 99.52 to yield 12.20 percent. The issue, which is led by underwriters from Lehman Brothers, has been rated A-3 by Moody's and BBB-plus by Standard & Poor's.

headline: Chrysler Unit's $200 Million Notes
abstract: The Chrysler Financial Corporation is offering $200 million of 13 1/4 percent notes due in 1999 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. At the option of the holder, the notes may be redeemed at a price of 100 after five years.    Rated Ba-2 by Moody's and BB- by Standard & Poor's, the notes were offered with a yield three-fourths of a percentage point more than the yield on five-year Treasury notes.

headline: Addendum
abstract: Ladies' Home Journal increasing its advertising rates 7 percent with the February issue.

headline: NIPPON TELEGRAPH SALE TO PUBLIC IS BACKED
abstract: A far-reaching package of bills to reshape Japan's telecommunications industry cleared a key parliamentary committee tonight, guaranteeing its evenutal passage by the full Parliament.    The final passage of the bills, expected next week, will end the 32-year monopoly of the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Company, privatizing the Government-owned telephone company and allowing competition for telecommunications services and equipment.   One-half to two-thirds of N.T.T.'s stock is to be gradually sold to the public - although ownership will be limited to Japanese citizens.   The move is part of an international trend to deregulate telecommunications and put Government-owned operations into the hands of the private sector. Earlier this month the British Government transferred just over 50 percent of British Telecom to private hands in a public offering that was heavily oversubscribed. Unlike Japan's plans, however, some British Telecom shares were made available for foreign buyers.

headline: U.S. Envoy Arrives In Sri Lanka
abstract: A special United States envoy, Gen. Vernon Walters, arrived in Sri Lanka today, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said.

headline: Reagan Endorses Limited Intelsat Competition
abstract: President Reagan today formally endorsed the idea of competition by privately owned satellite communications companies with Intelsat, the international consortium. But the endorsement was hedged with restrictions that might limit the competitors to 15 percent of Intelsat's business.     The decision appeared to be a compromise between a half-dozen United States companies that want to compete with the consortium and Intelsat's leaders, who feared unlimited competition could cause severe financial strains on the organization.

headline: Market Place; The Rate Bulls Vs. Profit Bears
abstract: THE stock market has been engaged in one of   its classic bull versus bear wrestling matches   in the past month.   Rapidly declining interest rates have given the bulls reason to cheer, but disappointing third-quarter corporate profits have sent analysts scurrying to revise their earnings-per-share forecasts sharply downward.    The question now is whether the steady stream of downward revisions will abate so that investors can experience the heady effect of lower rates. As interest rates decline, the expected return for equity investments becomes more attractive relative to fixed-income securities.

headline: Thai Leader to Quit Hospital
abstract: Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda has recovered from a lung ailment and will leave the hospital by the end of the week, a Government spokesman said today. The 64-year-old Prime Minister entered a military hospital on Sept. 29 for treatment of pleurisy and a blocked artery leading to his right lung.

headline: Hasbro Bradley Hires Ex-President of Mattel
abstract: Hasbro Bradley Inc., the toy manufacturer in Pawtucket, R.I., has announced that Raymond P. Wagner, former president of Mattel Toys, has been named to the new position of vice chairman.    Mr. Wagner, who is 52, was named to Hasbro Bradley's board earlier this year. In a telephone interview, he said he would devote about 50 percent of his time to Hasbro, and the rest to Wagner Associates, a California- based consulting firm he founded when he left Mattel in 1983.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: Altman Sale Set
abstract: The Altman Foundation said that, as expected, it had signed a definitive agreement to sell B. Altman & Company to a group of five investors. No purchase price was given, although retail trade reports have estimated it at about $115 million. The investors are Earle W. Kazis, Maurice S. Taprin, Peter L. Malkin, Morton L. Olshan and Sanford J. Zimmerman. Mr. Kazis, Mr. Taprin and Mr. Olshan are New York real estate developers; Mr. Malkin is a member of the Manhattan law firm of Wien, Malkin & Bettex, and Mr. Zimmerman is a former chairman of Abraham & Straus and chairman of Cohoes Specialty Stores Ltd., in Cohoes, N.Y.

headline: PATENTS; Screen Door Fastener
abstract: Raymond E. Smiley of Cranbury, N.J., was granted a patent this week for a way to fasten a screen door used in conjunction with a sliding glass door so that it does not fall off the track and stay open. Patent 4,478,267 provides for hinging the screen door to the nonmoving section of the glass door, allowing the screen to be easily shut. Mr. Smiley got the patent as an independent inventor, but handles more complicated devices as a patent attorney for the RCA Corporation.

headline: IN NEW DELHI, FIREWORKS AND ROSES
abstract: As returns from India's parliamentary elections poured in, hundreds of young supporters of Rajiv Gandhi danced for joy tonight on a broad, tree-lined avenue near the Prime Minister's official residence.     Elsewhere in the city and the country, millions of Indians listened to half- hourly radio and television newscasts on the elections and the apparently overwhelming victory of Mr. Gandhi's Congress Party. Others jostled for space outside newspaper offices and other places where results were announced on huge blackboards. Shattered opposition leaders cut off access to them as reports flowed in of an almost unbroken chain of Gandhi victories and opposition defeats.

headline: Economic Scene; Advising The President
abstract: THE White House has made known that President Reagan is seriously considering abolishing the Council of of Economic Advisers. But does the President have the right to do this?    After all, it was Congress that, through the Employment Act of 1946, created ''in the Executive Office of the President a Council of Economic Advisers,'' to be composed of three members, to be appointed by the President, ''by and with the advice and consent of the Senate.''    Each of the members was to be a person who, by ''training, experience and attainments,'' was ''exceptionally qualified'' to analyze and interpret economic developments, appraise Government programs and activities and ''formulate and recommend national economic policy to promote employment, production and purchasing power under free competitive enterprise.''

headline: UNESCO HEAD SEES NO FINANCIAL HURT
abstract: The head of Unesco said in Yemen today that the American withdrawal from the agency would not harm its operations.   Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow of Senegal, who has been Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization for 10 years, was asked for his reaction to the United States' announcement that it will withdraw from the organization and end its contribution to Unesco, which amounts to 25 percent of the agency's annual budget, at the end of this year.   ''I don't think this will have any adverse effect on Unesco's financial situation,'' Mr. M'Bow replied, then ended the conversation and walked away from reporters in Sana, the Yemeni capital. He had given a speech on the need for contributions to a Unesco fund to restore and protect the architecture of Sana's old city.

headline: DUBLIN SAYS THE U.S. HELPED IN SEIZURE OF ARMS SHIPMENT
abstract: Irish security sources asserted today that the seizure of an arms-laden trawler over the weekend resulted from a two-year undercover operation by security agents on both sides of the Atlantic that included both the Central Intelligence Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.    The security sources said that an American satellite was used to track a Canadian-registered vessel from a port on the East Coast of the United States to a point off the Irish coast, where the arms shipment was transferred to the trawler, the Marita Ann. The authorities said the ''huge consignment'' of weapons was en route to the Irish Republican Army.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1984   The Economy    The Christmas shopping season opens on an uncertain note, with indications of a sharper economic slowdown. But most retailers remain optimistic that sales will exceed the strong performance turned in last year. (Page D1.)

headline: ARCHBISHOP TELLS CHILE NOT TO BLAME CHURCH
abstract: The Archbishop of Santiago warned the Chilean Government today against blaming the church for the country's political problems and called for a day of prayer and fasting next Friday.    Archbishop Juan Francisco Fresno said in the pastoral letter that is to be read at Sunday masses around the country that he was ''profoundly worried'' about the level of subversive and repressive violence.   The statements were among some of the strongest made by the country's highest Roman Catholic Church leader, and they reflected growing tension between church and Government.

headline: YEMENI MEETS SOVIET LEADER MOSCOW, Oct. 2 (Reuters) - Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, attacked United States policies in the Middle East and the Persian Gulf today during talks with the leader of Southern Yemen, Ali Nasser Mohammed.
abstract: The official press agency Tass said the two men agreed that Washington and Israel were ''stepping up their aggressive course'' in the Middle East.   They also accused the United States of building up its forces in the Persian Gulf and the Red Sea.

headline: G.E. to Use Rock Video To Sell Tape Recorders
abstract: Not too long ago, about the only way to spread a message to the masses of teen-age consumers was through their kind of radio stations.    Now that important, but elusive, segment is available for a video message through the rock music cable networks, most notably MTV, as well as through similar programming on regular broadcast television, network and syndication.

headline: Vietnamese Say China Fired 52,000 Rounds Over Border
abstract: The Hanoi radio accused China today of stepping up border provocations by firing more than 52,000 rounds of mortar and artillery into Vietnam last month.   The radio, monitored here, said the Chinese artillery attacks, mainly in Ha Tuyen Province, had been coordinated with small ground and sea intrusions.   It said more than 100 Chinese troops were killed and more than 40 wounded between Nov. 24 and Nov. 28 in fighting along the border.

headline: Bobbie Brooks
abstract: Bobbie Brooks Inc. said it and the MacGregor Corporation had terminated their merger negotiations.

headline: 36TH CHESS GAME ADJOURNED
abstract: The 36th game of the world chess championship match between Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov was adjourned today on the 41st move with Kasparov, playing White, holding a pawn advantage.   Karpov sealed his 41st move and experts said he had reasonable chances of holding a draw when play resumes Saturday.

headline: I.B.M. DEAL WITH STORAGE REPORTED
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation has ordered a large number of data storage systems from the Storage Technology Corporation, according to sources in the industry. Storage Technology, a rival manufacturer, recently sought bankruptcy protection in part because of its inability to compete with I.B.M.    I.B.M. apparently needs the Storage Technology products because of an inability to meet demand for tape storage systems. I.B.M. tape units are in short supply because the company ran low on key components needed to make the systems.   I.B.M. and Storage Technology between them supply the bulk of tape storage systems for large, or mainframe, I.B.M. computers. The tape system consists of tape drives and controllers, which connect up to eight tape drives to the computer. Because of the I.B.M. shortage problems and because some customers are reluctant to buy from Storage because of its difficulties, prices for used I.B.M. tape controllers have surged above the list price of new devices, according to officials in the used computer equipment industry.

headline: LABANESE TROOPS TAKE CONTROL OF BEIRUT'S HARBOR
abstract: The Lebanese Government went into action today to shut down illegal ports that rival Moslem and Christian militias have been operating along the Mediterranean coast for the last nine years.   Troops moved into the Beirut harbor and took control of a pier that was in the hands of the private Christian army known as the Lebanese Forces. The pier, known as the fifth basin, has been a commercial operation.

headline: LABOR PARTY WINS IN AUSTRALIA, BUT MARGIN IS CUT
abstract: The Labor Government of Prime Minister Bob Hawke won the Australian parliamentary elections today, but its margin of victory was narrower than had been expected.     With more than 70 percent of the votes counted shortly before midnight, it appeared that the Labor Party would hold a majority margin of 18 to 20 seats in the 148-seat House of Representatives. Labor led for 80 seats and the opposition coalition of the Liberal and National parties for 56, while 12 were undecided.   Pre-election polls had predicted a far stronger showing for the Labor Party, based on Mr. Hawke's personal popularity and the robust performance of the Australian economy during his 21 months in office. The polls had predicted that Labor's majority would increase from its present 25-seat margin to more than 40 seats.

headline: TIMES CO. MAGAZINE PROMOTIONS
abstract: Several executives are being promoted in the magazine group of The New York Times Company, effective Jan. 1, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman of the company, announced yesterday.   William H. Davis, 62 years old, who has been president of the magazine group and vice president of The New York Times Company, was named senior vice president of the company and chairman of the five magazines that make up the division: Family Circle, Golf Digest, Tennis, Cruising World and Golf World of the United Kingdom. He continues as editor in chief of Golf Digest, which he founded in 1950.

headline: S.E.C. WILL STILL SEEK DISCLOSURE BY REPORTERS
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it intended to pursue the legal theory that news reporters have an obligation under law to publish certain information about their own financial dealings.   A spokesman for the agency, Mary McCue, said that it would retain the legal theory in a civil proceeding against a former Wall Street Journal reporter, R. Foster Winans, even though the agency dropped the same theory earlier this month in a Federal criminal case against Mr. Winans.    The theory had first been proposed in the S.E.C.'s civil insider-trading complaint against Mr. Winans, who was later indicted on charges of leaking information about what the newspaper would print in its ''Heard on the Street'' column.

headline: SHULTZ SAID TO DROP RECOMMENDATION ON NEXT ENVOY TO HONDURAS
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has dropped efforts to have a senior State Department aide named as the next Ambassador to Honduras, department officials said today.   Some White House conservatives, as well as some members of Congress, had expressed concern at Mr. Shultz's plans to replace a dozen ambassadors in Latin America as well as some senior State Department officials.   Much of the criticism had centered on Mr. Shultz's recommendation that President Reagan nominate L. Craig Johnstone, the Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, to replace John D. Negroponte as the next Ambassador to Honduras.   State Department officials said today that after weeks of debate in the Administration on the various Shultz personnel proposals, Mr. Shultz had agreed to withdraw his recommendation that Mr. Johnstone be named to the Honduran post. The officials said Mr. Johnstone would be named ambassador to a country not in Latin America.

headline: ARGENTINE-CHILEAN PACT ADVANCES
abstract: Argentina and Chile signed a Vatican-mediated protocol today declaring their agreement to a treaty resolving their century-old dispute over the Beagle Channel.   The signing, at a small 16th-century building behind St. Peter's Basilica, marked what one Western diplomat called ''an important achievement for Vatican diplomacy.''   The one-page protocol gave no details of the treaty. A Vatican spokesman said the treaty would be made public on Friday after Government officials initialed it in Buenos Aires and Santiago.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *  American Can Co., Greenwich, Conn., said it had completed the previously announced sale of the stock of its ACC Chemical subsidiary for $76 million to a subsidiary of Texaco Inc.     *  American Educators Financial Corp., Birmingham, Ala., a life insurance holding company, said in a S.E.C. filing that it holds the equivalent of 44,000 common shares, or 9.5 percent of the total outstanding, of American Underwriters Group Inc.     *  Consumers Glass Co., Toronto, said it had agreed in principle to acquire Bradley-Fenn Enterprises Inc. Terms were not disclosed.     *  Consolidated Oil and Gas Inc. , Denver, said in a S.E.C. filing that it holds 5.3 percent of the common shares of Premier Resources Ltd. for investment purposes.     *  Denny's Inc., La Mirada, Calif., a restaurant and doughnut shop franchiser, said it had signed definitive loan agreements relating to the financing of its acquisition by a private investor group.

headline: New Belgian Tax Rules
abstract: Belgium has devised new tax rules for affiliates of United States companies known as foreign sales corporations, Willy De Clercq, the Foreign Minister, said today. He said the new tax rules would effectively limit the taxable income in Belgium of each foreign sales corporation.

headline: ISRAEL EASES STAND ON TALKS WITH LEBANON OVER PULLOUT
abstract: Israel has softened its conditions for troop withdrawal talks with Lebanon and is prepared to hold negotiations on a military level rather than exclusively between diplomats, an Israeli Foreign Ministry official said today.   Israeli officials are still awaiting a response to their new position from the Beirut Government, which has been refusing to engage in direct diplomatic negotiations with the Israelis, since that would imply a degree of recognition and normalized relations that Beirut is unwilling to concede now.    The Lebanese are apparently awaiting a clear signal from Damascus on how to proceed. A senior Israeli military official said he expected the Lebanese to come back ''with some very Lebanese, complicated, half-way counterproposal.''

headline: Christiana Stake
abstract: The Transamerican Capital Corporation, a San Antonio investment concern, and John Holmes Jr., president of Holmes, Ferguson & Company, a New York investment bank, told the Securities and Exchange Commission they had acquired 29.8 percent of the total stock outstanding of the Christiana Companies.

headline: LABOR PARTY IN BRITAIN ACCUSES POLICE OF VIOLENCE AGAINST MINERS
abstract: The Labor Party's annual conference, which formulates party policy, overwhelmingly approved a resolution today accusing the police of perpetrating violent acts against striking miners. It made no mention of violence on picket lines.    Neil Kinnock, the Labor leader, sat silent and glum-faced as the delegates gave a rousing reception to Arthur Scargill, the miners' leader, some of whose men have been repeatedly seen by reporters and on television during the seven-month strike assaulting the police and trying to intimidate nonstrikers. Mr. Kinnock had condemned picket-line violence and intimidation in a major speech last month.   ''We have suffered attacks on the picket line from a state police force armed in full riot gear,'' Mr. Scargill said in a fervent speech that brought most of the delegates to their feet, roaring in approval. ''Yes, we have got violence, state-controlled violence against people whose only crime is fighting to save their jobs - and it should be condemned by the Labor Party and by socialists everywhere.''

headline: Vendo Official Returns To Fill Operating Post
abstract: The Vendo Company, the vending machine and electronic component manufacturer that has been in and out of financial difficulties for much of the last decade, said yesterday that it had named Joe R. Town, a former executive at the company, as president and chief operating officer.    Mr. Town, who is 41, succeeds Spencer L. Childers, Vendo's 72-year old chairman, who has served as president and chief executive officer since last March, when Richard O. Donegan resigned after less than two years on the job.    The company said that for the time being the office of chief executive would remain vacant, and that Mr. Childers would continue to serve as chairman.

headline: CORRIGAN MOVES TO CENTER STAGE
abstract: HE is usually outgoing and effervescent, but on that spring day in 1982, E. Gerald Corrigan was subdued. The elegant Washington office of Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, had been converted into a war room of sorts, where an unmistakable tension gripped some of the most powerful men in the central bank.     It had just been learned that an obscure securities firm in New York - the Drysdale Government Securities Corporation - would not be able to pay millions, perhaps hundreds of millions of dollars, that it owed to a number of brokerage firms. No one knew just how much was involved or who all the players might have been.   But one thing was clear: It was a giant crisis that threatened to wreck the world financial system. The Fed needed someone who could find out exactly - and quickly - what was going on and who could mediate among the warring financial institutions, each of which argued that the others should take the loss. That go-between would also have to reassure the big New York banks that the Federal Reserve would provide whatever liquidity might be needed to keep the system afloat.

headline: REGAN DECLARES NEW YORK TAX COULD BE CUT
abstract: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said tonight that his proposal to revamp the Federal income tax system would provide greater tax revenues for New York State and that, therefore, the state could afford to reduce its own taxes.   In an interview, Mr. Regan granted that many New Yorkers would owe more Federal tax if Congress adopts his plan than they do now because the plan would abolish deductions for state and local taxes.   But if the state reduced its tax rates enough, the Secretary said, the combined taxes that New York residents pay to the Federal Government and the state together would not rise.     ''New York has a problem,'' Mr. Regan said. ''But I submit New York's problem has always been they're a high-tax state. If they're going to get more revenue, perhaps New York will want to cut its rates.''

headline: ISRAEL IN LEBANON: WRONG TACTICS FOR TERRAIN?
abstract: An American military analyst has criticized the effectiveness of Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon, arguing that its armed forces were unprepared for fighting a war on Lebanese terrain.  The analyst, Maj. Richard A. Gabriel, an Army Reserve officer, asserts that the final outcome of the campaign ''ought not to obscure the fact that this was a military operation in which Israeli forces performed somewhat less brilliantly than expected and certainly less effectively than in their other wars.''     The major point in the article in Military Review, a monthly published by the Command and General Staff College at Fort Leavenworth, Kan., is that the Israel Defense Forces, with a history of successful armored operations in desert conditions, had no experience in the urban or mountain operations encountered in Lebanon.

headline: OPEC OUTPUT SAID TO EXCEED QUOTA
abstract: Oil production of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is exceeding the daily limit set last month, raising doubts that the group can keep its official prices from falling, oil analysts said yesterday.     They said OPEC's production was exceeding the limit of 16 million barrels a day by between 500,000 and 1 million barrels. The previous quota was 17.5 million barrels a day.

headline: ARA Services Approves Buyout
abstract: ARA Services said its board had approved a revised proposal from a number of investors led by senior management to acquire the company in a leveraged buyout.

headline: IN SOUTHERN AFRICA, TOO, FOOD CRISIS GROWS
abstract: While the famine in Ethiopia has aroused the compassion of the world, a quiet drama of comparable dimensions is in the making in southern Africa.    In Mozambique, where the Government estimates that 100,000 people died from hunger last year, grain stocks from last spring's bad harvest are running out, about five months before the new harvest. In large regions of the country's north and center hunger has already set in, and relief food is arriving at less than half of last year's rate.    Transport difficulties have been caused by an insurgency and critical shortages of trucks, tires, spare parts and fuel. A great shortage of seeds and ways of delivering them to the farmers insure that many farmers cannot hope for a normal harvest, or perhaps any harvest at all.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1984   International    Israel's Cabinet approved a package deal that would hold down wages and freeze prices for three months. Workers and industrialists voluntarily accepted the austerity measures, indicating how desperate the nation has become to escape the ravages of an 800 percent inflation rate. (Page A1.)

headline: PATENTS; New Video Telephone System
abstract: WASHINGTON  A new two-way video phone that makes use of any single standard telephone line was patented this week. The device was conceived by Jerome H. Lemelson, a prolific inventor with more than 350 other patents, and Christian Grund, a research scientist at the University of Wisconsin.

headline: WESTERN UNION
abstract: To the Editor:     On Dec. 2, The New York Times published an article on Western Union Corporation.

headline: GORBACHEV MEETS LABORITE LEADERS
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev met today with British Labor Party leaders and reiterated Moscow's concern about the issue of space weapons.    Mr. Gorbachev, a Politburo member who is considered the second-ranking leader in the Kremlin, urged that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher stick to her opposition to President Reagan's space weapons program when she meets with him this weekend at Camp David.   The Labor Party leader, Neil Kinnock, said he had asked the 53-year-old Soviet official if Moscow viewed progress toward a ban on space weapons as a condition for continuing arms negotiations.

headline: Research on Haggling Influences Ad Effort
abstract: Consumers in the market for electronic products can go to a department store, a specialty chain or a neighborhood mom and pop shop. Business is divided about evenly among them.

headline: Credit Market Mostly Quiet
abstract: While the Government securities market was closed on Election Day, activity in other sectors of the credit markets was listless, with no significant changes in interest rates.    Although stock market and financial futures markets were open, the over-the-counter market for Treasury securities and money market instruments such as certificates of deposit and commercial paper was closed because the Federal Reserve Bank of New York was closed and was not settling financial transactions on the books of major banks in New York.

headline: Wags-Clubmart
abstract: Wags Stores Inc. said it had agreed to acquire Clubmart of New York Inc. from Clubmart of America Inc. for $500,000 in cash and $700,000 in notes, subject to the approval of Clubmart shareholders. Wags said the closing is expected about March 15. Clubmart of New York operates an 18,000-square-foot store in midtown Manhattan.

headline: Nigeria Will Recognize Western Sahara Rebels
abstract: Nigeria said today that it would recognize the rebel movement fighting Moroccan rule in Western Sahara, an issue crucial to the success or failure of the Organization of African Unity meeting opening here tomorrow.

headline: Yemen Reports Large Oil Discovery
abstract: President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen said today that his country had discovered ''large'' quantities of oil that could be exported through the Red Sea in two years or less.    In an interview at his residence tonight, President Saleh said that the reserves of the two fields discovered so far and the amounts they could produce had not yet been fully determined. But, he added, the Hunt Oil Company had informed his Government that oil was available in ''commercial'' and ''exportable'' quantities.    First Confirmation    His statements tonight were the first official confirmation of rumors that have circulated through this capital and American oil circles for months that a vast amount of oil had been discovered by the Yemen Hunt Oil Company, a joint venture between Yemen's national oil company and the Dallas-based Hunt Oil Company, headed by Ray L. Hunt, one of the Texas Hunts.

headline: TWO GREEKS FACE WIRETAP CHARGES
abstract: The publisher and the editor of Ethnos, the newspaper with Greece's largest circulation, will be tried in December on charges of tapping the office telephone of a Cypriot- born journalist in Athens and of publishing a transcript, lawyers in the case said today.   The journalist, Paul Anastasiades, who writes under the name Paul Anastasi, is a correspondent for The Daily Telegraph of London and a part-time correspondent for The New York Times.    The case was brought by the Athens Public Prosecutor, the Greek equivalent of a district attorney, and Mr. Anastasiades is involved as the offended party. If convicted, the Ethnos publisher, George Bobolas, and the editor, Alexander Filipopoulos, could be sentenced to a maximum of five years' imprisonment. In the investigation preceding the placing of formal charges, both men acknowledged the use of material obtained by tapping but said they were not directly involved in the tapping itself.

headline: Market Place; Time Inc. As a Target
abstract: ANYONE who has been following Time Inc. lately can hardly help but wonder why its stock has been bouncing around so much.    Two months ago the giant publishing company's shares stood at close to $36. By early last month it had jumped to $44 in heavy trading, and by late last month it had continued on up to nearly $47. Rumors had been circulating that a major investor was buying stock in Time, but none of the rumors proved to have any substance. So by last week Time stock had plunged more than $5, to $41.50. Yesterday it closed at $40.75, down 25 cents.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: LABORITE CHIEF ASSAILS MINE STRIKE VIOLENCE
abstract: -   In a bold attempt to reassert his leadership, Neil Kinnock, the Labor Party's embattled leader, today vigorously condemned the violence that has marred the seven-month-old miners' strike.   Addressing the annual party conference at the end of his first year in office, Mr. Kinnock made a bitter attack on Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. He accused her of ''tearing our society apart'' and said she was motivated by ''political vanity on a manic scale.''   But he also sought to balance the resolution, adopted in an overwhelming vote by the conference on Monday, that condemned police violence in the miners' strike without mentioning violence perpetrated by pickets.

headline: REAGAN HOLDS FIRM ON CUTS TO HALVE THE DEFICIT BY '88
abstract: President Reagan said today that he was still committed to proposing spending reductions next year that would bring the Federal deficit down to about $100 billion by 1988.   In a brief exchange with reporters, Mr. Reagan did not indicate how he would meet this goal of halving the deficits without major savings in the military budget.    Several of his top budget advisers said it appeared to them that the President would not accept their proposal to reduce projected military spending by $58 billion over three years. Without that, the President would need to add to his sweeping package of domestic spending reductions to reach his goal.

headline: G. HEILEMANN TO ACQUIRE PABST FOR $69.3 MILLION
abstract: The Pabst Brewing Company said today that it had agreed to be acquired by the G. Heileman Brewing Company for $11 a share, or $69.3 million.   However, to satisfy antitrust concerns of the Justice Department, Heileman agreed to sell one of Pabst's breweries and some of Pabst's brands of beer to Paul Kalmanovitz, a California investor.    Both Mr. Kalmanovitz and Heileman had offered $10 a share to acquire Pabst. But after Heileman sweetened its offer and agreed to sell the Pabst assets to Mr. Kalmanovitz, he dropped his bid.

headline: THE ALTERNATIVE MINIMUM TAX BLUES
abstract: Mr. M had a problem. His $170,000 salary as a corporate executive put him in an uncomfortably high tax bracket. So he decided to invest in a real estate tax shelter that was rehabilitating a building. The investment in the shelter allowed him to claim a large investment tax credit, reducing a potential $35,000 1984 tax bill to $1,500.   But Mr. M had not counted on the Alternative Minimum Tax, a mechanism designed to insure that wealthy individuals do not minimize their taxes - or avoid paying them altogether - by making use of certain loopholes in the tax law. The A.M.T., as it is called, is calculated under separate rules, and must be paid if it is greater than your regular tax. The possibility of becoming liable for the A.M.T. can actually prompt a taxpayer to go against the grain of most year-end tax advice, and accelerate income and postpone deductions.

headline: ACCOUNTS OF RUSSIAN'S CHINA VISIT SUGGEST EXPECTATIONS ARE LIMITED
abstract: Official accounts today of the visit to China by a senior Soviet official offered new indications of the limited expectations both Governments appear to have for the occasion.     The official, Ivan V. Arkhipov, a First Deputy Prime Minister, is the most senior Soviet official to come here in 15 years. His visit is being closely watched for signs of any thaw in the chilly political relations that have prevailed for nearly a quarter of a century between Moscow and Peking.

headline: U.S. Envoy in Saudi Arabia
abstract: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia held talks today with the Assistant Secretary of State for Near East Affairs, Richard W. Murphy, the official Saudi Press Agency reported. It gave no details of the talks.

headline: SECURITIES ROLE GIVEN BANK UNITS
abstract: In what appears to be a major breach in the historical barrier separating the banking and securities industries, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation adopted a regulation today that would let subsidiaries of about 9,300 state-chartered banks underwrite corporate securities.   The rule, adopted over the strenuous objections of the securities industry, authorizes state-chartered banks, which are supervised by the F.D.I.C., to engage in underwriting through units physically distinct from their parent banks. The units could not use the banks' names.   The rule would also clarify the guidelines that already permit securities firms to own banking subsidiaries, a provision that so far has drawn little interest from the securities industry.

headline: Gen. Vessey to Visit China
abstract: Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has accepted an invitation to visit China early next year. Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger was in Peking in 1983. General Vessey's trip is believed to be the first by a chairman of the Joint Chiefs to China.

headline: I.B.M. Introduces 3 New Selectrics
abstract: Reuters    The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a generation of electric typewriters that it said would eventually replace its Selectric line, currently the best-selling typewriters on the market. I.B.M. revolutionized the market in 1961 when it brought out the Selectric line, replacing the old-fashioned printing keys with a golf-ball-shaped typing element and introducing the stationary carriage. The three new Selectric System 2000 typewriters replace the ''golf ball'' with a print wheel contained in a cartridge smaller than a cigarette pack.

headline: GRISLY DEEDS LEAVE ARGENTINE ARMY UNABASHED
abstract: In one corner is a model of the bombed-out bedroom of the Buenos Aires police chief who died in 1976 when his daughter's rebel friend placed a bomb under his mattress. In another corner is a ''people's jail'' complete with a hooded hostage and his rebel guard.    Displays of ''terrorist deeds'' have been carefully rendered in a museum at the First Army Corps dedicated to the military's interpretation of the Argentine guerrilla movement of the 1970's. The memorabilia include such items as gasoline bombs, ''subversive'' literature, book bombs and racks of disguises and torture gear used by the rebels.

headline: SOVIET SAYS '85 ARMS OUTLAY IS UP BY 12% TO KEEP MILITARY BALANCE
abstract: The Soviet Union said today that it was raising its military budget next year by 12 percent, to a new high, to maintain a strategic balance with the West.   The projected arms outlays were presented as part of the 1985 Government budget at a session of the Supreme Soviet, the nominal legislature, in the continued absence of Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov. He is said to have suffered a stroke in October.

headline: INNOVATIVE MORTGAGES AT JERSEY PROJECT
abstract: Creative financing has become so pervasive since the era of high interest rates began in the 1970's that innovative packages are now being used to originate even conventional fixed- rated mortgages.    A case in point is a plan recently announced by a 307-unit condominium project in Chatham Township, N.J.,, under which fixed-rate conventional mortgages will be offered to home buyers through what is called ''builder-backed bond financing.''    Under this method, the developer, Baker-Firestone Inc., plans to grant fixed-rate loans to buyers at its project, which is called Chatham Glen. The loans, which will be made through an affiliated company, the Baker Finance Corporation, will be used as collateral for a $20 million bond issue. The bond is to be purchased by the Carteret Savings and Loan Association of Morristown, N.J., which will also service the mortgages.

headline: Ameritech Sees Rise in Spending
abstract: Ameritech said its capital spending in 1985 was expected to reach $1.88 billion, up from $1.6 billion this year. William L. Weiss, Ameritech's chairman and chief executive officer, told securities analysts in New York that nearly half of the total was planned for the fiber optic and digital facilities.

headline: TEXTRON RAISES BID FOR AVCO
abstract: After barely two days of negotiating, Textron Inc. agreed to pay the Avco Corporation $50 a share, $3 more than it had proposed last week, to take over the company. The agreement, valued at $1.4 billion in cash, also calls for Robert P. Bauman, Avco's 53-year-old chairman, to be named vice chairman of Textron.    The merger of the two companies would create a powerful new supplier to the military, with combined Government contracts this year estimated at $1.7 billion - enough to rank it among the top 15 companies supplying the military.    Last Friday, as Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis multimillionaire, threatened to use his 12.2 percent stake in Avco stock to start an unwanted takeover attempt, Textron offered $47 a share, or $1.3 billion.

headline: Video Recorder
abstract: -   Japan exported 2.27 million   videotape recorders in November, an increase of 44.1 percent   from a year earlier, the Electronics Industries Association   of Japan said today.

headline: Sudanese Leader Replaces 3 Officials and Their Deputies
abstract: President Gaafar al-Nimeiry, whose Government faces a $9 billion foreign debt and other serious economic problems, announced today that he had replaced three Cabinet ministers and their deputies.   A presidential decree carried by the official Sudan News Agency said the shuffle of the 21-member Cabinet involved the Finance and Economic Planning Ministry, the Industry Ministry and the Ministry of Cooperation, Commerce and Supply.   The decree gave no explanation for the reorganization and Sudanese officials were not immediately available for comment.

headline: Movie Theater Tests TV Technique
abstract: A Chicago- based movie theater chain has introduced television technology, which could offer more flexibility than films, into the schedule of one of its theaters for a month to test audience acceptance.   The Essaness Theatres Corporation, in a joint venture with the General Electric Company and the Matsushita Company of Japan, has invested $1 million in developing proprietary technology to project video images on large movie-house screens and ''get very close to 35-millimeter quality,'' according to Alan T. Silverman, president of Essaness.   The theater company has put prototype equipment into one of its suburban Chicago theaters, Mr. Silverman said, and plans to offer a new ''venue'' for the growing body of video programming.   Mr. Silverman's long-term goal is to beam films by satellite to thousands of theaters across the country, saving first the cost of shipping 60- pound film canisters and later the cost of storing films. The technique would also allow live broadcasts of sports and theatrical events and other video programs.

headline: People
abstract: *  Rod W. Underhill promoted to executive vice president of Tracy-Locke, Dallas.

headline: Flush With Cash
abstract: IN what could almost be described as a hit list of   possible take-over candidates, Norman Weinger   and E. Michael Metz, analysts At Oppenheimer & Company, released a research report last week listing companies that generate a great deal of cash. Companies such as these, the analysts noted, are frequently the objects of ''entrepreneurial investors.''

headline: MAFIA ROLE SEEN
abstract: Eight people were shot dead in Palermo today in what the police believe was a settling of scores in a Mafia gang fight.    The authorities said the incident was one of the largest mass slayings in Sicily's series of gang wars.    ''This night's episode was an act of barbarism,'' said Nello Martellucci, the Mayor of Palermo.

headline: TEXT OF SUMMARY REPORT ON FUNDAMENTAL SIMPLIFICATION
abstract: Following is the text of the summary provided today by the Treasury Department of its Report on Fundamental Tax Simplication and Reform:         Introduction   The present U.S. tax system desperately needs simplification and reform. It is too complicated, it is unfair, and it retards savings, investment, and economic growth.   Under the current progressive tax system, all taxpayers face higher marginal tax rates in order to make up for the revenue lost by numerous special preferences, exceptions, and tax shelters used by a relatively small number of taxpayers.   As a result, the tax system is complex and inequitable. It reduces economic incentives, hampers economic growth, and is perceived to be so unfair that taxpayer morale and voluntary compliance have been seriously undermined.

headline: BUSINESS Digest; SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 10, 1984
abstract: The Economy    Producer prices fell 0.2 percent in October for their third consecutive monthly decline, the Labor Department said. A factor was a seasonal adjustment in auto industry prices. Foods, gasoline and heating oil were up. Economists welcomed the report as a still further indication of the deceleration of inflation but they cautioned that it also reflected the slowdown in economic growth. (Page 1.)   Big institutions are forcing down the commissions they pay securities firms, leading to worries on Wall Street of another blow to profits. Recently, brokers have been concerned that the commissions could plummet to as little as a nickel a share, down from an estimated 8 cents now and 10 cents at the start of the year. (31.)

headline: POPE, IN SANTO DOMINGO, CRITICIZES CLASS CONFLICT
abstract: Pope John Paul II, arriving here on the second leg of a trip commemorating Columbus's discovery of the New World, told a crowd today that the Roman Catholic Church must offer ''its generous support to the work of 'social liberation,' to the masses of the have-nots.''    But he said this ''important and urgent work'' must be realized in fidelity with the Gospel, which prohibits ''recourse to methods of hate and violence.''    The Pope's remarks underscored the central theme of the teaching known as the theology of liberation, which he said ''maintains a preferential option'' for the poor. But at the same time, he condemned the use of the Marxist concept of class struggle in the furtherance of that goal. Class struggle figures prominently in the views of some leading exponents of liberation theology.

headline: Mexico Halts Exports Of Natural Gas to U.S.
abstract: Mexico will ''temporarily suspend'' shipments of natural gas to the United States beginning Nov. 1, its United States distributor announced today.   The United States is Mexico's sole export market for natural gas, but Mexican imports account for less than 1 percent of the natural gas used in the United States. The suspension will mean a loss to Mexico of about $260 million a year. By contrast, Mexico's oil exports provide income of nearly $15 billion a year.

headline: Sonoma Warns Of Chapter 11
abstract: Sonoma Vineyards said it would have to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection if it does not obtain substantial financing or continue to receive creditor support.

headline: JAPAN MAY EASE CURB ON ARMS SPENDING
abstract: The Japanese Government, frequently criticized for its military policies, is debating whether to abandon a fundamental principle that tightly limits military spending.    Pressure is growing within the governing Liberal Democratic Party to drop an eight-year-old understanding that Japan's military budget should amount to no more than 1 percent of its gross national product.   A recommendation to that effect was made over the weekend by a Liberal Democratic study group. Within the next few days, an advisory panel to Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone is expected to propose that the military budget ceiling, first adopted by the party in 1976, be changed to a more ambiguous ''about 1 percent'' of the G.N.P.   A certain urgency has entered the debate because Mr. Nakasone's Cabinet has only until the end of December to prepare a budget plan for the fiscal year beginning April 1. Military spending is already within a hairbreadth of the 1 percent mark, and it would almost certainly be pushed over the limit if the increase is similar to those provided in recent budgets.

headline: TWO GERMANYS DISCUSS PRAGUE REFUGEES
abstract: West Germany and East Germany held more talks today on what to do about dozens of East German refugees who have crowded into the West German Embassy here, but a spokesman for the Bonn Government said the situation remained unchanged.    The statement came as Czechoslovak authorities lifted a police cordon around the embassy, where dozens of East Germans seeking asylum in the West have taken refuge. West Germany closed the embassy indefinitely on Friday in an apparently unsuccessful effort to keep more refugees from entering.    Czechoslovak officials offered no explanation for the removal of the police, who had been deployed around the embassy to keep more East Germans from gaining access. The officials have refused all comment on the situation since the influx of refugees into the embassy began last week.

headline: HANDLING 'GROWTH RECESSION'
abstract: Fourteen years ago, as the American economy dawdled, an economics professor, Solomon Fabricant, coined the term ''growth recession'' to describe a period in which the economy slows dramatically but keeps sputtering forward. While the economy was still growing, he suggested, the decline in the rate of expansion could seem almostas traumatic as an outright contraction.   Not everyone approved of the term. Herbert Stein of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers suggested that one might as well call a dog ''a growth horse.'' But the concept stuck, and in the last few months it has became fashionable to describe the current economic slump as a growth recession. (Gross national product grew at an annual rate of only 1.9 percent last quarter, compared with 10.1 percent in the first quarter and 7.1 percent in the second quarter.)

headline: AQUINO'S WIDOW SEEKS TO UNITE MARCOS FOES
abstract: Surrounded by mementos of her husband's career and assassination, Corazon Aquino, widow of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr., has taken an active role in reconciling differences among opposition groups here.   Her goal is to unite the opposition and prepare its leaders for a possible presidential election if Ferdinand E. Marcos leaves the presidency before the end of his term in 1987.   ''With all these rumors about President Marcos's ill health, it is urgent that the opposition not be fragmented,'' Mrs. Aquino said in an interview recently at her office in the Makati business district, a suburb of Manila.

headline: Preferred Stock
abstract: * Heritage Capital Corp. , a new financing subsidiary of Heritage Federal Savings and Loan Association of Monroe, N.C., filed an offering of 667,000 adjustable-rate preferred shares at $50 each.      Common Stock     *  Frank B. Hall, Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., an insurance services concern, has filed an offering of $60 million of subordinated exchangeable variable- rate notes due Nov. 1, 1994, through Prescott, Ball & Turben.

headline: Soviet Press Focusing On Negligence Charges
abstract: Soviet press reports on the poison gas leak in India have focused on allegations by Indian officials that the American company Union Carbide was negligent.   The official Soviet press agency Tass reported today from New Delhi that state officials in Madhya Pradesh ''have officially accused Union Carbide of neglect of safety standards, which has led to the death of a large number of people, and instituted legal proceedings against it.''

headline: OPPOSITION VOWS STRONG CHALLENGE TO SANDINISTAS
abstract: Opposition leaders who won seats in the new National Assembly said in interviews this week that they intended to present a strong challenge to the governing Sandinista Front.    ''When the Assembly convenes in January, the Sandinistas will be facing a strong and belligerent opposition, most of which was elected on explicitly anti-Communist platforms,'' said Adolfo Evertsz Velez, a leader of the Socialist Party of Nicaragua. ''They are going to have to make concessions.''    The opposition's determination to press its demands indicates that the Assembly will reflect a relative diversity of views. But key decisions that will determine the power of the Assembly, such as whether it will have the power to approve the national budget, remain to be made.

headline: A New Poll on Volcker
abstract: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the New York brokerage, will release the results of a poll today reporting on how 163 financial executives believe Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, is doing his job. The survey also asked the executives who they would select to replace Mr. Volcker if he leaves, and, in quite a different question, who they believed the President would appoint among 10 high-visibility possibilities.

headline: Market Place; Starts, Stops Seen for Stocks
abstract: IF you ask Charles I. Clough, a Boston-based   portfolio strategist, when the second leg of the   bull market will begin, he replies, ''You've already seen it.'' He's not particularly gloomy over equity prospects, but looking ahead over the next year he sees the likelihood of a ''start-and-stop'' market with the broad stock averages in November 1985 perhaps ending up about where they now stand.    As director of investment policy for Cowen & Company Institutional Services, Mr. Clough's job is to provide advice to professional managers who, in turn, direct the assets of pension funds and other pools of institutional money. Much of his work centers on analyzing year-to-year changes in production, shipments, backlogs, sales and overall economic data in an effort to seek out the potential for both industry segments and individual companies.

headline: PATENTS ; Way Devised at NASA To Fight Kidney Stones
abstract: Equipment for disintegrating kidney stones was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The patent, No. 4,474,180, was assigned to NASA because the inventor, Earl D. Angulo, an engineer at the Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, Md., devised the equipment as part of his duties.    Licenses for private manufacture are available from the Space Flight Center.
