headline: TOKYO PHONE FIASCO: SMILES WITHOUT THE SERVICE
abstract: The telephones are ringing again in Setagaya.    The Asanoya noodle shop is again taking orders by telephone. Businesses are moving their computers back from employees' homes to the office. And workmen have dismantled the emergency telephone banks where, braving the cold and the rain, people stood with hands cupped over their ears, shouting into the receivers.

headline: SEOUL SEES '88 GAMES AS CHANCE TO GAIN SPOTLIGHT
abstract: As far as this city is concerned, 1988 arrived last weekend.    With pageantry and athletic events, Seoul formally dedicated the Olympic Stadium that will be the main site of the Games to be held here in four years. The efficient, early completion of the 100,000-seat stadium south of the city center was a good indication of the importance that South Korea attaches to the Games as an advertisement for itself.    Official statements emphasize familiar Olympic themes of world peace and understanding. But organizers of the Seoul Games also make clear that they see a singular opportunity to demonstrate before a global audience how far the country has advanced economically and socially.

headline: TAKEOVER OFFER IS DEFENDED
abstract: T. Boone Pickens, chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, asserted today that the primary aim of his bid for the Phillips Petroleum Company was to obtain the full value of Phillips stock for its shareholders.   In a series of meetings with institutional investors and analysts here, Mr. Pickens said that oil company managers needed to address the fact that the appraised values of many companies were vastly different from their market prices.   This has been a recurrent theme in his previous bids, including the profitable attempt to take over the Gulf Corporation a year ago that prompted Gulf's acquisition by the Chevron Corporation. Mr. Pickens has portrayed himself as a champion of shareholders, saying that they have been hurt by low stock prices.

headline: TALK OF NEW VOTING RULES STIRS FEAR IN BRAZIL
abstract: Brazil's departing military Government is studying possible changes in the rules for indirect presidential elections next January, and some politicians and commentators fear that the aim is to frustrate an opposition victory.     Speculation about the changes has alarmed the opposition and spawned rumors of an impending coup - not against President Joao Baptista Figueiredo, but against moves to return the country to democracy after two decades of military rule.   ''Coups aren't proclaimed, they are carried out,'' said Jose de Magalhaes Pinto, a Government party deputy who, as Governor of Minas Gerais, played a key role in the 1964 coup. ''And if I had power in the my hands,'' he said, ''I would carry one out now.''

headline: Nippon Air Gets Loan
abstract: The Export-Import Bank said today that it was providing a 10-year, $13 million loan at 12 percent interest to help the All Nippon Airways Company buy $20.1 million of jet engines from the General Electric Company.

headline: F.C.C. Curbs Air Phone Use WASHINGTON, Nov. 21
abstract: Just five weeks after   the inauguration of air-to-   ground telephone service, the   Federal Communications Commission decided today against   permanently allocating frequencies for the calls.

headline: FED POLICY MAKERS' CHALLENGE
abstract: The Federal Reserve's senior policy-making body meets this week to set money- supply targets for the next eight weeks against a backdrop of renewed prodding by the Reagan Administration to drive interest rates down.   The Fed's Open Market Committee has eased its grip on the nation's money supply since last summer and interest rates have come down significantly, but only last week Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said the Fed had not done enough.    Mr. Regan's comments, which included a suggestion for bringing the Federal Reserve under Administration control, came before Thursday's report that the M-1 measure of the money supply fell a whopping $7.1 billion in the week ended Dec. 3.    Pressure Put on Volcker    Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and an object of Mr. Regan's criticism more than once in the last four years, has acknowledged in recent weeks that inflation was a diminished problem. He is being pushed from all sides to loosen the money supply further.

headline: Scott Energy Unit
abstract: The Scott Paper Company said its board had approved a $115 million energy generating facility at the company's Chester, Pa., paper mill. Scott, based in Philadelphia, said the project would enable the company to produce its own electrical power, as well as steam for mill processes.

headline: SOVIET SPACECRAFT HEADS FOR COMET
abstract: Leading off an international effort to greet the return of Halley's comet with a flotilla of spacecraft, the Soviet Union yesterday launched Vega 1 on an interplanetary voyage to reach the celebrated comet in March 1986.   The 8,800-pound Vega, carrying two television cameras and an array of scientific sensors, was reported to be functioning normally as it headed for the first close encounter with the comet, which has dazzled mankind with its spectacular visits every 76 years.    A Legend and an OmenOne of the more brilliant comets, Halley's is legendary as an omen of ill-fortune and irresistible as an object of scientific curiosity because so little is known about these wanderers from the fringes of the solar system.    Vega 1 is the first of four craft that are to visit the comet in the same month and conduct a comprehensive study of the comet's solid nucleus and surrounding cloud of gas, dust and other material. Vega's sensitive cameras could return the first images of the core of a comet.

headline: IN THAI WAR ON OPIUM, POPPIES YIELD TO POTATOES
abstract: In this tribal hamlet high in Thailand's northern hills, the farmers have just finished planting a new poppy crop. Acre after acre of freshly turned earth nurtures December's opium harvest.   Until now the 400 people of Pha Kluoy, in the heart of Thailand's most intensive opium-growing region, have relied heavily on the poppy for a livelihood. But this year, for the first time, some of their fields are giving way to new crops: potatoes, garlic, cabbages and coriander.

headline: Norwest Program Set in Wyoming
abstract: The Norwest Corporation, the Minneapolis-based bank holding company, said a Wyoming bank holding company had agreed to be the first financial institution to join in Norwest's new Alliance banking program.   Under the licensing agreement, the Affiliated Bank Corporation, a $525 million bank holding company with eight Wyoming banks, will adopt Norwest's name and will have access to Norwest programs, such as check clearing and teller machines.

headline: Computer
abstract: The Computer Sciences Corporation said it had received a $14.1 million subcontract to provide the International Business Machines Corporation with services for the design competition phase of a Federal Aviation Administration advanced automation system program. During the 35-month phase of the program, an I.B.M. team and a team led by the Hughes Aircraft Company will develop competitive designs for a new, more automated computer system for air traffic control operations.

headline: BITTER TIME FOR QUAD CITIES
abstract: For 114 Christmas seasons, McCabe's Department Store has anchored the downtown of this farm equipment center along the Mississippi.   But this Christmas, the windows of the stately four-story emporium display a hand-painted ''For Sale'' sign instead of toys and lights. The once- bustling ladies' tea parlor on its mezzanine, overlooking the cream-colored main shopping floor, is empty. Two weeks ago, McCabe's, its sales devastated by layoffs in the farm and construction equipment industries, closed its doors for good.    ''The last three or four years, economic conditions have worsened so much here that we got to the point where it wasn't practical to continue,'' said Robert E. Millett, the store's manager, standing in front of rows of used brown cash registers that he was selling for $50.

headline: Growth Rise Seen in Bonn
abstract: Five economic experts predicted today that West Germany's gross national product would rise 3 percent in 1985 after a 2.5 percent increase this year.   The Council of Economic Experts, often called the ''five wise men,'' said better growth could be expected because of strong capital spending, especially for new equipment, as well as increased exports.

headline: Economic Scene; Ambivalence On Tax Plan
abstract: THE Treasury Department's report to the   President, entitled ''Tax Reform for Fairness, Simplicity and Economic Growth,'' has been called the biggest trial balloon since the Hindenburg. And ever since the report sailed into view, affected groups, ranging from oil companies and stockbrokers to universities and churches, have been firing away at those parts of the plan that they think would hurt their interests.    Most of the critics say they favor broadening the tax base and cutting marginal tax rates in general but feel a serious mistake was made when it came to eliminating their tax break in particular. If all the missiles aimed at specific parts of the Treasury proposal hit their targets, however, obviously the whole plan will collapse.

headline: CHILE TO REQUIRE FOREIGNERS TO PLEDGE TO OBEY LAW
abstract: The Government moved today to crack down on foreigners who take part in political activity, issuing a decree that non-Chileans must sign an oath to obey Chile's laws and Constitution.     The action came as the military Government of President Augusto Pinochet continued to conduct raids in poor neighborhoods of the capital. Troops and police officers arrested at least a dozen men today and rounded up hundreds of others to check identity cards.   Government sources say the measures against foreigners and residents of poor neighborhoods are part of a strategy to weed out political troublemakers. Two days of anti-Government protests are to begin Tuesday.

headline: Amerifin's Assets To Be Distributed
abstract: The Amerifin Corporation, which is involved in commercial finance and banking, domestic and international factoring, mortgage banking and consumer finance, said it would distribute its assets to holders of its common stock at $36 a share cash on Oct. 31.    However, that amount could vary by 10 cents a share depending on the amount required for deposit in the company's liquidating trust, and investment yields between now and Oct. 31, the company said. Amerifin's stock closed at $35.625, up 62 1/2 cents, on the Big Board yesterday.

headline: Prime Cut Lifts Stocks; Dow Up 0.88
abstract: A late rally enabled the stock market to finish higher yesterday after being in the minus column until shortly before the close of trading.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was off more than 8 points at 3:30 P.M., finished ahead 0.88 point, at 1,176.79. The late buying spree was sparked when Manufacturers Hanover cut its prime lending rate to 10 3/4 percent from 11 1/4 percent 15 minutes before the 4 P.M. close.

headline: New Hampshire Public Service
abstract: An international group of investors, led by Morgens, Waterfall, Vintiadis & Company, a New York investment advising firm, said it had purchased the equivalent of 2,029,175 common shares, or 5.2 percent of the shares outstanding, of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire.   According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group purchased the shares only for investment.

headline: Staar Surgical
abstract: The Staar Surgical Company said it had received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to expand clinical studies on its foldable silicone lens implants and its line of conventional intraocular lenses.

headline: Honda Net Up 29.9% in 2d Quarter
abstract: The Honda Motor Company said today that higher sales of cars, parts and power products offset a decline in motorcycle sales and that total profits rose 29.9 percent in its fiscal second quarter from a year earlier.   The company said that reduced interest expenses, increased interest income and an improved cost-to-sales ratio were other major reasons for the increase in profit to 29.6 billion yen, or $119 million, in the June-August period, from 22.8 billion yen in the period a year earlier.

headline: Texas Bank Merger A Challenge for Mcorp
abstract: Texas is a big state, but distance is of no concern to Gene H. Bishop, chairman and chief executive of the newly created Mcorp. Mr. Bishop, who lives in Dallas, is not worried about getting access to his president and chief operating officer, John T. Cater, even though Mr. Cater lives in Houston.    ''I'll either be in Houston or John will be in Dallas at least once a week so that we can sit down and talk,'' the 54-year-old Mr. Bishop said.    ''I saw Gene yesterday and I'll see him tomorrow,'' said Mr. Cater, who is 49.

headline: VENTURE CAPITAL'S HOT NEW BREED
abstract: WASHINGTON LIKE the entrepreneurs they finance, a new generation of venture capitalists has spotted a market niche and rushed to fill it. Scooping up the riskiest deals around - new companies just starting up - and ''seeding'' them with small and ''seeding'' them with small amounts of capital in exchange for a hefty chunk of ownership, these new venture capitalists are handling deals that many of their older, larger brethren now shun.    ''This isn't venture capital,'' quipped Paul M. Kelley, the general partner in Zero Stage Capital Equity Fund, a $5 million seed fund started in capital.''   Venture capitalists have always provided start-up money to entrepreneurs and some well-established funds continue to do it. But today's brash - and often young - seed capitalists say that they are putting a different spin on the business even as they are returning it to its roots.

headline: U.S. MUST BE READY TO USE ITS POWER, SHULTZ DECLARES
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said yesterday that it was ''the burden of statesmanship'' for the United States to be ready to use military force even when it had no guarantee of public support for such action.   In a speech at a Yeshiva University convocation at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Mr. Shultz continued a public debate with Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger over the proper use of American force. The dispute dates from their disagreement over the deployment of the Marines in Lebanon, with Mr. Weinberger much more hesitant and wary about the use of force than Mr. Shultz.   Honorary Degrees Awarded    Mr. Shultz and Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel were awarded honorary degrees by Yeshiva at the convocation.

headline: End for Pound Note and Halfpenny
abstract: Britain announced today the demise of its one- pound note and its 704-year-old halfpenny.   Chancellor of the Exchequer Nigel Lawson also said that the current 20- pound note would be replaced with a newer version that would be more difficult to forge.    The halfpenny - pronounced ha'penny and also known as the ''tiddler'' - has been on Mr. Lawson's list for extinction for some time. Thanks to inflation, it has for several years cost more to make than it is worth. It will cease to be legal tender on Dec. 31.

headline: Six East Germans Quit Bonn's Prague Embassy
abstract: Six East Germans, who were among some 150 refugees at the West Germany Embassy in Prague, have gone home without assurance they will be allowed to emigrate, a spokesman for the West German Government said today.

headline: JAPAN DENIES PACT TO END ALL WHALING
abstract: Japanese officials today denied American reports that Japan had agreed to end all commercial whaling by 1988.    With an emotion unusual for official statements, the director of Japan's Fishery Agency, Hiroya Sano, categorized the attitude of the United States as ''outrageous'' and ''unfair'' at a news conference this morning.   Agency officials said that Japan had agreed only to limit its hunting of sperm whales and to withdraw a protest against an International Whaling Commission ban on sperm whaling.   Tatsuo Saito, deputy director of the Fishery Agency, said that Japan had not agreed to withdraw its objection to a separate commission decision imposing a worldwide five-year moratorium beginning in 1986 on all commercial whaling, as Malcolm Baldrige, the United States Secretary of Commerce, announced Tuesday in Washington. The commission's rulings are not binding, and the filing of an objection enables Japan to violate the ban.

headline: PATENTS ; Way to Dispose of Old Nuclear Power Plants
abstract: A method of disposing of shutdown nuclear power plants was patented this week for Alfred Kunz & Company of Munich, West Germany.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1984   The Economy    The index of leading indicators fell 0.7 percent in October, its third decline in five months. Most analysts, however, said they thought the economy would soon resume its expansion after the recent sharp slowdown, rather than sink into recession. (Page D1.)   Major retailers' sales were sluggish in November , although some chains that started heavy promotions saw sales pick up after Thanksgiving. Sears's sales rose 3.1 percent, K Mart posted a 16.7 percent increase and Penney gained 5.7 percent. (D1.)

headline: SEPTEMBER PRICE INDEX ROSE 0.4%
abstract: The Government's most widely followed gauge of inflation, the Consumer Price Index, rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Labor Department reported today.    The rise, a shade less than the August increase of five-tenths of 1 percent, was at an annual rate of 4.3 percent. For the last 12 months, the report said, the increase was 4.2 percent.    The figures mark the third consecutive year of lowest inflation that the economy has experienced since the early 1970's. Prices rose 3.8 percent last year and 3.9 percent in 1982.

headline: EARNINGS ; Woolworth Gains 30%
abstract: F.W. Woolworth & Company yesterday reported a 30 percent jump in earnings for the third quarter, ended Oct. 31. Sales increased 3.7 percent.

headline: CYANAMID WILL SELL FORMICA
abstract: The American Cyanamid Company, concentrating its energies on high technology, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Formica brand laminate business to an investor group headed by Shearson Lehman/ American Express and Formica's top executives for $180 million in cash, plus $20 million in preferred stock.     Formica is the laminate industry's leader, with sales of $340 million last year, or more than its top three competitors combined. Formica's operating earnings amounted to $15 million.

headline: SYRIA'S LEADER REPORTED TO BREAK UP POWER BASE OF BROTHER
abstract: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria has dissolved the main bases of power of his brother Rifaat in an effort to halt the infighting for succession and make his brother more ''manageable,'' authoritative Israeli sources said today.   The Israeli sources, who are familiar with internal Syrian politics, said that in the last three months President Assad had disbanded almost all of the Defense Companies - a Praetorian Guard outside the army chain of command that his brother used to head.   Rifaat Assad is said to remain in Switzerland, where he has essentially been banished since June by his brother. The Israelis said he was involved in intensive negotiations with President Assad to allow him to return to Damascus, possibly in the near future.

headline: THE NICARAGUAN VOTE
abstract: The election in Nicaragua today is likely to heighten tensions between Washington and Managua and make it more difficult to develop a peace plan for Central America, according to Reagan Administration officials and Latin American diplomats.  The problem, they say, is that the United States and Nicaragua view the election so differently. They agree on only one point: the election will have a major impact on political developments in the region.    Nicaraguan leaders have said the balloting for President and 90 members of the National Assembly, which is expected to produce an overwhelming victory for Sandinista candidates, will institutionalize and legitimize the revolution that toppled the Government of Anastasio Somoza Debayle in 1979.

headline: INDUSTRY USE DECLINES
abstract: The operating rate at factories, mines and utilities edged down in October for the third consecutive month, the Government reported today, as signals of a sharp slowdown in the economic expansion continue to mount.   The Federal Reserve Board reported that industry operated at 81.8 percent of capacity in October, down two-tenths of one percentage point from the September level.   The October decline compared with an even sharper drop of six-tenths of one percentage point in September and a decline of a one-tenth of one point in August.

headline: North Castle Partners Wins Additional Clients
abstract: North Castle Partners of Greenwich, Conn., a subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc., announced yesterday that it had won three new clients, who it will be billing between $8 million and $10 million.    One is an existing client, H.P. Hood Inc. of Boston, which is consolidating all of its dairy business in Greenwich.

headline: NEW MARGIN ACCOUNTS PROLIFERATE
abstract: MARGIN. The very word implies risk. To be on the margin, the dictionary says, is to be on the edge, or the brink. And for some investors, buying on margin - that is, buying with money borrowed from a broker - often represents being on the brink of disaster. But when used successfully, margin can multiply an investor's profit.  Margin trading has a long if not entirely venerable history in the United States. Its origins are somewhat murky, but the practice is thought to date to early in the last century, when investors were allowed to put up a fraction of the cost of a bank's stock and to borrow the rest from the bank.  Today, margin accounts are proliferating, partly because of the new types of services being pushed by brokerage houses and banks. The new asset-management accounts, for example, are margin accounts. They open up a line of credit for the customer based on the value of cash or securities in the account. Investors use the borrowed funds to buy more securities - most often common stocks - than they could in an outright cash transaction. Why borrow to buy?

headline: NEW-HOME SALES SLIP 8.1 PERCENT
abstract: New-home sales fell for the second consecutive month in August, dropping 8.1 percent as all parts of the country reported downturns, the Government reported today.   Sales of new single-family homes sank to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 569,000 units, 25 percent below the peak reached last December.   Rising mortgage rates have been blamed for the housing slump. Housing construction starts dropped 12.8 percent in August to their lowest level since December 1982 and sales of previously owned homes posted their fourth consecutive decline.

headline: Agca Said to Write Of Threats by Soviet
abstract: Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turk convicted of shooting Pope John Paul II, has written to a Turkish newspaper saying he was threatened by Soviet and Bulgarian secret services, the newspaper said today.    Turkey's largest-circulation daily, Hurriyet, published the text of what it said was as a letter dated Nov. 16 and mailed by Mr. Agca from a prison in Rome where he is serving a life term for shooting the Pope.

headline: Stiller & Meara TV Spot For Disposable Lighter
abstract: Jerry Stiller and Ann Meara, whose radio advertising activities are heard but not seen, will go on television in January as the voice-overs for Scripto's new Electra disposable lighter.

headline: Arrests in Philippine Killing
abstract: The police arrested two garbage collectors today on suspicion of killing Charles Turner, an American Peace Corps volunteer, during a robbery in a seaside town in the central Philippines, a police spokesman said.

headline: YEMEN'S RECENT OIL FIND MAT BECOME A BOON
abstract: Arab and Western officials here said today that the recent discovery of oil in Yemen was likely to revolutionize its backward economy, strengthen the Government, and alter its diplomatic position.    Some of the officials said the oil find might also enhance American interests in Yemen and reduce the Soviet presence. Others were skeptical that there would be a tilt toward the West, noting that American political ties with Yemen had traditionally been uneven.

headline: UNION CARBIDE DOWN
abstract: Stock prices finished moderately lower yesterday, with Union Carbide again holding the spotlight as its price continued to drop.    The Dow Jones industrial average finished the session down 7.28 points, to 1,163.21, its lowest close since Aug. 2, when it ended at 1,134.61.    In the general market, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered those that rose by 803 to 682 as volume contracted to 81 million shares, from 96.6 million shares on Thursday.   Reflecting the downward trend, the exchange's composite index lost 0.22, to 93.52, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 0.50, to 162.26.

headline: Volcker Remark Reviewed
abstract: When Paul A. Volcker was nominated by President Reagan in mid-1983 for a second four-year term as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, he told the Senate that he might not serve out the full four years.

headline: South Korea to Limit Steel Exports to U.S.
abstract: South Korea today became the last of the major suppliers of steel to the United States to conclude an export restraint arrangement, apparently assuring the achievement of President Reagan's plan to limit steel imports so that they account for less than 20 percent of domestic consumption.   Administration trade officials said that Seoul had agreed to limit shipments for the next five years to 1.9 percent of the domestic market, after having rejected an American demand last week that shipments be held to 1.7 percent.    Korea's chief trade negotiator, Chulsu Kim, broke off the steel talks with the United States last week, saying that Washington's negotiating position with Korea had been tougher than it had been with Japan.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  Braintech Inc., South Plainfield, N.J., has named Raymond Tsao chairman and chief financial officer, Barry Kass chief executive officer and William Stewart chief operating officer.     *  Bristol-Myers Co.  has elected Pamela D. Kasa and Russel A. Bantham vice presidents.

headline: 2 ALSATIAN MAYORS GIVE A SNUB TO MITTERRAND
abstract: The mayors of two French cities and other elected officials boycotted a state visit to Alsace today by President Francois Mitterrand. The President reacted with what was described by reporters as deep anger.    The boycott, involving the President's handling of a regional issue, constituted a new embarrassment for Mr. Mitterrand, who has been under editorial and political attack for an apparent series of blunders involving Libya's defiance of an agreement with France on a mutual troop withdrawal from Chad. French forces have left, but Libyan soldiers are still present in the former French colony.

headline: Esterline Plans
abstract: The Esterline Corporation said it had signed an agreement to acquire the assets and business of Hollis Automation Inc. for $17 million plus the assumption of bank debt of about $8 million. Hollis makes automated equipment used in the soldering and cleaning of printed circuit boards and related applications.

headline: SANCTIONS SOUGHT AGAINST JAPANESE WHALERS
abstract: Conservation groups announced today that they would sue to force the Reagan Administration to impose sanctions on Japan if the Japanese violate an international ban on catching sperm whales.    Spokesmen for the groups said at a news conference today that a Japanese fleet was poised to take sperm whales in defiance of a moratorium imposed by the International Whaling Commission.   A spokesman for the Japan Whaling Association, Alan Macnow, called the planned legal action ''ill advised.'' He confirmed that the Japanese were planning to go after sperm whales but said no international law would be broken by doing so. Japan filed an objection to the whaling commission's ban on the hunting of sperm whales as it is permitted to do under the commission's rules. After filing an objection, he said, a country can hunt the whales without violating the commission's rules.

headline: Chevron Unit's $1 Billion in Notes
abstract: Chevron Capital U.S.A. is offering $1 billion of notes, with proceeds aimed at retiring part of the debt associated with the Chevron Corporation's acquisition of the Gulf Corporation earlier this year.    The financing, though underwriters led by Salomon Brothers, consists of $500 million of 11 3/4 percent notes due in 1988, offered at a price of 100, and $500 million of 12 percent notes due in 1994, offered at a price of 99.1 to yield 12.158 percent.

headline: OIL PRICES ARE LITTLE CHANGED
abstract: Oil trading came to a virtual standstill yesterday and prices stabilized as nervous dealers awaited a response by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to the price cuts by Norway, Britain and Nigeria that threaten a general slide in world petroleum prices.    ''There is a tremendous amount of nervousness and uncertainty.'' said Gary M. Becker, head of the energy futures group at Paine Webber Inc. in Houston. ''The markets are very much in disarray.''    Some OPEC officials insisted yesterday that the organization would maintain its official prices by cutting production. But most oil analysts continued to say that a price cut was all but inevitable in view of an oversupply of oil and the large amount of discounting that includes unofficial price cuts by various Arab oil exporters.

headline: Roller Coaster Regulation
abstract: The folks who sell roller coasters and other bone- rattling rides expect another skirmish with consumer activists in the House over a revival of last year's unsuccessful effort to reinstate the Consumer Product Safety Commission's jurisdiction over their business.

headline: ETHIOPIA REBELS SEIZE KEY RELIEF CENTER
abstract: Secessionist rebels have seized a major famine relief center, resulting in a cutoff of food supplies for thousands of drought victims, according to sources connected with the relief effort.    The sources said the center, at Korem on the southern border of Tigre Province, was overrun Sunday after a daylong battle between Government troops and rebels of the Tigre People's Liberation Front. Korem, which is 250 miles north of here, has 40,000 refugees, 15,000 of them children    As a result, food was said to have stopped arriving in Korem, either by plane at the nearby Alamata airstrip, or by road. Stocks are said to be low.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1984
abstract: The Economy    Major banks cut their prime rates by a half point, to 12 percent. The drop, the third in a month, reflected both a weakening economy and a lower cost of funds for the banks. Many bankers said the rate could slip a bit more before the end of the year. (Page 1.)   Companies    Ford's profits climbed 14 percent, to $379.7 million, in the third quarter as unit sales rose 11 percent. Profits increased in the United States but fell in Europe. American Motors reported earnings of $2.5 million, reversing a $9 million loss. (35.)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS;
abstract: Air Cargo Equipment, an aircraft cargo concern based in Long Beach, Calif., said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire Transequip Inc., a defense products company, for about $3.5 million in cash, notes and securities.     *  American Exploration Co., Houston, said that through a partnership it had agreed to buy a majority interest in an oilfield in Howard County, Tex., for about $3.5 million.     *  Aum Corp., Jamestown, N.Y., said it had agreed in principle to sell its automotive products business to Maremont Corp. of Chicago for more than $9 million.

headline: Stocks Finish Lower in Slow Trading
abstract: Stock prices finished slightly lower yesterday in slower trading as uncertainty over the near-term outlook for interest rates weakened investors' enthusiasm.    The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow price range throughout most of the day, closed off 4.53 points, to 1,228.69. On Wednesday, the average tumbled almost 11 points on profit taking after having soared about 40 points in the preceding seven sessions.

headline: U.S. OFFICERS PLAY DOWN MOVES IN NICARAGUA
abstract: United States military officers said today that the recent arrival of Soviet helicopter gunships in Nicaragua would add only a limited military capacity to the armed forces of that nation and that the additional capacity would be more defensive than offensive.    The officers also suggested that the deployment of Soviet-built radar, which was believed to have arrived recently in Nicaragua, would be defensive if linked with Soviet-made surface- to-air missiles already in Nicaragua.    If the Soviet Union furnished Nicaragua with MIG-21 fighters, the subject of widespread speculation this week, even that would add more to the defensive than to the offensive power of the Nicaraguans, the officers said.

headline: ISRAELIS ARREST SOLDIER, 18, IN ROCKET ATTACK ON BUS
abstract: The police said today that they had arrested an 18- year-old soldier from a crack army unit on suspicion of firing a rocket at an Arab bus in Jerusalem last week.    Three other soldiers, including a woman, were also detained in connection with the attack Sunday in which one Arab was killed and 10 others were wounded. The police said the three were being questioned about their relations with the main suspect. None of the suspects were identified.

headline: BOLIVIAN LEADER STARTS A FAST
abstract: President Hernan Siles Zuazo began a hunger strike today to protest a congressional censure of his decision to negotiate with drug traffickers.    The traffickers are believed to be responsible for a $2 billion-a-year cocaine industry.   ''In an act of supreme protest, I have decided to declare a hunger strike to restore a climate of peace and reflection by all Bolivians,'' Mr. Siles Zuazo said in nationwide broadcast Thursday night.
